title: A Refined Multi-Scale Reserve Capacity Configuration Method Based on Empirical Mode Decomposition and Kernel Density Estimation
authors: Qiaoyu Zhang, Guobing Wu, Kai Dong, Qiuna Cai, Zhongfei Chen, Zelin Wang, Yongyao Fan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: The safe operation of the new power system relies on the scientific configuration of reserve capacity, making it crucial to accurately quantify reserve demand across different time scales. This paper analyzes the current state of reserve capacity configuration methods and delves into the limitations of the traditional fixed-proportion method in addressing the strong fluctuations and uncertainties of net load. Targeting the multi-scale fluctuation characteristics of net load, a refined configuration method based on Empirical Mode Decomposition and Kernel Density Estimation is proposed. This paper details the key aspects of the method, including the multi-scale decomposition of the net load signal, the probabilistic modeling of prediction errors for each component, and the quantification of reserve demand. Through these steps, the paper demonstrates how a refined assessment of reserve requirements is achieved. Using actual net load data from a region in China, a case study validates the effectiveness and economic viability of the proposed method. The conclusions indicate that the proposed method shows good potential in effectively covering uncertainties and reducing reserve redundancy and deficiency. This approach helps to achieve a better balance between system security and economy and provides a more scientific basis for configuring reserve resources with different response characteristics, offering a new perspective on enhancing the operational efficiency and flexibility of the new power system in facing uncertainty challenges.

title: Design of a Miniaturized TR Module with Low RF Interference in K-band
authors: Hao Li, Zhi Li, Xiangbo Zhang, Zongcheng Wang, Tao Xiu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In response to the current demands for miniaturization, high isolation, and high integration in multi-frequency systems, this paper proposes a K-band transmit-receive (TR) module design method with low radio-frequency (RF) interference. The approach encompasses the functional composition, circuit design, structural design, and multi-frequency electromagnetic compatibility of TR modules. First, by integrating suppression filters to enhance isolation degree, the electromagnetic compatibility between the difference frequencies is improved. Next, miniaturization and high integration of the TR modules are achieved through a strip line power divider network. The design results were validated through physical testing, meeting the predetermined performance standards and successfully realizing the miniaturized TR module design.

title: Design and Application of a Window-Based Fixture for Shielding Effectiveness Measurement
authors: Zheng Xianze, Liu Qi, Li Rong, Su Xiaoming, Li Xiaofeng
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Radio telescopes are extremely sensitive to Electromagnetic Interference (EMI) from electronic equipment integrated on the telescope. The proposed Qitai Radio Telescope (QTT) requires extremely high shielding design. However, the traditional window-based shielding effectiveness (SE) measurement fixture is very inefficiency for telescope constructing. To solve the issue above, this paper designed a novel window-based testing fixture which the slider mounting structure was employed for improving installation efficiency. Meanwhile, we tested the performance of the fixture integrated into the SE measurement window, showing that this fixture can reduces installation time by 67% compared to traditional solutions, and its SE is stably greater than 90 dB over 0.1–6 GHz frequency band, which can be better applied to the window–based SE measurement.

title: Privacy-Preserving LLM Inference in Intelligent Enterprises: Threats, Defenses, and Research Frontiers
authors: Reza Fotohi, Fereidoon Shams Aliee
publish: 2025 9th Iranian Conference on Advances in Enterprise Architecture (ICAEA)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly integrated into intelligent enterprises to support critical services across healthcare, finance, and government domains. While their inference capabilities offer unprecedented utility, they also introduce significant privacy risks, as both user queries and model outputs are directly exposed during operation. Recent studies have demonstrated the vulnerability of LLMs to inference-time attacks, including Membership Inference Attacks (MIA) and Model Reconstruction Attacks (MRA), which can extract or reconstruct sensitive enterprise data. Although multiple defense mechanisms have been proposed, they often suffer from limited scope, high computational overhead, or reduced utility, making them unsuitable for enterprise-scale deployment. This survey provides a structured and comprehensive overview of privacy-preserving LLM inference. We first review the main threats in the inference stage and categorize existing defense mechanisms into input-level defenses, output-level defenses, and adaptive/feedback-based strategies. Each category is examined for its strengths, weaknesses, and applicability in real-world enterprise settings. We further analyze key research gaps, including the lack of dual-attack robustness, limited enterprise-grade evaluations, and the absence of standardized benchmarks. Building on these insights, we highlight open challenges and outline promising future directions. By consolidating the state of the art, this work serves as a reference for both academia and industry, guiding the development of secure, efficient, and compliant LLM deployment in intelligent enterprises.

title: A Literature Review on the Intelligent Pheromone Update Mechanism for ANT Colony Optimization in Metaheuristics
authors: Prind Triajeng Pungkasanti, Danny Manongga, Krismiyati, Tad Gonsalves, Hindriyanto Dwi Purnomo
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The traditional Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) algorithm frequently faces challenges related to convergence speed, a propensity for local optima entrapment, and restricted search efficiency in the context of complex combinatorial optimization problems. To address these challenges, several enhancement methods or Improved Ant Colony Optimization (IACO) have been formulated. This method incorporates adaptive pheromone update strategies, dynamic parameter adjustments, and the integration of ACO with other algorithms, including Genetic Algorithm (GA), Differential Evolution (DE), and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). Numerous studies have shown the efficacy of IACO across multiple real-world application domains, such as logistics scheduling, robot path planning, chlorophyll content estimation in agriculture, pipeline route design, and data collection in wireless sensor networks. The implementation of IACO has demonstrated substantial enhancements in accuracy, stability, and efficiency of solutions, while broadening its applicability to complex systems, including autonomous vehicles, avionics, adaptive teaching, and imbalanced data classification. IACO demonstrates significant potential as a basis for the development of advanced, intelligent, and adaptable metaheuristic approaches.

title: MAVRIC: Enabling Vertical Link Misalignment Tolerance in 2.5D Photonic Interposer Networks
authors: Mohammad Amin Mahdian, Ebadollah Taheri, Mahdi Nikdast
abstract: We present a novel routing mechanism, called MAVRIC, designed to tolerate vertical link misalignments in 2.5D photonic interposer networks. Results show that MAVRIC achieves more than 70 % power savings and at least 30 % improvement in network reachability, improving system's energy efficiency and robustness despite misalignments.

title: Design and Application of Microwave 3dB Couplers
authors: Shubin Chen, Shixiong Deng, Changzheng Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The microwave 3dB coupler is a key component of microwave systems, playing a crucial role in power distribution, signal synthesis, and phase control. With the development of wireless communication technology, the demand for high-performance, miniaturization, and multifunctional 3dB couplers has increased. This article introduced the basic principles, latest research progress, and applications of microwave 3dB couplers, exploring their uses in communication systems, radar, and RFID fields. By analyzing new synthesis methods, broadband phase detectors, and LTCC microwave integrated circuits, the article demonstrates how these innovations enhance the performance and application range of couplers. Although significant progress has been made in miniaturization, broad-banding, and cost reduction of microwave 3dB couplers, challenges such as manufacturing complexity and high cost remain. Future research should focus on addressing these challenges to promote the application of microwave 3dB couplers in more scenarios.

title: Compact Broadband Discone Antenna for Electric Field Generators in EMC Testing
authors: Jiaming Li, Qi Zou, Hao Ruan, Gaosheng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A compact broadband disc–cone antenna is proposed for use as an electric field generator in Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC) testing, particularly for RS103 radiated susceptibility requirements. The design integrates monopole-inspired dimensional reduction with the broadband characteristics of biconical antennas, resulting in a footprint significantly smaller than conventional solutions. A linearized disc surface and wire-frame cone structure improve impedance matching, reduce weight, and enhance deployment flexibility. Covering the 40–110 MHz range, simulations show S11 below –6 dB, omnidirectional H-plane radiation, and stable electric field intensity exceeding 200 V/m at 1 m under 2,500 W excitation, fully meeting RS103 standards. The proposed antenna offers a practical, high-performance alternative for space-constrained EMC test environments.

title: Single-Branch Detection of Carrier-Envelope Offset and Beat Note for Strontium Optical Lattice Clocks Network Using a Dual-Pitch Waveguide
authors: Kenichi Hitachi, Hiromitsu Imai, Kota Nishiyama, Tomoya Akatsuka, Haruki Sanada, Katsuya Oguri
abstract: We present a robust single-branch scheme for transferring a 698 nm clock laser to the telecommunication band using a dual-pitch periodically poled lithium niobate waveguide, enabling detection of the carrier-envelope offset and beat note at 698 nm and eliminating intermediate lasers.

title: FDTD Algorithm for Magneto-thermal Coupling Analysis
authors: Shanghao Chen, Xiao Jia, Yinghong Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Radoms is a important part in communication and radar systems. High-power microwave (HPM) technology is extensively utilized across a range of communication and radar applications,but lack of analysis tool. Therefore, investigating the magneto-thermal coupling effects and underlying mechanisms of radomes under high-power microwave exposure is of great significance. In this work, the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method is employed to solve the coupled electromagnetic and thermal fields, enabling an in-depth analysis of electromagnetic-thermal interactions. Specifically, the magneto-thermal coupling behavior of a radome modeled with the Debye dispersion model is studied. A comparison between the FDTD-based simulations and COMSOL Multiphysics results demonstrates a high level of agreement in all examined cases.

title: Polarization Transformations and Compressed Sensing from Solution-processed, Meso-ordered, Metaphotonic Films
authors: Ji Feng, Xiaojing Weng, Altai Perry, Alma K. González-Alcalde, Mario J. Mencagli, Luat T. Vuong
abstract: Solution-processed, metaphotonic films exhibit short-range order and offer randomizing optical-computing operations. We demonstrate nonlocal effects and the polarization transformations of air-filled, hollow-sphere films. The deviation from perfect order offers the “incoherence” for compressed sensing.

title: Efficient Analysis of EM Scattering from Conducting Objects with Thin Lossy Coatings
authors: Xiaocui Liu, Wei Du, Dechen Wang, Ping Bao, Yongpin Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Electromagnetic (EM) scattering from conducting objects with thin lossy coatings is studied in this paper. To account for the thin coating layer, the impedance boundary condition (IBC) is applied to the electric field integral equation (EFIE). The Calderon identities are then leveraged to construct the Calderon multiplicative preconditioner (CMP) to improve the iterative convergence. Two numerical schemes are studied and compared to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Driving Sustainable Development Through Data: A Looker Studio Dashboard for Philippine HEIs
authors: Adrian Forca, Desiree Morales, Dan Christian Gellada, James Ryan Ga
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Data serves as backbone to the operation of a higher education institutions for more data-driven decision making, however with significant and volumes of data due to multiple commitments and engagements. The lack of centralized data source for quick insights still exists caused by scattered and unprocessed data across different offices. The increasing demand for rapid and accurate reporting in HEIs motivated the researchers to adapt the latest computing tools towards sustainability of goals leading to data visualization. In this study, the researchers devised an interactive dashboard focusing on accessibility, low-cost, and specific in the context of an HEI that is connected to various dataset sources and aggregated using Google Looker Studio. While other dashboards exists, the novelty of practical application of the platform for developing a dashboard designed for HEIs focusing on the exploration of the unique and operational environment makes this study significant such that data fields and types were defined: calculated fields, selection of appropriate visualization types, dashboard layout, and interactivity. Results presents actionable insights offerings a clear picture of progress, challenges, and opportunities related to the goals particularly SDGs. Evaluation results were seen in the report that there are increase in the following: users average engagement time; the Platform measurement card yielding 100% that can be accessed through mobile and desktop; reaching 3 out of 10 ASEAN nations (including the Philippines) which shared their location while accessing the dashboard.

title: Ultra-Short Bessel Beam Enables High-Resolution Two-Photon Microscopic Imaging
authors: Xiaobin Weng, Qiannan Song, Jun Dong, Hongsen He
abstract: We significantly enhance the lateral resolution of a two-photon imaging system by shortening the axial extent of the Bessel beam. Under identical numerical aperture conditions, the Bessel beam achieves a lateral resolution of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 2 0} \boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{2 5 ~ n m}$</tex>, indicating a 41 % improvement over the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$547 \pm 22 ~\text{nm}$</tex> resolution obtained with a conventional Gaussian beam. This enhanced resolution was further validated by imaging two adjacent <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 - n m}$</tex> fluorescent microspheres. The proposed approach effectively improves imaging resolution without modifying the optical hardware, offering a new strategy for high-resolution and depth-flexible nonlinear optical imaging.

title: A Method for Rapid Calculation of Shielding Effectiveness of Irregular Cavities with Apertures
authors: Xingrui Zhu, Jinjing Ren, Zhongyuan Zhou, Mingjie Sheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A BLT-based method for rapid shielding effectiveness analysis of irregular cavities is proposed by this paper, in which apertures and irregular structures are equated to two-port networks. In this method, a generalized BLT equation is used to solves electric field responses and mode decomposition is employed to identify modes. The method is applied to four irregular structures. The results were compared with the CST simulation results to verify its validity and efficiency. This method can be used as a rapid cavity electromagnetic assessment tool in the field of electromagnetic compatibility.

title: Blockchain Framework for Shared Real Estate Ownership Certification Using Fractional NFTs
authors: Abdullah J. Abualhamayl, Mohanad A. Almalki, Firas Al-Doghman, Abdulmajeed A. Alyoubi, Farookh K. Hussain
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Traditional real estate markets are often dominated by institutional investors, which may limit access for small investors due to high entry costs and limited opportunities for fractional participation. Such market dynamics create slow, expensive, and inflexible transaction processes that limit liquidity and prevent broader participation in property ownership. To address these challenges, we propose a blockchain-based framework using fractional non-fungible tokens (F-NFTs) to digitally certify and manage shared real estate ownership. Our approach involves improvements to the ERC-721 token standard to support fractional ownership, development of smart contract algorithms for property registration and transfer, implementation of a prototype, and deployment on the Ethereum Sepolia testnet. The performance evaluation reveals that the complete certification process costs around $47.16 USD and can be completed in roughly 264 seconds, which reflects notable enhancements in transaction efficiency compared to traditional systems. By enabling costeffective and transparent property certification, this framework enhances transparency, democratizes property investment, and broadens market accessibility.

title: Compact Design of Low-Loss Optical Vias for 3D Silicon Photonic Integrated Circuits
authors: Sarad Subhra Bhakat, Kumar Piyush, Riddhi Goswami, Arnab Goswami, Marigo Eloi Ferrer, Gan Yih Loong, Ng Chew Yan, Bijoy Krishna Das
abstract: We present the concept of an 'optical-via' enabling 3D photonic integration with multi-material stacks. Low-loss, and compact optical-via designs are optimized for optical routing from conventional single-mode SOI waveguide to front-end defined single-mode SiN waveguide, and from SiN waveguide to back-end defined single-mode AIN waveguide.

title: Bionic Tactile Sensing with IPMC-Based Stacked Ion Sensor for Fingertip Applications
authors: Xin Zhao, Gangqiang Tang, Dong Mei, Zhuoao Du, Chun Zhao, Yanjie Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: In this work, based on the deformation-electrical response mechanism of IPMC and the mechanical adjustment characteristics of PDMS pressure buffer layer, the stacked ion sensor produced distinct electrical response signals under external load stimulation, with a sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.128 \text{mV} \text{Pa}^{-1}$</tex> in the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-176 \text{kPa}$</tex>. The sensitivity is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.023 \text{mV} \text{Pa}^{-1}$</tex> in the pressure range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{>} \mathbf{2 7 0 k P a}$</tex>. It is found that the geometric shape of the IPMC has little effect on the sensing characteristics of the sensor. Therefore, the circular stacked ion sensor is integrated into the fingertip of the fabric glove to realize the tactile response and injury warning function in the process of pressing, pinching and feeling the pulse. The flexible sensor proposed in this work is expected to be transplanted to the bionic robot system and provide a technical path for the robot to build a biology-like graded tactile sensing system.

title: BIC Driven Chirality in Triple-Notch Bianisotropic Dielectric Metasurfaces
authors: Shubhanshi Sharma, Monica Pradhan, Shailendra Kumar Varshney
abstract: Numerical simulations demonstrate that the designed meta-atom unit made of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TiO}_{2}$</tex> disk with three notches, out of which two notches are thorough while one notch is partial, exhibits chirality and bianisotropy driven by the bound state in continuum. The proposed metasurface also has high CD.

title: Convergence of Beam Propagation Through Turbulent Air Modelling Using Full-3D Statistics
authors: K.R.H Bottrill, D. Majumder, S. Liang, P. Petropoulos
abstract: By relinquishing the Markov approximation and modelling turbulence in 3D, we are able to show improved convergence behavior of the split-step method for light propagation through turbulent air. We use this improved model to identify step-sizes for which the Markovian model is accurate.

title: 3D Reprojection-Driven Robot Navigation Improves Depth Sensing
authors: Marvin Chancán, Alex Wong, Ian Abraham
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Depth perception models have shown to be effective in several robotic vision systems such as depth completion and 3D reconstruction. However, these models have been extensively trained using non-interactive, video-based datasets with predetermined camera trajectories, which do not necessarily provide task-specific data samples to achieve competent learning. One of the key questions for downstream task-aware data acquisition is: what motion planning strategy to use? In this work, we investigate how to achieve 3D image reprojection-driven autonomous path planning to further improve supervised and unsupervised depth completion model learning. Specifically, we (i) derive a method for robot navigation based on photometric reconstruction errors, as a proxy for visiting high depth uncertainty locations, and (ii) introduce a framework for integrating motion planning systems with depth completion models, along with a new benchmark. We evaluated 4 depth models, trained on data collected by our approach and by 8 existing navigation algorithms. Experiments spanning 861 training and 118 testing environments, derived from scanning a diverse set of residential, commercial, and civic spaces from the real-world, show that our approach outperforms conventional techniques on all 4 models by an average greater than 18%.

title: Multimodal Approach for Depression Detection on Social Media: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Anas Fikri Hanif, Ema Utami
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Depression is one of the most burdensome mental health conditions worldwide. With the rapid advancement of technology, the classification of depression can now be conducted using data obtained from social media platforms. However, most existing studies focus on unimodal data, leaving a gap in understanding how multimodal data can be effectively utilized. This study reviews 38 research articles published between 2020 and April 2025 that explore the use of multimodal data for depression classification through social media. The review process involved systematically retrieving relevant studies from digital libraries followed by a structured selection and analysis process guided by predefined research questions. The findings show that Twitter is the most frequently used platform for data collection. Datasets were obtained through three main strategies, which include using benchmark datasets, modifying existing datasets, and collecting new data independently. For independently collected data, annotation methods included keyword-based labeling, human annotation, a combination of both, self-disclosure, and questionnaire-based labeling. Most studies employed a combination of textual data with other modalities in their multimodal approaches. Feature-level fusion or early fusion was the most commonly applied fusion technique. Regarding evaluation, accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score were the most widely used metrics.

title: Development of an Automatic Trash Sorting System Using Vision Transformer (ViT) Model
authors: Rafael Dillon Hasan, Vincent Gavrila Aprilliano, Edmund Abraham Setiady, Maulin Nasari, Alfi Yusrotis Zakiyyah
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: The success of environmental sustainability depends heavily on solving waste management challenges. Waste man- agement can be improved through the implementation of auto- mated sorting systems which separate organic materials from recyclables during the initial segregation stage. Such a system uses a classification model as its core component to analyze images of waste and trigger a mechanical sorter. For this purpose, we developed an image classification model that uses a Vision Transformer (ViT), which is a deep learning model with self- attention mechanisms. A Google-pretrained Vision Transformer model received fine-tuning through a specialized waste dataset before deployment. The PyTorch framework was used to deploy the model into a Flask web application which enables users to submit images for real-time classification results. The model shows excellent prediction capabilities through the evaluation of precision, recall, F1-score, and AUC-ROC metrics, which validates its suitability for real-world deployment. This study proves that Vision Transformers show immense potential for developing modern, environment-focused visual classification systems that can power automated sorting machinery.

title: Is Viral Content Superman or Iron Man? the Factors Behind Successful Digital Content
authors: Susi Ramdhania, Mohammad Rakan Nawwaf, Devyano Luhukay, Lianna Sugandi, Erwin Halim
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Digital Content Virality (DCV) is vital yet unpredictable in social media marketing, as only a small fraction of digital content goes viral. Prior studies examined content quality, emotions, creator credibility, and electronic word-of-mouth (EWM) separately, limiting understanding of their combined effects. This study analyzes the simultaneous influence of Creator Characteristics (CC), Content Characteristics (CTC), Environment (ENV), Audience Behavior (AB), Interactivity (INT), Engagement (ENG), and EWM on DCV. Data were collected from 533 active Indonesian social media users through an online survey (April–May 2025) and analyzed using Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM) with SmartPLS 4. Results show that EWM, CTC, and CC have the strongest effects, while AB, INT, ENG, and ENV also contribute significantly. These findings highlight that virality emerges from both internal content quality and external strategic amplification. The Superman or Iron Man metaphor is thus supported: viral success is shaped by the interplay of intrinsic resonance and engineered dissemination.

title: Assessing m-Government Service Quality: A Transformer-Based Sentiment and Topic Modeling Analysis of Indonesia's Police Super App
authors: Irfan Dwi Arya Prasetyo, Herry Irawan
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The successful implementation of mobile government applications is highly dependent on user satisfaction, making rigorous service quality assessment a critical requirement for public service bodies. This study looks at Indonesia's national police super app, Polri Presisi, by using both aspect-based sentiment analysis (ABSA) and unsupervised topic modeling to look at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5, 4 3 6}$</tex> user reviews. The four service quality dimensions of interactivity, authenticity, connectivity, and understandability were the basis for the ABSA part. We compared fine-tuned IndoBERT, MBERT, and GPT-2 models for this classification task, with IndoBERT emerging as the top performer with a macro <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score of 0.73. The results show that negative sentiment is predominantly concentrated in the Interactivity and Authenticity dimensions. These quantitative findings are explained by specific problems identified through topic modeling, including failures in core application workflows, unresolved payment statuses, and a critical discrepancy between online and offline procedures. This study translates unstructured user feedback into actionable insights, providing the Indonesian National Police with a data-driven roadmap for redesigning high-friction user journeys and rebuilding public trust in their digital services.

title: Complementary Transmission in a Racetrack Resonator With Dual-Bus Waveguides
authors: Taewon Kim, Mehedi Hasan, Yu Sung Choi, Jae Woong Yoon, Sangsik Kim
abstract: We present a racetrack resonator with dual-bus waveguides exhibiting complementary transmission characteristics depending on the selected excitation-measurement ports. Both intrinsic and coupling quality factors are extracted, showing excellent matching between experimental and simulation results.

title: Octave-Spanning Supercontinua Generation from a Sub-Millimeter-Length Gallium Phosphide Waveguide
authors: Xucheng Zhang, Weiren Cheng, Chunxue Wang, Ning Ding, Qiancheng Zhao, Xingchen Ji, Yikai Su
abstract: We demonstrate the first octave-spanning supercontinuum generation with a spectrum ranging <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$800-2200 ~\text{nm}$</tex> from a sub-millimeter (sub-mm)-length gallium phosphide waveguide.

title: A Dual-Polarized and Double-Slot Vivaldi Antenna with Low Cross Polarization
authors: Chao Han, Huaqiang Gao, Xiaoming Chen, Yuanan Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The conventional Vivaldi antenna is widely used due to its simple structure and ultra-wideband operating range, but with low gain and high cross polarization. This paper presents a dual-polarized, low cross polarization and dual-slot balanced Vivaldi antenna with a tri-layer configuration. The top and bottom layers comprise identical radiating plates with dual exponentially tapered slot lines, while a T-junction power divider is placed in the middle layer to provide the same amplitude and phase currents for the dual slots. The coupling energy of the top and bottom layer is equal to reduce the transverse E-field, which lead to a low cross polarization. The simulated results show that the impedance bandwidth range of the antenna is 2-7.5 GHz with the voltage standing wave ratio (VSWR) less than 1.5, the simulated peak gain of both probes is better than 11.4 dBi, and the cross-polarization ratio is less than -34 dB.

title: Design and Integration of a Range Extension Device Based on Wind-Solar Hybrid Power Generation for Electric Tricycles
authors: Lei Nie, Yishan Zhang, Fang Chen, Xu Yang, Wen Bo, Yidi Huang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: To address the challenges of short driving range and inconvenient charging of electric tricycles, this paper proposes a range extension system based on solar-wind hybrid power generation. By integrating photovoltaic and wind power generation coupled with an efficient energy management module, the device enables real-time energy self-replenishment during operation. Theoretical analysis indicates that this system can increase the range by over 30%, significantly reduce reliance on traditional charging infrastructure, and prove suitable for remote areas and long-distance transportation scenarios.

title: Direct Emission of Vector Vortex Beam (VVB) from Buried Heterostructure (BH) Laser
authors: Soumi Pal, Arpit Khandelwal, Nitin Bhatia
abstract: This work provides a method for vector vortex beam generation by utilizing the emission of two stable higher transverse modes of orthogonal polarization from a BH laser.

title: Advanced Model Predictive Direct Torque Control with Space Vector PWM for Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors
authors: Great Tomar, Nishant Kumar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Advanced Model Predictive Direct Torque Control (MPDTC) is proposed in this paper, which stands as a superior solution over DTC (Direct Torque Control) for controlling PMSMs. Because DTC produces inferior performance in PMSM systems. This method decreases various issues, such as high torque and flux ripples at variable switching frequencies and unwanted harmonic distortions. An MPDTC control method utilizes cost functions in its design for enhanced control performance and achieves smooth torque and flux generation alongside regular switching frequency operation. Real-time implementations in MATLAB Simulink become more efficient through the usage of Euler's forward approximation to simplify both flux and torque calculations. The proposed control technique i.e. MP-DTC, helps in the improvement in system stability while decrease in the electromagnetic interferences, optimisation of steady-state and as well as transient response.

title: CTC_STN: A Connectionist Temporal Classification Model for Industrial Text Recognition
authors: Wenbin Zhang, Shanshan Ba
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: In response to the issues of low recognition accuracy, high labor costs, and lack of universality in models established by traditional industrial text recognition techniques when identifying texts in industrial scenarios, this paper proposes an improved Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC) based industrial text recognition model named CTC_STN. To enhance text recognition accuracy, the Spatial Transformer Network (STN) is employed to perform spatial transformations on input images, effectively correcting irregularly shaped texts such as tilted and curved texts. Subsequently, the corrected images are fed into a CTC-based recognition model. To address the problems of increased model complexity and slower recognition speed resulting from the introduction of STN, the convolution layer feature extraction module in the CTC model is improved by utilizing ResNet_cnn for feature extraction, thereby enhancing both recognition speed and accuracy. Compared with models such as Convolution Recurrent Neural Network (CRNN), CRNN+CTC, and Transformer, the proposed CTC_STN model achieves improved industrial text recognition speed while maintaining recognition accuracy and parameter efficiency. Finally, experimental results demonstrate that the CTC_STN model exhibits higher accuracy compared to classical text recognition algorithms.

title: Cyber Hygiene Awareness and Practices Among Saudi Micro and Small Enterprises
authors: Adel Ibrahim M Alluhayb, Saeed Ur Rehman, Naeem Janjua
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Cyberattacks are increasing rapidly as the digital world becomes integral to daily life, raising the necessity for robust cybersecurity measures. During the COVID-19 pandemic, digital transformation accelerated, particularly through the replacement of cash payments with contactless methods to reduce virus transmission. This also result in cyberattacks rise and often outpace protective measures. This paper investigates the level of cybersecurity awareness and practices among Saudi MSMEs using a behaviour-based survey. The survey is designed to assess cyber hygiene awareness and behaviour across five critical domains. The results show that awareness of cybersecurity measures does not always translate into consistent practice, particularly within MSMEs. Despite this vulnerability, MSMEs in Saudi Arabia remain understudied in terms of their cybersecurity awareness at the behavioural level. Hence, addressing this gap requires more than one-time training sessions or static guidelines. If Saudi Arabia intends to strengthen its digital security, particularly for MSMEs, it must focus on improving not just awareness but also actual day-to-day cybersecurity behaviours.

title: LLM-MVs: An LLM-Enhanced Materialized Views-Based Query Rewriting System
authors: Chong Sun, Hao Hu, Huili Zhang, Enqing Wu, Jiahao Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Query rewriting, which aims to enhance query efficiency by modifying the structure of SQL queries without altering their results, stands as one of the pivotal research directions in the database domain. Traditional query rewriting approaches perform language-equivalent transformations based on manually predefined rewriting rules, thereby failing to fully harness the potential of Materialized Views (MVs) for query optimization. Furthermore, with the emergence of Large Language Models (LLMs), natural language interaction with LLMs can better unlock the potential of MVs in query rewriting. Nevertheless, the direct application of LLMs for query rewriting exhibits several limitations, including overreliance on predefined rules, inadequate accuracy in complex tasks, and insufficient utilization of MVs. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a prototype system called LLM-MVs, which leverages natural language processing with LLMs to generate and select MVs. To further enhance the reasoning capability of LLMs in recommending MVs, we introduce a MV management model that provides LLMs with more efficient MV options. Experimental findings demonstrate that our proposed approach substantially enhances query execution efficiency.

title: Maneuvering Autonomous Vehicles in Urban Environments
authors: Kavitha T, Suman Shekhar Reddy, Mohit Sudhakar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: Autonomous vehicle navigation demands advanced object detection capabilities to ensure safe and efficient maneuvering. This study integrates the YOLO (You Only Look Once) algorithm with a hardware-driven vehicle system to enhance real-time obstacle recognition in dynamic traffic environments. By combining YOLO’s rapid, multi-object detection with sensor data, the vehicle adapts its navigation through immediate path adjustments. Testing indicates that this approach improves obstacle recognition accuracy and reduces response latency, enabling safer autonomous navigation. The model utilizes a custom-trained YOLO network, with optimization for real-world traffic scenarios. This paper outlines data processing, system integration, and mathematical modelling, alongside a comparative analysis of detection accuracy, efficiency, and performance against existing approaches. Results reveal YOLO’s efficiency in identifying obstacles, coupled with reduced false detection rates and faster decision-making, demonstrating the model’s potential to improve autonomous vehicle safety and reliability in complex environments. This paper innovatively found a better method of using currently existing technology to better optimize the maneuvering of autonomous vehicles in an urban environment.

title: A thermal protection method of transmitter based on thermal monitoring mechanism
authors: Chuan Yang Liu, Yuansheng Shi, An Yan Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In wireless communication systems, the transmitter is a critical component whose operational safety and reliability directly impact the entire system’s functional chain. Heat generation during transmitter operation is an inherent phenomenon that negatively affects performance and often leads to significant degradation or safety hazards. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a thermal protection method. By integrating temperature sensors with a controller and implementing a temperature threshold detection mechanism, long-term thermal stability of the transmitter is achieved. Specifically, our research identifies a temperature observation point on the amplifier module that exhibits a linear coupling relationship with the amplifier tube's temperature. The controller continuously interacts in real-time with distributed temperature sensors via bus networks (such as SPI/I2C), processes the data using the thermal protection algorithm, and outputs a corresponding temperature feedback voltage to the power control board. This regulates the temperature of critical circuit modules within a safe operating range. In this way, the thermal protection measures utilizing the temperature detection and feedback algorithm solves the problem of overheating and shutdown of the transmitter, and greatly improves the reliability and stability of the transmitter.

title: Design of Multi Level H-Bridge Inverter for Single Phase AC Loads
authors: Kangkan Jyoti Kalita, Shreyosi Roy Choudhury, Harshanya Darathi, Ronil Baruah, Kumari Nutan Singh, Arup Kumar Goswami
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Multilevel inverters (MLIs) have gained significant attention compared to conventional two-level converters, especially in medium-voltage and high-power domains, owing to their advantages such as reduced voltage stress on switches, improved harmonic profile, and superior scalability. These attributes make MLIs highly suitable for applications in photovoltaic (PV) systems and smart grid frameworks. Among different topologies, the cascaded Hbridge configuration is widely adopted due to its modular structure and operational efficiency. Recent research efforts have been directed toward enhancing MLI performance through improved power quality, reduced component count, and voltage-boosting features. Advanced approaches, including optimization algorithms like Namib Beetle Optimization (NBO) and intelligent controllers such as Recalling-Enhanced Recurrent Neural Networks (RERNN), have been employed to achieve better regulation and lower total harmonic distortion (THD). Similarly, asymmetrical designs with transistor-clamped H-bridge cells have shown promise in terms of cost and efficiency. Building on these developments, this work presents the design and simulation of three-level and five-level H-bridge inverters using MOSFET switches, with control facilitated by an Arduino platform. The system is modelled and validated through Proteus simulations and further realized through laboratory-scale hardware implementation

title: Research on the Suppression Function of Reactive Power Compensation Device Based on Harmonic Source Detection
authors: Zhilin Kang, Yuan Luo, Jianzhen An, Yanwei Feng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: To address the lack of standardized validation methods for harmonic suppression in low-voltage reactive power compensation devices (RPCDs), this study designs a test system compliant with GB/T 15576-2020. The system features a programmable harmonic source (2–50th order, 400–690 V, ±5% current accuracy), isolation transformer (>8% impedance), and Class A harmonic analyzer. Testing on a 140-kvar RPCD demonstrated a harmonic suppression rate of 55.72% ± 1.8%, exceeding the 50% threshold. This system provides a reproducible solution for manufacturers and certification bodies to quantify harmonic performance under controlled conditions.

title: CSGAN: A Conditional Semi-Supervised Adversarial Learning Framework for Haptic Texture Recognition
authors: Pengwen Xiong, Muye Hu, Yang Xiao, Yuanfang Mao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Robots frequently obtain abstract and less interpretable texture information via tactile sensors, resulting in complex and costly data annotation processes. To mitigate this challenge, this paper proposes a Conditional Semi-Supervised Adversarial Learning Framework (CSGAN) tailored specifically for haptic texture recognition tasks. In contrast to the existing Semi-supervised Generative Adversarial Network (SGAN), the proposed framework incorporates explicit class conditional information into the generation phase, thereby enhancing semantic consistency among samples generated within each categorical space. Furthermore, classification feedback derived from the generated samples is integrated into the optimization of the generator, empowering the discriminator to acquire enriched category-specific representations within the latent space through adversarial training. This mechanism significantly improves the discriminator's utilization efficiency of the generated data. Consequently, the adversarial learning framework facilitates the model in revealing a more comprehensive and structured latent distribution of texture categories, enhancing the model's generalization capabilities and recognition accuracy, particularly under conditions of limited labeled data. Additionally, a multi-head structure is introduced into the discriminator's architecture, effectively decoupling category prediction from the real/fake discrimination task, thereby mitigating task interference. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method in comparison to existing advanced techniques.

title: MSNR-Based Blind Source Separation for Mainlobe Jamming Suppression in Sum-Difference Four-Channel Systems
authors: Fuxue Jia, Fengkai Liu, Mingliang Xie, Hongzhang Gao, Jiahao Zhang, Jin Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: When interference enters into the radar mainlobe, traditional spatial anti-jamming methods not only fail to suppress mainlobe interference but also cause mainlobe distortion and sidelobe elevation, severely degrading the target detection performance of radar. To address this, a mainlobe interference suppression method based on maximum signal-to-noise ratio (MSNR) blind source separation with sum-and-difference four-channel processing is proposed. The MSNR blind source separation technique is applied to process the mixed signals received by the sum-and-difference four channels, enabling the separation of target signals and mainlobe interference signals. Subsequently, pulse compression and target signal detection are performed to obtain the target echo signals. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively extract target echo signals from the mixed signals containing target echoes and mainlobe interference, even at a jamming-to-noise ratio of 40dB, achieving effective anti-mainlobe jamming performance.

title: MVP: A Multi-Sensor Vehicle-Mounted Positioning Framework for Autonomous Driving
authors: Xiaowen Tao, Jian Zhao, Bing Zhu, Hongyi Jiang, Pengxiang Meng, Jiayi Han, Yuanyang Qi
abstract: Positioning technology plays a critical role in environmental perception and serves as the foundation for decision-making and motion control in autonomous vehicles. Existing positioning frameworks often face challenges such as limited accuracy, high costs, or poor adaptability to diverse environments. To address these issues, this paper proposes a Multi-Sensor Vehicle-Mounted Positioning (MVP) framework for autonomous driving, leveraging the complementary strengths of multiple sensors and advanced graph optimization techniques. The proposed MVP framework integrates data from inertial measurement units (IMUs), cameras, and global positioning systems (GPS) to achieve robust and precise positioning. Through nonlinear optimization, the system tightly integrates vision-based odometry with IMU data to enhance short-term motion estimation, even in challenging scenarios such as feature-sparse environments and abrupt maneuvers. Furthermore, the incorporation of a novel outlier rejection mechanism significantly boosts positioning accuracy and adaptability, ensuring robust performance in complex and dynamic conditions. To ensure global positioning consistency, the framework employs adaptive fusion of visual-inertial odometry and GPS data, enhanced by real-time kinematic processing, through global pose graph optimization. This approach effectively balances positioning accuracy and cost while enhancing the system’s adaptability to diverse operating environments. Experimental validation shows promising results with 0.7359m mean APE on KITTI dataset (79.60% improvement over ORB-SLAM) and 0.20m accuracy in real-world campus testing. Results demonstrate that the MVP framework outperforms existing approaches in terms of accuracy, stability, and cost-effectiveness, making it a promising solution for real-world autonomous driving applications such as campus shuttles, depot logistics, and low-speed urban operation domains.

title: Geometric Insight in Solving Optimal Control Problems and the Emergence of Generalized Functions.
authors: Erik I. Verriest
abstract: Geometric insight may lead to a quick solution for a class of non-LQ optimal control problems. We illustrate this with a simple, inconspicuous-looking example. While necessary conditions for optimality are easily obtained, their analytic solution may not be easy. But some problems are locally reducible to an Euclidean distance problem, but not necessarily globally due to the underlying topology. This insight leads to the additional realization that in some cases, optimality may require impulsive inputs. However, Dirac deltas cannot be compatible with nonlinear operations in Schwartz’s distribution theory. Thus, it seems that we may have a solution but not a theory. Since the solution is transparent in its geometric form, it suggests that another approach to generalized functions, as proposed by Colombeau, should be used. This is very valuable as it corroborates our earlier work. Generalizations are then sought for other problems reducible to Euclidean minimum distance problems, and even more general Riemannian spaces. We make some connections with the notion of persistence of behavior, where these results apply.

title: Endmember Extraction from Hyperspectral Images Using Self-Dictionary Approach with Linear Programming_supp1-3624413.pdf
authors: Tomohiko Mizutani
abstract: Hyperspectral imaging technology has a wide range of applications, including forest management, mineral resource exploration, and Earth surface monitoring. A key step in utilizing this technology is endmember extraction, which aims to identify the spectral signatures of materials in observed scenes. Theoretical studies suggest that self-dictionary methods using linear programming (LP), known as Hottopixx methods, are effective in extracting endmembers. However, their practical application is hindered by high computational costs, as they require solving LP problems whose size grows quadratically with the number of pixels in the image. As a result, their actual effectiveness remains unclear. To address this issue, we propose an enhanced implementation of Hottopixx designed to reduce computational time and improve endmember extraction performance. We demonstrate its effectiveness through experiments. The results suggest that our implementation enables the application of Hottopixx for endmember extraction from real hyperspectral images and allows us to achieve reasonably high accuracy in estimating endmember signatures.

title: TG-FCM: A Prediction Model of Transformer and GRU Fusion Based on Improved Fuzzy C-Mean_supp1-3646225.pdf
authors: Hai-Long Yang
abstract: Predictive models play a pivotal role in industrial control systems, particularly demonstrating extensive and significant applications in data processing and data mining. Currently, both the gated recurrent unit (GRU) and the Transformer play a crucial role in building predictive models. However, most of the research methods still face the problems of imperfect data processing and simple model construction. Regarding data processing, the lack of redundant feature removal inevitably complicates the model's learning process. In terms of model construction, existing methods simply combine the two without deeper exploration and combination. To address these challenges, we present TG-FCM, a new prediction model in this study. Specifically, this paper develops a feature selection method using AGglomerative NESting (AGNES) and fuzzy c-mean (FCM), and constructs a Transformer prediction framework with memory function with the help of GRU. In the feature selection stage, the data features are first clustered using AGNES to obtain clustering results, which are then used as initial cluster centers for FCM. This combination method effectively alleviates the problem of FCM's dependence on initial values. In the prediction framework part, GRU is utilized to have the ability of storing historical data to provide memory function for Transformer. The specific situation is to add GRU-based storage memory unit and extraction memory unit to the encoder and decoder of Transformer respectively, so as to store the memory in the encoding process and extract the memory in the decoding process, thus realizing the memory function of Transformer. The experimental analysis of TG-FCM and five comparative models on eight real datasets shows that TG-FCM has high prediction performance and better generalization ability.

title: Quadratic Equality Constrained Least Squares: Low-complexity ADMM for Global Optimality_supp1-3646132.pdf
authors: Huiping Huang
abstract: This letter addresses the quadratic equality constrained least squares (QEC-LS) problem, a class of non-convex optimization problems that arise in various signal processing and communication applications. We revisit the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) approach to QEC-LS problem and investigate its convergence and efficiency. Despite the inherent non-convexity, the proposed ADMM algorithm is proved to converge globally only requiring the quadratic term equal to a positive constant. Numerical results demonstrate that our method achieves global optimality with significantly reduced complexity compared to existing approaches such as semidefinite relaxation and primal-dual methods.

title: PriDFL: Computation-optimized Secure Aggregation with Byzantine-resilient in Decentralized Federated Learning
authors: Shuai Wang, Youliang Tian, Jinbo Xiong, Renwan Bi, Jianfeng Ma, Yan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Privacy-preserving federated learning (PPFL) is a strong-privacy distributed learning paradigm, which typically employs secure aggregation (SA) protocols to protect the aggregation results of federated learning. However, the high computational cost of existing SA protocols is difficult to generalize to decentralized federated learning (DFL) with the large number of clients and fails to defend against model poisoning attacks launched by Byzantine adversaries. In this paper, we propose an efficient computational SA protocol compatible with DFL, referred to as PriDFL, and address the issue of Byzantine-robust aggregation. Specifically, we design an advanced secret-sharing protocol based on number-theoretic transformations to reduce the computational complexity from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O(n^{2})$</tex-math></inline-formula> to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {O}(n\log n)$</tex-math></inline-formula> during data sharing. We employ a single-mask approach to provide lightweight gradient privacy protection for DFL. To mitigate the impact of poisoned gradients on model convergence, we develop a Byzantine resilience criterion grounded in model cross-updating. The proposed criterion efficiently detects poisoned gradients and non-independent identically distributed (non-IID) data with local computation. Security analysis shows that PriDFL satisfies the security requirements in an honest but curious setting. We evaluate PriDFL on typical datasets (e.g., MNIST and CIFAR-10) and the results show that PriDFL is computation-communication efficient and Byzantine resilient. In particular, PriDFL optimizes the computational efficiency by 6-10× compared to the well-utilized SA protocols while supporting Byzantine robustness.

title: Integrating Fault Diagnosis into Prognostics for Fuzzy Stochastic Distribution Control Systems: An Optimization-Based Online Approach
authors: Youxuan Gao, Lina Yao, Shuiwang Yuan, Shenze Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Detailed degradation information can help uncover the underlying mechanisms of system degradation and provide essential guidance for accurate prognostics. However, obtaining such information in practice is often costly and challenging, which has motivated the development of prognostics methods that integrate fault diagnosis. Most existing methods, however, primarily focus on degradation magnitude while neglecting trend information, and they also lack sufficient robustness to uncertainties. As a result, they often suffer from low prediction accuracy and limited prediction horizons. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes a novel diagnosis-integrated prognostics framework in which the remaining useful life prediction task is formulated as an explicit parameter optimization problem. Specifically, the robustness of optimization algorithms contributes to reliable prediction accuracy even under imprecise prior knowledge and low-quality data, while the integration of degradation trend information enhances the ability to capture long-term dynamics, which in turn extends the prediction horizon. To better reflect realistic operating conditions, concurrent actuator and sensor faults are considered. The approach first extracts both magnitude and trend information via fault diagnosis, and then employs parameter optimization for RUL prediction. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through simulation studies of actuator and sensor degradation in a grain processing system.

title: Speech2Blend: A Hybrid Network for Speech-Driven 3-D Facial Animation by Learning Blendshape
authors: Lei Wang, Gongbin Chen, Feng Liu, Jiaji Wu, Jun Cheng
abstract: Recent advances in speech-driven facial animation have attracted significant interest across computer graphics, human–computer interaction systems, and immersive virtual reality applications. However, existing methods remain constrained by dependencies on specific reference videos or proprietary face mesh structures, limiting their applicability across diverse production pipelines and reducing compatibility with industry-standard animation workflows. To overcome these fundamental limitations in generalization and deployment flexibility, we propose Speech2Blend—an end-to-end hybrid convolutional-recurrent network that directly learns nonlinear speech-to-blendshape parameter mappings. This novel approach enables markerless speech-driven facial animation generation without restrictive inputs like video references or specialized facial rigs. Trained on the largest available digital human dataset (BEAT) and rigorously evaluated using three benchmark datasets with photorealistic visualization tools, Speech2Blend achieves state-of-the-art performance. It delivers superior audio-visual synchronization through learned temporal dynamics and reduces lip vertex error by 30% compared to existing baseline methods. These advances significantly lower production costs for virtual human speech animation while enabling cross-platform compatibility with common game engines and animation software.

title: Distributed Secondary Control Based on Proportional-Integral Observers for Microgrids under DoS Attacks and Encoding Mechanisms
authors: Yangkai Chen, Derui Ding, Qinyuan Liu, Xingzhen Bai
abstract: Microgrids (MGs) are continuously evolving with the advancement of distributed energy storage devices and renewable energy generation. However, limited bandwidth and denial-of-service (DoS) attacks are threatening the stable operation of MGs by impacting data availability. By characterizing DoS attacks with attack frequency and duration, this paper pays attention to the secondary voltage restoration issue of a discrete MG by utilizing proportional-integral observers (PIOs) and dynamic encoding-decoding mechanisms (DEDMs). First, a local PIO with a predefined forgetting coefficient in its accumulative term is employed to estimate the states of the discrete-time MG, thereby mitigating the impact of DoS attacks. Subsequently, a consensus-based secondary controller is developed for the addressed system, leveraging the feedback linearization and PIO. DEDMs are implemented in communication channels to ensure efficient and reliable data exchanges. By resorting to the Lyapunov stability theory, sufficient conditions for voltage restoration are derived, taking into account the average dwell time and the proportion of attack silence. Moreover, desired observer and controller gains are calculated by solving a couple of matrix inequalities. Finally, a series of simulations based on Simulink are conducted to verify the practicality of the proposed controller.

title: LLM-Driven Design for Fluid Antenna Systems
authors: Chao Wang, Bowen Zhang, Zan Li, Kai-Kit Wong, Hao Xu, Gan Zheng, Chan-Byoung Chae
abstract: We address the joint optimization of port selection and precoder design for a FAS to minimize power consumption under a minimum signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) constraint. This formulation results in a challenging mixed-integer nonconvex problem. To solve it, we introduce a novel large language model (LLM)-based hyper-heuristic. Our approach leverages alternating optimization to decompose the problem into a convex precoder subproblem and a port selection subproblem. For the latter, we employ a genetic algorithm (GA) that is automatically enhanced by a dual-LLM architecture. This architecture uses one LLM to generate crossover operators and another to critique and refine them, eliminating manual tuning. Under the simulation conditions of 10 dB SINR, 10 users, and antenna sizes between 8×8 cm and 13×13 cm, the proposed LLM-enhanced GA outperforms the conventional GA by an average of 22.09%.

title: A Representation Learning Approach to Feature Drift Detection in Wireless Networks
authors: Athanasios Tziouvaras, Blaž Bertalanič, George Floros, Kostas Kolomvatsos, Panagiotis Sarigiannidis, Carolina Fortuna
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computing
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is foreseen to be a centerpiece in next generation wireless networks enabling ubiquitous communication as well as new services. However, in real deployment, feature distribution changes may degrade the performance of Artificial Intelligence (AI) models and lead to undesired behaviors. To counter for undetected model degradation, we propose ALERT; a method that can detect feature distribution changes and trigger model re-training that works well on two wireless network use cases: wireless fingerprinting and link anomaly detection. ALERT includes three components: representation learning, statistical testing and utility assessment. We rely on Multi-layer Perceptron (MLP) for designing the representation learning component, on Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) and Population Stability Index (PSI) tests for designing the statistical testing and a new function for utility assessment. We show the superiority of the proposed method against ten standard drift detection methods available in the literature on two wireless network use cases.

title: Energy-Efficient Speed Planning for Automated Truck Platoon With Uncertainty-Aware Trajectory Prediction
authors: Renzong Lian, Binghong Jiang, Zhiheng Li, Junqing Wei, Li Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: For fully automated heavy-duty truck platoons, the uncertain behavior of surrounding traffic participants makes platooning control and stability extremely complex. This may lead to a deterioration in fuel efficiency and could even result in collisions. To mitigate the impact of traffic participants’ uncertainty and enhance fuel economy, this paper proposes an energy-efficient speed planning method for automated truck platoons considering uncertainty-aware trajectory prediction. In trajectory prediction uncertainty modeling, perceptual uncertainty is incorporated into the loss function of the prediction module to reduce overconfidence in long-horizon predictions. To generate accurate long-horizon platoon speed trajectories that better align with vehicle dynamic characteristics, vehicle response delays are identified and and integrated into the planning process. With varying levels of prediction uncertainty and response delays, the platoon speed planning method adapts more safely and proactively to multi-vehicle interaction scenarios. Experimental results from two representative traffic flow conditions demonstrate that the proposed method effectively enhances both safety and energy efficiency in complex traffic conditions, particularly in cut-in events.

title: Federated Chain Context Optimization for Long-Tailed Multi-Label Image Classification
authors: Libao Zhang, Suxia Zhu, Wenjie Yao, Guanglu Sun
abstract: Federated learning is an emerging machine learning paradigm that effectively alleviates the data silo problem by distributing the model training process to multiple data holders. However, data from real-world mobile applications often has multi-label and presents a long-tailed distribution, where labels are generally non-independent and non-identically distributed, thereby increasing the challenges caused by data heterogeneity. To address the above problems, we propose a Federated Chain Context Optimization (FedCCO) for long-tailed multi-label image classification. Inspired by the success of Chain of Though (CoT) in enhancing the semantic expressive ability of models, this method fine-tunes the CLIP model using semantic descriptive vectors generated by the Chain Context Optimization (ChCoOp) to establish semantic correlations between head and tail classes across clients, which improves the ability of the model to recognize tail classes. The experimental results show that the FedCCO achieves satisfactory performance in long-tailed multi-label image classification in federated learning on VOC-LT and COCO-LT datasets.
