title: Coffee Bean Quality Classification Using the Variational Autoencoder and Support Vector Machine Algorithms
authors: Marsellus Oton Kadang, Indrabayu, Syafruddin Syarif
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: The conventional process for sorting coffee bean quality on a large scale in the downstream coffee industry is still prone to human error, labour-intensive, and time-consuming. This research utilises autoencoder and support vector machine (SVM) techniques to develop a coffee bean quality classification model with four categories: ripe, unripe, non-coffee, and damaged beans. Additionally, this study aims to evaluate the model's performance using F1 score metrics, confusion matrix analysis, and k-fold cross-validation. A total of 1,000 image samples were used and evenly distributed into four classes. This was then further divided into a training subset of 70%, a validation subset of 20%, and a testing subset of 10%. The proposed model achieved a classification accuracy of 96%, demonstrating a high level of reliability. Additionally, the weighted average F1 score of 0.961 indicates a strong balance between precision and recall values across all classes. VAE + SVM outperformed the baseline CNN in classifying coffee bean quality, increasing accuracy by 3% from 93% to 96%. These results confirm the model's ability to effectively predict coffee bean quality and highlight its potential as a robust solution for automating the sorting process in real-world coffee.

title: A High-power microwave field-line coupling analysis method based on the antenna reciprocity theorem
authors: Bo Zhang, Song Zha, Jijun Huang, Ming Xu, Honglin Zhang, Zesen Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper extends a fast computational method based on the antenna reciprocity theorem to analyze field-line coupling in electronic information systems under high-power microwave irradiation. The method first treats the cable in electronic information systems as an antenna for simulation to obtain its input impedance, radiation pattern, and other data. Subsequently, the waveform of the induced voltage, generated by high-power microwave irradiation on the cable and then transmitted to the cable-connected load, is calculated by using the reciprocity method. The advantage of this method is that when considering High-power microwave under different incident conditions, it can rapidly solve for the peak induced voltage on the cable load without requiring new full-wave simulations.

title: A Metasurface-Based Circularly Polarized Magneto-Electric Dipole Antenna With Wide Bandwidth for Ku Band
authors: Ting Wu, Min-Yao Wang, Zhuo-Yue Bai
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This letter proposes a novel broadband circularly polarized magnetoelectric dipole antenna element loaded with metasurfaces(MS). A 4×4 MS structure is loaded on the top layer of the common magnetoelectric dipole element, which further enhances the gain and broadens the axial ratio(AR) bandwidth. The final test results show that within the operating frequency band, the impedance bandwidth is 12.58GHz - 15.85GHz (23%), the AR bandwidth is 12.11GHz-15.18GHz (22.5%), and the gain is approximately stable at 7.8dBi - 8.7dBi. Therefore, the antenna proposed in this letter is a good candidate for Ku-Band (12-18 GHZ) communication.

title: Comparison Between Support Vector Machine, Naïve Bayes, and Long Short-Term Memory Methods on Sentiment Analysis Performance
authors: Anthony Anggrawan, Chritofer Satria, Aprilia Dwi Dayani, Lilik Widyawati, Heroe Santoso, Rini Anggriani
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: The importance of sentiment analysis has been widely recognized. Sentiment analysis is effective in evaluating public opinion for decision-making. Sentiment analysis is constructive in extracting opinions and classifying sentiments to determine their polarity. Therefore, sentiment analysis has received considerable research attention from scholars to analyze various news and public information, categorizing it as positive, neutral, or negative. Additionally, research on various sentiment analyses using different technical methods and approaches has become a recent focus of study. That is the reason why this study aims to conduct sentiment analysis and research it using more than one method. This study compares the performance of three sentiment analysis machine learning algorithms: Support Vector Machine (SVM), Naïve Bayes (NB), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM). The study results show that SVM achieves the best performance, with an accuracy of 83.60%, an F1-score of 89%, and a recall of 95%. Naïve Bayes follows with an accuracy of 81.20%, precision of 77%, recall of 100%, and F1-score of 87%. LSTM records an accuracy of 81.40%, precision of 87%, recall of 90%, and F1-score of 83%.

title: Automatic Pill Dispenser to Improve Medication Adherence in Elderly and Chronic Disease Patients
authors: Elissa Patricia, Erika Roselyn Husen, Sharon Hermawan, Moh. Erdda Habiby
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: This research showcases an Arduino-driven automatic pill dispenser designed to enhance medication adherence by providing scheduled dispensing and user notifications. The system integrates an RTC module, servo motors, an alarm buzzer, and an interactive LCD display with push buttons, enabling users to configure several medication schedules. It does not require a net connection, which will make this product very applicable for those areas with limited internet access. First, an initial 10-cycle laboratory test intended to simulate a three-times-a-day medication regimen was conducted, followed by a prolonged 30-cycle stress test under the same conditions. A cycle would be considered successful if pills are released at the scheduled time without mechanical jams or servo malfunction. Tests performed did show that the system repeatedly dispensed pills at defined time intervals, with an average timing deviation of +1.75 seconds and a maximum deviation of +2 seconds, achieving an overall success rate of 80%—well within clinically permissible limits for non-critical medication.

title: Mediating Roles of AI-Driven Adoption in IT Agility Drivers on Digital Transformation
authors: Sandy Kosasi, Po Abas Sunarya, Susanti Margaretha Kuway, I Dewa Ayu Eka Yuliani, Utin Kasma, Febriana Giovani
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Regarding AI-driven adoption being the primary catalyst for digital transformation, a considerable disparity in technology acceptance persists between large corporations and micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs). Previous studies predominantly concentrate on the impact of IT agility drivers, specifically regarding IT flexibility, IT capability, and IT governance, on the facilitation of digital transformation, neglecting the correlation with AI-driven adoption. The research seeks to examine how AI-driven adoption mediates the influence of IT agility factors on enabling smooth digital transformation in MSMEs. The research methodology utilizes a convergent triangulation approach with an explanatory design supported by subsequent clarification. The research population consists of MSME companies that have been in existence for more than five years. Questionnaires were disseminated to 305 participants online through random sampling methods, yielding 262 responses, resulting in a return rate of 85.90%. Data processing utilizing the Likert scale and analytical tools employing SEM-PLS. The findings indicated that IT flexibility does not affect AI-driven adoption, and in this context, enhancing IT flexibility may impede AI-driven adoption. Furthermore, IT governance and IT flexibility do not significantly contribute to enabling a smooth and efficient digital transformation.

title: Research and Application of Differential Mode Interference Monitoring Technology for MVB (Multifunction Vehicle Bus) Train Control Bus
authors: Bo Zhang, BuZhao Niu, ChengBin Jiao, XiaoTong Mu, NaiLei Sui, BinFeng Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Rail vehicles in operation frequently encounter sporadic network failures, largely due to the plethora of devices mounted on the Multifunction Vehicle Bus (MVB) cable and the intricate operational conditions. Ensuring full risk mitigation from the design phase is inherently challenging. Consequently, there's a distinct demand for an online monitoring technology to scrutinize the MVB differential mode harmonic interference and pinpoint the fault source. This study delves into the origin of abnormal MVB waveforms in rail vehicles and the transmission mechanism of harmonic interference. It introduces a novel monitoring methodology, outlining its essential capabilities and implementation strategy. Empirical evidence, derived from three distinct case studies, attests to the robust application potential of this technology in the contemporary context

title: Research on Radar Signal Recognition Based on Deep Learning
authors: Hongyan Wang, Rui Zhou, Jiawei Qi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Radar signal sorting and recognition play a critical role in radar countermeasure reconnaissance and intelligence systems, significantly contributing to threat assessment and information acquisition. Given the increasingly complex electromagnetic environment and the growing density of signals, traditional manual sorting methods can no longer meet the real-time processing demands of modern battlefields. Leveraging the capability of artificial intelligence in handling large-scale data, this paper conducts research on intelligent radar signal sorting and recognition. Time-frequency images of intra-pulse characteristics are extracted using the Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) and are automatically classified and identified using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). Through controlled variable experiments examining four aspects---signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), number of iterations, learning rate, and attention mechanism---this study systematically analyzes the impact of various factors on model performance. Simulations validate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Smart Anti-Snoring Pillow with Rotating Disc: A Novel Design for Medical Robots in Sleep Caregiving Field
authors: Kai Feng, Hanyuan Zhao, Tianyi Yang, Xinyi Zhao, Pengyi Wang, Yaoyang Han, Bin Fang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Snoring is a common symptom of sleep apnea syndrome and can be alleviated by adjusting the posture of the head during sleep. This is the design principle behind existing Smart Anti-snoring Pillows (SAPs). The majority of SAPs modify head posture by adopting air pumps or mechanical structures to adjust the height, angle, or hardness of the pillow, thereby inducing a change in position. However, they possess certain imperfections including noise, comfort, cost or effect. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to SAP design, which considers the alteration of head pose as a two-degree-of-freedom rotation problem. We utilize a disc generated by a specialized algorithm to dynamically adjust the slope of the contact surface between the pillow and the user, thereby simulating the natural rotation of the head. Additionally, we modify the support height at the back of the head to achieve the flat or reclined position. Our solution mitigates noise and cost, enhances comfort and effect, and offers a novel concept for advancing the development of sleep-care robots, while also improving the method of altering head posture employed by existing pillows. This paper presents our design concept, theoretical foundation, algorithmic details, and experimental findings.

title: Development of IoT-Enabled BLDC Motor Control System Integrated with Battery Management
authors: Anuradha Rathod, Aditi Falkey, Mrunal Nagalwade, Vaishnavi Thakare, Swapnil Khubalkar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: To ensure optimal performance, electric vehicle batteries require a reliable battery management system (BMS). The smart BMS outlined in this article is suitable for any device equipped with lead-acid battery banks. This system includes tools for monitoring, evaluating, and fault identification of battery health while integrating IoT for realtime data collection. As the use of electric vehicles (EVs) increases, optimizing motor efficiency and battery health becomes crucial for both performance and sustainability. The BLDC motor was selected for its ability to provide precise control and require less maintenance compared to traditional motors, making it ideal for EV applications. The BMS plays a vital role in ensuring safe and efficient operation by monitoring and managing the battery's temperature, charge level, and overall condition. Additionally, with IoT integration, key metrics such as motor performance, battery health, and energy consumption can be monitored remotely, allowing for real-time data collection. The ESP32 serves as the BMS controller and CPU, paired with an ACS712 current sensor module capable of monitoring currents, temperature, while a voltage sensor measures battery voltage. Experimental validation shows stable charging at 15 V, current regulation at 5 A, and automatic cooling fan activation at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$45{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>.

title: Focus-TimesNet: An Attention-Guided Deformable Network for Detecting Anomalies in Steel Manufacturing Processes
authors: Ziyang Han, Hanjin Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: In modern steel manufacturing, detecting anomalies in slab thickness is crucial for ensuring product quality and production efficiency. However, the highly nonlinear, multivariate, and noisy nature of industrial time series data makes this task extremely challenging. In this paper, we propose Focus-TimesNet, a novel anomaly detection model that enhances the original TimesNet architecture by integrating two key components: deformable convolution and a Transformer-based attention mechanism. The deformable convolution enables the model to adaptively focus on critical time points and variable dimensions, while the attention mechanism strengthens the capture of long-range dependencies. Experiments conducted on a real-world dataset collected from a steel plant show that Focus-TimesNet significantly outperforms the original TimesNet and its variants, achieving improvements in Precision, Recall, F1 Score, and AUC. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in identifying rare and complex anomalies in industrial time series data, and its potential for deployment in practical manufacturing environments.

title: Research on Amplitude Statistics from Composite Rough Surface with Vegetated Sub-Regions Based on the SBR-VRT Hybrid Method
authors: Zou Yu-Feng, Chai Shui-Rong, Zhu Fang-Yin, He Zhenxiang, Guo Li-Xin, Liu Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this paper, the Monte Carlo method and Gaussian spectral function are first employed to simulate various ground background scenarios. Subsequently, a weighted inverse tangent function is adopted to smooth the seams of the rough surface, and on this foundation, a geometric model of the composite rough surface is further established. The SBR-VRT method is applied to compute the electromagnetic scattering characteristics of vegetation-covered rough surfaces. The maximum likelihood (ML) estimation method is utilized to estimate the parameters of the clutter amplitude probability density function (PDF), and the distribution characteristics of clutter amplitude in the L-band and S-band are systematically investigated. The fitting analysis of the simulated data demonstrates that the Lognormal distribution is the optimal model for characterizing the amplitude PDF of clutter from both L-band and S-band composite rough surfaces with vegetated sub-regions.

title: Talk-To-Your-Data: Bridging Human Language and SQL with AI
authors: Harini T, Annsi Jerolin E, J Gold Beulah Patturose, R Priscilla
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: By enabling natural language explores driven by Large Language Models (LLMs), the “SQL Chatbot” project SEKS to modify the interaction between users and databases. For nontechnical users, traditional database querying challenges since it depends on SQL knowledge. This work demonstrates a method to interpret natural language input and translate it into SQL queries by combining LangChain with concurrent LLMs. The system upgrades structured database real-time interaction, so clarifying data retrieval access. We evaluate the efficiency of the model, talk on implementation difficulties, and suggest future paths to enhance performance and improve applicability.

title: Deflicker-Awared Foggy Video Generation for UAV Defogging
authors: Liyao Wang, Zijie Zhang, Yongkang Cao, Yipeng Feng, Haobo Zuo, Changhong Fu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Intelligent unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) is crucial in applications such as port monitoring and water rescue. However, fog significantly reduces the perceptual capability of UAV in common water scenarios. Existing methods primarily address the limitations of visual perception by training on paired foggy data. Nevertheless, it is difficult to obtain highquality real-world paired UAV foggy datasets. Furthermore, existing fog generation methods synthesize fog frame by frame, leading to flicker that degrades the performance of defogging methods for UAVs. Additionally, existing metrics for evaluating fog authenticity are insufficient and overlook foggy video generation. To address these issues, this work proposes a novel deflicker-awared foggy video generation framework that reduces flicker in fog generation by leveraging temporal context information. Specifically, an innovative inter-frame depth-map deflicker is designed to refine distance information within sequences. A new long-term light consistency is introduced to achieve time-invariant atmospheric light values. A new benchmark comprising 84 high-quality video sequences with diverse scenes and challenging conditions captured by the UAV is established to address the scarcity of high-quality paired foggy sequence data in water scenes. A new evaluation metric is also presented to assess the authenticity of synthetic fog data. Extensive experiments and visual comparisons with real fog demonstrate the feasibility of our method. The code and demo video are available at https://github.com/vision4robotics/DFVG.

title: Improving Medical Image Segmentation Using Gaze Guidance from Non-Professionals
authors: Yinfeng Fang, Wenlong Ma, Xixia Yu, Qingsong Liu, Yuxi Wang, Yong Peng, Dalin Zhou, Zhaojie Ju
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Medical image segmentation using artificial intelligence (AI) has significantly improved diagnosis and treatment, enhancing patient outcomes. However, AI's reliance on large amounts of labeled data and expert annotations limits its scalability. This paper explores the use of eye movement data from non-professionals to improve segmentation accuracy. A novel gaze-enhanced image segmentation model (GISM) is proposed, consisting of two main components: a transformer-based gaze feature extraction block (TGFB) and a multi-head gazeattention block (MHGB). The MHGB fuses gaze and image data by using gaze features as queries within a transformer framework. The colon polyp dataset, is applied to assess the model's performance. The outcomes reveal that 1) gaze data from non-professionals enhances segmentation accuracy, 2) TGFB outperforms other methods in fusing gaze information, and 3) TGFB is highly adaptable to encoder/decoder-based segmentation frameworks.

title: Model-Based Investigation of Regenerative Braking Impact on Electric Vehicle Battery Performance Under Indian Driving Conditions
authors: Muhammed Inamu Rahman Thekkedath, Panithan Chakkuchan, Santanu Kumar Dash, Mohammed Shijas V, Rahul Surya M, Saichol Chudjuarjeen
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) have emerged as a sustainable alternative to internal combustion (IC) engine vehicles, especially for urban use. One of the effective strategies for improving energy efficiency is regenerative braking, which allows kinetic energy to be recovered during deceleration and fed back into the battery. However, the extent to which regenerative braking benefits EV performance varies depending on driving conditions, motor control, and battery characteristics. This study presents a simulation-based analysis comparing regenerative and non-regenerative braking modes in an electric vehicle driven by a Permanent Magnet DC (PMDC) motor, using MATLAB/Simulink. The vehicle model is tested under a composite 1180-second Indian drive cycle, combining repeated Indian Urban Driving Cycle (IUDC) segments with an extra-urban phase to reflect typical stop-go and mid-speed driving patterns seen in Indian cities. The simulation incorporated two common battery chemistries, lithium-ion (Li-ion) and lead-acid. The primary objective was to investigate how braking mode affects state of charge (SOC), voltage, and responsiveness of current. Results indicate that regenerative braking significantly reduces SOC drop and enhances energy utilization, especially in high-braking-frequency segments of the drive cycle.

title: Progress in Chip-Based Quantum Key Distribution
authors: T.K. Paraïso, A. Khurana, H. Du, J. A. Dolphin, L. Wells, R.M. Stevenson
abstract: We review recent progress in developing photonic integrated circuits that implement core functions for high performance quantum cryptography. We show how they can be configured to meet the requirements of different schemes and protocols, offering a promising route to the scalable deployment of quantum communications.

title: Evaluation of Healthcare Professionals' Satisfaction with the Use of AI in Supporting Clinical Diagnosis
authors: Muhammad Agreindra Helmiawan, Sri Bekti Handayani Ningsih, Iyat Ratna Komala, Mona Yulianti, Uu Sunarya, Balkis Fitriani Faozi
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence in clinical diagnosis promises improved efficiency and accuracy, but healthcare professionals' acceptance and satisfaction with this technology remain concerns. This study assessed the satisfaction levels of healthcare professionals utilising AI in clinical diagnosis, with a focus on the factors that influence their attitudes toward AI tools. A mixed-methods approach was employed, combining quantitative and qualitative methods. Quantitative data were collected through surveys that measured satisfaction and explored perceptions, experiences, and concerns regarding the use of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex> in clinical diagnosis. Quantitative analysis used descriptive and inferential statistics, and qualitative data were analysed through thematic analysis. Results indicated that satisfaction levels with AI varied based on factors such as transparency, reliability, and ethical considerations. Main concerns included a lack of understanding of AI algorithms, potential bias in decision-making, and legal liability implications. Conversely, professionals with positive AI experiences viewed it as a tool to reduce workload and enhance efficiency. This discussion highlights the importance of developing a comprehensive strategy to improve awareness, offer targeted training, establish clear ethical guidelines, and promote collaboration between AI developers and healthcare professionals. The study concludes that successful AI integration in clinical diagnosis requires attention to psychological, social, and ethical factors. By addressing barriers and maximising the potential of AI, the healthcare community can create a more efficient, empathetic, and equitable system.

title: Enhanced Flood Rescue Operations with Vision-based Object Detection and Recognition
authors: Priyanka M, Suresha R, Allagunta Sudheer, Abhishek S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: Finding people who are alive amid flood disasters is an urgent and challenging part of search and rescue operations. Floodwater often has very low visibility, which significantly affects the quality of images captured by the far-UAV range. This issue makes it challenging to notice where objects blend in due to their small size, busy backgrounds, poor lighting, and reflections in the water. This study focuses on aerial drone images, utilizing a robust image preprocessing pipeline to enhance the visuals before passing them to YOLOv8n for object detection and recognition. The model achieves 80% precision, 82% recall, and an mAP@50 of 81%. The 4,528 annotated images comprised survivors and cars that were either entirely visible, partially visible, or completely absent. The outcomes suggest that the system detects circumstances instantly and adapts to the environment, making it suitable for use where needed with minimal alteration.

title: Voltage Inversion based on Three-dimensional Simulated Charge Method with Improved Genetic Algorithm
authors: YunFan Tan, JianYu Zhang, ZhongBin Chen, Wei Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: For conductor structures with finite lengths and non-parallel orientation to the ground, such as busbars in substations, the traditional two-dimensional Charge Simulation Method (2D CSM) becomes inadequate. This paper proposes a novel non-contact voltage inversion technique. A three-dimensional forward modeling of the electric field is constructed by incorporating 3D coordinate transformation and linear charge simulation equations. An adaptive Genetic Algorithm (GA) is employed to optimize measurement point locations, thereby reducing the condition number of the coefficient matrix and mitigating the ill-posed nature of the electric field inversion problem. Simulations using PROGRAMMING SOFTWARE and Finite Element Simulation on a 72.25kV three-phase Alternating Current (AC) model demonstrate that this method accurately inverts voltage magnitude and phase even with 10% measurement error, providing support for non-contact voltage measurement in complex three-dimensional field environments.

title: A SBR Algorithm for Near-field RCS Simulation of Targets
authors: Jincong Huo, Jie Ma, Shigang Zhou, Weishan Li, Xueyao Xiong, Haoming Ren
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this work, a near-field shooting and bouncing ray (SBR) algorithm for calculating the near-field RCS of targets is proposed. The proposed algorithm first uses the triangular meshes on the object surface as ray tubes and performs ray tracing based on them. Then, the near-field SBR integration formula is derived, and effective ray tubes are integrated and accumulated to obtain the total near-field scattering of the object. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm is verified by comparing the results with the near-field scattering simulation formula for a flat and the multilevel fast multipole method (MLFMM) for a dihedral corner reflector.

title: A Comprehensive Photon Detection Probability Model for CMOS Single-Photon Avalanche Diodes
authors: Xuanyu Qian, Zecheng Gao, Junle Chen, M. Jamal Deen, Wei Jiang
abstract: Photon detection probability (PDP) modeling is essential for optimizing CMOS single-photon avalanche diode (SPAD) designs. However, process variations and experimental non-idealities can hinder accurate PDP predictions. To address these challenges, an improved PDP model is proposed and validated against the measured data.

title: Heart Disease Prediction Using Random Forest in Machine Learning Using The Concepts of Data Mining
authors: Shane Ryu Cahya, Jonathan Hartanto, Bakti Amirul Jabar, Jurike V. Moniaga
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Heart disease remains one of the leading causes of death worldwide, making early prediction essential for treatment and prevention. This study applies machine learning techniques, specifically the Random Forest algorithm, to predict the likelihood of heart disease based on patient data. Using the standard UCI heart disease dataset, we employed data mining techniques for cleaning, preprocessing, and feature selection to ensure model reliability. The Random Forest model, implemented with bagging as an ensemble method, achieved an accuracy of 90.16%, outperforming several other classification algorithms and exceeding results reported in previous studies. These findings highlight the potential of Random Forest, supported by effective data mining strategies, as a practical tool for clinical decision-making and early intervention in heart disease management.

title: Implementation of Pre-Trained Model Wav2Vec2 XLS-R for Reciting of Quran Verses Accuracy Detection
authors: Fenty Eka Muzayyana Agustin, Belvin Shandy Aurora, Tabah Rosyadi, Muhammad Sobri, Nurul Faizah
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) in this research aim to predict the correctness student's Quran recitation used a pre-trained model Wav2Vec2 XLS-R. The Dataset source comes from student voice recordings of Al Insyirah, with 463 training data and 32 testing data. The process of data preparation such as noise reduction, audio segmentation, and adjusting the format of input data to the ASR model. In the modeling phase, the model applies data augmentation, dropout, and hyperparameter tuning on learning rate, dropout rate, and activation function in order to find the best performance. The best model was found using data augmentation and dropout to avoid overfitting with hyperparameter learning rate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \mathrm{e}-4$</tex>, dropout rate 0.1, and GELU activation function. The best model achieved a WER 2.77 % and CER 0.82 % on the test data. Meanwhile, the results of the model prediction on the experts validation results get a WER <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2. 0 3 \%}$</tex> and CER 2.95%.

title: A New Platform for Investigation of Electrode Moving Speed Effect and Characteristics in Small-gap Electrostatic Discharge
authors: Ruan Fang-Ming, Xu Kai, Lou Shi-Chao, Wang Wen-Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A new measurement system, after analyzing problems in references and conducting large number of experiments, was designed and realized with a prototype machine on electrode moving speed effect in electrostatic discharge. The difficult problem was resolved with the new measurement system that electrode need to move at high speed to the target for research speed effect on result in small-gap electrostatic discharge events, whereas strong collision must be avoided to protect experiment device from being damaged. A theoretical model was built on electrode moving speed effect based on two basic principles of fluid quantity conservation law and Bernoulli theorem in fluid mechanics. Considering analysis of numerous algorithms, effect on discharge results of gas pressure and electrode moving speed to the target were discussed and preliminary verification was given with experiment data resulted from the new measurement platform.

title: Evaluating Communication Performance in Private 5G Smart Factory Deployments
authors: William O’Brien, Adam Dooley, Mihai Penica, Denis Moore, Eoin O’Connell
abstract: The integration of private 5G networks in Industry 4.0 presents a significant opportunity to enhance manufacturing automation, real-time machine-to-machine (M2M) communication, and industrial IoT applications. This study evaluates the throughput and latency performance of private 5G networks in smart manufacturing environments, focusing on two distinct Radio Access Network (RAN) platforms: Stock RAN and Open RAN. The experimental analysis assesses subscriber-to-subscriber and subscriber-to-data centre communication, measuring performance under varying network loads. The results highlight key trade-offs between Open RAN and Stock RAN, emphasizing the need for application-specific deployment strategies in private 5G networks. These insights contribute to ongoing research in wireless industrial networking, guiding network engineers and system integrators in optimizing private 5G deployments for smart manufacturing applications.

title: An Improved Diagnosis System with Dynamic Weight Learning and Trustworthy Evaluation
authors: Sirun Wang, Hui Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Case-based reasoning (CBR) as a flourishing problem-solving method enables decision makers to utilize the specific knowledge of previously experienced. While facing with problems that require high accuracy and reliability, such as disease diagnosis, it is crucial to build an assistive system that can provide highly accurate and reliable results. In this study, an improved CBR diagnosis framework is designed: In the case retrieval step, aiming to improve the diagnosis accuracy, an iterative learning method is proposed to distribute appropriate weights for the attribute. Moreover, in order to improve the reliability of the diagnosis system, a trustworthy evaluation strategy is introduced to assess the reliability of the suggested diagnosis result. The comparison experiments are conduct on the pulse wave data for cardiovascular disease (CVD) with other common diagnosis models, the results indicated that the proposed framework could provide a more accurate and reliable diagnosis performance, proved that the improved CBR system is capable of helping people on the early diagnosis of CVD with an accurate diagnosis and the low uncertainty risk of the diagnosis results.

title: Power Consumption Forecasting Method Based on Multi-Model Fusion
authors: Taiyu Zheng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that traditional linear models and single deep learning models fail to achieve high accuracy in power load forecasting due to the non-stationary characteristics of load sequences and the coupling of multi-type features, this study proposes a multi-model dynamic weighted fusion forecasting method based on prior extraction. The method constructs a 3D time-series dataset suitable for deep learning through data prior extraction and integration (including data cleaning, feature engineering, and windowing), selects complementary Transformer (for capturing long-range temporal dependencies) and TFT (for identifying feature mutations at key time nodes) as base models, and designs an adaptive dynamic weighting mechanism based on real-time MSE to fuse prediction results. Validated on the Australian Electricity Price and Power Dataset with MSE and MAE as metrics, compared with models like PatchTST, LSTM, and TCN, the proposed method reduces MSE by 7%–32% and MAE by 4%–22% against the optimal results of comparative models under different dataset sizes, while showing minimal error fluctuation and strong robustness.

title: Non-Hermitian Time Topology from Complex Momentum Bands
authors: A. Steinfurth, J. Feis, J. Görsch, T. Sheppard, H. M. Price, A. Szameit, S. Weidemann
abstract: We introduce momentum point gaps in complex momentum bands as a new topological object and implement them in non-Hermitian photonic lattices. This concept allows the observation of a temporal analogue of the non-Hermitian skin effect, manifesting as robust topological light localization at a time interface.

title: Research on Security-Constrained Economic Dispatch for Power Systems Based on Broad-Deep Fusion Learning
authors: Chunhua Huang, Zhijun Qin, Yude Yang, Caihao Zhai, Chaoyang Lu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: The traditional driving method of Safety Constrained Economic Dispatch (SCED) in power systems relies on strict mathematical modeling and iterative optimization, which poses complex problems in power flow verification and model solving. Therefore, this article proposes a hybrid driven SCED solution method based on a wide depth fusion learning system using data-driven methods. Firstly, a wide deep fusion model (CNN-BLS) is constructed, which includes convolutional neural networks (CNN) and Broad Learning System (BLS). The end-to-end mapping relationship of active power flow in the line is trained using historical operating data, replacing the traditional power flow calculation module; Secondly, by using the power flow mapping model to quickly calculate sensitivity, efficient solving of the Jacobian matrix can be achieved, avoiding the computational bottleneck of matrix inversion in traditional methods; Finally, establish a model data hybrid driven architecture to form an SCED optimization framework that combines data-driven flexibility and physical model reliability, achieving efficient solutions. The effectiveness of the proposed method was verified through simulation calculations using a 10 machine 39 node system.

title: Cross-Modal Meta-Generalization for Silent Speech Recognition via Ultrasound Tongue Images
authors: Minghao Guo, Qiang Fang, Hongcheng Zhang, Wenhuan Lu, Jianguo Wei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Silent Speech Recognition (SSR) technologies utilize assistive devices to facilitate specific human-computer interaction by decoding speech from non-acoustic biosignals generated during speech production. Current Ultrasound Tongue Images (UTIs)- based SSR technologies fail to address the domain-shift problem that arises from sensor displacement artifacts, articulatory patterns, and speaker deviations. Moreover, existing solutions seldom utilize cross-modal knowledge to enhance uni-modal generalization. This paper proposes a novel Domain Generalization (DG) method to learn domain-invariant representations from synchronized audio and lip video encoding, named the Cross-Modal Meta-Generalization (CMMG) framework. We proposed a multi-modal co-learning pipeline to randomly combine the tri-modal streams into a modality-agnostic feature space, constructing expanded domain-shift episodes from multi-modal source domains. Moreover, we designed several meta-tasks that involve classifying various speech attributes (e.g., tongue height) to implement cross-modal semantic regularization. Subsequently, the model is trained episodically, with each task or episode simulating a domain shift to seek optimal generalization in unseen uni-modal domains. Experimental results across various cross-domain sets demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms both uni-modal baselines and existing domain-shift solutions. Additionally, we explore the coupling information of multi-modal heterogeneous features through both segmental and sub-segmental level meta-tasks, finding that the proposed CMMG effectively enhances the generalization and discriminative capability of uni-modal representations.

title: Towards a Framework of Innovation Ecosystem Performance: A Case Study
authors: Jack Adams, Ozgur Dedehayir, Saku J. Mäkinen, J. Roland Ortt
abstract: The ability of innovation ecosystems to deliver desired economic output, particularly under conditions of uncertainty shaped by market shifts, competitive change, and regulatory pressure, concerns all ecosystem stakeholders. Understanding innovation ecosystem performance therefore emerges as an important topic for scholars, managers, and policymakers. The objective of this paper is to propose a conceptual framework of ecosystem performance that builds on the inherent connection between system-level outcomes and the performance of all components that constitute the ecosystem. To this end, we apply a socio-technical lens to identify performance-deficient social or technical components known as ‘reverse salients’ that influence the performance of the ecosystem as a whole. Our case study of a regional Australian food innovation ecosystem identifies numerous reverse salients that inhibit ecosystem performance as the system transitions from its current focus on high-quality produce to a future state characterized by increased output capacity and value-added offerings. We categorize these reverse salients as those associated with ‘actors’ in the ecosystem, ‘connections’ between actors, and ‘resources’ flowing among them. While these categories align with the ecosystem-as-structure perspective, our findings additionally underscore the moderating role of ecosystem ‘leadership’ and ‘rules of engagement’ that can themselves act as reverse salients when misaligned. We present a conceptual model that integrates these insights and offer a set of propositions to guide future empirical research.

title: Robot-Assisted Surgery: A Comprehensive Review of Literature, Challenges, Ethical Considerations, and Current Trends
authors: Muhammad Nadeem, Yehia Ibrahim Alzoubi, Ersin Elbasi, Ahmet E. Topcu
abstract: Robot-Assisted Surgery (RAS) has revolutionized modern surgical practice by enhancing precision, reducing invasiveness, and improving patient outcomes across various medical specialties. This comprehensive review explores the evolution and impact of robotic systems in surgery, synthesizing findings from recent literature on their clinical effectiveness, technical advancements, and integration into standard healthcare practices. This study highlights the key challenges, including high costs, limited accessibility, training complexity, and system reliability. In parallel, ethical considerations such as informed consent, data privacy, surgeon accountability, and patient safety were critically examined. Current trends in RAS, such as the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) for autonomous functions, haptic feedback systems, and remote telesurgery, are also discussed, providing insights into the future trajectory of this rapidly developing field. By evaluating existing technologies and addressing multidisciplinary concerns, this review aims to inform stakeholders and guide the responsible advancement of robot-assisted surgical systems in healthcare.

title: FAS-LLM: Large Language Model–Based Channel Prediction for OTFS-Enabled Satellite–FAS Links
authors: Halvin Yang, Sangarapillai Lambotharan, Mahsa Derakhshani
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: This paper proposes FAS-LLM, a novel large language model (LLM)–based architecture for predicting future channel states in Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS)-enabled satellite downlinks equipped with fluid antenna systems (FAS). The proposed method introduces a two-stage channel compression strategy combining reference-port selection and separable principal component analysis (PCA) to extract compact, delay–Doppler–aware representations from highdimensional OTFS channels. These representations are then embedded into a Low Rank Adaptation (LoRA)-adapted LLM, enabling efficient time-series forecasting of channel coefficients. Performance evaluations demonstrate that FAS-LLM outperforms classical baselines including GRU, LSTM, and Transformer models, achieving up to 10 dB normalized mean squared error (NMSE) improvement and up to threefold root mean squared error (RMSE) reduction across prediction horizons. Furthermore, the predicted channels preserve key physical-layer characteristics, enabling near-optimal performance in ergodic capacity, spectral efficiency, and outage probability across a wide range of signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). These results highlight the potential of LLM-based forecasting for delay-sensitive and energy-efficient link adaptation in future satellite IoT networks.

title: How Does Firms' Artificial Intelligence Adoption Affect Different Stakeholders? A Systematic Review and the AIMS Framework_supp1-3646221.docx
authors: Hugo K.S. Lam
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has been increasingly adopted by firms for different organizational purposes. While such AI adoption is expected to affect firm performance, it may also have different effects on firms' stakeholders such as employees, shareholders, and customers. To provide a more comprehensive understanding of the stakeholder implications of AI adoption, we conduct a systematic review of 84 relevant papers published in business journals in the past 8 years (2017-2024). Our review suggests that firms' AI adoption does have different, sometimes conflicting, effects on different stakeholder groups. We also uncover several limitations of the extant literature and develop an integrative AIMS (AI Impacts Multiple Stakeholders) framework that summarizes important directions for future research. Our AIMS framework emphasizes the need to consider underexplored stakeholder groups such as suppliers and competitors, as well as the trade-offs and dynamics among different stakeholder groups induced by AI adoption. Our framework also encourages future research to move beyond examining the direct impact of AI adoption on stakeholders by investigating when (contextual factors) and why (underlying mechanisms) AI adoption affects stakeholders, thereby advancing the literature on AI-stakeholder relationships. Finally, we discuss the implications for future operations management research, encouraging scholars to adopt a supply chain perspective to study the stakeholder implications of firms' AI adoption.

title: OpenVocabCT: Towards Universal Text-driven CT Image Segmentation_supp1-3646046.pdf
authors: Xiaofeng Yang
abstract: Computed tomography (CT) is extensively used for accurate visualization and segmentation of organs and lesions. While deep learning models such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and vision transformers (ViTs) have significantly improved CT image analysis, their performance often declines when applied to diverse, real-world clinical data. Although foundation models offer a broader and more adaptable solution, their potential is limited due to the challenge of obtaining large-scale, voxel-level annotations for medical images. In response to these challenges, prompting-based models using visual or text prompts have emerged. Visual-prompting methods, such as the Segment Anything Model (SAM), still require significant manual input and can introduce ambiguity when applied to clinical scenarios. Instead, foundation models that use text prompts offer a more versatile and clinically relevant approach. Notably, current text-prompt models, such as the CLIP-Driven Universal Model, are limited to text prompts already encountered during training and struggle to process the complex and diverse scenarios of real-world clinical applications. Instead of fine-tuning models trained from natural imaging, we propose OpenVocabCT, a vision-language model pretrained on large-scale 3D CT images for universal text-driven segmentation. Using the large-scale CT-RATE dataset, we decompose the diagnostic reports into fine-grained, organ-level descriptions using large language models for multi-granular contrastive learning. We evaluate our OpenVocabCT on downstream segmentation tasks across 14 public datasets and 1 institutional dataset for organ and tumor segmentation, demonstrating the superior performance of our model compared to existing methods. All code, datasets, and models will be publicly released at https://github.com/ricklisz/OpenVocabCT.

title:
Epitaxial Fe(Se,Te) Film Deposited on CaF
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Single Crystal Substrate: Defect Generation and Film Stability
authors: Angelo Vannozzi, Antonella Mancini, Andrea Masi, Laura Piperno, Valentina Galluzzi, Alessandro Rufoloni, Giuseppe Celentano
abstract: Epitaxial iron chalcogenide (FeCh, Ch = Se, Te) film deposited by pulsed laser deposition (PLD) represents the gold standard to obtain high superconducting performances. (100) CaF2 single crystal represents the ideal substrate due to structural compatibility, low lattice mismatch and chemical compatibility with FeCh. Epitaxial thin FeCh films grown on CaF2 show optimal performances, with zero-resistance critical temperature Tc0 as high as 9.2 K and 17 K for FeSe and Fe(Se,Te), respectively. Higher Tc up to 20 K can be obtained using a seed layer in Fe(Se,Te).However, film buckling and delamination sometimes occur. Furthermore, the presence of submicrometric wrinkles arranged in graticule pattern was occasionally observed. In this contribution, we provide information on extended defect formation in epitaxial FeCh thin films deposited on (100) CaF2 single crystal by PLD, and their influence on the superconducting properties of such films.

title: Vertical Heterogeneous Networks Beyond 5G: CoMP Coverage Enhancement and Optimization
authors: Tian Shi, Wenkun Wen, Peiran Wu, Minghua Xia
abstract: Low-altitude wireless networks are increasingly vital for the low-altitude economy, enabling wireless coverage in high-mobility and hard-to-reach environments. However, providing reliable connectivity to sparsely distributed aerial users in dynamic three-dimensional (3D) spaces remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates downlink coverage enhancement in vertical heterogeneous networks (VHetNets) beyond 5G, where unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) operate as emerging aerial base stations (ABSs) alongside legacy terrestrial base stations (TBSs). To improve coverage performance, we propose a coordinated multi-point (CoMP) transmission framework that enables joint transmission from ABSs and TBSs. This approach mitigates the limitations of non-uniform user distributions and enhances reliability for sparse aerial users. Two UAV deployment strategies are considered: i) random UAV placement, analyzed using stochastic geometry to derive closed-form coverage expressions, and ii) optimized UAV placement using a coverage-aware weighted K-means clustering algorithm to maximize cooperative coverage in underserved areas. Theoretical analyses and Monte Carlo simulations demonstrate that the proposed CoMP-enabled VHetNet significantly improves downlink coverage probability, particularly in scenarios with sparse aerial users. These findings highlight the potential of intelligent UAV coordination and geometry-aware deployment to enable robust, adaptive connectivity in low-altitude wireless networks.

title: Real-Time Optimal Cutting Control for Continuous Casting-Rolling Systems via Enhanced PPO Algorithm
authors: Xudong Hong, Kai Wang, Wei Zhao, Bin Xu, Zhi Liu
abstract: In continuous casting and rolling (CCR) systems, precise billet cutting is critical for ensuring product dimensional accuracy and minimizing material waste. However, conventional rule-based cutting strategies rely on static parameters and heuristic rules, which often fail to adapt to real-time disturbances such as thermal expansion, cross-sectional fluctuations, and trimming losses. These limitations frequently lead to suboptimal control performance and excessive residual lengths. Deep reinforcement learning (DRL), with its dynamic decision-making and self-adaptive capabilities, offers a promising alternative. This study proposes an intelligent billet cutting strategy based on the Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm, integrating process disturbances, thermodynamic characteristics, and physical constraints into a unified control framework. Extensive evaluations conducted in a high-fidelity CCR simulation environment demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms both traditional approaches and existing RL-based methods in terms of control accuracy, generalization ability, and robustness to disturbances, highlighting its practical potential in intelligent steel manufacturing systems.

title: Bayesian Multifractal Image Segmentation
authors: Kareth M. León-López, Abderrahim Halimi, Jean-Yves Tourneret, Herwig Wendt
abstract: Multifractal analysis (MFA) provides a framework for the global characterization of image textures by describing the spatial fluctuations of their local regularity based on the multifractal spectrum. Several works have shown the interest of using MFA for the description of homogeneous textures in images. Nevertheless, natural images can be composed of several textures and, in turn, multifractal properties associated with those textures. This paper introduces an unsupervised Bayesian multifractal segmentation method to model and segment multifractal textures by jointly estimating the multifractal parameters and labels on images, at the pixel-level. For this, a computationally and statistically efficient multifractal parameter estimation model for wavelet leaders is firstly developed, defining different multifractality parameters for different regions of an image. Then, a multiscale Potts Markov random field is introduced as a prior to model the inherent spatial and scale correlations (referred to as cross-scale correlations) between the labels of the wavelet leaders. A Gibbs sampling methodology is finally used to draw samples from the posterior distribution of the unknown model parameters. Numerical experiments are conducted on synthetic multifractal images to evaluate the performance of the proposed segmentation approach. The proposed method achieves superior performance compared to traditional unsupervised segmentation techniques as well as modern deep learning-based approaches, showing its effectiveness for multifractal image segmentation.

title: Architectural Selection Framework for Synthetic Network Traffic: Quantifying the Fidelity-Utility Trade-off
authors: Dure Adan Ammara, Jianguo Ding, Kurt Tutschku
abstract: The fidelity and utility of synthetic network traffic are critically compromised by architectural mismatch across heterogeneous network datasets and prevalent scalability failure. This study addresses this challenge by establishing an Architectural Selection Framework that empirically quantifies how data structure compatibility dictates the optimal fidelity-utility trade-off. We systematically evaluate twelve generative architectures (both non-AI and AI) across two distinct data structure types: categorical-heavy NSL-KDD and continuous-flow-heavy CIC-IDS2017. Fidelity is rigorously assessed through three structural metrics (Data Structure, Correlation, and Probability Distribution Difference) to confirm structural realism before evaluating downstream utility. Our results, confirmed over twenty independent runs (N = 20), demonstrate that GAN-based models (CTGAN, CopulaGAN) exhibit superior architectural robustness, consistently achieving the optimal balance of statistical fidelity and practical utility. Conversely, the framework exposes critical failure modes, i.e., statistical methods compromise structural fidelity for utility (Compromised fidelity), and modern iterative architectures, such as Diffusion Models, face prohibitive computational barriers, rendering them impractical for large-scale security deployment. This contribution provides security practitioners with an evidence-based guide for mitigating architectural failures, thereby setting a benchmark for reliable and scalable synthetic data deployment in adaptive security solutions.

title: Secure Event-triggered Molecular Communication–Information Theoretic Perspective and Optimal Performance
authors: Wafa Labidi, Vida Gholamian, Yaning Zhao, Christian Deppe, Holger Boche
publish: IEEE Transactions on Molecular, Biological, and Multi-Scale Communications
abstract: Molecular Communication (MC) is an emerging field of research focused on understanding how cells in the human body communicate and exploring potential medical applications. In theoretical analysis, the goal is to investigate cellular communication mechanisms and develop nanomachine-assisted therapies to combat diseases. Since cells transmit information by releasing molecules at varying intensities, this process is commonly modeled using Poisson channels. In our study, we consider a discrete-time Poisson channel (DTPC). MC is often event-driven, making traditional Shannon communication an unsuitable performance metric. Instead, we adopt the identification framework introduced by Ahlswede and Dueck. In this approach, the receiver is only concerned with detecting whether a specific message of interest has been transmitted. Unlike Shannon transmission codes, the size of identification (ID) codes for a discrete memoryless channel (DMC) increases doubly exponentially with blocklength when using randomized encoding. This remarkable property makes the ID paradigm significantly more efficient than classical Shannon transmission in terms of energy consumption and hardware requirements. Another critical aspect of MC, influenced by the concept of the Internet of Bio-NanoThings, is security. In-body communication must be protected against potential eavesdroppers. To address this, we first analyze the DTPC for randomized identification (RI) and then extend our study to secure randomized identification (SRI). We derive capacity formulas for both RI and SRI, providing a comprehensive understanding of their performance and security implications.

title: Federated Learning with a Temporal-Degradation-Aware Transformer for Robust Joint SOC and SOH Estimation in Electric Vehicle Batteries
authors: Prasanta Kumar Mohanty, Premalata Jena, Narayana Prasad Padhy
abstract: Accurate estimation of State-of-Charge (SOC) and State-of-Health (SOH) is critical for the safe and reliable operation of Electric Vehicle (EV) batteries. However, centralized approaches face challenges such as data privacy, communication overhead, and poor scalability under non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data. Although some methods attempt joint estimation, most rely on centralized learning, lack computational efficiency for embedded systems, and overlook uncertainty quantification, limiting real-world applicability. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a federated framework for joint SOC and SOH estimation that is privacy-preserving, lightweight, and uncertainty-aware. The core model is a Temporal-Degradation-Aware Informer (TDA-Informer), which incorporates an Informer-Lite encoder and a multi-task prediction structure. A Battery-Focused Multi-Feature Attention (BFMFA) module emphasizes critical inputs such as voltage, current, and temperature. The Stochastic Controlled Averaging for Federated Learning (SCAFFOLD) algorithm is employed to mitigate client drift under non-IID conditions, enhancing convergence across distributed EV clients. Uncertainty Quantification is achieved via Monte Carlo Dropout to provide confidence intervals for SOC and SOH predictions. The framework is trained and validated on the NASA battery dataset and tested for generalization on the unseen Oxford dataset, with realistic sensor noise added to simulate practical conditions. Extensive experiments, including ablation studies and comparisons with baseline models, confirm its superior accuracy, robustness, and scalability. While physical deployment remains future work, the results confirm the framework’s potential for intelligent, scalable Battery Management Systems (BMS).

title: Underwater Acoustic Spectrum Sensing Algorithm Based on Personalized Federated Learning and RepViG
authors: Kai Wang, Jun Fang, Liliang Zhang, Ping Xiao, Bixin Cai, Gengfeng Zheng, Lingwei Xu, T. Aaron Gulliver
abstract: The Ocean Internet of Things (OIoT) has promoted the development of the ocean devices, which generate a large amount of underwater acoustic data. The transmission of underwater acoustic data requires a large amount of spectrum resources. Aiming at the problems of improving the utilization rate and security of spectrum resources, an underwater acoustic spectrum sensing algorithm based on personalized federated learning (PFL) and RepViG is proposed. A security protection framework is established for underwater acoustic data based on PFL. The common features of each underwater acoustic data are extracted through the meta-model. Each client only needs to fine-tune the parameters of the meta-model based on the local underwater acoustic data to achieve a personalized model. Based on the improved RepViT and the improved ViG, a dual-branch sensing model of RepViG is designed. In the improved RepViT, we employ the Haar wavelet downsampling (HWD) module to retain the low-frequency and high-frequency detail features of the underwater acoustic signal through multi-resolution. And we employ Interactive Convolution Block (ICB) to capture the relationship between local features and global features through multi-scale dynamic convolution kernels. In the improved ViG, we adopt the lightweight Star-Blcok module to reduce feature redundancy and enhance sensing efficiency. Compared with other algorithms, the simulation results show that the detection probability is increased by 7.6%, and the false alarm probability is reduced by 7.5%.

title: OBC and APM Integration Topology and Decoupling Design for Solar Electric Vehicle
authors: Desheng Rong, Zhongbao Lin, Xuanjin Sun, Yadong Han, Changxuan Li
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: Integration of electric vehicle power conversion units presents a promising solution, yet introduces challenges including inter-port power coupling and compromised efficiency in integrated systems. This paper proposes a photovoltaic compatible integrated converter combining on-board charger (OBC) with auxiliary power module (APM), featuring cost effectiveness and high power density. Introduction of decoupling capacitor enables charging decoupling between high voltage battery (HVB) and low voltage battery (LVB), thereby simplifying multi-port energy management. Furthermore, minimum current ratio is employed to determine optimal phase shift, achieving minimized conduction losses during HVB charging while maintaining zero voltage switching (ZVS) for all switches. Comprehensive analysis of proposed converter is conducted, covering operational principles, steady-state performance, soft switching characteristics, efficiency and loss breakdown, along with control methodology. Experimental prototype rated at 500W for OBC and 300W for APM is implemented to validate converter performance. Experimental results demonstrate peak system efficiency of 95.3% during simultaneous HVB and LVB charging, and 93.16% during LVB charging alone, confirming effectiveness of proposed converter.

title: Three-Level Circulant Modulation With Submodule Capacitor Voltage Natural-Balance Capability for Bidirectional Modular DC-DC Converter
authors: Guangdi Li, Qizhen Wu, Abhishek Kumar, Bowen Zhou, Bikash Sah, Ramesh C. Bansal, Yan Deng
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Industrial Electronics
abstract: A three-level duty cycle phase-shift circulant modulation with submodule (SM) voltage natural balancing for bidirectional modular DC-DC converter (Bi-MDC) is proposed in this paper. Compared to the conventional single-phase-shift circulant modulation to achieve capacitor voltage balance in SMs, the proposed duty cycle phase-shift circulant modulation method offers advantages such as lower current stress and voltage change rate (dv/dt) along with voltage natural balancing. Furthermore, circulant modulation enables a highly flexible voltage conversion ratio while inherently achieving natural balancing of SM capacitor voltages, without additional feedback control. Additionally, the low switching frequency operation of SMs, combined with a high operational frequency, facilitates a significant reduction in the size of passive components, thereby enhancing system efficiency and compactness. This paper presents the working principle and theoretical analysis of the converter in detail, followed by experimental validation based on a hardware prototype built and tested in the laboratory.

title: Economic and Power System Condition Aware Operation of Complex Thermal-Electric Microgrids
authors: Dimitra G. Kyriakou, Fotios D. Kanellos, George J. Tsekouras
abstract: The ongoing transition to sustainable and resilient energy systems has led to the increasing adoption of microgrids, which integrate diverse energy resources to enhance local energy management. However, existing approaches often overlook the complex interplay between these diverse energy resources. Addressing these limitations, this work proposes a comprehensive microgrid optimization framework that simultaneously coordinates the operation of combined cooling and heating power (CCHP) systems, large-scale building prosumers, and plug-in electric vehicles (PEVs) within a unified strategy. The proposed approach jointly minimizes microgrid operation cost, flattens the electrical load profile at the substation level, and ensures net-zero energy exchange with the main grid. Moreover, the optimization of the CCHP system is achieved while explicitly limiting greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, contributing to environmental sustainability—an increasingly critical goal in the context of decarbonization. Additionally, the proposed optimization framework incorporates a wide range of technical and operational constraints including building thermal comfort at thermal zone level, energy storage and charging power limitations of PEVs and voltage drop throughout the distribution network. Furthermore, aggregation is applied to the PEVs hosted by the microgrid and smart thermal power dispatch techniques are developed and hierarchically applied at building and thermal zone levels, achieving improved computational efficiency and scalability. Extensive simulations were performed to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: A Design-Fit Approach to Architecture, Engineering, and Construction Digitalization: Leveraging Big Data and Real-Scene Imaging in Landscape Projects
authors: Yu-I Lai, Tzu-Chuan Chou, Ling-Pu Huang
abstract: The architecture, engineering, and construction (AEC) industry is undergoing a major transformation driven by information and communication technologies (ICTs). Landscape design is significantly impacted. This study explores how organizations can agilely recombine data and information from multiple digital artifacts to enhance design practices. Conducted within a landscape design company, the research focuses on the need for integrated total solutions that incorporate diverse emerging technologies, making issues of recombination highly relevant and essential. Given the complexity of design-fit processes, understanding interoperability and compatibility is critical to effectively implementing information technology strategies. To enhance decision making, the proposed system leverages big data analytics to address specific decision problems. Through continuous accumulation of real-scene imaging data, the system enables better cost control and waste reduction. Overall, this study contributes to the literature on the digitalization of the AEC industry and provides managerial insights for practitioners who aim to advance AEC practices through innovative technologies.

title: Inverse-Designed Silicon Nitride Wavelength Demultiplexers Bridging the Visible and Telecom Bands
authors: Aolong Sun, Yuqin Yuan, Junhui Hu, Xuyu Deng, Sizhe Xing, Junhao Zhao, Ouhan Huang, Ziwei Li, Jianyang Shi, Chao Shen, Junwen Zhang, Nan Chi
abstract: We propose two compact (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 8 \mu^{2}$</tex>) silicon nitride wavelength demultiplexers bridging <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$600 / 1550 ~\text{nm}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$600 / 1310$</tex> nm bands via inverse design. title: A Systematic Literature Review on Digital Health Continuance Intention: Applying the Expectation Confimation Model (ECM)
authors: Yusuf Durachman, Nurbojatmiko, Alvin Aryan, Muhammad Qomarul Huda, Nuryasin
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The rapid evolution of digital technologies has led to the widespread adoption of digital health services, including telemedicine, e-health, and m-health. However, the sustainability of these services relies heavily on users' intention to continue using them over time-known as Continuance Use Intention (CUI). This study aims to systematically review the application of the Expectation Confirmation Model (ECM) in analyzing CUI within digital health contexts. Using a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) approach, 17 peer-reviewed studies published between 2019 and 2024 were examined. The review identifies key factors influencing CUI, including confirmation of initial expectations, perceived usefulness, and user satisfaction. Findings reveal that ECM is the most widely used theoretical framework to explain continuance behavior in digital health, often extended with models such as TAM, UTAUT, and trustbased theories to provide a more holistic analysis. Future research is encouraged to further explore contextual factors such as digital literacy, trust in technology, and types of health conditions, which may moderate the relationships among ECM variables, including self-efficacy and service quality. The results of this review offer both theoretical and practical implications for enhancing the sustainability of digital health platforms.

title: Design of a Metagrating-Based PCB Spatial Power Divider with Arbitrary Ratio
authors: Zhen Tan, Jianjia Yi, Shah Nawaz Burokur
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This work presents the design of a PCB-based metagrating for spatial power division, capable of achieving arbitrary power-splitting ratios while controlling the propagation directions of the splitted beams through the metagrating’s period configuration. Each unit cell of the metagrating consists of five meta-atoms (three on the top layer and two on the bottom layer of the dielectric substrate), implemented as capacitive structures using simple metallic strips. To validate the design, a beam splitter with output angles of −50° and +50° and a power ratio of 3:7 is modeled and numerically simulated. The simulation results show excellent agreement with the predictions, confirming the performances of the proposed design.

title: Research on the Coexistence of Interference between Mobile and Portable WPT Devices and Broadcast Service
authors: Xiaoyong Liu, Ke Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: With the popularity of mobile and portable electronic devices, the use of mobile and portable WPT devices has become increasingly widespread. However, the electromagnetic radiation generated during their operation may interfere with broadcast service, affect the normal reception of broadcast signals, and restrict the coordinated development of the two technologies. Therefore, conducting research on the coexistence of interference between the two is of great practical significance. This article mainly conducts compatibility coexistence research on mobile and portable WPT devices and broadcast service.

title: Beyond Matching: An LLM-Based Diagnose of SDG Misalignment in University Curriculum
authors: Zheru Dong, Wensi Jiang, Lili Dai, Omar Hussain, Yu Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Higher education institutions (HEIs) face increasing scrutiny to document how their curricula advance the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Existing semantic matching approaches successfully label about 75 percent of courses but leave persistent unlabelled units and provide no guidance for remediation. This study addresses the critical diagnostic gap in SDG curricular alignment by introducing a novel large language model-based (LLM-based) framework that transforms unmatched courses into actionable sustainability insights. Leveraging GPT-4, the proposed diagnostic framework identifies reasons for misalignment, offers targeted revision recommendations, and suggests actionable SDG mappings for each course. It integrates a dynamic, evolving codebook that systematically categorises the reasons for SDG misalignment and informs strategic curriculum development. Analysing 749 unlabelled courses from an Australian university, the framework reduced the unlabelled courses to under two percent and identified disciplinary blind spots, particularly in engineering and business. In addition, the study found that nearly half of the courses lacked explicit societal or environmental dimensions, while many others were too general for effective alignment. Furthermore, the framework recommended SDG matches, revealing substantial latent alignment potential. The framework not only improves explainable AI in education by producing transparent, audit-ready outputs, but also enables school-level dashboards for targeted SDG forecasting. The proposed framework operates in a fully automated workflow with an optional expert validation step to support audit-readiness, and is designed for institutional scalability and potential cross-institutional adoption.

title: Estimation of Phase-Shift in Phase-Shifting Digital Holography Using Checkerboard Diffraction Grating
authors: T. Maeda, S. Yanase, H. Sotobayashi, K. Akahane
abstract: Single-shot phase imaging was experimentally demonstrated using a checkerboard grating by estimating the phase shift that varies depending on the grating position using the designed markers. The estimated shifts enabled accurate phase reconstruction, validating the method feasibility under practical conditions without precise optical alignment.

title: A Low-Redundancy Programmable Optical Delay Line Network Based on Dynamic Allocation of Optical Delay Resources
authors: Ting Lyu, Shaofu Xu, Bo Li, Ruicheng Qiu, Yixi Liu, Weiwen Zou
abstract: We present a programmable optical delay line network that enables inter-channel delay reuse via dynamic allocation and optical switch scheduling, doubling the maximum inter-channel delay difference and reducing delay line count compared to cascade architectures, and enabling efficient beamforming, microwave photonic processing, and quantum circuits.

title: Reflective Metalens Architecture for Broadband Achromatic Performance in the LWIR Range
authors: Sani Mukhtar, Jaime Viegas
abstract: We present the design of broadband reflective metalens for 9.6-11.6 μm using ZnSe nanopillars on a Ge/ZnSe DBR. Dispersion-engineered design enables diffractionlimited focusing with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<7 \%$</tex> focal length variation and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 73 \%$</tex> average efficiency. Chromatic correction is analytically embedded, enabling scalable, high-NA infrared optics without global optimization.

title: Ultraviolet Micro-Light-Emitting Diodes for Satellite Quantum Key Distribution
authors: J.J.D. McKendry, J. Gray, J. Hill, E. Xie, H. Willett, J. Sagar, C. Jones, S. Joshi, J.G. Rarity, D.K.L. Oi, J. Herrnsdorf
abstract: We report progress in the integration of micro-lightemitting diodes as compact, low-power, robust transmitters for satellite-based quantum key distribution.

title: A Broadband Circularly Polarized Phased Array with Wide-Angle Scanning Capability for Telemetry Communication
authors: Qi Yu, Jianmin Zhang, Hairong Deng, Qing Zhang, Yingsong Li, Luyu Zhao, Adrian Bekasiewicz
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this work, a broadband circularly polarized phased array designed for telemetry applications is presented. To ensure broad frequency range and polarization stability in C-band—both required for transmission of telemetry data—the structure incorporates a probe-coupled feed and slots within the radiating patch. The relative bandwidth of optimized topology is 29.8% (i.e., from 4.85 GHz to 6.55 GHz). The proposed array adopts a 4 × 4 layout with rotational feeding which ensures high directivity and low cross-polarization. Simulation results demonstrate that the structure offers a wide beam steering of ±60° with a stable axial ratio maintained below the 3 dB level. Owing to compact, planar architecture, broadband circular polarization, and flexible scanning ranges the proposed topology is well-suited for supporting multi-angle dynamic communication scenarios imposed by modern telemetry systems.
