title: Dual-Mode Control Switching Strategy of Converter Based on Non-Intrusive Impedance Recognition
authors: Han Jiang, Zhenguo Liu, Xinwei Li, Kai Ma, Wang Jinyu, Chengbo Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: With the development of distributed generation system, the system equivalent impedance fluctuates over a wide range, leading to significant changes in grid strength. The interactive coupling between the phase-locked loop and the grid impedance causes the grid-following (GFL) control converter to easily lose synchronization with the grid. The grid-forming (GFM) control can improve the grid-tied stability under weak grid, but it is easy to destabilize under strong grid. A dual-mode adaptive switching strategy based on non-intrusive sensing is proposed. First, the least squares method is used to realize the non-intrusive impedance identification and calculate the short circuit ratio (SCR). Then, the adaptive switching between the GFL and the GFM modes is realized according to SCR. This strategy enhances the stability of the grid-tied converter when the grid strength varies over a wide range. Finally, simulation verifies the effectiveness of the proposal.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Soliton Generation in Micro-Ring Resonators
authors: Viswanathan Sankar, Christophe Peucheret, Darko Zibar
abstract: We numerically demonstrate a reinforcement learning framework that autonomously adjusts detuning in microring resonators. By leveraging spectral feedback, our approach efficiently navigates the bistability curve, achieving stable soliton formation and pointing toward automated, model-free microcomb control.

title: Large Language Models for Disease Diagnosis using Symptom-Based Dataset: Exploring Reasoning and Non-Reasoning
authors: Robert Wiliam, Jessica Ryan, Alexander Ivan Gumilang, Derwin Suhartono
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Diagnostic errors are a major global health challenge that demonstrates the need for better clinical decision support. The emergence of Large Language Models (LLMs), with their powerful natural language processing capabilities, provides a novel opportunity to mitigate this global challenge. This study aims to quantitatively assess and compare the diagnostic capabilities of various LLMs on a symptom-based disease classification task. We compare models based on their architecture (reasoning vs non-reasoning), and the impact of enhancement strategies such as Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) and Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT). Using the CoD-PatientSymDisease dataset, we examined a sample of open-source and API-accessed models. Our result shows a positive correlation between model size with its diagnostic performance. Evidence also shows that for symptom-based diagnostic tasks, non-reasoning models outperform their reasoning model counterparts. For example, GPT-4.1 accessible via the API had the highest precision using RAG (62.75% accuracy and 56.90% F1 score). Other open-source models such as LlAma-3.1 8B and Qwen-3 Non-Think 8B also showed competitive performance, especially when enhanced with SFT. Using SFT on the language model also generally increases its diagnostic performance, which bodes well for the adaptability of LLMs to specific domains. Overall, our findings suggest that in a practical symptom-based diagnostic context, adaptive techniques, such as fine-tuning, produce better results than reasoning alone, which suggests the benefit of domain-based contextual training for AI diagnostic support products. These insights highlight the importance of domain-specific adaptation in AI rather than relying solely on complex reasoning architectures.

title: Coherent Optical Sensor for Contactless Eye Movement Measurement in REM-Sleep Analysis
authors: M. Schmidt, S. Ernst, M. Berking, C. Carlowitz
abstract: We demonstrate a novel precise contactless eye movement sensor for REM sleep analysis enabled through coherent optical reflectometry. Our experiments show that the closed eyelid surface micro-movement can be tracked from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 m}$</tex> distance with an eye-safe low optical output power of 0.2 mW.

title: Emotion Classification on Customer Reviews of Drinking Water Services Using IndoBERT and Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: I Nyoman Yoga Sumadewa, Anthony Anggrawan, Hairani Hairani, I Putu Hariyadi, Christofer Satria, Dian Syafitri Chani Saputri
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Improving service quality has become a major focus for public service providers, including in the drinking water sector. Customer reviews reflect both satisfaction and direct experiences. This study aims to detect emotions in customer reviews using the IndoBERT model and compare its performance with other machine learning algorithms, such as Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Random Forest. The study follows an experimental method by applying different models to a dataset of customer reviews to evaluate and compare their performance in emotion classification. The dataset consists of 63521 customer reviews categorized into five emotion labels: "satisfied," "disappointed," "angry," "urgent," and "neutral." The analysis involves data preprocessing, tokenization using IndoBERT, feature extraction through word embeddings, and classification using machine learning algorithms. Model evaluation is based on accuracy and F1-score. The results show that IndoBERT combined with Logistic Regression and SVM performs best, reaching an accuracy of 89.08%, while Random Forest achieves only 77.91%. The study concludes that IndoBERT is an effective approach for emotion detection in customer reviews and holds strong potential to support more targeted improvements in PT Air Minum Giri Menang’s service quality and response.

title: Calibration-Free Vision-Guided Localization Method for Refueling Robots Using Adaptive Kalman Filter
authors: Xia Dong, Siqi Jiang, Yuwang Yang, Kedian Wang, Haibo Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: To address the localization challenges arising from arbitrary stopping poses of refueling vehicles, this paper introduces a calibration-free vision-guided method based on adaptive Kalman filter. First, it establishes a vision-guided localization framework using a calibrated camera perspective model. Then, an adaptive Kalman filtering algorithm is incorporated to eliminate calibration dependencies, enhancing the system's flexibility and robustness. After validating the method through MATLAB simulation, we construct an experimental refueling robot platform. Experimental results demonstrate the localization error of end-effector less than 2 mm, meeting the precision requirements for automatic refueling processes. This research provides a novel approach to precise guidance for random vehicle poses.

title: Differentiable Function-Based Control for Multi-Robot Systems in Pursuit-Evasion Games
authors: Zhaoming Zhang, Long Zhang, Xinxin Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: This paper investigates pursuit-evasion games in the context of multi-player differential games, focusing on the problem of N pursuers versus M evaders. By employing differentiable distance approximation functions, strategies for both pursuers and evaders are derived. Differentiable approximation functions are utilized to approximate the performance index functions for both sides. Evasion and pursuit strategies are formulated based on these approximations, and a control method is proposed to enable the robots to execute the strategies accurately. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategies, showing that all evaders are eventually captured by the pursuers.

title: $300 \text{Tb} / \mathrm{s} \mathrm{O}+\mathrm{S}+\mathrm{C}+\mathrm{L}$-Band Deployed Fibre Transmission
authors: Jiaqian Yang, Romulo Aparecido, Eric Sillekens, Mindaugas Jarmolovičius, Ruben S. Luís, Zelin Gan, Ronit Sohanpal, Vitaly Mikhailov, Jiawei Luo, David J. DiGiovanni, Polina Bayvel, Robert I. Killey
abstract: We demonstrate a record WDM transmission throughput of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$300.28 ~\text{Tb} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> GMI (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$275.82 ~\text{Tb} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> decoded) over 39 km of field-deployed fibre using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30.4 \text{THz} \mathrm{O}+\mathrm{S}+\mathrm{C}+\mathrm{L}$</tex>-band signals. This represents a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 50 \%$</tex> improvement over previous SCL-band transmission while maintaining the same total launch power (20 dBm) using only doped fibre amplifiers.

title: Stokes Skyrmion in Few-Mode Fibers
authors: Zekun Shi, Yan-Ge Liu
abstract: This work establishes a novel platform for topological optical fields by demonstrating the tunable generation of Stokes skyrmions in actual few-mode fibers used for modedivision multiplexing, with fiber lengths reaching up to 60 meters.

title: Dual-Circularly Polarized Wearable Array Antenna Based on A Dual-Port Rotational Feeding Network
authors: Wenfei Tang, Xiang Gao, Kun Guo, Yuesong Ding, Xiangyuan Bu, Jianping An
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper presents a dual-circularly polarized 2×2-array antenna with a dual-port sequential rotational feeding network for wearable applications. The antenna utilizes dual-feed patch elements arranged in a 2×2 sequential rotation array fed via a dual-channel feeding network. Dynamic switching between the left-hand circular polarization (LHCP) and right-hand circular polarization (RHCP) is achieved by selectively exciting different ports of the dual-channel feeding network. Results demonstrate that the antenna operates stably across a frequency band ranging from 2.33 GHz to 2.39 GHz, with a 3-dB axial ratio bandwidth spanning 2.375 GHz to 2.395 GHz. The peak gains for the LHCP and RHCP operating states are 9.01 dBi and 9.24 dBi, respectively.

title: Multienergy cooperative scheduling method for virtual power plants based on reinforcement learning
authors: Fulin Zhao, Xinyu Li, Wei Dai, Chenghan Fan, Ze Lin, Renhao Liu, Kaihan Guo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of traditional manual scheduling strategies for virtual power plants (VPPs), such as slow response, poor adaptability to dynamic markets, poor renewable energy accommodation, unordered EV charging, and lack of multienergy synergy, this paper proposes a multienergy cooperative scheduling method based on reinforcement learning (RL). It constructs a "source-load-storage-grid" multi-dimensional state space, divides discrete action spaces for energy storage and EVs, designs a multi-dimensional reward function, and adopts the DQN model to realize closed-loop scheduling. Results show the strategy generation time is shortened to 5 minutes, profits rise by 15%-20%, balancing economy and user experience.

title: Research on Simulation and Optimization Design of High-Frequency Transformers for LLC Resonant Converters
authors: Min Shen, Yanling Wang, Xiumin Li, Wenjing Zhao, Shen Gjin Guo, Jian Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: To enhance the power density and conversion efficiency of LLC resonant converters, this paper conducts refined simulation and optimization design research on their high-frequency transformers. By analyzing the operating modes of the LLC circuit, a multi-physics field coupling model that comprehensively considers the high-frequency eddy current effect of windings and the nonlinear characteristics of the magnetic core is established, accurately quantifying the transformer loss distribution and temperature rise characteristics. The performance of EE and EI type magnetic cores is compared, and it is found that the EE type has advantages in efficiency, loss control, and leakage suppression. The influence mechanism of air gap layout on winding loss is deeply analyzed, indicating that the optimization effect is significant when the longitudinal avoidance distance is approximately three times the air gap. By collaboratively optimizing parameters such as magnetic core materials, winding structure, and turn ratio, the final design scheme effectively controls the volume and temperature rise of magnetic components while ensuring electrical performance, achieving a balance between efficiency, volume, and thermal management. This provides an important theoretical basis and practical reference for the development of high power density LLC converters.

title: Millimeter-wave Low-loss GaAs Bandpass Filter
authors: Chao Ma, Yinzhi Wang, Guohui Yang, Kuang Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The millimeter-wave filters fabricated using the GaAs IPD (Integrated Passive Device) process offer advantages such as low-loss, compact size, easy integration, high manufacturing precision, and suitability for mass production. Based on this technology, this paper utilizes full-wave simulation software to design a microstrip interdigitated bandpass filter with a passband ranging from 33GHz to 37GHz. The center frequency is set at 35.15GHz, featuring a 1dB difference passband spanning 32.60GHz to 37.71GHz and a maximum insertion loss of 1.97dB. Within the 32.68GHz to 36.91GHz frequency range, the return loss meets the requirement of being better than 15dB. Band-stop suppression reaches 37.2dB and 37.5dB at 28GHz and 42GHz respectively. The voltage standing wave ratio remains below 1.5 between 32.66GHz and 37.06GHz. The group delay peaks at the passband edges, measuring 0.37ns, indicating excellent linearity in the filter's phase response. These characteristics demonstrate that the filter has practical application value.

title: Edge Computing-Based Waste Sorting Robot Using Convolutional Neural Network and Raspberry Pi
authors: Nenny Anggraini, Aulia Nisa Agus Setiana, Nashrul Hakiem, Muhammad Arif Suwari, Luh Kesuma Wardhani, Nadya Kharima
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Waste management at the Faculty of Science and Technology, UIN Syarif Hidayatullah Jakarta, faces challenges such as odor and increased waste volume, particularly during student orientation events. Manual sorting is considered ineffective by 74.4% of respondents. This study proposes a smart waste sorting robot using artificial intelligence, embedded systems, and sensors to automate classification. A key novelty lies in the implementation of edge computing, where a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model is deployed directly on a Raspberry Pi, enabling real-time, offline waste classification without cloud dependency. This approach offers low latency and high system autonomy, making it suitable for limited-connectivity environments. The development process includes data collection, prototype design, model training using MobileNet in Google Colab, and deployment on Raspberry Pi. Testing results show that the CNN model achieved a 90.53% validation accuracy and the robot reached an 85% user acceptance rate. This research supports green campus initiatives and demonstrates the potential of edge AI in improving waste management and environmental education on campus.

title: A Miniaturized Bandpass Frequency Selective Surface Based On Liquid Crystal
authors: Jian-Feng Lv, Ming Gu, Li-Sheng Liu, Fan-Yi Meng, Chang Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this article, a design method for tunable liquid crystal (LC)-based frequency selective surface (FSS) with miniaturization unit cell and wide tuning range is proposed. A miniaturized LC-based FSS unit cell with a dimension of 0.1 λ × 0.1 λ is designed based on a pair of planar metallic structures with two large parallel patches, U-shaped strip, L-shaped strip, and two straight lines, which can provide inductances and a large capacitance. The LC material is sandwiched between parallel patches, and a large capacitance achieves tunability. The numerical simulation results show that the operating frequency of the FSS is tuned from 11.87 GHz to 12.96 GHz. Moreover, the structure achieves bandpass frequency responses under various incident angles from 0° to 70° for arbitrary LC states.

title: Deep Learning to Recognize Book Titles: Leveraging the Front Image Feature
authors: Erwin Rommel, Michael Christopher Yuvi, Kenzie Timothy Ebenezer, Abdul Harris Rangkuti
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Manual book management in libraries often results in inefficiencies, delays, and human errors that negatively affect service quality and inventory accuracy. This study proposes an automated book cover recognition system using deep learning methods to recognize book covers such as computer vision techniques. By researching methods such as the You Only Look Once (YOLO) object detection models, to address these issues. Five YOLO versions (v8 to v12) were trained and evaluated on a curated dataset of book covers, annotated and processed according to standard object detection workflows. Performance was assessed using precision, recall, mean Average Precision (mAP), and confusion matrix analysis. Experimental results show that YOLOv10 outperformed other versions by achieving the best balance between detection accuracy and coverage, with the highest precision (0.7273) and strong recall (0.6953). Confusion matrix analysis revealed that all models effectively identified visually distinctive genres, while struggling with categories that have overlapping or subtle features. The findings highlight that model selection must be empirically validated, as newer versions do not always yield superior results. This work provides a benchmark for deploying AI-based book recognition systems and lays the groundwork for future multimodal approaches integrating both image and text features.

title: Evolutionary Algorithm Behavior to Optimize the IoT Scheduling Problem
authors: Muhammad Abid Jamil
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: The number of linked devices has increased exponentially as a result of the Internet of Things (IoT), producing enormous volumes of data that need to be processed using effective scheduling techniques. The dynamic and varied nature of IoT environments is frequently too much for traditional scheduling techniques to handle. With a focus on multi-objective optimization to balance conflicting goals including makespan, energy consumption, and resource utilization, this study investigates the use of evolutionary algorithms (EAs) to solve the IoT scheduling problem. Our performance is assessed through comprehensive tests, and we present a multi-objective evolutionary method based on the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic method II (NSGA-II) as compared to Particle Swarm optimization (PSO) and Multiobjective Particle Swarm optimization (MOPSO). The outcomes show that EAs have the potential to improve IoT scheduling efficiency by offering notable improvements over conventional scheduling techniques. The proposed algorithm achieves 16.7 % reduction in makespan, 16.7 % decrease in energy consumption, and 13.3 % improvement in resource utilization compared to traditional method.

title: Design of Skewed CMOS Ring Oscillators with Controlled Frequency for On-Chip Clock Generation
authors: Srilakshmi Badri Seshadri, Yashovardhan Jaydeep Gaikwad, Parth Nandan Shetiya, Arjun Sunil Rao, Basavaraj S Sannakashappanavar, S. Senthil Kumar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: This work aims to study the effect of variation in aspect ratio <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(W_{p} / W_{n}\right)$</tex> on the frequency of ring oscillator waveforms with constant gate size. Ring oscillator is designed using 11 identical NOT gates with different skews (downskewed, balanced, upskewed) cascaded in series with a feedback loop. The simulations are conducted in Cadence Virtuoso EDA tool using gpdk90 technology. Five ring oscillator circuits are designed each using 11 identical NOT gates with aspect ratios <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1: 3,1: 2,1: 1,2: 1$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3: 1$</tex> corresponding to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$W_{p} / W_{n}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.33,0.5,1$</tex>, 2, and 3, respectively, cascaded in series with a feedback loop. The five ring oscillator circuits are named <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R O}_{1: 3}, \mathbf{R O}_{1: 2}, \mathbf{R O}_{1: 1}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R O}_{2: 1}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R O}_{3: 1}$</tex>, with sub-script representing the aspect ratio <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{p}} / \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{n}}\right)$</tex> of the NOT gates used. Ring oscillators <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{RO}_{1: 3}, \text{RO}_{1: 2}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{RO}_{1: 1}$</tex> are downskewed, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{RO}_{2: 1}$</tex> is balanced skewed, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{RO}_{3: 1}$</tex> is upskewed. Our results show that <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R O}_{1: 3}, \mathbf{R O}_{1: 2}, \mathbf{R O}_{1: 1}, \mathbf{R O}_{2: 1}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{RO}_{3: 1}$</tex> produced a square waveform with frequencies 43.73 MHz, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$58.51 \text{MHz}, 68.15 \text{MHz}, 76.87 \text{MHz}$</tex>, and 63.68 MHz, respectively. This shows that the aspect ratio has significant effect on the frequency of ring oscillator, and the idea of the aspect ratio can be used to design clock generator or Schmitt trigger circuits to produce square waves with desirable frequencies.

title: Full-Chip Afterpulsing Behavior in a SWIR SPAD Array
authors: Chi-En Chen, Shih-Min Huang, Pi-Ju Cheng, Ming-Chieh Hsu, Tzu-Jui Wang, Jau-Yang Wu, Chao-Hsin Wu
abstract: We first present the afterpulsing characterization of a full-chip, room-temperature-operated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 6 0} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{1 1 6 ~ G e}$</tex>-on-Si pixel short-wave infrared single-photon avalanche diode array, revealing significant pixel-to-pixel variation. These results highlight the importance of full chip afterpulsing evaluation in determining optimal operating conditions.

title: A Koopman-based interactive learning method for sea surface temperature prediction
authors: Peihao Yang, Zhuozhao Chen, Zhentao Li
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Accurate prediction of sea surface temperature (SST) is essential for marine economic development, early warning of extreme climate events, and ocean resource management. However, the non-stationarity and nonlinear dynamics of oceanic meteorological data pose significant challenges for prediction. This study proposes a Sampling-based Koopman Interactive Model (SKIM), which integrates Koopman theory to improve SST prediction through interactive feature extraction and linearized modeling. SKIM first employs a downsampling interaction structure to enhance the capture of multi-scale features and to improve the efficiency of temporal representation. Then, a Fourier filter is applied to decompose the complex non-stationary time series into linear and nonlinear components, which are further analyzed by the Koopman operator to enhance the model’s generalization ability. We conducted experiments on real-world datasets from the South China Sea and the Bohai Sea. The results show that SKIM significantly outperforms traditional machine learning methods (RF, SVR) and deep learning models (ConLSTM, TCN, SCINet), achieving the lowest prediction error and the highest accuracy in spatial distribution prediction.

title: A Study of PMBLDC Motors with a Focus on Electric Traction, Analytical and FEM Analysis
authors: G. R. Bruzinga, A. J. Sguarezi Filho, A. Pelizari, U. Prones
abstract: This article proposes an analytical-numerical methodology for designing PMBLDC motors with a focus on electric scooter traction. The analytical calculation was prepared to ensure that the geometric parameters of the stator, rotor, characterisation of the windings, selection of permanent magnets, and calculation of losses were obtained from nominal data and remained within the limits of the vehicle wheel. For validation purposes, nominal data from an existing motor were applied to the analytical method, the resulting geometric parameters were compared to those of the existing motor, and variations of about 1% were observed. As a next step, three simulations were performed using Finite Element Method software, two in 2D, static and stationary (steady state), and one in 3D transient. The simulation results showed that the nominal data were achieved, with variations of up to 3% for mechanical power and 2% for shaft torque. The temperatures obtained showed that there was no damage to the permanent magnet (63°C) or the stator’s enamelled conductors (107°C), while the flux density presented values within the expected range for the air gap and there was no saturation in the core. These results demonstrated the analytical method’s ability to dimension the motor.

title: Enhanced Traveling Wave Stability in MEMS Motor via Mode Self-Compensation
authors: Tianyu Yang, Kaisheng Zhang, Xiaoshi Li, Yu Chen, Xiangyu Sun, Wei Su
abstract: Microelectromechanical system (MEMS) traveling wave ultrasonic motors (TWUMs) are prone to frequency drift and performance degradation due to fabrication imperfections, long-term wear, and residual stress release. These issues distort the traveling wave’s modal shape, compromising load capacity and reducing device lifespan. This study proposes an embedded sensor-based modal shape detection and self-compensation control scheme to address these challenges. By leveraging the direct and inverse piezoelectric effects, the system enables real-time monitoring and active adjustment of the modal response. A feedback sensor array was designed and validated through simulation, followed by the development of an equivalent resonant model and a self-compensation control algorithm. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method accurately tracks modal deformation and dynamically adjusts driving parameters to counteract modal drift caused by preload variations and stress relaxation. After prolonged storage conditions, this approach significantly enhances motor performance, increasing output torque from 7.6 μNm to 19.3 μNm, rotational speed from 5,268 rpm to 11,865 rpm, and reducing rotational fluctuation from 45% to 12.4%.

title: BONDS Protocol: A Blockchain-Based Optimized N-Step N-Party Digital Contract Signing Protocol
authors: Rosa Pericàs Gornals, Macià Mut-Puigserver, M. Magdalena Payeras-Capellà, Jaume Ramis-Bibiloni, Joan Camps-Tomàs
abstract: Electronic contract signing has revolutionized theway agreements are formed across individuals, institutions, and governments, offering speed, security, and global accessibility. Despite these advances, multiparty agreements remain a challenge due to the complexity of ensuring fairness, efficiency, and trust among all participants. However, as these agreements increasingly involve multiple participants, the need for efficient and secure multiparty digital contract signing protocols has become critical. This paper addresses this gap by introducing BONDS, a blockchain-based protocol designed for optimized digital contract signing among N parties. Unlike existing synchronous multiparty protocols that require a minimum of 3(N-1)steps, BONDS achieves contract finalization in just N steps—reaching the theoretical optimum without relying on any Trusted Third Party (TTP). Our methodology leverages blockchain technology and the use of smart contracts to ensure fairness and non-repudiation. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that BONDS reduces communication overhead compared to leading alternatives, while maintaining robust security guarantees. These results propose BONDS as a scalable and efficient solution for secure multi-party contract signing in decentralized environments.

title: Physics-Informed Deep Learning for Traffic State Estimation on Freeways: A Comprehensive Comparative Study
authors: Hongxin Yu, Yibing Wang, Fengyue Jin, Claudio Roncoli, Mingming Zhao, Pengjun Zheng, Jingqiu Guo, Lihui Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Traffic state estimation (TSE) lays the foundation for freeway traffic monitoring and control. This paper develops a novel freeway traffic state estimator based on physics-informed deep learning (PIDL), whereby the deep-learning neural network is guided with physical laws of traffic. The innovative features of this work are as follows. In the data-driven aspect, the representation capability of neural networks is enhanced by introducing a nonlinear expansion layer, an attention mechanism, and a point-weighting mechanism. In traffic flow modeling aspect, a neural network is designed for the adaptive identification of model parameters. Additionally, a ramp flow self-learning neural network is constructed in consideration of system observability. This study employs four macroscopic traffic flow models LWR, ARZ, JWZ and PW to design PIDL-based traffic state estimators. Field-data evaluations and comparative analyses are conducted with respect to an urban expressway of 17.5 km. The results show that the designed PIDL traffic state estimators are able to simultaneously achieve traffic state estimation, ramp flow estimation, and adaptive identification of model parameters. The PIDL estimators outperform a number of baseline estimators, and are least sensitive to the number of input sensors and missing data. It is also discovered that the effectiveness of PIDL hinges on the appropriate tuning of the imbedded physical model as well as accurate boundary condition inputs, and failure to meet these requirements may lead to performance degradation.

title: UAV Trajectory Optimization Based on Pointer Networks and Adaptive Region Partitioning
authors: Zhiqi Guo, Fengxiao Tang, Tiao Tan, Linfeng Luo, Ming Zhao
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), characterized by their agility, affordability, and flexible deployment, exhibit significant advantages in scenarios such as disaster monitoring, target tracking, and environmental data collection. However, the limited onboard energy of UAVs poses a major challenge for long-duration or large-scale missions. To address this issue, this paper proposes a dynamic trajectory planning framework for cooperative task search involving multiple UAVs. First, a UAV capability evaluation approach is developed to assess the relative performance of heterogeneous UAVs. Next, a density-aware clustering mechanism is employed to partition the search region based on spatial distance and regional density. After clustering, a sequential matching strategy is employed to assign UAVs with higher capabilities to larger or more complex task regions, ensuring efficient resource utilization. The problem is then formulated as a combinatorial optimization task, and a pointer network is designed to generate UAV trajectories. The network is trained using deep reinforcement learning to produce near-optimal paths, thereby minimizing the overall system cost. Experimental results confirm that the proposed method can substantially lower total task execution expenditure.

title: Deep Self-Reinforced Multi-View Subspace Clustering for Cancer Subtyping
authors: Cheng Liu, Baoyuan Zheng, Jiaojiao Wang, Xibiao Wang, Hang Gao, Fei Wang, Wenjun Shen, Si Wu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Identifying cancer subtypes is crucial for understanding disease progression and guiding precision medicine. With advances in high-throughput experimental technologies, the integration of multiple types of omics data for cancer subtype identification has become increasingly feasible. However, despite the promising performance of existing integrative cancer subtyping methods, efficiently integrating and clustering multi-omics datasets remains challenging due to the high levels of noise inherent in omics data, which impede the accurate characterization of relationships among samples. To address these challenges, we propose a novel deep multi-view subspace clustering model that incorporates a self-reinforced learning strategy. This strategy iteratively improves the quality of self-representation, which is critical for accurately capturing sample relationships and enabling effective clustering. Specifically, during model training, the proposed method learns a highly reliable self-representation through a good-neighbor learning mechanism, allowing it to model more accurate and robust inter-sample relationships. Building upon this reliable self-representation, we further develop a learnable view-graph fusion framework that integrates complementary information across multiple omics views to derive a consensus representation for clustering, thereby guiding the overall learning process. In addition, we introduce a local graph-guided learning mechanism based on an initial graph constructed from the raw data. This mechanism serves as an effective regularization strategy to prevent the model from converging to suboptimal solutions, thereby enhancing stability and robustness during training. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms several state-of-the-art approaches, validating its effectiveness and robustness for cancer subtype identification.

title: Highly Efficient and Cost-Effective Soft-Switched Quasi-Single-Stage AC-DC Resonant Converter for EV Charging Applications
authors: Kamran Zeb, Waqar Uddin, Mohammad A. Abido, Muhammad Khalid
abstract: This research proposes a novel current-fed quasi-single-stage AC-DC resonant converter with regulated output voltage, extreme simplicity and compact component size, reduced switching losses, and almost unity power factor for electric vehicle (EV) charging. A Four-Quadrant Controlled Switch (FQCS) is employed between the voltage doubler circuit and the resonant inductor on the secondary side of the converter to accomplish these objectives. The presence of the FQCS switch sets the duty ratio of the primary side switches at 50%, hence accomplishes zero-voltage switching (ZVS), inherent power factor capability, and reduced size of DC-link capacitor. The duty D of the FQCS is used to regulate the other parameters, such as output voltage control and power factor correction. Moreover, all switches are either ZVS turned on or ZCS turned off at 50 kHz due to the converter’s resonance operation and fixed duty operation. Therefore, incurs very little switching loss with high efficiency and power density. The converter’s operational concept is presented alongside its design methodology. A 1.2 kW prototype was designed and tested to demonstrate the viability of this approach. The converter has achieved an efficiency of 96.4%, a power factor of 0.995, and regulated the output voltage to 400 V.

title: Domain adaptation and data augmentation to improve the diversity and realism of geophysical datasets for deep learning
authors: Zichen Liu, Xinming Wu, You Li, Yimin Dou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Recent advancements in deep learning have high-lighted its significant potential in geophysics. However, a major challenge in practical applications is the limited availability of comprehensive and diverse datasets. To address this, synthetic datasets have been developed. However, their inherent limitations in quality and diversity prevent deep learning models from effectively generalizing from synthetic to field data. This often results in overfitting and hinders the accurate learning of geophysical patterns. To tackle these challenges, we propose a comprehensive strategy to enhance the generalization capabilities of deep learning models, incorporating domain adaptation and data augmentation techniques. First, we introduce a domain adaptation method that adjusts the amplitude spectrum of the data in the frequency domain, generating synthetic samples that closely resemble field data. Additionally, we employ various data augmentation techniques to further enrich the diversity of the data. By improving both the realism and diversity of synthetic data, convolutional neural networks trained on these augmented datasets can effectively mitigate overfitting and enhance generalization, leading to more accurate feature identification in field data. We validated our strategy in geophysical tasks such as fault identification and channel detection. Experimental results demonstrate that our strategy significantly improves the models’ performance on both synthetic and field datasets.

title: A Neurodynamic Solution to Mobile Robot Navigation and Obstacle Avoidance Formulated as Time-Varying Convex Optimization_supp1-3621663.mp4
authors: Weibing Li
abstract: Obstacle avoidance (OA) is a critical safety challenge in mobile robot navigation, particularly in unstructured environments. In this article, the navigation task is formulated as a time-varying convex optimization (TVCO), with OA incorporated as inequality constraints. Accordingly, an error-dynamics-based neurodynamic network (EDNN) utilizing a nonlinear complementarity problem (NCP) function, referred to as the NCP-EDNN solver, is developed to solve TVCO problems accurately. It is worth mentioning that this is the first application of NCP-EDNN to mobile robot navigation with OA. For comparison, the NCP-EDNN solver, the interior-point method (IPM) based on a barrier function, and typical iterative QP solvers are applied to a same TVCO problem and a same robot navigation task. Comparative results demonstrate that the NCP-EDNN solver obtains more accurate solutions compared to the IPM solver, avoids the risk of solution failures, and delivers faster computation compared to representative iterative QP solvers. Its effectiveness is further validated through high-fidelity Gazebo simulations and real-world experiments with an IR-C100 mobile robot, demonstrating the practical applicability and physical feasibility.

title: Words Strip Wardrobe: Learning Invariant Textual Prompts for Cloth-Changing Person Re-Identification
authors: Bingliang Jiao, Liying Gao, Feiyue Zhao, Dapeng Oliver Wu, Wenxuan Wang, Peng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Cloth-changing person re-identification (CC-ReID) aims to match individuals wearing varying clothes across camera views. Existing CC-ReID methods typically focus on extracting clothing-invariant features such as body shape, pose, gait, etc. However, these features are diverse and often entangled with clothing-related visual clues, posing significant challenges for comprehensively and effectively separating and leveraging them for re-identification. To address these challenges, we propose a text-guided clothing generalizable (Tex-CG) model, which employs multi-modal large language models (MLLMs) to comprehensively and explicitly decouple clothing-invariant features from pedestrian images in the textual domain. By shifting feature disentanglement to the textual domain, the interference caused by visual entanglement between clothing and clothing-invariant clues can be significantly reduced. Additionally, to ensure compatibility between offline-decoupled features from MLLMs and our online-trained Tex-CG model, we utilize CLIP-based image-text matching to train implicit clothing-invariant prompts that embed discriminative pedestrian information. A dynamic fusion module is subsequently introduced to leverage these implicit prompts for selectively integrating valuable and compatible components from the MLLM’s explicitly decoupled features, constructing robust guidance to direct our model to effectively capture clothing-invariant visual clues for re-identification. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our method, and the Tex-CG model achieves state-of-the-art performance on five mainstream CC-ReID benchmarks. Our code is available at https://github.com/JiaoBL1234/Tex-CG.
