title: A Unified Framework for Document-Level Translation and Repair With Global Awareness
authors: Xinglin Lyu, Junhui Li, Mengxin Ren, Xiang Geng, Daimeng Wei, Min Zhang, Shimin Tao, Hao Yang, Min Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Most studies in document-level neural machine translation (DNMT) use either the source-to-target Translation framework or the target-to-target Repair to model the unilateral (source-side or pseudo-target-side) inter-sentence context. Besides, the autoregressive decoder of Translation or Repair accommodates inter-sentence context to local decoding context only. In this paper, we consider both the inter-sentence contexts and global decoding context in a unified DNMT framework. Specifically, we consider the various inter-sentence contexts via the Fusing Attention and the Gating Mechanism modules in the unified model. Meanwhile, we accommodate the extracted inter-sentence context to the global decoding context by jointly training the unified model with a conditional masked language model (CMLM). Furthermore, by employing CMLM as a teacher, we incorporate bidirectional global information into the unified model for target words with low prediction confidence through knowledge distillation. We verify the proposed approach on several popular datasets in the DNMT community, covering Chinese $\rightarrow$ English and English $\rightarrow$ German translation tasks. Experimental results on both BLEU score and discourse-related metrics suggest: 1) Unifying Translation and Repair is a more effective approach to modeling inter-sentence context, and 2) bidirectional global context is necessary for facilitating better modeling of inter-sentence context and alleviating of discourse issues.

title: Modeling and Control For Minimally Invasive Intracerebral Hemorrhage Evacuation
authors: Anthony L. Gunderman, Satya A. Velumuri, Saikat Sengupta, Dimitri Sigounas, Kevin Cleary, Yue Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a severe type of hemorrhagic stroke that causes nearly 3 million deaths annually. Recent studies have indicated minimally invasive surgery (MIS) can improve functional outcomes in patients with lobar ICH. However, despite these promising results, challenges persist, including tool dexterity and visualization. Our group has been developing a concentric tube robot (CTR) for MR-guided ICH evacuation to address these concerns. We have demonstrated feasibility in prior ex vivo studies. However, to improve clot evacuation, better control strategies, such as closed-loop evacuation control, are needed. In this short paper, we present a modeling strategy for hybrid pneumatic-hydraulic closed-loop evacuation control that is suitable for use in the MR-environment, which requires long pneumatic (for vacuum canister regulation) and hydraulic (for hematoma evacuation) transmission lines. The control strategy is evaluated in a bench-top setting using our CTR and evacuation system. The CTR is used to evacuate an artificial hematoma at volumetric flow rates ranging from 2.5 cm3min to 10 cm3min. Notably, prior to steady-state, the system exhibits a mean evacuation volumetric flow rate error of 0.533 cm3min and a steady-state mean error of 0.229 cm3min.

title: An Improved Open Resonator for Complex Permittivity Measurement in 0.11~0.5THz under Microwave Field Loading
authors: Jin Cheng, Xiangbao Zhu, Yong Gao, Chengyong Yu, En Li, Yunpeng Zhang
abstract: The dielectric properties of terahertz semiconductor materials significantly impact the operational performance of terahertz devices, which typically operate in an environment with a certain microwave field strength. Therefore, it is significant for the design of terahertz semiconductor devices to achieve dielectric measurement under simulated microwave field loading environment. This paper proposes an improved dual-cavity integrated sensor technology that enables dielectric property measurement of materials using the terahertz open resonator method under microwave field loading. This technology addresses the critical challenge of weak test signal extraction in strong microwave fields through a dual-mode cooperative and decoupled mechanism. The open resonator is used for complex permittivity inversion, while the re-entrant coaxial cavity provides the microwave field environment. The open resonator is designed with multi-channel coupling and operates at 0.11~0.5 THz. Meanwhile, the phenomenon of the microwave field effect on the terahertz dielectric properties of semiconductor is observed through the parameter variation of the open resonator. Based on this system, the non-thermal and thermal effects of semiconductor materials can be accessed through changes in their dielectric parameters by setting the signal source for microwave field excitation to either pulsed or continuous wave signals. This system can provide a variable microwave field environment, which provides a support for the measurement of the complex permittivity of semiconductor materials in a simulated working environment.

title: A Non-Interleaved Dual-Band Janus Metasurface with Four Bi-directional Wavefront Control Channels for Vortex Beam Generation
authors: Zou Long, Zhengji Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: We propose and experimentally validate a non-interleaved, dual-band Janus metasurface that multiplexes frequency and incidence direction to realize four bidirectional and mutually independent wavefront-control channels. The unit cell comprises two layers of rotatable double-split rings and a central polarization-selective grating, enabling 0/π phase coding at 26 GHz and 40 GHz for forward (+z) and backward (−z) incidence, respectively. Based on this design, a 30 × 30-cell prototype generates four OAM beams with topological charges +1, +2, +3, +4. Full-wave simulations and microwave-chamber measurements yield mode purities of 0.72-0.77 (sim.) and 0.62-0.70 (meas.), with inter-channel isolation better than −22 dB and an aperture-level transmission efficiency 0.48. Furthermore, The non-interleaved bidirectional multiplexing achieves 100% spatial utilization without interleaving, offering a compact route to multi-functional, OAM links and multi-target detection.

title: Robust H ∞ Control of Discrete-Time Uncertain Systems Based on the Extended Finsler’s Lemma
authors: Eduardo Nunes Gonçalves, Douglas Junio Pereira, Frederico Barcelos Dos Santos
abstract: In this paper, the first contribution is the introduction of two novel conditions derived from the application of Finsler’s Lemma sequentially, which enable a new approach to controller design for discrete-time uncertain systems. Finsler’s Lemma enables the derivation of analysis and synthesis conditions in the form of linear matrix inequalities that incorporate additional slack variables and parameter-dependent Lyapunov functions. Relying on these conditions, the second contribution is the development of new controller parameterizations for both robust stabilization and robust H∞ control of polytopic discrete-time linear time-invariant systems. The core contribution of this work is the robust H∞ control parametrization based on a novel bilinear matrix inequality condition derived from the extended Finsler’s lemma, which has not appeared in previous studies in the literature. To synthesize robust H∞ controllers, we apply a two-step iterative algorithm. Each step involves solving a convex semidefinite program with a linear objective function and linear matrix inequality constraints. In the second step, by fixing some slack variables to values obtained in the first step, the controller becomes the decision variable. The algorithm requires an initial controller that robustly stabilizes the uncertain system. For this purpose, we apply an auxiliary iterative algorithm that computes a stabilizing controller by progressively shrinking a disk in the complex plane containing all closed-loop poles. The radius of the disk is reduced until it lies strictly inside the unit circle, ensuring robust stability. This algorithm is also formulated as a semidefinite program, using the newly proposed Finsler-based conditions, with the controller treated as a decision variable. Three numerical examples demonstrate that the combination of the two proposed algorithms can outperform existing methods in the literature, without requiring scalar tuning parameters. In all examples, the controllers computed using the proposed method achieve lower H∞ guaranteed costs than those obtained with existing methods in the literature, implying improved robust disturbance rejection performance.

title: Multi-Crop Disease Detection in Computer Vision for Resource-Constrained Farms: A review
authors: Rosemary Nalwanga, Luuk Spreeuwers, Estefania Talavera, Godliver Owomugisha
abstract: Crop diseases remain a major threat to global agricultural productivity, particularly in resource-constrained regions, where early intervention is critical to ensuring food security. Smallholder farmers often practice intercropping, creating complex field conditions that challenge conventional disease detection systems. Although computer vision and machine learning offer powerful tools for early diagnosis, most existing approaches are tailored to single-crop scenarios and rely on cloud-based or high-resource environments, limiting their applicability in the field. This review synthesizes and explores recent advances in AI-based crop disease detection with emphasis on multi-crop and intercropped systems. We provide an overview of the detection pipeline from data acquisition and preprocessing to model training and deployment. We highlight technical challenges such as dataset scarcity, lack of modality diversity, poor model generalization, and limited real-world validation. Unlike prior reviews that isolate crops and modalities, this review uniquely integrates multi-crop, multimodal and edge deployable perspectives. We identify key research gaps and outline emerging opportunities for scalable solutions, including lightweight, multimodal models, offline-capable inference, edge deployment, and the integration of conversational AI for field-level support. By centering on the realities of low-connectivity, heterogeneous farming environments, this review aims to offer guidance toward inclusive and sustainable AI-driven agriculture.

title: Low-latency Dissemination Scheduling Scheme for Collaborative Transmission within Heterogeneous Networks
authors: Yiyi Zhang, Peng Guo, Junyi Zhou, Chao Cai, Hongbo Jiang
abstract: Many reconnaissance missions require a group of mobile terminals (such as soldiers, mobile robots, and unmanned boats) to jointly operate within a region which is far away from the command centre. When a critical event occurs and is detected by a terminal, it is often required for the terminal to upload some critical data to the command centre (or via the satellite). As the bandwidth of the upload link is usually low due to the long distance, uploading the critical data often has long latency. To reduce the latency, a feasible way is to utilize the nearby terminals’ idle uplinks to help with the upload process, which requires the terminal’s data to be disseminated to other terminals as soon as possible. This is a new dissemination problem because the data being disseminated is also partially being uploaded, which seems as a novel data-leaking dissemination problem. To solve it, we propose LHDS (Low-latency Heterogeneous Dissemination Scheduling) scheme by transforming the problem into two special sub-problems, i.e., constructing a special degree-decreasing tree with maximum multichild nodes, and designing a leaking-sustained dissemination schedule for each subtree. Extensive simulation experiments have been conducted on LHDS as well as two heuristic algorithms (i.e., DBO and S-GA) designed for baselines. The results show that LHDS scheme significantly outperforms the DBO and S-GA algorithms in terms of total collaborative data uploading latency, with saving 41% and 42% latency on average, respectively.

title: A Parametric Workflow for the Design of High-Field Magnets for Optimized Stellarators
authors: Daniel Biek, Kamil Sedlak, Xabier Sarasola, Ambrogio Fasoli, Gaetano Bongiovi, Felix Warmer
abstract: A major challenge for stellarators are the complex non-planar 3D coil shapes required to create the necessary magnetic field to confine the plasma. This work presents a parametric approach for the magneto-static and mechanical analysis of stellarator coils, considering Nb3Sn coils with a 12 T peak B-field. In addition, a thermal-hydraulic simulation for the winding pack is performed, which includes the steady state analysis and the determination of the hotspot temperature during a quench. Given the existence of various stellarator configurations, the developed parametric tool for magnetic design will significantly accelerate the overall stellarator design process and its evaluation. The parametric tool has been applied to the HELIAS 5-B configuration which serves as case-study and is using LTS magnets. For HELIAS 5-B, the peak B-field is ∼12 T, with hotspot temperature and margin well within the limits, and the mechanical analysis showing the peak stress only exceeds the allowable limits locally and strain values remain below degradation threshold Nb<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>Sn.

title: A Hybrid Analytical-Numerical Approach to the Evaluation of the Flux Linkage of Misaligned Coils Above a Stratified Earth
authors: Mauro Parise, Jonas Ekman, Giulio Antonini
abstract: This work presents a hybrid analytical-numerical procedure that allows the efficient computation of the flux linkage of two misaligned circular coils placed above a stratified ground, which may include non-magnetic as well as magnetic materials. After deriving the Hankel transform describing the flux linkage, the semi-infinite integration interval is continued to the negative real axis. Next, the part of the integrand that exhibits branch point singularities is expressed in pole-residue form. This task is accomplished through the use of a well-established rational function fitting algorithm. Finally, the integration contour is deformed in the complex plane, so as to surround the pole singularities produced by the fitting algorithm. This makes it possible to apply the residue theorem, which leads to converting the integral representation for the flux into the sum of residues at the poles of the integrand. The derived solution has value in practical applications like wireless power transfer systems for battery electric vehicles charging.

title: EEG2GAIT: A Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Network for EEG-based Gait Decoding
authors: Xi Fu, Rui Liu, Aung Aung Phyo Wai, Hannah Pulferer, Neethu Robinson, Gernot R Müller-Putz, Cuntai Guan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Decoding gait dynamics from EEG signals presents significant challenges due to the complex spatial dependencies of motor processes, the need for accurate temporal and spectral feature extraction, and the scarcity of high-quality gait EEG datasets. To address these issues, we propose EEG2GAIT, a novel hierarchical graph-based model that captures multi-level spatial embeddings of EEG channels using a Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) Pyramid. To further improve decoding performance, we introduce a Hybrid Temporal-Spectral Reward (HTSR) loss function, which integrates time-domain, frequency-domain, and reward-based loss components. In addition, we contribute a new Gait-EEG Dataset (GED), consisting of synchronized EEG and lower-limb joint angle data collected from 50 participants across two laboratory visits. Extensive experiments demonstrate that EEG2GAIT with HTSR achieves superior performance on the GED dataset, reaching a Pearson correlation coefficient (r) of 0.959, a coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) of 0.914, and a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.193. On the MoBI dataset, EEG2GAIT likewise consistently outperforms existing methods, achieving an r of 0.779, an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.597, and an MAE of 4.384. Statistical analyses confirm that these improvements are significant compared to all prior models. Ablation studies further validate the contributions of the hierarchical GCN modules and the proposed HTSR loss, while saliency analysis highlights the involvement of motor-related brain regions in decoding tasks. Collectively, these findings underscore EEG2GAIT’s potential for advancing brain-computer interface applications, particularly in lower-limb rehabilitation and assistive technologies.

title: A CMOS Time-of-Evaporation Measurement Technique for Binary Chemical Solvent Monitoring
authors: Saghi Forouhi, Hamed Osouli Tabrizi, Abbas Panahi, Yasaman Tahernezhad, Ebrahim Ghafar-Zadeh
abstract: This paper introduces a novel Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS)-based sensing mechanism for measuring the Time of Evaporation (ToE) of binary chemical solvents. Utilizing an integrated CMOS capacitive sensor, the system detects evaporation from micro-liter volumes of chemical solvents deposited on the surface of interdigitated electrodes. This platform enables precise ToE measurement, which varies based on the composition of the binary solvent mixture. The functionality and practicality of the proposed sensing method were validated through experiments involving mixtures of pure water, ethanol, and methanol. Over 66 experimental results demonstrate that at room temperature, ToE serves as an indicator of the relative composition of two chemical solvents. Specifically, the ToE Change Ratio (TCR) and Capacitance Change Ratio (CCR) for water-ethanol mixtures were approximately 21.13% and 1.19%, respectively. Despite the droplet being freely placed on the CMOS chip at room temperature, the characterization curve between ToE and alcohol concentration exhibits linearity, with an R² value exceeding 0.945 for water-ethanol mixtures. These findings underscore the sensor's ability to provide rapid, accurate, and cost-effective liquid characterization. This evaporation-based sensing platform holds significant potential for advancing life sciences, offering a reliable and efficient tool for liquid analysis.

title: LEVIO: Lightweight Embedded Visual Inertial Odometry for Resource-Constrained Devices
authors: Jonas Kühne, Christian Vogt, Michele Magno, Luca Benini
abstract: Accurate, infrastructure-less sensor systems for motion tracking are essential for mobile robotics and augmented reality (AR) applications. The most popular state-of-the-art visual-inertial odometry (VIO) systems, however, are too computationally demanding for resource-constrained hardware, such as micro-drones and smart glasses. This work presents LEVIO, a fully featured VIO pipeline optimized for ultra-low-power compute platforms, allowing six-degrees-of-freedom (DoF) real-time sensing. LEVIO incorporates established VIO components such as Oriented FAST and Rotated BRIEF (ORB) feature tracking and bundle adjustment, while emphasizing a computationally efficient architecture with parallelization and low memory usage to suit embedded microcontrollers and low-power systems-on-chip (SoCs). The paper proposes and details the algorithmic design choices and the hardware-software co-optimization approach, and presents real-time performance on resource-constrained hardware. LEVIO is validated on a parallel-processing ultra-low-power RISC-V SoC, achieving 20 FPS while consuming less than 100mW, and benchmarked against public VIO datasets, offering a compelling balance between efficiency and accuracy. To facilitate reproducibility and adoption, the complete implementation is released as open-source.

title: Streamer Evolution Mechanism in Cottonseed and Mineral Oil under Extremely Uneven Electric Field
authors: Wenjing Su, Haoxi Cong, Linghe Kong, Kexin Zhang, Junzhang Li, Xuefeng Hu, Qingmin Li, Xuelei Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Cottonseed oil is a promising natural ester insulating oil for transformers. However, its discharge behavior under lightning impulse voltage remains unclear. Based on the drift-diffusion model, this study establishes a discharge model under extremely uneven electric fields. High-speed imaging experiments are employed to validate the spatiotemporal evolution of streamers. The results indicate that cottonseed oil, which possesses a relatively higher permittivity, exhibits a smaller electric field gradient. Streamers in cottonseed oil demonstrate stronger spatial expansion and more pronounced lateral electric field components, along with a shorter duration of the fieldstrength surge phase. Increasing the impulse voltage significantly enhances the streamer length, brightness, and branching density, with the number of secondary streamers in both oils being approximately proportional to the voltage amplitude. A smaller tip radius triggers earlier streamer inception. Cottonseed oil exhibits a velocity transition following the I–II–III–II mode sequence, whereas mineral oil displays only an I–II transition, and only at small tip radius. These findings clarify the streamer evolution mechanisms in cottonseed and mineral oils, providing theoretical support for insulation enhancement and discharge mitigation in high-voltage equipment.

title: Deep Fade Event Probability Analysis of FSO Channels with Strong and Weak Turbulence
authors: Akhil Misra, B. Sainath
abstract: The probability that the free space optical (FSO) channel experiences deep fade is significant due to the randomness of channel gain. Here, we present a deep fade event probability analysis of FSO channels with strong and weak turbulence scenarios. Specifically, we obtain closed-form approximate expressions.

title: Design of RF Front-end Electromagnetic Protection Limiter
authors: Yining Cheng, Peiran Liu, Xiao Li, Yingwei Chen, Shixiong Liang, Dawei Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The limiter plays an important role in protecting the back-end sensitive devices in the radio frequency (RF) receiving system. In this paper, a limiter with fast-response capacity based on a GaAs Schottky barrier diode (SBDs) is designed and taped out to verify. In order to reduce the error of simulation, we propose a design method based on field-circuit co-simulation. Through the experiment, the limiter has low insertion less than 0.5 dB from 1 to 2 GHz, and its voltage standing wave ratio (VSWR) is less than 1.2.

title: Utilization of the Hot-Fit Model to Measure the Success of Information Systems: a Literature Review
authors: Nur Muhammad Asnadi, Yusuf Durachman, Saepul Aripiyanto
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The Human-Organization-Technology Fit (HOTFit) Model has been widely used in evaluating the success of information system (IS) implementation and adoption across various sectors. This research aims to systematically review ten scientific journal articles that utilized the HOT-Fit model in diverse contexts, such as hospitals, government, industry, and education. Employing a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) approach, this article identifies trends, gaps, and contributions of the HOT-Fit model in supporting the evaluation and decisionmaking related to information systems. The analysis results indicate that “human” and “organizational” factors often serve as key determinants of IS success. This research also recommends integrating HOT-Fit with other evaluation methods to enhance the accuracy of evaluation results.

title: Analysis of the Impact of Shielding Gasket Size Selection on Shielding Effectiveness in Shielding Design
authors: Chao Zhang, Qi Liu, Na Wang, Yuming Fan, Xiaoming Su, Minghui Cai
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In practical shielding engineering, apertures and seams on the surface of shielding enclosures are prone to electromagnetic leakage, which can be effectively mitigated by installing EMI gaskets. To analyze the influence of gasket dimensions on shielding effectiveness and support electromagnetic shielding design, this study employs isotropic materials to fill regular gaps, establishing an analytical model to evaluate the impact of gasket size. The shielding effectiveness of gaskets with dimensions ranging from 1 mm to 10 mm is calculated and analyzed. The findings indicate that smaller gasket sizes result in higher shielding effectiveness. Therefore, in practical electromagnetic shielding design, selecting smaller gaskets—while ensuring basic functionality and reliability—can enhance the overall shielding performance of the product.

title: Characterization of Inter- and Intrachannel Nonlinear Effects Under Different Channel Loading Conditions
authors: Joana Girard-Jollet, Lina Shi, Fabien Boitier, Patricia Layec, Jean-Christophe Antona
abstract: We experimentally analyzed nonlinear effects from adjacent QPSK channels and ASE noise loading over a long-haul link, including the impact of CPE. ASE-induced penalties were smaller than predicted by format-dependent models, and CPE was found to significantly mitigate both intra- and interchannel nonlinearities.

title: Machine Learning Algorithms for Attack Detection on Encryption Systems Based on Activity Logs
authors: Tri Kuntoro Priyambodo, Widyastuti Andriyani, Muhammad Husni Santriaji, Yudi Prayudi, Bambang Purnomosidi Dwi Putranto
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Encrypted communication ensures confidentiality but remains vulnerable to brute-force, MITM, data injection, and key spoofing attacks. Detection is challenging due to the infeasibility of payload inspection and the lack of real-world datasets. This paper proposes a machine learning–based intrusion detection system using a synthetic dataset simulating encrypted traffic. By analyzing metadata features such as entropy, packet count, connection duration, and block size, the Random Forest model achieves 92.8% accuracy, 91.5% precision, 93.2% recall, and 92.3% F1 score. With Explainable AI visualizations, the system highlights feature contributions for interpretability, demonstrating an effective and privacy-preserving approach to anomaly detection in encrypted environments.

title: Smart Warehouse Monitoring System with License Plate Recognition for Vehicle and Goods Movement
authors: Dharma Vija Putra Sugianto, Gabrielle Jeconiah Christiando, Wijaya Pratama Suteja, Mochammad Haldi Widianto
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: This study proposes a Smart Warehouse Monitoring System to automate the monitoring of vehicle and goods movement using computer vision, specifically by using an Automatic Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) approach. The primary objective is to design and evaluate a pipeline that integrates YOLOv8 Medium, character recognition using EasyOCR, and validation against the official government vehicle database (Bapenda Jabar) for a plate detection system. The primary contributions are: (1) detection-OCR pipeline integration linked to official government databases for verification, (2) a lightweight image-processing system suitable for and can be applied to resource-limited devices, and (3) comparative analysis of YOLOv8 and YOLOv11 on an internal dataset. Three sample categories (Kaggle, foreign plates, and direct captures; n_total = 13 images) used for initial testing showed correct readings for all samples; however, the results have yet to be generalized as the results are limited by the small size and low variability of the dataset. Detection metrics, average inference time, environmental limitations, and plans for further improvement are included in the discussion. However, the overall results of the initial testing have proved the very effective potential that exists within the proposed system for implementation in Automatic Number Plate Recognition as well as Intelligent Transport Systems.

title: Incremental Learning-Based Autorotation Control Scheme for Small Unmanned Helicopter
authors: Yao Zhang, Mou Chen, Zengliang Han, Min Wan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: In this paper, the autorotation dynamic model of small unmanned helicopter with power failure is established, while a data-driven incremental learning method is proposed in its flight controller design to optimize the control performance offline. Firstly, The speed attenuation model of the main rotor after power failure and the six degree of freedom (DOF) dynamic equation are described, respectively. Secondly, an incremental learning (IL)-based control framework is presented, where the nominal controller and the IL-based controller are designed in parallel, and the nominal control law is developed using backstepping control approach to theoretically ensure the system stability, while the incremental learning control law is proposed with a data-driven form to optimize the indicators. Considering the low computing power of the flight controller, an adjustable neural network (NN) is introduced with an adaptive algorithm, and the size of the NN is determined by the need for the user. Finally, the simulations are given to validate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme.

title: Controllable Integrated Photonic Devices Based on Nematic Liquid Crystals and Gold Nanorods
authors: Carlo Santini, Maria Laura Sforza, Federica Zaccagnini, Francesca Petronella, Luciano De Sio, Antonio d'Alessandro
abstract: We investigate a test platform to assess the optical response of a waveguiding LC layer embedding ordered Au-NRs. Au-NR axis alignment by means of the LC molecular director reorientation, induced by an applied voltage, results in the modulations of transverse and longitudinal plasmonic resonance peaks.

title: Hundred-Millijoule-Level Water Cooled Ultrafast Yb:YAG Laser at 100 Hz Repetition Rate
authors: Hang Yang, Kun Liu, Zihan Zhou, Jiajia Mao, Junhao Chen, Xiang Gao, Liujing Xu, Dayong Zhang, Hong Zhao
abstract: We demonstrate an ultrafast laser system based on water cooled Yb:YAG active mirror, delivering 101 mJ pulses with 2.8 ps duration at 100 Hz. The beam quality factors are 1.52 (x) and 1.43(y). This work offers a viable path for high-energy ultrafast laser development.

title: A VLM-Based Method for Visual Anomaly Detection in Robotic Scientific Laboratories
authors: Shiwei Lin, Chenxu Wang, Xiaozhen Ding, Yi Wang, Boyuan Du, Lei Song, Chenggang Wang, Huaping Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: In robot scientific laboratories, visual anomaly detection is important for the timely identification and resolution of potential faults or deviations. It has become a key factor in ensuring the stability and safety of experimental processes. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a VLM-based visual reasoning approach that supports different levels of supervision through four progressively informative prompt configurations. To systematically evaluate its effectiveness, we construct a visual benchmark tailored for process anomaly detection in scientific workflows. Experiments on two representative vision-language models show that detection accuracy improves as more contextual information is provided, confirming the effectiveness and adaptability of the proposed reasoning approach for process anomaly detection in scientific workflows. Furthermore, realworld validations at selected experimental steps confirm that first-person visual observation can effectively identify processlevel anomalies. This work provides both a data-driven foundation and an evaluation framework for vision anomaly detection in scientific experiment workflows.

title: Implementation and Evaluation of Inverse Dynamics Actuation Control with Respect to Human Coordinates for Exoskeletons
authors: Daniel Greve, Christian Kreischer
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Accurate control of support torques within the human body caused by an exoskeleton contributes to its efficacy as well as the understanding of its functionality. Hence, it is a basis for higher level control functionalities. A standardized technical test procedure has already been established to measure support torques for lower-back support exoskeletons. However, appropriate inverse dynamic control approaches directly considering the accurate control of these torques with respect to human coordinates have not yet been implemented and tested with technical procedures. The main objective of this contribution is to formulate such a control approach for an exemplary application of a cable-based lower-back support exoskeleton and to test it with a novel test bench. A combination of a neural network and a solution of a nonlinear equation is applied to calculate kinematic quantities. Kinematic and inverse dynamics calculations are conducted on microcontroller hardware in real-time. It is revealed that the consideration of support torques with respect to human coordinates instead of exoskeleton coordinates decreases the root mean square error for two different reference support torques by approx. 62 % (13 % of its reference value) for the application example. Difficulties in precise actuation of support torques are present mostly due to friction in cable-based actuation. Further, kinematic calculations show significant errors. The findings suggest that, depending on differences between human and exoskeleton kinematics, control approaches considering support torques are superior when referred to human coordinates.

title: CM4SLE ver 1.0: Conceptualizing Business Architecture for Blockchain-Enabled Organizational Agility in Software-Led Enterprises
authors: Neda Seyedin Hashemi, Aylar Ziapour Sohi, Araz Saie Arasi, Aidin Ziapour Sohi, Mahmood Neshati
publish: 2025 9th Iranian Conference on Advances in Enterprise Architecture (ICAEA)
abstract: Blockchain is increasingly positioned as a driver of organizational agility, yet existing research remains fragmented across process, governance, and ecosystem perspectives. This academic paper develops a UFO-grounded conceptual model that embeds blockchain capabilities into business architecture for software-intensive enterprises. A PRISMA-guided systematic literature review (2020–2025) was conducted to synthesize insights on blockchain-enabled process transformation, enterprise architecture mediation, and ecosystem-centric adoption. Ontological modeling with the Unified Foundational Ontology ensured semantic rigor, capturing constructs such as governance relators, lifecycle agility, and ecosystem roles. The resulting model integrates three domains - core, futuristic, and gap-bridging concepts-providing a holistic architecture that connects blockchain affordances to agility-enabling mechanisms. Evaluation through competency questions demonstrated its applicability in aligning governance with architecture, translating ecosystem adoption drivers into organizational design, and operationalizing agility capabilities. The study contributes by consolidating dispersed insights into a unified socio-technical framework and by offering managers a blueprint for aligning technology, strategy, and ecosystem readiness.

title: Commutation-Overlap PWM Strategy for Torque Ripple Suppression in Reaction Wheel BLDC Motors
authors: Zhicheng Wang, Xiangwen Chen, Haitao Li, Yize Wang, Yumeng Liang, Haitao Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: To mitigate the adverse effects of commutation torque ripple in reaction wheel systems, this paper establishes an analytical model of brushless direct current motor (BLDC) motor currents, back Electromotive Force (back-EMF), and torque to reveal its formation mechanism. A commutation-overlap-based PWM control strategy is then proposed. Unlike conventional dual closed-loop control, the method adaptively sets the overlap duration from current dynamics and employs high-frequency PWM to balance current slopes, ensuring smooth phase transitions. Simulation and experimental results confirm that the proposed strategy effectively suppresses commutation torque ripple, thereby enhancing torque smoothness, stability, and control precision.

title: A Comparative Study of Isolation Forest, LOF, OCSVM and Elliptic Envelope for Anomali Detection in Insurance Dataset
authors: Wilsen Grivin Mokodaser, Green Arther Sandag, Semmy Wellem Taju, Raissa Camilla Maringka, Rolly Junius Lontaan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Data analysis plays a crucial role in the insurance industry for processes such as claim prediction, risk management, and fraud detection. One of the major challenges in this field is the presence of outliers—values that significantly deviate from normal patterns in financial data. This study applied four anomaly detection algorithms—Isolation Forest (IF), Local Outlier Factor (LOF), Elliptic Envelope (EE), and One-Class SVM (OCSVM)—to a dataset consisting of 766 insurance records, each containing monthly income data from January to December. The detection results show that IF, LOF, and EE each identified 39 anomalies, while OCSVM detected 38. Among these, 36 records were flagged as anomalies by at least two algorithms, 22 by at least three, and 17 were consistently identified by all four methods, forming a high-confidence anomaly subset. A comparison of results highlights that IF and LOF often overlap in their detections, suggesting strong suitability for joint use in financial anomaly detection. OCSVM displayed a more conservative approach, detecting fewer anomalies, while EE, based on Gaussian distribution assumptions, produced distinct results compared to distance-based methods. Overall, the findings indicate that while no single algorithm is universally superior, Isolation Forest and LOF demonstrated the best balance of consistency and responsiveness in detecting anomalies within monthly insurance income data.

title: Automated Scrap Metal Sorting System Using Magnetic, Resistive, and Visual Features
authors: Joseph A. Escuro, Kyla Nicole G. Cruz, Charmaine C. Paglinawan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: This study presents the development of an AI-assisted scrap metal classification and sorting system designed for small-scale junk shop applications. Focusing on aluminum, copper, and steel, the system integrates a convolutional neural network with visual, magnetic, and resistive sensing to achieve automated material identification. A two-level prototype featuring a conveyor and servo-based sorting mechanism was built to demonstrate full operation. The classification model achieved 96.77% accuracy, while the sorting system maintained an average accuracy of 93.55%. Errors were minimal and primarily due to misclassification, sensor delays, or mechanical handling issues. The results highlight the system’s potential to improve recycling efficiency and support a more consistent valuation of scrap materials in resource-constrained settings.

title: An Explainable Control Framework (XCF): A Novel Fuzzy Model-Agnostic Explanation (FMAE) Approach with Case Study
authors: Faliang Yin, David Watson, Hak-Keung Lam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) can enhance the transparency and trustworthiness of control systems by delivering decision-making insights that are readily understandable to humans. This is especially crucial in scenarios where data-driven controllers employing closed box approaches, or mathematically rigorous yet complex controllers, are adopted. However, existing XAI methods typically focus on predictive tasks such as classification and regression, with limited applications in control. To bridge this gap, this paper integrates XAI techniques into control systems by proposing an eXplainable Control Framework (XCF) which explains how controllers determine their control actions and their underlying working mechanism. A novel XAI method, fuzzy model-agnostic explanation (FMAE), is introduced as an instantiation of the proposed framework. The innovations and contributions of this work include applying and adjusting the hierarchical structure, model-agnostic algorithm and user interface of FMAE within the proposed XCF to better align with the needs of explainable control. To validate the proposed XCF based on FMAE in real control scenarios, we conduct a case study on the cartpole inverted pendulum system. The generated explanations comprise comprehensible IF-THEN rules revealing the decision logic of controller and the salience values of the system states illustrating their contributions to control output. Furthermore, we employ large language models (LLMs) to refine the explanations. Experimental results based on the designed evaluation metrics demonstrate that the explainer accurately approximates the behavior of real controller. This work enhances control system explainability and usability for accessible design, analysis, and deployment.

title: Multiple-Layered Colloidal-Quantum-Dot Color Conversion Layers for Solar Cell Enhancement
authors: Yu-Ting Hsieh, Bo-Ming Huang, Yan-Ke Chen, Chin-I Chen, Tao Deng, JyunWei Ji, SungYu Chen, Chien-Chung Lin
abstract: An hybrid incoherent optical model was established to achieve the calculation of various designs of the colloidal quantum dot layer integrated with solar cell. Quantum dot samples with 1cm by 1cm size were fabricated and high color conversion efficiency was obtained.

title: High Quality Factor Micro-Ring Resonator with Ultra-Low Thermo-Refractive Noise
authors: Chunxue Wang, Congyu Hu, Xucheng Zhang, Yadong Jiao, Xingchen Ji, Yikai Su
abstract: We demonstrate an ultra-high thermal stable micro-ring resonator based on a polymer-SiN platform, utilizing SU-8 as the cladding layer. This architecture enables exceptional thermal stability with high quality factor, making it highly suitable for on-chip frequency stabilization and applications requiring low thermo-refractive noise.

title: An SBR method Based on Panel Subdivision for RCS Prediction of Electrically Large Target
authors: Jin-Peng Xiong, Juan Li, Wei Meng, Yu-Lu Biao, Lei Zhao, Zhe Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This article proposes an improved SBR method based on the subdivision of facets, which is used to calculate the electromagnetic scattering of electrically large and complex targets composed of small and fine structures and a large number of planar structures. In order to restore the fine structure of the target, it is necessary to perform fine segmentation of the target, which can result in redundant segmentation of large planar structures. This article is based on the integral characteristics of Physical Optics(PO) to perform panel subdivision on large planar structures, which improves the computational efficiency of the target's large planar structure. The effectiveness of the proposed method is compared and verified with the results of FEKO-MLFMM.

title: Multi-Fiber Optic Sensing Solution for Real-Time Condition Monitoring of Eco-Friendly Gas-Insulated Switchgear
authors: H. K. Jung, J. G. Shin, J. Eom
abstract: A multi-fiber optic sensor system was developed for real-time monitoring and diagnostics of eco-friendly gas-insulated switchgear (eGIS). It accurately measures critical parameters like internal temperature, pressure, and partial discharge using fiber Bragg gratings (FBG) and fiber interferometers, reducing electromagnetic interference and enhancing long-term stability.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization Model for Diesel Vehicle Emissions Based on AGE-MOEAII
authors: Zhenyi Xu, Jiaren Li, Jun Huang, Xihong Fei
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are primary emission of diesel engines, which are composed of nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NO}_{2}$</tex>). Traditional energy control strategies overlook the perturbations caused by frequent changes in driving intentions and fail in complex scenarios without vehicular connectivity. To overcome these challenges, we propose a multi-objective control strategy based on data from the OnBoard Diagnostic (OBD) system. This strategy employs the AGE-MOEAII algorithm to construct three fitness functions for multi-objective optimization, achieving a comprehensive optimal control of energy consumption, NOx emissions, and driving comfort. Furthermore, to enhance the convergence speed in solving the optimization problem, we adopt a local optimization approach, which nearly doubles the solution speed compared to global optimization methods. When applied to reduce NOx emissions, the optimized solutions consistently yield a mean reduction of NOx levels between 300 and 350 ppm across five experimental trials, demonstrating both significant and stable reductions in NOx emissions.

title: Lateral MOCVD Growth of stacked III-V Membranes on Double-Layer SOI
authors: Zhiwei Liang, Donghui Fu, Yingzhi Zhao, Yunjiang Jin, Siyuan Yu, Yu Han
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) photonic integration is essential for overcoming the density and scalability limitations of silicon photonic integrated circuits (PICs). In this work, we propose a 3D integration strategy that combines wafer bonding with lateral MOCVD growth to realize dislocation-free, vertically stacked InP membranes on a custom-designed double-layer SOI substrate. This approach enables uniform lateral heteroepitaxy and precise vertical alignment, allowing the integration of InGaAs/InP multiple quantum wells (MQWs) that emit at telecom wavelengths. Our results offers a promising route toward waferscale integration of III-V active photonic devices on silicon platforms.

title: Machine Learning Prediction of Optical Response in Bragg Gratings: From Partial to Full Spectrum
authors: M. R. Mahani, Igor A. Nechepurenko, Yasmin Rahimof, Thomas Flisgen, Andreas Wicht
abstract: We present a machine learning framework that predicts Bragg grating reflectance spectra from structural features. By combining spectral-fitting strategies (Gaussian, coupled-mode theory, SVD) and Bayesian data acquisition, our method reduces computational cost while preserving full-spectra prediction accuracy in modeling the optical responses of semiconductor waveguides.

title: An Efficient TDR/TDT Simulation Method for High-Speed Interconnects
authors: Beining Sun, Tingting He, Wenhao Zhou, Zheng Guo, Kanglong Zhang, Peng Zhao, Shichang Chen, Gaofeng Wang, Haogang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this paper, we present an efficient simulation method for fast time-domain reflectometry (TDR) and time-domain transmission (TDT) analysis based on S-parameters. An equivalent TDR circuit is established to compute the reflected and transmitted voltages at both ends of the S-parameter model. A synthesis method of Y-parameters is proposed, and the equivalent impedance is derived from Y-parameter response. The key results of TDT/TDR simulation (TDR voltage, TDR equivalent impedance, and TDT voltage) are given and compared to commercial software to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Performance Analysis of Metasurface Unit Cells Based on Deep-learning
authors: Yinuo Wen, Xiao Jia, Jianjun Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Metasurfaces can manipulate the wavefront of incident light by altering the geometric shape, dimensions, or material of their unit structures. However, traditional electromagnetic simulation methods for parametric sweeps of metasurface structures require extensive manual modeling, are prone to errors, and suffer from long simulation times. This paper proposes a residual neural network-based method for predicting reflection parameters of metasurface unit structures, significantly improving analysis speed. By using 2D structural images as input data, a metasurface reflection parameter prediction model was trained. Test results show close agreement between model predictions and traditional software simulations, validating the model's accuracy.

title: Self-Optimizing Enterprise Architecture for Digital Government: Telemetry-Driven Maturity and Generative Co-Design
authors: Sadegh Aref, Marzieh Hatami, Seyedakbar Mostafavi
publish: 2025 9th Iranian Conference on Advances in Enterprise Architecture (ICAEA)
abstract: Digital government increasingly depends on enterprise architecture (EA) to align strategy with technology portfolios, yet current practices remain static, survey-based, and detached from operational data. This paper introduces a self-optimizing EA framework that integrates telemetry-driven maturity monitoring, generative co-design, and an AI governance layer. Telemetry from service logs and performance metrics feeds a real-time maturity orchestrator, while an AI meta-layer performs predictive analytics and generates policy-compliant BPMN workflows and capability maps under human oversight. A knowledge-graph backbone links policies, processes, and technologies to enable reasoning and interoperability across agencies. A proof-of-concept prototype demonstrates near real-time maturity updates (latency below five seconds), artefact accuracy of up to 100 percent after review, and complete governance traceability. The results indicate that EA in government can evolve from static documentation toward an adaptive, evidence-driven, and trustworthy foundation for digital transformation.

title: Performance of Neural Network Controller Based Micro Grid Station Connected to Railway System
authors: Killi Ramoji, Jaganmohan Rao Tarra, Nagalla Sowjanya
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: This project presents the development and evaluation of a NN controller for a microgrid station integrated with a railway system. In this framework, the railway network is considered as an extended microgrid that incorporates distributed active loads such as trains, along with renewable sources and energy storage units. Traditional control strategies, typically based on PI controllers, often encounter steady-state errors and increased harmonic distortion. To overcome these challenges, the proposed system combines solar and wind generation with battery storage, coordinated through an NN-based energy management scheme. The controller regulates the DC bus voltage and controls the current through the buck-boost converter. A comparative analysis between the PI and NN controllers is performed in MATLAB/Simulink, focusing on voltage and current performance. The simulation findings confirm that the proposed configuration enhances the efficiency and reliability of the powertrain and the microgrid station.

title: Day-Ahead and Intra-Day Coordinated Optimal Scheduling of a Bi-Mode Air Energy Storage System Considering Uncertainties
authors: Zhimo Chen, Qingshan Xu, Yongbiao Yang, Fan Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Compared with traditional single-mode energy storage systems, dual-mode air energy storage systems (BM-AES), combining advanced adiabatic compressed air energy storage (AA-CAES) and liquid air energy storage (LAES), offer significant advantages in addressing renewable energy variability. This paper proposes a bi-level coordinated scheduling framework for the integration of dual-mode air energy storage systems (BM-AES) to optimize operational costs and address uncertainties in load and wind power forecasting. Firstly, a multi-time-scale coordination optimization method is proposed, accounting for uncertainties in wind power and load prediction using triangular fuzzy numbers. Then, a day-ahead and intra-day coordinated optimal scheduling model is developed to minimize system operation costs, including wind curtailment. The model is formulated as mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) problem. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified through simulations, demonstrating its ability to enhance the grid’s economic and operational performance, particularly under high renewable energy penetration.

title: Scalable Optical Crosshaul for Future Wireless Systems
authors: Christina Lim, Yijie Tao, Chathurika Ranaweera, Ampalavanapillai Nirmalathas, Lena Wosinska
abstract: To meet the bandwidth and connectivity requirements of future wireless networks, the optical crosshaul network is anticipated to be intelligent and could dynamically reconfigure the network depending on the traffic load. This work explores the underlying architectures and technological advancements of optical crosshaul networks.

title: Non-Volatile Integrated Photonics for Reconfigurable Filtering Applications
authors: Kai Xu, Maoliang Wei, Yiting Yun, Weiquan Wang, Lan Li, Hongtao Lin
abstract: Flexibly reconfigurable and multitype photonic filters were demonstrated by modeling a scalable architecture of photonic programmable gate array with low power consumption and high integration density, which can be compatibly fabricated by combining silicon photonics and back-end-of-line integration of phase change materials.

title: Application of Infrastructure as Code (IaC) in Multi-Cloud Network Infrastructure Management Using Terraform and Aviatrix on AWS and Azure
authors: Akhyar Lubis, Elviawaty Muisa Zamzami, Ade Candra, Herman Mawengkang
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Managing network infrastructure across multiple cloud providers introduces operational complexity, security risks, and inconsistencies in configuration. This paper investigates the application of Infrastructure as Code (IaC) for automating multi-cloud network deployment using Terraform and Aviatrix on AWS and Azure. A three-phase implementation model is proposed: initial infrastructure provisioning, configuration enhancement, and secure automation through CI/CD pipelines. Each phase is executed using a structured IaC workflow, involving collaborative roles of NetOps, DevOps, and SecOps teams. Functional validation demonstrates successful connectivity between isolated cloud environments and effective enforcement of egress filtering through FQDN-based policies. The research highlights the effectiveness of combining Terraform with Aviatrix in managing scalable, secure, and automated multi-cloud networks, offering a replicable approach aligned with modern DevSecOps practices. Limitations related to performance metrics and real-world deployment scenarios are also discussed.

title: Speckle Reduction Using a 1D Optical Phased Array Edge-Coupled to a Multi-Mode Fiber
authors: Bernat Molero Agudo, Irwan D. Setija, Martijn J. R. Heck
abstract: An edge-coupled one-dimensional InP optical phased array drives a multimode fiber to scramble spatial coherence without moving parts. Simulations validate a predictive contrast model, reaching low speckle contrast and demonstrating a compact, GHz-speed low-coherence laser source for imaging, sensing, and metrology applications.

title: Invisible Identities: Privacy-Aware Object Detection for Autonomous Vehicles and Public Surveillance
authors: Muhammad Jehanzaib Yousuf, Mamoona Asghar, Mohammad Samar Ansari, Brian Lee, Nadia Kanwal
abstract: Anonymising visual data dynamically presents challenges for achieving privacy and security by design, as currently addressed by Privacy-Enhancing Technologies (PETs) and Security-Enhancing Technologies (SETs). The need to decrypt data before applying anonymization or masking techniques introduces potential vulnerabilities, where data could be exposed during processing. This article provides a comprehensive solution to implement robust security measures throughout the entire data lifecycle, including training machine learning models on data without applying differential privacy. Our approach ensures end-to-end encryption to protect data at rest, during processing, and in transit. We encrypt the region of interest in visual imagery at the source, allowing machine learning or deep learning models to use it directly for training purposes. This ensures models focus on abstract visual information rather than private details such as facial features or clothing colour. Our work demonstrates that machine learning models trained on privacy-aware data can be as accurate as those trained on raw data. We employed widely used AES encryption and object detectors like YOLO, Single Shot MultiBox Detector (SSD-MobileNetv1-FPN-640x640, SSD-ResNet101-FPN-640x640), and the EfficientDet family (EfficientDet-D0 and EfficientDet-D1) for detection and classification of visual objects.

title: Identification of Intra-Span Hybrid Fiber Types Using Longitudinal Power Profile Estimation in Optical Networks
authors: Choloong Hahn, Zhongqiu Zhong, Zhiping Jiang
abstract: We present a method for identifying intra-span hybrid fiber types using a longitudinal power profile estimation technique. By introducing an alien fiber indicator, we estimate the minimum detectable fiber length. We also propose an analytical calculation method that enables the estimation of hybrid fiber parameters.

title: Blockchain Scalability Challenges for Public Services Adoption: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Firman Munthaha, Kalamullah Ramli
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Several studies have reported that blockchain implementation for public services can offer numerous benefits to both the government and its citizens, such as transparency, efficiency, and citizen trust. However, the adoption of blockchain for public services faces significant challenges, particularly in terms of technological issues. Blockchain scalability has become one of the primary challenges related to the nature of public service requirements themselves, due to the need for high-availability systems and continuous data growth. This paper presents a systematic literature review conducted under the PRISMA framework, covering the publication period between 2020 and 2025. This systematic literature review examines the current challenges to blockchain scalability, particularly within the context of public services. The review identifies significant scalability challenges, including limited throughput, latency, storage expansion, interoperability, and governance, and categorizes proposed solutions across blockchain layers. This study contributes to the field by mapping the state of the art in blockchain scalability for public services and outlining potential research directions based on the findings of the literature.

title: 650 Mbps Optical Wireless Communications Using Far-Ultraviolet-C Micro-Light-Emitting Diode Arrays
authors: J.J.D. McKendry, H. Zimi, S. Rajbhandari, J. Ruschel, J. Rass, S. Einfeldt, J. Herrnsdorf, M.D. Dawson
abstract: We demonstrate optical wireless data communications using arrays of far-UVC LEDs emitting at 235 nm. Micro-pixelation of the LED active area is shown to enhance the modulation bandwidth by a factor of 2. Optical wireless data rates up to 650 Mbps are shown.

title: A High-Efficiency Microwave Power Combining System Based on a Tuned H–T Waveguide Tee
authors: Dayang Wang, Jianlong Liu, Kongyi Hu, Zhijianmucuo Dong, Zheng Yang, Feifan Ma, Zhong Wang, Baoqing Zeng
abstract: This brief presents a system for high-efficiency S-band magnetron microwave power combining based on the mutual synchronization mechanism (peer-to-peer locking mechanism) between magnetrons, which effectively addresses the issues of low efficiency and complex architecture in the existing magnetron microwave combining systems. The system is simplified through a modification of the H–T waveguide tee by introducing multiple tuning pins to control the coupling coefficient precisely. This modification achieves tunable coupling strength and mutual frequency pulling and locking. It leverages the intrinsic coupling characteristics of microwave signals between magnetrons and ensures stable interlocking. Moreover, it significantly simplifies the combining system and eliminates the need for circulators or phase shifters. Additionally, a fixed-length (or tunable) straight waveguide is added to fine-tune the phase difference between the two magnetrons, thereby maximizing the combining efficiency to approximately 99% in experiments. The high combining efficiency is maintained once the combining system is established. The combining efficiency remains above 95% even when different magnetrons are alternated. These results highlight its potential as a high-efficiency solution for magnetron microwave combining applications and industrial-scale use.
