title: Efficient and Accurate Remote Sensing Image Registration with Hierarchical Mamba Networks
authors: Tao Cao, Zhengyang Zhang, Hongfei Cao, Shuchen Bai, Na Liu
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Existing remote sensing image registration methods face an inherent trade-off among accuracy, efficiency, and generalization capability. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel hierarchical Mamba network, named GeoMamba. This network introduces three core innovations: a Pyramid Mamba Block (PMB) to effectively capture hierarchical spatial features, an innovative Feature Dual-Fusion Module (DFM) to achieve efficient feature interaction with linear complexity, and a Dual Regression Constraint (DRC) strategy to enforce geometric consistency. Comprehensive experiments on the large-scale Aerial Image dataset show that GeoMamba’s performance comprehensively surpasses current state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods, reducing the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) by up to 28.1% compared to the strongest baseline, while maintaining an average registration time of 0.3 seconds. More importantly, when directly applied to the SUIRD dataset for zero-shot generalization testing, the model demonstrates exceptional robustness and adaptability, proving that it has achieved a new SOTA level in terms of accuracy, efficiency, and generalization.

title: Mode-Constrained Two-Stage Current Injection Optimization for Voltage Unbalance Mitigation in IBR-Rich Distribution Network
authors: Tiantian Ji, Pengfeng Lin, Miao Zhu, Wentao Jiang, Xinan Zhang, Changyun Wen, Peng Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Under unbalanced grid conditions, inverter-based resources (IBRs) are required to remain connected to the grid and provide reactive current injection to mitigate voltage unbalance at the point of common coupling. Most existing research focuses primarily on steady-state reference current generation under such conditions, whereas current overshoot and oscillations induced by reference-switching have been largely overlooked. Driven by this gap, this paper proposes a mode-constrained two-stage current injection optimization framework. In the first stage, the dominant oscillatory modes of a grid-connected IBR are identified through closed-loop transfer function modeling and eigenvalue analysis. In the second stage, a reference-switching trajectory optimization problem is formulated in the frequency domain, in which the trajectory is constructed through a virtual acceleration sequence. By maximizing the virtual energy contained in the sequence under spectral energy constraints, the fastest and optimal trajectory is indirectly obtained, and the excitation of dominant oscillatory modes during reference switching is thereby prevented. Since this framework is implemented at the reference level, it is fully compatible with existing controllers and adaptable to varying operating conditions. Simulation and experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed optimization framework.

title: Adaptive Dynamic Programming Based Dynamic Surface Control for Nonlinear Systems with State Constraints and Unmodeled Dynamics
authors: Danfeng Zhu, Qin Wang
abstract: This paper addresses the optimal control problem for a class of nonlinear systems that present significant challenges due to state constraints, unmodeled dynamics, and a nonstrict feedback structure. To tackle the filtering errors typically associated with classic dynamic surface control methods, novel compensation signals are designed and integrated into the control framework. The proposed control strategy is divided into two main phases. In the first phase, a feedforward control input is constructed to ensure the boundedness of all system states, while a first-order auxiliary signal is introduced to effectively suppress the influence of unmodeled dynamics. In the second phase, a near-optimal control input is developed by minimizing a carefully formulated cost function based on a reconstructed error system. This is achieved through the use of adaptive dynamic programming techniques, where radial basis function neural networks are employed to approximate the unknown nonlinear components. A rigorous stability analysis confirms the uniform ultimate boundedness of all closed-loop signals. The effectiveness of the proposed control method are validated through comprehensive simulation studies on two representative nonlinear systems.

title: Human-in-the-Loop Segmentation of Multispecies Coral Imagery
authors: Scarlett Raine, Ross Marchant, Brano Kusy, Frederic Maire, Niko Sünderhauf, Tobias Fischer
abstract: Marine surveys by robotic underwater and surface vehicles result in substantial quantities of coral reef imagery, however labeling these images is expensive and time-consuming for domain experts. Point label propagation is a technique that uses existing images labeled with sparse points to create augmented ground truth data, which can be used to train a semantic segmentation model. In this work, we show that recent advances in large foundation models facilitate the creation of augmented ground truth masks using only features extracted by the denoised version of the DIstillation of knowledge with NO labels version 2 (DINOv2) foundation model and K-nearest neighbors (KNN), without any pretraining. For images with extremely sparse labels, we use human-in-the-loop principles to enhance annotation efficiency: if there are five point labels per image, our method outperforms the prior state-of-the-art by 19.7% for mean intersection over union (mIoU). When human-in-the-loop labeling is not available, using the denoised DINOv2 features with a KNN still improves on the prior state-of-the-art by 5.8% for mIoU (five grid points). On the semantic segmentation task, we outperform the prior state-of-the-art by 13.5% for mIoU when only five point labels are used for point label propagation. In addition, we perform a comprehensive study into the number and placement of point labels, and make several recommendations for improving the efficiency of labeling images with points.

title: Experimental Investigation of Wave Energy Converters: Pneumatic Power Absorption in Oscillatory Flows
authors: Julia A. Gionet-Gonzales, Paul M. Koola, Sharath S. Girimaji
abstract: Oscillating water columns (OWC) offer a robust option for ocean wave energy conversion due to their minimal underwater moving parts. The OWC devices harness wave energy by trapping air in a chamber, which converts ocean wave motion into a pulsating airflow that drives an air turbine coupled to an electrical generator. Efficient energy extraction necessitates a clear understanding of the complex interactions among hydrodynamic, pneumatic, turbine, and electrical subsystems. The power takeoff (PTO) mechanism is particularly critical, as it governs the entire energy conversion chain from hydraulic to electrical power. Given the analytical challenges, experimental studies are essential for model validation, with small-scale experiments offering a cost-effective approach before full-scale prototype deployment. This study decouples the hydrodynamic and pneumatic subsystems for efficient testing. A piston rig, constructed from 6-in cylindrical pipes and driven by a reciprocating actuator, generates controlled oscillatory pneumatic flow. The downstream end of the cylindrical pipe is fitted with the power generation device or its proxy—miniature Wells turbine, orifice plate or porous plug. Key performance metrics for all the above devices subject to different levels of oscillatory flow are determined and compared. The turbine achieved the highest pneumatic power output (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\sim$</tex-math></inline-formula>28 W) due to elevated chamber pressures, while an orifice plate yielded approximately 9 W and a porous plug 0.8 W. Notably, the porous plug exhibited qualitative flow behavior similar to that of the miniature Wells turbine. These experiments provided valuable insights into the effectiveness of oscillatory pneumatic systems. Such knowledge is critical for developing scaled damping proxies for PTO systems in oscillatory flows, ultimately contributing to the advancement of OWC converters.

title: A Multi-Scale Attention Transformer for Martian Dust Devil Detection in Remote Sensing Imagery
authors: Gan Liu, Linlin Shi, Jialong Lai, Feifei Cui, Xiaoping Zhang, Yi Xu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Detecting Martian dust devils remains a challenging task due to the scarcity of high-quality annotated data, significant variations in scale, blurred boundaries, and complex surface textures. To address these difficulties, we construct a cross-regional, manually annotated benchmark dataset named MDD-Human and propose a novel Transformer-based detection network, MDT (Mars Dust Devil Detection Transformer). The model adopts FasterNet as its backbone to ensure a balance between computational efficiency and feature extraction capability. A key innovation lies in the multi-scale attention fusion module, which incorporates hierarchical fusion strategies and hybrid attention mechanisms to effectively enhance the representation of dust devil features under diverse Martian terrains. In addition, we introduce a shape-aware localization loss function, SMIoU (Shape-Augmented Minimum Point Distance IoU), which improves geometric sensitivity by integrating corner distance constraints and structural shape priors. Experimental results on the MDD-Human dataset demonstrate that MDT achieves 92.7% Precision, 90.8% Recall, 92.4% mAP@50, and 91.8% F1-score, outperforming several classical and state-of-the-art detectors. Further tests on unseen THEMIS and CRISM datasets confirm the model's strong cross-source generalization, highlighting its robustness and applicability in diverse Martian imaging scenarios.

title: Novel Approach and Index for Evaluating Harmonic Contributions of Multiple Harmonic Sources Based on Gaussian Mixture Model with Multipoint Harmonic Phasor Measurements
authors: Chuan Wang, Fangwei Xu, Kai Guo, Wantong Cai, Wei Wu, Bo Zhao, Cheng Liu, Xinyang Li
abstract: Determining the harmonic contributions (HCs) of multiple harmonic sources (HSs) is a challenging task owing to the large fluctuations of background harmonic sources (BHSs) that impede the accurate evaluation of HCs for the existing approaches. To address this problem, this paper proposes a novel approach based on the Gaussian mixture model (GMM) using multipoint synchronized harmonic phasor measurements. In the proposed approach, the multipoint model capable of simultaneously solving multiple harmonic transfer impedances (HTIs) is first constructed, where the fluctuations of background harmonic voltage are treated as the statistical variables represented by multiple different Gaussian distributions. Then, we resort to the expectation maximization (EM) algorithm and Bayesian information criterion (BIC) for the estimation of the model parameters associated with BHSs and HTIs, achieving good estimation performance under large fluctuation levels of BHSs. Finally, a new HC index is formulated to synthetically evaluate the overall HCs of each HS to the harmonic problems of the concerned area. The proposed index considers not only the differences in the severity degree of harmonic-standard-exceeding problems on different concerned buses but also the time-varying characteristics of the HSs being evaluated. It is more effective than the existing index in identifying the real harmonic contributors to the concerned area. The simulations performed in the IEEE 33-Bus test system have demonstrated the advantages of the proposed approach, with more than 50% accuracy improvement over the existing approaches.

title: Energy Minimization in UAV-Enabled Cargo Pickup Systems: A Radio Map-Aided Hierarchical Optimization Framework
authors: Jiangling Cao, Shi Peng, Dingcheng Yang, Qinghua Wu, Tiankui Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: This article studies the energy efficiency optimization of cargo uncrewed aerial vehicle (UAV) pickup systems, with constraints on on-board energy and load capacity. In the UAV-enabled cargo pickup system, minimizing the total energy consumption and ensuring the safe flight of the cargo UAV is a problem to be solved. However, due to building blockages, the channel between the UAV and ground base stations (GBSs) frequently switches between line-of-sight (LoS) and non-line-of-sight (NLoS), thereby affecting the UAV’s communication quality. This effect is further aggravated by environmental noise interference. Moreover, limited by the on-board energy, it is unrealistic for the UAV to pick up all the cargo in a single flight without charging or replacing the battery. To address the above-mentioned challenges, we propose a UAV pickup system energy efficiency optimization (UPSEEO) framework. In this framework, the UAV’s trajectory between any two pickup points is optimized via the A<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{*}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> algorithm to ensure the stability of the UAV communication link. Next, we employ the particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm to optimize both task allocation and flight speed to minimize the total energy consumption, subject to constraints on UAV on-board energy limits and payload capacity. Numerical results show that the proposed framework can ensure the UAV’s communication quality in any spatial topology, with an improvement in energy efficiency of approximately 5% to 50% compared to the comparison experiment.

title: Byzantine Attacks in Over-the-Air Cooperative Sensing Networks: Analysis and Defense
authors: Weiwei Wang, Vincent Huynh, Carlos Feres, Lifeng Lai, Zhi Ding
abstract: Cooperative Sensing Network (CSN) is an important system in broad applications such as Cognitive Radio Networks (CRNs) and Internet-of-Things (IoT). Recent advances in Overthe-Air (OTA) computation have enhanced CSN efficiency by significantly lowering communication overhead, allowing multiple sensing agents to simultaneously transmit over the same spectrum resource. However, OTA-based sensing networks can be vulnerable to Byzantine Attacks (BAs), and detailed analyses of their effects remain unaddressed. This paper formulates a general BA model for OTA-based CSN that aims to maximize the probability of false alarm (PF) and minimize the probability of detection (PD). We identify the most damaging BA strategy under the linear attack model and evaluate its impact on OTA-based CSN. To mitigate the impact of Byzantine attacks, we propose a direct defense mechanism by adapting the joint detection threshold to lower PF to a desired level.We present analyses to show how such defensive approaches weaken detection performance. These findings highlight the need for further developing advanced defense strategies against BAs in OTA-based collaborative networks.

title: Phased Array Calibration based on Rotating-Element Harmonic Electric-Field Vector with Time Modulation
authors: Shiyuan Li, Yuyue Zhou, Chi Zhang, Liang Kong, Kebin Liu, Chong He, Xiaoming Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Calibration is crucial for ensuring the performance of phased array since amplitude-phase imbalance between elements results in significant performance degradation. While amplitude-only calibration methods offer advantages when phase measurements are impractical, conventional approaches face two key challenges: they typically require high-resolution phase shifters and remain susceptible to phase errors inherent in these components. To overcome these limitations, we propose a Rotating element Harmonic Electric-field Vector (RHEV) strategy, which enables precise calibration through time modulation principles. The proposed technique functions as follows. Two 1-bit phase shifters are periodically phase-switched at the same frequency, each generating corresponding harmonics. By precisely adjusting the relative delay between their modulation sequences, the phase difference between the +1st harmonics produced by the two elements can be precisely controlled, utilizing the time-shift property of the Fourier transform. Furthermore, the +1st harmonic generated by sequential modulation of individual elements exhibits a linear relationship with the amplitude of the modulated element, enabling amplitude ambiguity resolution. The proposed RHEV-based calibration method generates phase shifts through relative time delays rather than physical phase shifter adjustments, rendering it less susceptible to phase shift errors. Additionally, since the calibration process exclusively utilizes the +1st harmonic, which is produced solely by the modulated unit, the method demonstrates consistent performance regardless of array size. Extensive numerical simulations, practical in-channel and over-the-air (OTA) calibration experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and distinct advantages of the proposed method.

title: A Compact, Low-cost, Highly Sensitive and High Speed Fiber Optic Vibration Sensor Based on Liquid Mass Block
authors: Shuang Zeng, Jun-Hao Zhao, Hui Huang, Wei-Cheng Cai, Tao Sun, Jian-Wei Zhang, Peng-Bo Liu, Jian Zhao, Qing-Xin Wu, Jing Chen
abstract: Currently, for fiber optic vibration sensors (FOVS), realizing high sensitivity (sub-μg) and high speed (~ kHz) simultaneously is still a challenge. Herein, a high speed and highly sensitive FOVS was demonstrated by using the liquid mass block (silicone oil), which can transmit the inertial force to all the direction inside the FOVS for omnidirectional sensing. Owing to the liquid nature of oil, the inertial force can be uniformly applied on the diaphragm without deteriorating its mechanical properties. The response magnitude of FOVS can be enhanced ~48 dB by employing the liquid mass block. Moreover, because without using any optical interference effect, precise control on the light wavelength and cavity length is no longer needed, which simplifies sensor fabrication and demodulation system for compact and low cost. An omnidirectional detection limit of 0.1 μg, a sensitivity of 3.2 V/g, and a resonance frequency of 2.7 kHz was realized for the FOVS.

title: A Weak-Coupling and Compact Magnetic Pendulum Array Antenna for SLF Communication:2D and 3D Expansion
authors: Yuzhu Ren, Wei Dan, Kewen Dong, Shizhan Jiang, Jianming Sun, Tianxiang Nan, Zhaoqiang Chu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Portable and efficient super low frequency (SLF) transmitters enable the building of a real-time cross-domain communication link deployed in small unmanned platforms. Building upon our previous work that introduced a compact, weakly coupled 1D magnetic pendulum array (MPA) for SLF band transmission, this research advances the technology through dimensional expansion from 1D to optimized 2D and 3D array configurations. The 2D array has a circular-orthogonal configuration to minimize magnetic coupling and enhance space utilization. Finite element modeling and experimental validation are both conducted. The optimal “0101” 2D array achieves a high figure of merit (FOM1) of 12,100 A2·m/W — representing nearly a threefold improvement over the 1D array. On this basis, 3D arrays by strategically stacking 2D arrays in parallel along the maximum transmission direction are studied, which performs enhanced transmission efficiency of 22,676 A2·m/W when adjacent layers are orthogonally arranged and the transmissible magnetic field strength reaches 3.66 pTpk at a distance of 100 meters, with a low power consumption of only 1.55 W. Finally, error-free 4 bps BPSK communication is implemented using the proposed 3D MPA in two scenarios: penetrating six building floors (24 m vertical range) and operating in free airspace (100 m horizontal range).

title: Multi-Scale, Multi-Basis Wavelet Voting Network for Automatic Analysis of Fetal Heart Rate Signals
authors: Yaosheng Lu, Jiewen Liu, Jieyun Bai, Jingbo Rong, Jianguo Qi, Ziduo Yang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate computer-aided interpretation of fetal heart rate (FHR) recordings depends on detecting the baseline and transient accelerations (Acc) and decelerations (Dec) that deviate from it. Most deep learning models treat FHR as a simple 1-D time sequence, overlooking the spectral separation between the low-frequency baseline and high-frequency Acc/Dec patterns. Neglecting this clinically important time-frequency structure can result in missed detections of Acc and Dec events and increased susceptibility to noise. To overcome these limitations, we present WaveFHR-VNet—a U-Net-style, multi-scale, multi-basis wavelet-voting network that analyzes FHR signals in the joint time-frequency domain. WaveFHR-VNet embeds a discrete wavelet transform (DWT) in every encoder block. Each DWT splits the features into approximation (low-pass) coefficients, which preserve the low-frequency baseline trends, and detail (high-pass) coefficients, which preserve the high-frequency Acc/Dec edges. Cascading these decompositions through successive layers yields a hierarchical, multi-scale representation. The decoder uses inverse DWT for full-resolution reconstruction. Skip connections are equipped with an Interactive Coefficient Selection (ICS) module that learns attention masks to suppress Doppler noise and motion artefacts in the detail stream while amplifying diagnostically salient transients. To enhance spectral diversity, five complementary wavelet bases (db4, db6, sym4, sym5, bior3.5) operate in parallel; a simple voting layer fuses their outputs, eliminating manual basis tuning. Evaluated on four FHR datasets, WaveFHR-VNet achieved state-of-the-art performance, with improvements of up to 5.3995% Dice, 5.4758% IoU, and 4.6263% accuracy over the best baselines on LCU-DB, the most widely used public benchmark. It also demonstrates strong cross-dataset generalization, consistently outperforming all comparison models. These results suggest that WaveFHR-VNet can serve as a reliable tool for intrapartum monitoring.

title: Sequence-To-Sequence Voice Conversion With Weighted Guided Attention
authors: Haruki Yamashita, Takuma Okamoto, Ryoichi Takashima, Yamato Ohtani, Tetsuya Takiguchi, Tomoki Toda, Hisashi Kawai
abstract: Voice conversion (VC) using non-autoregressive sequence-to-sequence (S2S) models has gained attention in recent years. Compared with conventional framewise VC models, these S2S VC models can control features, such as prosody and speech speed, and enable high-quality and fast conversion. In S2S VC, the accuracy of alignment between source and target speakers strongly affects conversion performance. In this paper, we propose EdenVC and WSAS-VC using attention-based alignment. EdenVC simply introduces a diagonal-guided weighting initially proposed in EdenTTS, while WSAS-VC integrates the attention weights and those based on the alignment path obtained from the monotonic alignment search. We evaluate the conventional MAS-VC, EdenVC, and WSAS-VC using two types of speaker conversion conditions, from native to native speech and from non-native to native speech. Experimental results show that WSAS-VC achieves more stable training than EdenVC and better conversion accuracy than MAS-VC.

title: Cross-Frequency Attention and Color Contrast Constraint for Remote Sensing Dehazing
authors: Yuxin Feng, Jufeng Li, Tao Huang, Fangfang Wu, Yakun Ju, Chunxu Li, Weisheng Dong, Alex C. Kot
abstract: Current deep learning-based methods for remote sensing image dehazing have developed rapidly, yet they still commonly struggle to simultaneously preserve fine texture details and restore accurate colors. The fundamental reason lies in the insufficient modeling of high-frequency information that captures structural details, as well as the lack of effective constraints for color restoration. To address the insufficient modeling of global high-frequency information, we first develop an omni-directional high-frequency feature inpainting mechanism that leverages the wavelet transform to extract multi-directional high-frequency components. While maintaining the advantage of linear complexity, it models global long-range texture dependencies through cross-frequency perception. Then, to further strengthen local high-frequency representation, we design a high-frequency prompt attention module that dynamically injects wavelet-domain optimized high-frequency features as cross-level guidance signals, significantly enhancing the model’s capability in edge sharpness restoration and texture detail reconstruction. Further, to alleviate the problem of inaccurate color restoration, we propose a color contrast loss function based on the HSV color space, which explicitly models the statistical distribution differences of brightness and saturation in hazy regions, guiding the model to generate dehazed images with consistent colors and natural visual appearance. Finally, extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches in both texture detail restoration and color consistency. Further results and code available at: https://github.com/fyxnl/C4RSD.

title: 50,000-Spin Count Integrated Photonic Chip Ising Solver
authors: Yuan Gao, Guanyu Chen, Wujie Fu, Jianing Wang, Anil Prabhakar, Aaron Danner
abstract: Photonic Ising machines offer a scalable advantage in solving combinatorial optimization problems compared to traditional computers. In this work, we experimentally implement a silicon photonic chip with a compact footprint of just <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.6 \text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. Meanwhile, we solve a 50,000 -spin problem entirely optically, demonstrating scalability.

title: Towards Linearizing Fiber Links with Optical Phase Conjugation
authors: Mark Pelusi, Ryosuke Matsumoto, Christian K. Schou, Michael Galili, Leif K. Oxenløwe, Shu Namiki
abstract: Improved compensation of nonlinear signal distortion in long-distance fiber links is demonstrated using optical phase conjugation plus tailored nonlinearity in Raman amplified fibers or dispersion compensating fiber. For unrepeatered links, this outperforms using forward Raman amplification, making it redundant. Calculations also show its ultra-broadband potential.

title: MOCHA:Memory-Optimized Learned Index Based on Chameleon
authors: Chong Sun, Ruiyu Chen, Meng Xia, Jin Xie, Enqing Wu, Ziheng Han
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Indexes are important components in database systems, capable of significantly improving the speed of data lookup. Under locally skewed data distributions, traditional indexes (such as B+-trees) exhibit poor query performance and high memory consumption; while the existing learned index Chameleon achieves faster query speed under skewed data, it still occupies a large amount of memory space. To optimize the utilization of memory space, this paper proposes MOCHA-a memory-optimized learned index based on Chameleon, aiming to solve the problem of inefficient memory usage under skewed workloads. MOCHA introduces three key strategies: cold node compression strategy (compressing cold nodes with low access frequency), subindex construction strategy (excluding cold keys to save more memory space), and redundant node cleanup strategy (eliminating redundant nodes). Experiments on dataset such as FACE (extremely skewed) show that MOCHA retains the query efficiency of Chameleon (faster than other indexes such as DIC and ALEX), and under skewed workloads, memory usage is reduced by up to 24 %, making it more suitable for systems with limited memory resources.

title: Novel Non-Prehensile Rolling Problem: Modelling and Balance Control of Pendulum-Driven Reconfigurable Disks Motion with Magnetic Coupling in Simulation
authors: Ollie Wiltshire, Seyed Amir Tafrishi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: This paper presents a novel type of mobile rolling robot designed as a modular platform for non-prehensile manipulation, highlighting the associated control challenges in achieving balancing control of the robotic system. The developed rolling disk modules incorporate an innovative internally actuated magnetic-pendulum coupling mechanism, which introduces a compelling control problem due to the frictional and sliding interactions, as well as the magnetic effects between each module. In this paper, we derive the nonlinear dynamics of the robot using the Euler-Lagrange formulation. Then, through simulation, the motion behavior of the system is studied and analyzed, providing critical insights for future investigations into control methods for complex non-prehensile motion between robotic modules. Also, we study the balancing of this new platform and introduce a new motion pattern of lifting. This research aims to enhance the understanding and implementation of modular self-reconfigurable robots in various scenarios for future applications.

title: A Reconfigurable Electromagnetic Bandgap Structure for Wide-Band SSN Suppression in High-Speed PCBs
authors: Qiwei Liu, Dan Shi, Yanchi Liu, Na Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Simultaneous Switching Noise (SSN) severely undermines the stability of high-speed digital circuits. This paper proposes an improved reconfigurable electromagnetic bandgap (REBG) structure, integrating a modified uniplanar compact EBG (UC-EBG) with PIN diodes. By adjusting PIN diode states, the structure’s stopband can be tuned from 2.15 GHz to 10.47 GHz, outperforming most existing EBGs. To address potential signal integrity (SI) issues, eye diagrams are used to evaluate digital signal performance. After balancing SSN suppression and SI, the effective stopband remains 2.15–10.47 GHz, suitable for high-speed circuit applications.

title: Data-Driven Based Solution Method for Security-Constrained Unit Commitment
authors: Xuyu He, Chunhua Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: The security-constrained unit commitment (SCUC) problem is characterized by its high-dimensional, non-convex, and mixed-integer nonlinear nature. The incorporation of grid security constraints significantly expands the model scale, resulting in low computational efficiency. To improve solving performance, this paper proposes a data-driven solution method for SCUC. First, a surrogate model for AC power flow calculation is constructed using a CNN-BLS (Convolutional Neural Network-Broad Learning System) architecture. By training on extensive historical power flow data, a nonlinear mapping between system operating states and power flow results is established. Furthermore, the implicit relationship between generator output and line power flow is derived. Using sensitivity analysis, the complex AC power flow constraints are transformed into linear constraints expressed in terms of generation power variables. Consequently, the SCUC problem is reformulated into a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model, which is solved using Cplex. Simulation results on the 10 -unit 39-bus system demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces solution time while maintaining accuracy, thereby effectively enhancing the computational efficiency of the SCUC problem.

title: Adaptive Multi-Dimensional Spatial Mapping for 3D Face Reconstruction
authors: Tao Du, Yuping Guo, Shuwen Zhao, Jinchao Ge, Jiahui Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: As the application of 3D faces becomes increasingly widespread across various fields, reconstructing 3D faces with precise facial shapes and faithful emotional conveyance is of great significance. Recent progress in methods based on 3D Morphable Models (3DMMs), which regress parametric 3D facial models from single facial images, have proven effective in restoring the overall facial shape. However, these methods struggle to capture subtle, due to flaws in the supervision cues. This paper proposes the Adaptive Multi-Dimensional Spatial Mapping Network (AMDSM-Net) as a solution. By incorporating an adaptive photometric loss function, we effectively reduce the domain gap, thus improving the fidelity of 3D face reconstruction. In particular, we designed a joint learning paradigm which leverages a spatial relationship weighted photometric loss among 2D image and 3D mesh. Our qualitative and quantitative evaluation evaluation outcomes on the dataset verify the superior performance of the method.

title: Optimization of Exoskeleton-Assisted Gait Using Predictive Simulation to Reduce Joint Load for Knee Osteoarthritis Patients
authors: Kaifeng Li, Shuhao Ma, Xin Wang, Jiawei Jia, Yu Cao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Knee osteoarthritis (KOA) is a prevalent joint disorder that leads to increased knee joint loading during gait. Exoskeletons have been introduced as assistive devices to alleviate joint stress and enhance mobility. However, most commercially available exoskeletons rely on predefined gait patterns, which may not effectively reduce knee joint load. This study integrates musculoskeletal modeling and predictive simulation to optimize exoskeleton-assisted gait strategies for KOA patients. In this framework, a reflex-based controller produces muscle excitation signals. These signals are then introduced into the musculoskeletal model to compute muscle forces, which in turn drive gait motion. By incorporating joint load reduction into the optimization process and refining exoskeleton torque application, we enhance the realism and efficacy of simulated gait patterns. The simulation results demonstrate the optimized gait pattern can reduce joint load for KOA patients. Our proposed approach provides valuable insights into exoskeleton design and clinical rehabilitation, supporting future efforts in simulation-based exoskeleton gait optimization.

title: Gas Spectroscopy Powered by Broadband and Flat Supercontinuum Generation in Tantalum Pentoxide Waveguides
authors: Zhenyu Liu, Mingjian You, Xingyu Tang, Zhengqi Li, Weiren Cheng, Ning Ding, Junke Zhou, Jiaxin Hou, Ziming Zhang, Qiancheng Zhao
abstract: We generate broadband and flat supercontinuum in tantalum pentoxide waveguides with spectral fluctuations smaller than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 ~ d B}$</tex> in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8 0 ~ n m}-wide$</tex> span. Using this waveguide as a broadband photonic engine, acetylene absorption spectrum is characterized and the results show good agreement with the reference measurement.

title: 3.4 μm High-Peak-Power Laser Source Based on Synchronization-Free Parametric Conversion
authors: Junjie Jiang, Lin Li, Hang Yang, Zihan Zhou, Xiang Gao, Kun Liu, Hong Zhao, Xia Yu
abstract: We demonstrate a high-peak-power <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 3.4 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> ultrafast laser source based on parametric down-conversion in a KTA crystal within a synchronization-free system. The output delivers 3.4 ps pulses with a peak power exceeding 5 MW-the highest reported for synchronization-free architectures. This achievement holds significant promise for DIRCM systems.

title: A Direct Adaptive Control Method for Magnetic Guidewire Navigation in Constrained Environments
authors: Chen Wang, Xiao-Hu Zhou, Mei-Jiang Gui, Xiao-Liang Xie, Shi-Qi Liu, Shuang-Yi Wang, Zhen-Qiu Feng, Bo-Xian Yao, Zeng-Guang Hou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Constrained environments impact the motion dynamics of magnetic guidewires, introducing uncertainties into control. To address this challenge, a robust control method for magnetic guidewire navigation is proposed. First, a kinematic model is formed to characterize the behavior of the magnetic guidewire, which integrates both steering and advancement motions. Based on this model, a direct adaptive control (DAC) method is proposed, where a learnable parameter is employed to dynamically compensate for environmental disturbances, thereby significantly improving trajectory tracking performance. Additionally, Lyapunov stability analysis is further employed to verify the stability of the proposed control method. Finally, extensive simulation experiments demonstrate its effectiveness, achieving a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 0.0182 m in tracking a desired trajectory. These results highlight the robustness and practical potential of the proposed framework for vascular intervention tasks.

title: Optical Architectures for Photon-Photon Resonance in Vertical-Cavity Surface-Emitting Lasers and Distributed Feedback Lasers
authors: Jack Jewell
abstract: Both Distributed-Feedback and Vertical-Cavity Surface-Emitting Lasers with 2 cavities generate 2 longitudinal modes, with design-tunable frequency separations. Optical simulations target data rates up to 448-896 Gigabits/sec. Production requirements are analyzed to optimize lasers' optical structures for highest speeds with minimal electrical power.

title: CM-PharmE ver.1: Towards a Conceptual Model for Pharmaceutical Ecosystem with a Business-Architecture Perspective
authors: Araz Saie Arasi, Hassan Haghighi, Hossein Azgomi
publish: 2025 9th Iranian Conference on Advances in Enterprise Architecture (ICAEA)
abstract: Pharmaceutical ecosystems involve multi-layered interactions across organizational, regulatory, and digital domains, demanding a coherent conceptual foundation to capture their dynamics. Previous frameworks have rarely combined business architecture with ontology, leaving ecosystem-level interactions only partially represented. This study addresses these gaps by proposing a business-architecture-informed conceptual framework grounded in the Unified Foundational Ontology (UFO). Importantly, the framework positions business architecture as a bridge to enterprise architecture, ensuring that ecosystem-level conceptualization aligns with organizational structures and strategic objectives. The framework was developed through a systematic literature review (PRISMA-guided) of 17 peer-reviewed studies (2018–2025) and a qualitative thematic synthesis. It formalizes key components and relationships across domains to ensure semantic coherence and structural clarity. The proposed model contributes to advancing theory and provides a reference for ontology-based system design, strategic governance, and policy development in pharmaceutical contexts. Furthermore, the framework offers extensibility for future adaptation at both the enterprise and ecosystem levels, supporting broader applicability in digital health, regulatory alignment, and inter-organizational collaboration.

title: Multiple Rewards for Unsupervised Q-Learning and HBOS Anomaly Detection
authors: Christopher C. O’Neill, Jorge Martinez Carracedo, Yaxin Bi
abstract: Applying multiple rewards of equal value to QLearning is necessary for accurate anomaly detection, but there is so far little research done into the topic. In this paper, the authors make use of the HBOS algorithm to establish multiple bandpass ranges, which are then used in the training of a Q-Learning algorithm, which is itself based on the Gridworld game, to create Multiple Rewards for Q-Learning Version 2 (MRQLv2). A brief introduction into the concepts and formulae behind Q-Learning and the HBOS algorithm are included. The methodology section shows how the bounds of the bandpass filters are created; how the data is prepared; how the algorithm handles different types of data; the creation of category maps and the use of parameters. The full MRQLv2 algorithm is tested on the Statlog Shuttle and Satellite UCI datasets. The results show a recall of 1, a precision of 0.946408 and a ROC-AUC score of 0.973204 on the Shuttle dataset. These results are compared against a variety of machine learning, deep learning and hybrid models including; OCSVM, MF, kNN and Fast kNN, GNNs, RNNs, MCOD and Approx-Storm using precision, recall and averaged AUC scores. The results show a significant improvement on previous models for the Shuttle dataset, but more research needs to be done to improve the performance of the MRQLv2 algorithm overall.

title: Active Frequency Selective Surface with Tuning/Absorption Functionality in S band
authors: Haobin Yang, Huaibin Wang, Yefeng Tong, Chong-Zhi Han, Jian Shu, Ying Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper proposes a dual-functional active frequency selective surface (AFSS) capable of rapidly switching between transmission and absorption modes. The unit consists of a top layer with a cross-shaped structure loaded with a varactor diode and a bottom layer with a PIN diode-loaded absorption circuit. In tuning mode, the resonant frequency can be continuously adjusted from 2.18 to 3.27 GHz, achieving a relative bandwidth of 40%; in absorption mode, it operates within the 2.40–3.69 GHz range with an absorption rate of 74.9%–91.7%, enabling fast mode switching. The compact planar structure and simple fabrication process offer promising applications in reconfigurable radome, dynamic spectrum selective filtering and related fields.

title: Fast Microwave Magnetic Field Imaging Method Based on Diamond NV Center
authors: Jiong Tang, Yangyang Zhou, Peng Han, Jian Qiu, Yiqiang Chen, WeiHeng Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Diamond nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center is a solid-state quantum sensor with high sensitivity and spatial resolution, holding promising prospects for electromagnetic fault diagnosis of components. However, conventional microwave magnetic field detection methods based on Rabi oscillations suffer from time-consuming measurement procedures. In this study, a rapid microwave magnetic field imaging method based on the mathematical relationship between fluorescence and microwave field intensity in diamond NV center is proposed. By correlating the fluorescence intensity emitted by NV centers with microwave field strength, the single-point measurement time is reduced from minutes to seconds. Experimental validation on a serpentine microstrip line demonstrates that this method enables fast and high-resolution 2D microwave magnetic field imaging with high spatial resolution.

title: Fast Design Optimization Framework for Low-Profile Dual-Polarization Frequency-Selective Rasorber Using the Space Mapping Approach
authors: Chang Hao Zhao, Yu Xing Li, Yi Qian Mao, Jian Wei You, Jia Nan Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper proposes a design optimization framework for a low-profile dual-polarized frequency-selective rasorber, leveraging a combination of equivalent circuit theory and the space mapping (SM) technique. The reflection coefficient formula derived from the equivalent circuit model (ECM) serves as the coarse model, while the full-wave electromagnetic (EM) simulation of the rasorber functions as the fine model. An artificial neural network (ANN) is employed to establish the mapping between these two models. This integration of the coarse model and the ANN mapping forms the neuro-SM model, which rapidly predicts the EM response, effectively replacing the need for computationally intensive EM simulations. To enhance efficiency by reducing the number of training samples for this surrogate model, a star sampling approach is implemented. The application of this model has successfully led to an optimized design that achieves a reflection coefficient below -10 dB within the 2.3-5.8 GHz frequency band. This approach has demonstrated a significant reduction in design optimization time, achieving an approximate 80% decrease compared to conventional full-wave simulation methods. These results validate the efficacy of the space mapping technique in the design of frequency-selective rasorbers.

title: Inhibition in an Integrated Spiking Laser Neuron Using an Intra-Cavity Phase Shifter
authors: L. Puts, J. Borms, W. Yao
abstract: We examine the influence of a tunable intra-cavity phase shifter on the excitable dynamics of an integrated twosection spiking laser neuron in generic InP technology. The results show that the excitable threshold and timing are controllable, and inhibition is observed for relatively large phase tuning.

title: Analysis and Research on the Internal Flow Field of Centrifugal Pump by Blade Wrap Angle
authors: Jinlong Wang, Tianyu Wang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 11th Annual International Conference on Network and Information Systems for Computers
abstract: None

title: Study on the Problem of Conductor Wind Deviation Caused by Valley Wind
authors: Zhenbing Zhu, Xiwen Yue, Chang Li, Suo Zhu, Feng Mi, Zha Yang, Zhuojun Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: When high-voltage transmission lines operate in high-altitude complex terrain areas, conductor windage yaw has become a key external factor that threatens the safe and stable operation of the power grid. Based on the typical windage yaw fault cases in Naqu City and Yanglang area of Tibet, combined with field investigation, windage yaw angle check and simulation analysis, this paper reveals the occurrence mechanism and evolution law of wire offset under special meteorological conditions such as valley wind and brash wind. The research shows that the combination of thin air, strong wind and topographic circulation in high altitude areas significantly aggravates the suddenness and unpredictability of windage yaw fault. In view of the above problems, this paper proposes a multi-dimensional prevention and control strategy covering design, operation and maintenance, including wind speed data collection, windproof design standard improvement, parameter optimization and local environmental adaptability design, and further proposes comprehensive measures for operation monitoring, fault warning and operation and maintenance improvement. The research results can provide theoretical basis and engineering reference for the safe operation of UHV transmission lines in extreme environments, and have important academic value and engineering application significance.

title: Starting Performance Improvement of a Novel Line-Start Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor with Fractional Slot Concentrated Winding
authors: Tongxin Liu, Jinlin Gong, Lele Qi, Qiqi Wang, Jinle Zhang, Frédéric Gillon
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Line-start permanent magnet synchronous motor (LSPMSM) offers the advantage of direct grid starting without converters in fixed-speed applications such as fans and pumps. Structurally, they can be regarded as electromagnetic hybrid of induction motor and permanent magnet synchronous motor. Fractional slot concentrated windings (FSCW), which feature short end turns and simplified manufacturing, have been adopted successfully with PMSM. However, their inherently rich magnetomotive force (MMF) harmonics negatively impact starting performance, generate torque pulsations, and reduce efficiency, which restrict the application with LSPMSM. This paper proposes an interleaved squirrel-cage design method which can effectively suppress the influences of the MMF harmonics. Through the optimal design of the starting unit, FSCW becomes viable for LSPMSM. Finite element method (FEM) validates the proposed method.

title: Face Recognition Classification Using Mtcnn and Transfer Learning Vgg19 in Face Position Tracking
authors: Anif Hanifa Setianingrum, Nurul Faizah Rozy, Viva Arifin, Nenny Anggraini, Muhammad Raihan Akbar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: A critical challenge in implementing face recognition systems is accurately predicting how well they will perform on new, unseen data. This research addresses this challenge by presenting a detailed performance analysis of an MTCNN-VGG19 pipeline on a custom campus dataset comprising 400 images from 8 subjects. Following a methodology where the dataset was augmented to 12,000 images prior to being split for training and validation, the model achieved a high validation accuracy of 99.33%. In contrast, testing conducted on 48 entirely new images resulted in a practical accuracy of 75%. This significant performance disparity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 24$</tex> percentage points is the central finding of this study. Consequently, the work's primary contribution is methodological, providing a crucial insight: it quantitatively demonstrates that a clean data split, performed before any augmentation, is a non-negotiable prerequisite for the robust training and valid evaluation of face recognition models.

title: Coupling Path Visualization and Noise Mitigation for the Power Network of AI Core System
authors: Jiaqi He, Chenxi Liu, Xu Wang, Jun Fan, Xiuqin Chu, Feng Luo, Bo Pu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In voltage regulator modules (VRMs), rapid switching of field-effect transistors (FETs) produces fast voltage and current transients, generating significant noise. This noise can couple to other power networks, degrading power integrity, while coupling paths are often difficult to be determined due to the complexity of the power delivery system from chip to board. To address this issue, the coupling electromagnetic energy density is proposed for visualizing noise coupling paths. This method is applied in a practical case where the system includes multiple power domains, and the coupling path is successfully identified. After localizing the sensitive area for coupling, targeted layout optimization for noise suppression is proposed. Both coupling path visualization and noise suppression strategies are verified by simulation and measurement.

title: Quantum Nanoplasmonics for Enhanced Coherence and Single-Photon Detection
authors: O. Hess
abstract: Plasmonic nanoresonators confine fields far below diffraction limits, significantly enhancing optical fields and enabling robust room-temperature quantum coherence. Leveraging these engineered plasmonic environments advances ultrasensitive quantum sensing and substantially improves singlephoton detection, critical for scalable quantum technology applications.

title:
Hydrogen-Terminated Diamond MOSFETs with 10
