title: Single-ended Fault Location Method Based on Control Characteristics of Inverter-Based Resources for Low-frequency Transmission System
authors: Jiaheng Jiang, Guobing Song, Chenhao Zhang, Wenbin Cao, Yutao Qiu, Shuiyao Chen
abstract: Accurate fault location is crucial for power system emergency repair. However, the existing fault analysis-based fault location methods for the outgoing line of inverter-based resources use the traditional synchronous generator-based source model as the remote-end source model. The reliance on traditional source characteristics limits the adaptability of these methods in low-frequency transmission system (LFTS) used for offshore wind farm integration, where both ends of the system are inverter-based resource. Therefore, a novel fault location method is proposed for LFTS, which incorporates the source equations and fault network equations. Firstly, the source equations of LFTS are derived from control characteristics, while the network equations are derived from sequence networks and fault boundary conditions. Then, the fault location is converted into an optimization problem. The constrains of source equations, network equations and actual measured values are integrated in the objective functions, thereby the fault distance and fault resistance can be identified by solving optimization problem. Finally, the performance of proposed fault location method is verified in PSCAD/EMTDC. The proposed fault location method exhibits an error of less than 1% in most cases, with a maximum error of less than 4%, and a fault resistance tolerability up to 300 Ω.

title: Robust Power Management: A Key Aspect of SDC-free Systems
authors: Pradip Bose, Ramon Bertran, Alper Buyuktosunoglu, Hans M. Jacobson, Karthik Swaminathan, Matthias Pflanz, Charles F. Webb, Tobias Webel, Christian Jacobi
abstract: Silent data corruption (SDC) is a term that has created a specter of doubt and fear amongst the information community in recent years. In this position paper, we focus our attention on the problem of power management and the need for vigilance in ensuring SDC-free functionality in future power-constrained processor systems.

title: Low-Ripple Modulation Strategy for a Photovoltaic-Based Triple-Port Hydrogen Production System
authors: Shiqi Zhang, Ziang Jiao, Jiaxin Su, Ning Wang, Zheng Li, Xiaoqiang Guo, Changchun Hua
abstract: Among various production methods, hydrogen generation via electrolysis powered by renewable energy plays a key role in achieving large-scale green hydrogen production. The triple active bridge isolated dc–dc conversion system exhibits significant application potential in hydrogen production due to its advantages, such as high energy density, wide step-down ratio, and high reliability. However, the output current ripple at the hydrogen production port critically affects the efficiency of the electrolyzer and the hydrogen production rate. Existing studies have limited optimization effects on current ripple and struggle to achieve dynamic optimization, leading to constrained ripple suppression under dynamic operating conditions. To address this issue, this article proposes a low-ripple modulation strategy based on coordinated optimization of inner and outer phase-shift angles for multiport power conversion systems in renewable energy hydrogen production. By establishing an accurate mathematical model, the optimal phase-shift angle combination under minimal current ripple conditions is derived. An improved differential evolution algorithm with adaptive parameter strategy is employed to achieve global optimization under dynamic conditions. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed strategy effectively suppresses current ripple, providing an efficient and reliable solution for hydrogen production from fluctuating renewable energy sources.

title: Research on the Application of LLM for Electric-carbon-specific Question and Answer System
authors: Cuiling Jia, Qiming Wan, Zitian Liu, Hongrui Wang, Chenxi Fu, Qi Yao, Xin Shi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: With the increase of global energy demand, carbon emissions have drawn widespread attention. A vast and complex body of domain knowledge has emerged as the relationship between electricity consumption and carbon emissions grows increasingly complex. Consequently, there is a growing demand across sectors for intelligent services related to energy and carbon. Large language models (LLMs), with their powerful natural language understanding and generation capabilities, offer a promising foundation to meet these challenges. To enhance the accuracy and domain relevance of LLMs in the carbon field, we introduce a retrieval augmented generation framework that integrates both structured and unstructured carbon-related knowledge. The performance in the domains of energy, electricity, and carbon of the developed question and answer system is validated through testing and evaluation. The system is capable of extracting information from unstructured files and generating text that incorporates accurate details, ultimately supporting the development of intelligent and reliable electric-carbon-related services.

title: FPGA-Accelerated Computational Photon Counting
authors: Chiby Onyeador, Janet E. Sorrells
abstract: We present an FPGA-accelerated approach to computational photon counting for multiphoton fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy. We implement an encoding scheme that reduces data transfer bottlenecks by compressing photon count information. Our method maintains temporal precision while increasing throughput, enabling faster acquisition for observing biological dynamics.

title: Terahertz Demethylation for Cancer Therapy
authors: Joo-Hiuk Son
abstract: DNA methylation is one of the earliest epigenetic events that can drive carcinogenesis, often preceding genetic alterations. Aberrant methylation patterns are frequently observed in tumors. We show that terahertz (THz) radiation can both detect abnormal methylation signatures through spectroscopic resonance and reduce methylation levels when applied at resonant frequencies. This suggests a promising optical route for cancer diagnosis, regulation of epigenetic states, and therapeutic intervention.

title: A Clustering Representation Method for Battery Energy Storage
authors: Xiaogang Li, Ming Wu, Fei Du, Bin Zou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: This article proposes a representation method for battery clustering. This method can reduce the number of dynamic equations for battery energy storage state in the unit combination model that includes battery energy storage, thereby the computation time for solving the problem is reduced. The data verification results based on the IEEE-RTS-97 system show that the method proposed in this paper can reduce the calculation time of the traditional model from 4.74 seconds to 1.12 seconds, and the improvement is very significant.

title: Optimal Sitting and Sizing of Renewable Energy Sources and Electric Vehicle Charging Stations in Smart Grids Using Different Optimization Techniques
authors: B Hariprasad Associate Professor, G Sreenivasan, P Bharath Kumar, P Sujatha, Venkatasivanagaraju S, Anil Kumar Sambugari
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: This paper presents an adaptive hybrid optimization framework for siting and sizing renewable energy sources and EV charging stations in smart grids. Building upon Genetic Algorithm (GA), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and fuzzy logic, our method dynamically adjusts algorithm parameters in response to grid variability, improving convergence and solution quality. We enhance robustness by modeling uncertainties (e.g., traffic and charging demand fluctuations) and conduct comprehensive sensitivity analyses. Statistical validation through repeated trials and ANOVA demonstrates the significant superiority of our approach over traditional static hybrids.

title: Identifying Linux Kernel Instability Due to Poor RCU Synchronization
authors: Oisin O’Sullivan, Eoin O’Connell, Colin Flanagan
abstract: Read-Copy-Update (RCU) is widely used in the Linux kernel to manage concurrent access to shared data structures. However, improper synchronization when removing RCU-protected hash table entries can lead to stale pointers, inconsistent lookups, and critical use-after-free (UAF) vulnerabilities. This paper investigates a driver-level synchronization issue arising from the omission of explicit synchronize_rcu() calls during hash table updates, using a discovered weakness in the Intel® ICE network driver’s Virtual Function (VF) management. Previous kernel vulnerabilities, such as a bug in the Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) subsystem, show how improper RCU synchronization can directly cause kernel crashes. Experimental results demonstrate that removing VF entries without proper synchronization leaves transient stale entries, delays memory reclamation, and results in significant memory fragmentation under rapid insert/delete workloads. RCU hash tables are widely deployed in Linux kernel subsystems such as networking, virtualization, and file systems; improper synchronization can cause memory fragmentation, kernel instability, and out-of-memory (OOM) conditions. Mitigations are proposed, recommending explicit insertion of synchronize_rcu() calls to ensure timely and safe memory reclamation. These findings reinforce established best practices for RCU synchronization, highlighting their importance for maintaining kernel stability and memory safety.

title: The Impact of Nonlinear Satellite Channels on the Performance of 5G Waveforms and Compensation Techniques
authors: Ruiying Shi, Ying Zhou, Yingnan Zhang, Jiahe Ye
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: With the escalating demand for high throughput and low latency in 5 G communication systems, high-power amplifiers (HPAs) in satellite communication links exhibit significant nonlinear characteristics during broadband $\mathbf{5 G}$ waveform transmission (e.g., OFDM, FBMC), leading to signal distortion, spectral regrowth, and out-of-band radiation degradation. This paper proposes a digital predistortion (DPD) technique based on the Volterra series memory polynomial (MP) model, integrated with deep learning architectures (LSTM, BiLSTM, and self-attention mechanisms) for nonlinear compensation optimization. By employing an indirect learning architecture (ILA) and reverse modeling methodology to extract the nonlinear inverse characteristics of the power amplifier, the proposed approach significantly reduces the parameter complexity inherent in conventional DPD methods. Experimental results demonstrate that the self-attention enhanced neural network model effectively suppresses both in-band distortion and out-of-band spectral regrowth, thereby optimizing signal linearization output.

title: Review on the Effects and Management of DC Bias Caused by Leakage Current into Power Grids
authors: Mingwei Tang, Shuai Zhang, Xinting Yang, Lin Zhang, Yuqi Han, Liyang Liu, Wei Chen, Gang Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Urban rail transit has the advantages of being fast, efficient, and pollution-free, and presents the development trend of large-scale and high-speed in China. With the rapid development of urban rail transit, the DC bias of transformers brought by the invasion of metro stray current into the power grid is becoming more and more prominent, endangering the safe and stable operation of the power system. The causes of DC bias are mainly related to the high voltage DC grounding pole, geomagnetic storms and metro systems. However, the generation and characteristics of stray current in the power grid are very different from the first two. Considering the increasingly close coupling of stray currents between metro and power grids, stray currents in power grids deserve the attention of urban power grid planners. This paper firstly clarifies the mechanism of stray current invasion in urban power grids; secondly, it analyzes the effects and characteristics of DC bias of transformers under the action of stray currents, and puts forward the shortcomings of the existing research; finally, it summarizes and looks forward to the corresponding research progress for the management of stray currents in two categories of source-end and receiver-end. The research results can provide theoretical and technical references for the engineering management of stray currents in power grids.

title: Real-time Unsupervised Denoising for Ophthalmic Robotic Optical Coherence Tomography
authors: Renxiong Wu, Guangming Ni
abstract: Optical coherence tomography (OCT) enables noninvasive three-dimensional high-resolution imaging. Ophthalmic robotic OCT extends this capability to acquire retinal volumes in emergency and surgical settings by actively tracking the subject's eye. High-quality denoised images provide intraoperative navigation and scan path planning for both the operator and the robot. However, conventional denoising algorithms remain computationally burdensome, limiting their integration into low-latency robotic systems. Here, we distilled a lightweight denoising network and integrated it into a graphics processing unit to accelerate a robotic OCT system, enabling highperformance real-time denoising of OCT images.

title: A Condition-Guided Motion Generation Framework for a Rat-Like Robot
authors: Changwen Dong, Guanglu Jia, Dixuan Jiang, Zhiqiang Yu, Tao Sun, Qing Shi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Realistic generation of animal-like motion is essential for natural robot-animal interactions, which provide valuable insights into animal behavior research. However, existing approaches often rely on imitation using low-dimensional action steps or motion primitives, which are not effective in capturing the characteristics and diversity of behaviors. In this paper, we propose a condition-guided motion generation framework for a rat-like robot called SMuRo. To model motion distributions at the sequence level, a freely behaving rat dataset is first retargeted to a robot motion dataset. We then design a transformer-based diffusion model that employs cross-attention mechanisms for condition injection. The model directly predicts motion samples and integrates kinematics-based loss functions, enabling the generation of stable motions for robotic execution. Using the nose tip activity area as the condition, we perform repeated conditional motion generation and conduct clustering analysis. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework generates motions that exhibit both diversity and biomimetic characteristics. In common nose tip activity areas, the framework achieves a motion generation success rate of 80 %. This work contributes to improving the biological compatibility of robots within animal groups.

title: Potential of Hollow-Core Fibers in Power-Constrained Submarine Networks
authors: A. Carbo Meseguer
abstract: We assess the viability of hollow-core fibers for submarine transmission under power constraints. Using a GSNR-based model, we compare future cable designs at transatlantic and transpacific distances. Results highlight that attenuation reduction outperforms SDM scaling at ultra-long distances, reinforcing the importance of power-efficient technologies.

title: High-Speed 100 Gbps Traveling-Wave (TW) Electro-Absorption Modulator Laser (EML) Using Ridge-Type Waveguide
authors: Tzu-I Hsieh, Zhen-Hua Wang, Bo-Hong Chen, Rih-You Chen, Shou-Ming Chen, Wei Lin, Yi-Jen Chiu
abstract: A high-speed traveling-wave (TW) electroabsorption modulator laser (EML) using a ridge-type waveguide and low-dielectric-constant BCB cladding structure has been demonstrated to promote impedance matching in TWEAM. 500 hm termination on TWEAM with >10dBm optical power, >60GHz bandwidth, 100 Gbps PAM4 eye diagram has been shown.

title: Coated Phase-Shifted Fiber Bragg Grating Pressure Sensor for High-Sensitivity Heart Rate Monitoring
authors: Yuxuan Liu, Yuting Zhou, Simeng Li, Feiyu Jiao, Yansong Du, Xun Guan
abstract: We demonstrate, for the first time, a coated PhaseShifted Fiber Bragg Grating pressure sensor for noninvasive heart rate monitoring, which exhibits <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 5 9 8 ~ d B / k P a}$</tex> sensitivity. In the 80 -second heart rate test, the result of our sensor is 65 bpm, showing a 96 % consistency with PPG result, offering a new method for wearable heart rate detection.

title: Broadband Frequency Selective Surface with Improved Amplitude and Phase Consistency for High-Incidence Angle Applications
authors: Yuqing Sun, Da Li, Wang Bao, Erping Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A novel three-layer broadband Frequency Selective Surface (FSS) is proposed for circularly-polarized antenna radomes that must maintain stringent amplitude and phase integrity at extreme incidence angles. By deliberately breaking rotational symmetry and separately tailoring the TE and TM modes with complementary capacitive patches and inductive strips , the structure equalizes the inherently opposite trends of characteristic admittance and phase slope in both polarizations. Full-Wave simulations demonstrate a 40 % fractional passband (8–12 GHz) with insertion loss <1 dB, amplitude difference <0.15 dB, and relative phase difference <30° for incidence angles between 75° and 80°. The design thus simultaneously delivers wideband transparency and high polarization purity, offering a practical solution for next-generation wide-scanning circularly-polarized arrays.

title: Ultra-Wideband Metasurface Absorbers with Programmable Features for Electromagnetic Compatibility and Shielding Applications
authors: Jun Wei Zhang, Wanwan Cao, Zhen Jie Qi, Hui Dong Li, Jun Yan Dai, Qiang Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Electromagnetic (EM) shielding technologies have garnered significant global attention from researchers, representing a cutting-edge research focus. Conventional devices are limited by their singular functionality, typically addressing either absorbing or reflecting requirements. Here, we propose an innovative programmable metasurface with the capable of dynamic absorption modulation. The designed metasurface absorber can flexibly manipulate the reflection amplitude attenuation ranging from 1 to 15 dB across 5.5-13.5 GHz with the aid of integrated PIN diodes. We have fabricated a metasurface absorber prototype with the scale of 37×11 units and measured its EM losses. Experimental results demonstrate good agreement with simulation data. To evaluate its absorption characteristics under conformal conditions, we have conducted the EM loss measurements with the fabricated conformal prototype. The good results validate its dynamic EM absorbing capabilities, demonstrating substantial potential to drive technological innovation in EM absorbing applications.

title: Analysis of User Experience in the Blood Donor Information System Using the User Experience Questionnaire Plus (UEQ+) and Usability Testing: A Case Study at RSUD Dr. Moewardi
authors: Muhammad Fahman Yusuf, Widyanida Amalia Pramesti, Pebry Putri Pratiwi, Sunardi Sunardi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: The Dr. Moewardi Hospital in Surakarta Central Java needs more than 2,000 blood bags monthly. The hospital created SINORAH (Blood Donor Information System of RSUD Dr. Moewardi) as a digital platform to help with donor screening and support blood donation efforts. This study aims to assess the user experience of SINORAH and to identify areas for improvement using a mixed-method approach. The User Experience Questionnaire Plus (UEQ+) was used to collect data from 104 participants while usability testing was conducted with 8 participants. The results of the UEQ+ showed that the system was perceived as useful (2.34), perspicuous (2.01), efficient (1.99), and attractive (1.93) by the users. The Trust dimension scored the lowest (1.81), which reflects the concerns about data security. The usability testing showed that the overall task success rate was 85.9%, but the updating WhatsApp number tasks had higher error rates and the data entry for old users is repetitive. The average user satisfaction was 3.55 out of 5. The recommendations are presented in the form of user interface (UI) redesigns. This research contributes to academics by giving insights into user experience evaluation using a mixed-method approach combining UEQ+ and Usability Testing. In practice, this research provides recommendations for improving the system’s usability and user experience, potentially increasing donor participation and supporting blood supply availability in hospitals.

title: Ontology Model for Lombok Tourism Knowledge System Using Apache Jena Fuseki
authors: Helna Wardhana, Hartono Wijaya, Husain, Kartarina, Suriyati, Rini Anggriani
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Lombok Island is one of Indonesia's premier tourist destinations, renowned for its natural beauty and cultural richness. However, tourism information in Lombok is still fragmented and difficult to access in a structured manner, thus hindering tourists in planning their trips. This research aims to develop a semantic web-based tourism information system to address the issue by presenting tourism data accurately, efficiently, and contextually. The method used is Methontology, which includes the stages of specification, conceptualization, formalization, implementation, and maintenance. The research results show that this system can represent Lombok's tourism knowledge in an ontology that includes tourist destinations and is capable of displaying relevant information through a semantic web interface. This system not only facilitates tourists in accessing information but also serves as a foundation for the development of a more modern and sustainable tourism information infrastructure in the future. However, challenges such as dynamic tourism data, limited structured sources, and local terminology complexity remain, requiring continuous updates to ensure system relevance and accuracy.

title: Uncertainty-Decoupled Active Learning for Annotation-Efficient Deep Face Recognition
authors: Qiang Huang, Jianchong Su, Wenlian Huang, Zhuangzhuang Chen, Yijing Huang, Lei Yang, Jianqiang Li, Jie Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Despite the substantial progress of deep models for face recognition, it still struggles in efficiently developing face recognition models, due to the high costs and low efficiency of the annotation process. Existing representation learning methods (e.g.CNN-based pre-trained models) are good at extracting features but struggle to disentangle multi-modal facial attributes, leading to entangled uncertainty estimation in latent spaces and biased uncertainty estimation in active learning. Traditional confidence metrics are prone to prediction smoothing in fine-grained tasks, limiting the effectiveness of active sampling. Considering this, this paper proposes the Uncertainty-decoupled Active Learning framework (UDAL), which synergizes variational uncertainty disentanglement with Monte Carlo mutual information (MI)-based sampling for efficient feature extraction and precise uncertainty quantification. To achieve this, UDAL employs the Variational Autoencoder in a co-training manner to enhance the discriminability of latent features. Then, Bayesian MI estimation can be realized via Monte Carlo dropout explicitly distinguishes epistemic uncertainty from aleatoric uncertainty, prioritizing annotation of semantically ambiguous samples. Our experiment results demonstrate that our proposed method achieves a 2.20% performance gain over the existing SOTA active learning methods on the MRFD face dataset.

title: Improving TS-PDV Accuracy Through Systematic Non-Ideality Quantification and Mitigation
authors: Deenabandhan, Mandeep Singh, Lakshmi Narasimhan Theagarajan, Deepa Venkitesh
abstract: We present a time-stretched photon Doppler velocimetry (TS-PDV) system covering <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.5 \text{km} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7 \text{km} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> with sixfold bandwidth reduction. Displacement compensation reduces frequency error by 20 MHz, keeping it below 100 MHz when probe power exceeds <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.5 \mu \mathrm{W}$</tex> and spectral width is under 15 nm.

title: Evaluation and Combination of XGBoost, Artificial Neural Network, and Fuzzy Models for Credit Card Payment Default Classification
authors: Bq Nadila Nuzululnisa, Dadang Priyanto, Raisul Azhar, Suriyati Suriyati, Muhamad Wisnu Alfiansyah, Mitranikasih Laia
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Credit card default is a major risk in banking, causing significant financial losses and instability. This study evaluates and combines three classification models Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), Artificial Neural Network), and Fuzzy using the UCI Credit Card dataset with 30,000 records and 25 features. The data were preprocessed through normalization, irrelevant feature removal, and split into 80% training and 20% testing. Model performance was assessed with Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1-score, and AUC. Results show that XGBoost achieved the highest accuracy (95.61%, AUC = 0.95), Fuzzy obtained the highest recall (0.94), while ANN reached perfect precision (1.00). The hybrid Artificial Neural Networks-Xgboost model provided a balanced trade-off between precision and recall, whereas Artificial Neural Networks-Fuzzy performed the weakest. These findings highlight that XGBoost is the most effective model for accuracy, Fuzzy is more sensitive in detecting defaults, and Artificial Neural Networks-Xgboost offers a practical balance for credit risk management. Future improvements may involve data balancing techniques such as SMOTE to enhance sensitivity to minority cases.

title: Simulation and Testing Key Issues and Rectification Practices of Grid-connected Distributed Energy Storage Systems
authors: Guangkun Ming, Xiqiang Chang, Yizhi Tian
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: This paper addresses the stability challenges associated with high-penetration renewable energy grids, with particular emphasis on key engineering issues related to grid-forming energy storage systems. Based on multiple demonstration projects conducted in Kezhou, Xinjiang, Shache, and other locations, the study systematically conducts electromagnetic transient modeling simulations and field tests. These analyses reveal 12 typical problems categorized into four major areas: insufficient model compatibility and accuracy, flawed control strategies and logic, dynamic response and stability deficiencies, and improper strategy configuration. In response to these issues, a set of systematic solutions has been developed and implemented: at the model level, the user-defined (UD) module was reconfigured to a standardized 50-μs simulation step, and the inertia-damping coefficient matching relationship was optimized using Lyapunov stability theory, achieving a dynamic error convergence of 0.1pu; at the control level, the fault judgment logic threshold was adjusted to ensure compliance with reactive power support standards, and control strategies and logic were unified to meet dynamic response requirements; symmetrical and asymmetrical current limits were standardized to 3.0pu, and the accuracy of sequence component calculations was improved through the adoption of an enhanced double dq rotating coordinate system; at the strategy configuration level, voltage dead zones were eliminated and reactive power limits were extended to 3.0pu to enhance grid support capability. Additionally, the rectification cycle was shortened through coordinated project management. All proposed solutions were validated through electromagnetic transient simulations, hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) tests, and on-site artificial short-circuit tests. The results demonstrate that the reactive power support rate reaches 100%, the amplitude of power fluctuations is reduced by 75%, and oscillation risks are completely eliminated. These improvements significantly enhance the fault ride-through and grid support performance of grid-forming equipment. Furthermore, the reusable technical framework and practical engineering experience derived from this study provide critical support for the large-scale deployment of the new power system and contribute to the stable operation of high-penetration renewable energy grids under the "dual-carbon" strategy.

title: Integration of AI-Augmented CloudOps with EAM and IT4IT: A Strategic–Operational Framework for Intelligent Cloud Infrastructure Management
authors: Maryam Mayabi Joghal, Alireza Shameli-Sendi
publish: 2025 9th Iranian Conference on Advances in Enterprise Architecture (ICAEA)
abstract: In the era of digital transformation, Enterprise Architecture Management (EAM) must evolve from a static blueprint into a dynamic framework that strategically integrates emerging technologies across the IT lifecycle. This paper examines the role of intelligent Cloud Operations (AI-Augmented CloudOps) in linking EAM with the IT4IT operating model. First, AI-Augmented CloudOps is viewed as an operational capability in the Detect-to-Correct value stream, using AI to enable predictive monitoring, failure detection, and self-healing. Second, it is treated as a digital product whose lifecycle spans all four IT4IT value streams. The proposed model was implemented in a real-world organization, where OpenStack and Ceph-based automation enabled secure and sovereign cloud deployment with continuous architectural compliance. The system automatically generates optimized architecture recommendations based on existing organizational assets and performs fully offline and automated deployment. The results demonstrate significant reductions in incident response time, downtime, and operational costs. Moreover, the model enables the delivery of stable, secure, and governance-compliant digital services— particularly critical in highly regulated industries—while also addressing challenges such as technical complexity, the need for specialized expertise, and ensuring security in offline environments.

title: Optimizing Persistent Fault-Based Collision Attacks via Collision Differential Analysis
authors: Yaqi Zhang, Hongxin Zhang, Xing Fang, Yuanzhen Wang, Hua Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Fault attacks, as a major form of side-channel attacks, exploit induced errors to compromise cryptographic systems. Persistent fault analysis (PFA) introduces long-lasting faults that affect multiple encryption rounds. PFCA combines PFA with collision analysis for efficient key recovery under random fault conditions. Yet, existing models rely on redundant plaintexts, reducing practicality. Addressing the bottlenecks of high complexity and excessive resource consumption, this paper innovatively proposes collision differential (ΔP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">col</inf>) and cross-collision differential (ΔP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">cross</inf>) theoretical models within the PFCA framework to systematically optimize attack efficiency. Through theoretical modeling and experimental validation, hierarchical optimization strategies are established for single-fault (nf=1) and multi-fault (nf=2) scenarios: 1) Under single-fault injection, ΔP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">col</inf> reduces plaintext requirements by over 40% (for single-byte S-boxes) through fault-collision mapping relationships; 2) For dual-fault injection, combined multi-level correlation analysis via ΔP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">cross</inf> further decreases attack complexity by 65% (single-byte S-boxes). This research not only provides an efficient implementation pathway for PFCA, but also establishes theoretical foundations for physical security evaluation and fault-tolerant design of cryptographic algorithms.

title: Real-Time Jumping Trajectory Optimization and Control for Wheeled Biped Robots
authors: Haoyang Yu, Xu Li, Shiqi Guan, Haibo Feng, Songyuan Zhang, Yili Fu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: As a fundamental motion mode of legged robots, jumping can significantly enhance their mobility and terrain adaptability. However, due to the high mobility involved, jumping places stringent demands on real-time trajectory planning. This paper presents a real-time jumping trajectory planning and control method for wheeled biped robots (WBRs). A dual-mass spring (DMS) model is employed to simplify the description of the robot's jumping dynamic behavior and decouples the planning in the vertical and horizontal directions. By solving two nonlinear programming (NLP) problems, the spring parameters in each motion phase and the center of mass (CoM) motion sequence in the horizontal direction are optimized, generating a jump trajectory with precise control over both height and distance. The proposed method can significantly reduce the dimensionality of the optimization variables, thereby improving solution efficiency. Whole-body control is then applied for trajectory tracking. Experimental validation on a human-scale WBR demonstrates the successful achievement of stable jumping.

title: Response Characterization of High Power Microwave Impulse Interference Shielding Efficiency of Carbon-Based Materials
authors: Jun Chen, Shiyue Wu, Wei Song, Jianjing Zhou, Xiaosong Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The wide application of new weapons such as high-power microwaves urgently requires effective electromagnetic protection for electronic equipment. The existing electromagnetic shielding materials, such as carbon-based materials only in the low-field environment to explore the shielding performance of the material, ignoring the high-field environment such as high power microwave electromagnetic protection of electronic equipment, failing to form an effective electromagnetic protection against high-field environment. Hence, this study was carried out to characterize the response of the shielding effectiveness of graphene materials for a high-power microwave environment with a field strength of 20,000 V/m, using frequency and thickness as the study variables. The results indicated that the shielding effectiveness of graphene films showed a decreasing trend with increasing frequency at the same thickness. The shielding effectiveness of graphene film at the same frequency increases gradually with the increase in thickness. The study can provide simulation and theoretical support for the preparation of high-performance electromagnetic protective materials in high field strength environments.

title: Performance Testing of the Backpropagation Method in Predicting Carbon Dioxide Emissions Based on Root Mean Square Error and Mean Absolute Error Results
authors: Christofer Satria, Lilik Widyawati, Anthony Anggrawan, Peter Wijaya Sugijanto, Aprillia Dwi Dayani, I Putu Hariyadi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions are a type of gas that is highly detrimental to the environment, accounting for up to 80% of total global greenhouse gas emissions. Therefore, it is not surprising that researchers recognize the need to conduct immediate research on CO2 emissions. Besides that, making predictions without using intelligent tools often results in wrong decisions. In the meantime, Backpropagation has gained widespread use for prediction as one of the algorithms that exhibits intelligence. In turn, research on CO2 is a significant research challenge today. That is why this research aims to predict CO2 emissions using the Backpropagation method, based on the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE). The findings of this study revealed that the CO2 gas emission prediction had an RMSE of 0.063 and an MAE of 0.032. These findings indicate that the proposed model in this study can predict well, with no significant signs of overfitting, and yields a prediction result with low error.

title: Span-Resolved Polarization Sensing in Submarine Telecom Cables with PDG and PDL
authors: Hui Dong, Hailiang Zhang, Dora Juan Juan Hu
abstract: The measurement approach is proposed to realize the crosstalk-free span-resolved polarization sensing in submarine telecom cables with polarization dependent gain and loss. The validity of the proposed approach is confirmed by simulation results.

title: COMSOL-Based Simulation and Optimization of Microwave Cavity for Coffee Roasting
authors: Junxi Zhu, Chenxi Zhao, Yun Ma, Xueying Li, Qiuping Mi, Dezhi Gou
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This study focuses on microwave systems in food processing, with emphasis on coffee bean roasting. Through electromagnetic field and heat conduction simulations using COMSOL Multiphysics software, the effects of different microwave power levels, cavity structures, and stirring mechanisms on the temperature distribution of coffee beans were analyzed. The simulation results show that the design of a cubic cavity with dimensions of 150 × 150 × 150 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">³</sup>, a heating cylindrical container with a radius of 55 mm and a height of 88 mm, combined with the stirring mechanism, can effectively reduce the temperature gradient and improve roasting uniformity. This provides a theoretical basis for the microwave roasting process.

title: Lessons Learnt from Expert-Centred Studies Exploring Opportunities and Challenges for Immersive Forensic Investigation
authors: Vahid Pooryousef, Tim Dwyer, Richard Bassed, Maxime Cordeil, Lonni Besançon
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Engaging Critical Workforce In co-Design aNd Assessment (ECWIDNA)
abstract: Research studies involving human participants present challenges, including strict ethical considerations, participant recruitment, costs, and many human factors. While human-computer interaction researchers are familiar with these challenges and current solutions, expert-centred studies can be even more challenging in ways that researchers may not anticipate. This issue is particularly important as research grants are increasingly based on practical and real-world problems, which necessitate close collaboration with experts. In this paper, we reflect on and discuss the challenges, solutions, and specific requirements that arose during our expert-centred studies conducted over three years of a PhD study exploring immersive forensic investigation.

title: High-Sensitivity Bimodal Waveguide Sensor Based on Dispersion Turning Point
authors: Rui Li, Jiewen Li, Wanxin Li, Zheng Cao, Fatao Chen, Weiming Yao, Yong Yao, Yongkang Dong, Xiaochuan Xu
abstract: This paper presents a high-sensitivity bimodal waveguide sensor based on a dispersion turning point (DTP), realized through a fishbone-like bimodal waveguide (BiMW) design. Experimental validation confirms a maximum sensitivity of 10666.7 nm/RIU, indicating strong promise for integrated optical sensing applications.

title: Microwave Photonic Probe for Magnetic Field Sensing
authors: Kai Pan, Junkai Dong, Chujun Wu, Liwei Li, Xiaoyi Tian, Linh Nguyen, Xiaoke Yi
abstract: We report a microwave photonic probe for magnetic field sensing, integrating a selectively coated microdisk resonator and two-dimensional grating coupler to mitigate polarization dependency, achieving over 1355-fold resolution bandwidth improvement, and a notch rejection ratio exceeding 50 dB.

title: Adaptive Robust Swift and Accurate Formation Control of UAV Swarm System Based on Constraint-Following
authors: Jiawen Dai, Zheshuo Zhang, Bangji Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: To accomplish more complex tasks, multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) often operate in formation, making the formation control of UAV swarm systems a focal point of research. Due to the inherent nonlinearity and uncertainties in UAV swarm systems, formation control remains challenging, particularly when swift and accurate formation (SAF) is required. This article proposes a constraint-following-based adaptive robust swift and accurate formation control (ARSAFC) for UAV swarm systems, which accounts for unknown time-varying uncertainties. The UAV swarm system is modeled as an artificial swarm, where ideal swarm behavior serves as the target equality constraint for formation. The formation control problem is then converted into a constraint-following problem. To meet the SAF requirements, user-defined hard-limit functions are introduced, and the SAF requirements are formulated as inequality constraints. A diffeomorphism approach is adopted to uniformly transform both classes of constraints into new equality constraints. An adaptive robust control strategy is introduced to handle uncertainties, featuring an adaptive law that online estimates the bounds of uncertainties and counteracts their influence. The proposed formation control approach is validated for robustness and effectiveness via rigorous proofs and simulations.

title: Dynamic Control of Guiding Wave Amplitude and Phase Using PIN-Diode-Loaded Spoof Plasmonic Metasurfaces
authors: Dawei Zhang, Yaxiu Sun, Kuang Zhang, Yingsong Li, Tao Jiang, Shah Nawaz Burokur
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper proposes an active spoof plasmonic metasurface for dynamically controlling the amplitude and phase of electromagnetic (EM) guiding waves. By integrating PIN diodes, the system can dynamically alternate among various modes. A comprehensive investigation into the dispersion properties and transmission characteristics of these diodes in different states was undertaken to elucidate the fundamental theory and method. The guiding wave amplitude and phase can be manipulated in real time when the diodes are switched between ON and OFF states. For amplitude control, the propagating waves transition from bandpass (ON state) to bandstop (OFF state) characteristics. The measured -3 dB passband ranges from 3 to 8.1 GHz, while the measured -10 dB stopband ranges from 3.7 to 5.6 GHz. As for phase control, the measured dual-band phase shifts range from 192° to 203° and 248° to 292° in the 3.1-3.4 GHz and 6.1-9.4 GHz frequency bands, respectively. The demonstrated ability to control both amplitude and phase opens up possibilities for tunable SSPPs in advanced multifunctional microwave devices.

title: Evaluating the Physics and Repeatability of Human Brushers in Delivering Affective Touch
authors: Zackary T. Landsman, Matthew Clark, Seongkook Heo, Afsaneh Doryab, Gregory J. Gerling
abstract: Research in affective touch often utilizes a pleasant stroking paradigm, with touch typically delivered at velocities between 0.3-30 cm/s and forces about 0.4 N. These values are derived from perceptual and physiological responses of touch receivers rather than natural behaviors of touchers. Herein, we observe untrained touchers in delivering pleasant touch as gentle strokes to a receiver's forearm through high-resolution force and position measurement using an instrumented brush. Twenty participants delivered about eleven strokes in each of five trials, yielding data on stroke velocity, force, duration, and length. The cohort deployed forces (0.37 N ± 0.24, 2 SD) near 0.4 N, but stroking velocities (13.7 cm/s ± 8.8, 2 SD) slightly higher than typically considered “optimal” (1-10 cm/s). We observed no correlation between stroke force and velocity, which led us to consider these factors jointly in characterizing an individual's brushing strategy. Moreover, while the cohort of participants exhibited a compact range of forces and velocities, individuals tended to occupy only subsets of this range with high repeatability across trials. Altogether, the findings suggest a need to further evaluate the velocity range between 10-30 cm/s and to jointly consider force, velocity, and consistency in characterizing an individual's brushing strategy.

title: Data-Driven Deployment of Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces in Cellular Networks
authors: Sina Beyraghi, Javad Shabanpour, Giovanni Geraci, Paul Almasan, Angel Lozano
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: This paper presents a fully automated, data-driven framework for the large-scale deployment of reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) in cellular networks. Leveraging physically consistent ray tracing and empirical data from a commercial deployment in the UK, the proposed method jointly optimizes RIS placement, orientation, configuration, and base station beamforming in dense urban environments across frequency bands (corresponding to 4G, 5G, and a hypothetical 6G system). Candidate RIS locations are identified via reflection- and scattering-based heuristics using calibrated electromagnetic models within the Sionna Ray Tracing (RT) engine. Outage users are clustered to reduce deployment complexity, and the tradeoff between coverage gains and infrastructure cost is systematically evaluated. It is shown that achieving meaningful coverage improvement in urban areas requires a dense deployment of large-aperture RIS units, raising questions about cost-effectiveness. To facilitate reproducibility and future research, the complete simulation framework and RIS deployment algorithms are provided as opensource software.

title: Leveraging Domain-Specific Features for High-Performance Obstacle Classification in Railway Monitoring
authors: Luca Eisentraut, Merlin Schadt, Christopher Mai, Walter Koehn, Ricardo Buettner
abstract: Railway systems are among the most important transportation routes. Due to their vastness, limited evasion possibilities for trains, and their long braking distances, ensuring the safety of these networks is challenging and can be improved through the application of deep learning. While the localization of objects in the track bed is a common topic, the classification of obstacles is not yet solved robustly for all relevant classes at a high-performance level. This study proposes an architecture tailored to the specific characteristics of track bed images based on a ResNet-50 backbone, leveraging individual characteristics of those images (i.e. high frequency noise, repetitive textures) and significantly reducing misclassifications in this problem domain. Using a five-fold cross-validation and a dataset of 2,003 images in six classes, an average balanced accuracy of 99.26 % can be achieved, outperforming the baseline model (98.50 %) and thereby reducing misclassifications by approximately 46 %. We demonstrate that rather than increasing model complexity, leveraging domain-specific characteristics can lead to highest accuracies. This will enable the application of automatic railway surveillance in the future to ultimately enhance security.

title: Pareto-Optimal Frozen Set Design for Polar Codes with Dynamic Frozen Bits under Small-List SCL Decoding
authors: Vera Miloslavskaya
abstract: This paper focuses on low-complexity design of polar codes with high error-correction capability for 6G networks. We propose a novel frozen set design approach for polar codes with dynamic frozen bits that guarantees the best possible trade-offs between closed-form bounds on successive cancellation (SC) and maximum-likelihood (ML) decoding error probabilities, where the ML bound is the union bound parameterized by the ensemble-averaged weight distribution. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first method to generate Pareto-optimal frozen sets for these dual objectives. The low complexity of generating the frozen set Pareto front stems from our analysis of the bounds. Experimental results show that the resulting polar codes with dynamic frozen bits and near-uniformly distributed frozen bit expressions outperform the state-of-the-art codes under successive cancellation list (SCL) decoding with list sizes ranging from 2 to 16. These results suggest promising applications for next-generation wireless communication systems requiring both high reliability and computational efficiency.

title: A High-Power SPDT Switch with Resonant Isolation Based on GaAs BiFET Technology for Sub-6 GHz Front-End Modules
authors: Jaehyun Kwon, Jaeyong Lee, Jinho Yoo, Changkun Park
abstract: In this study, we present the design of a single-pole double-throw (SPDT) switch for Sub-6 GHz applications, implemented using a 500-nm GaAs BiFET process. To enhance power handling capability, multi-gate transistors are selectively employed. The frequency characteristics of return loss, insertion loss, and isolation are analyzed through an equivalent circuit model. Based on this analysis, we propose a design methodology that optimizes transistor on-resistance and parasitic capacitance for the target frequency range, thereby improving power handling, insertion loss, return loss, and isolation. The fabricated switch is evaluated across an operating frequency range of 3.0-5.0 GHz. In Tx mode, the input P1dB exceeds 38.1 dBm at 4.0 GHz. The measured insertion loss and isolation in Tx mode are below 0.38 dB and above 36.6 dB, respectively. In Rx mode, insertion loss remains below 0.38 dB, while isolation exceeds 35.0 dB.

title: Quantized Penalty Gradient Algorithm For Massive MIMO Systems with Low-Resolution ADCs
authors: Qiqiang Chen, Zheng Wang, Chenhao Qi, Feng Shu, Yongming Huang
abstract: In this paper, we propose a quantized penalty gradient (QPG) detection algorithm for massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems with low-resolution analog-to-digital converters (ADCs). To tackle the challenges of maximum likelihood (ML) detection under discrete constraints, we reformulate the detection problem into an unconstrained optimization by introducing two customized penalty functions that promote alignment between the estimated signals and target constellation set. Based on this, the QPG algorithm is developed to efficiently solve the resulting problem, achieving competitive detection performance with only second-order computational complexity. We further provide a theoretical analysis establishing the Lipschitz continuity of the objective function, which guarantees the monotonic descent property of QPG and ensures its convergence. Moreover, we prove that QPG efficiently finds the local minima with an accessible linear convergence rate, thus leading to an explicit trade-off between detection performance and computational complexity. Finally, simulation results confirm the significant performance gains of QPG over the conventional quantized detectors across various channel conditions, while maintaining low computational complexity.

title: Cooperative advertising in a sustainable supply chain: The role of government subsidies_supp1-3646488.docx
authors: Qian Zhao
abstract: Sustainable supply chain operations that emphasize environmental and social welfare have drawn significant attention. Supply chain members and governments are increasingly implementing incentive strategies to promote sustainability. This paper develops a game-theoretical model of a sustainable supply chain to examine the effectiveness of cooperative advertising under different government subsidy schemes. We consider that the supply chain consists of a green manufacturer and a retailer who sells a green product through advertising. The manufacturer can share advertising costs with the retailer, a strategy known as cooperative advertising, while the government can offer either the advertising subsidy or the consumption subsidy to support sustainability. Our analytical findings uncover that cooperative advertising may not always benefit the sustainable supply chain. Without the government subsidy, cooperative advertising is beneficial to the manufacturer, consumers, and the government only when the negative effect of cooperative advertising is mild; however, it is always detrimental to the retailer. In contrast, when a government subsidy is provided, not engaging in cooperative advertising is always superior. On the other hand, we find that government subsidies are always effective in facilitating sustainable supply chain operations, with the consumption subsidy outperforming the advertising subsidy. We further extend the model to explore the scenarios under (i) the manufacturer encroachment and (ii) a marginal advertising cost. We find the major findings remain valid in two extensions. This study not only contributes to the existing literature on sustainable supply chain management, but also offers practical insights for firms and governments to design incentive mechanisms.

title: Multi-Modal Generative AI for Scalable Synthetic Dataset Generation in Autonomous Vehicles: Advancements, Challenges and Opportunities in Intelligent Transportation Systems
authors: Sajid Hussain G, Akeel Ali G, Yen-Lin Chen, Belal Ahmad, Lip Yee Por
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) is emerging as a transformative tool for synthetic dataset generation in Advanced Driver-Assistance Systems (ADAS). Traditional Autonomous Vehicle (AV) datasets face high collection costs, limited edge-case diversity and scalability challenges, making alternative data generation approaches essential. This paper introduces an innovative application of multi-modal generative AI models for AV perception tasks with a focus on ADAS applications. Specifically, the study explores Text-to-Image (T2I), Text-to-Video (T2V), Image-to-Video (I2V), and Image-to-Image (I2I) models to generate high-fidelity data for object detection, segmentation, and trajectory prediction. Despite their promise, practical deployment is obstructed by prompt adherence failures, mode collapse, uncontrollability, domain adaptation inconsistencies, and computational inefficiencies. We provide a comparative evaluation of these models, benchmarking their realism, consistency and adaptability in bridging the synthetic-to-real gap and enhancing AV robustness. Experimental results highlight the strengths and limitations of different approaches, with insights into controllable data synthesis and improvements in real-time efficiency. Furthermore, YOLO models fine-tuned on generative AI-generated datasets achieve superior detection performance with GAI_YOLOv7 reaching 74.48% mAP and GAI_YOLOv8x achieving 76.16% mAP, outperforming VR-based models (29.76%, 23.44%).

title: Optimizing Transmit Power and Antenna Tilt Angle for Non-Terrestrial Networks
authors: Junhyeong Jo, Mingun Kim, Jemin Lee, Miyoung Yun, Junhwan Lee
abstract: In non-terrestrial networks (NTNs), the uptilted antenna for base stations (BSs) has been considered to serve most aerial users (AUs) with a main-lobe. However, an inappropriate antenna tilt angle can lead to severe interference from the BSs. In this letter, we jointly optimize the transmit power for each AU and antenna tilt angle for each sector to maximize the sum data rate. Specifically, we propose the parallel algorithm to determine the optimal power allocation and antenna tilt angle. Finally, we show the effect of antenna tilt angle and the superiority of the proposed scheme over the baselines.

title: Message from the General Chairs ICEBE 2025
authors: Kuo-Ming Chao, Salem AlKhalaf, Osama Alfarraj, Saleem Alsaleem, Farookh Khadeer Hussain

abstract: On behalf of the conference committee for ICEBE, it is our pleasure to welcome you to the 21st IEEE International Conference on e-Business Engineering (ICEBE 2025) and to Mustaqbal University, Buraydah, Saudi Arabia. title: Reconfigurable Soft Exoskeleton for Shoulder Support Using Tendon-Driven Underactuation
authors: Francesco Missiroli, Alessandro Ciaramella, Luca Radaelli, Emanuele Rambaldi, Antonio Frisoli, Maura Casadio, Lorenzo Masia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: This study presents a soft, wearable shoulder exosuit designed to assist shoulder abduction and flexion through adaptive gravity compensation. In contrast to traditional rigid exoskeletons that often restrict natural movement and are limited to controlled environments, the proposed system features a lightweight, tendon-driven architecture that preserves mobility while providing effective support during shoulder-intensive activities. The exosuit integrates a dual-motor Bowden cable actuation system with a real-time control strategy that dynamically aligns assistive forces with the users voluntary motion. This responsive design reduces muscular effort and supports sustained activity by adapting assistance levels in real time. Experimental evaluations with eight healthy participants demonstrated significant reductions in muscle activation, namely 36% in the anterior deltoid, 29% in the medial deltoid, and 27% in the trapezius. Prioritizing portability, modularity, and user comfort, the exosuit offers a compelling alternative to bulkier assistive systems. By combining a soft, wearable form factor with synchronized, multi-degreeof-freedom assistance, it highlights a promising direction for shoulder-assistive technologies suited for daily and occupational use.

title: Masked-Aware Directional Attention Network for DOA Estimation Under Sensor Failure Conditions
authors: Anuj Kumar Mishra, Aditya Srivastava, Ripul Ghosh
abstract: We investigate direction-of-arrival (DoA) estimation for airborne sound sources using a tetrahedral microphone array, addressing key challenges in drone detection and situational awareness applications. Practical deployment of DoA systems is often constrained by computational demands, stringent calibration requirements, and susceptibility to sensor failures. To address these limitations, we propose MADANet, a lightweight signal processing pipeline coupled with a pairwise attention-based neural architecture designed for robust performance under sensor failure scenarios. The architecture extracts magnitude, phase, and geometric features for each microphone pair from resampled acoustic signals (4-20 kHz), selects active frames via energy gating, and embeds these features through a shared multilayer perceptron before applying multi-head self-attention for adaptive fusion. A structured sensor dropout mechanism is introduced to mask feature pairs from randomly deactivated microphones and normalize attention weights accordingly. Experiments conducted in a semi-anechoic chamber demonstrate that down-sampling to 4 kHz and using four attention heads minimizes mean spherical error, approaching the Cramér-Rao lower bound for the given array geometry. The model exhibits strong generalization to single and double-microphone failure scenarios, maintaining sub-degree accuracy.
