title: The Influence of Perceived Enjoyment on Generation Z's Intention to Consume Religious Content: an Ecm Model
authors: Rinda Hesti Kusumaningtyas, Sallma Diana Putri, Nur Aeni Hidayah, Eri Rustamaji
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The objective of this study is to analyze the variables affecting Indonesian Generation Z's (Gen Z) propensity to use social media to consume religious content. The study concentrates on examining which forms of religious content attract user interaction and on analyzing the role of factors incorporated within the extended ExpectationConfirmation Model (ECM). This study applies a quantitative methodology by distributing questionnaires to UIN/IAIN students located across several major islands in Indonesia. Data was collected using Google Forms and analyzed with SmartPLS version 4.1.0.9. The results indicate that Generation Z shows a significant interest in religious content, particularly Islamic fashion, and holds high expectations for such content on social media. All tested hypotheses were accepted, indicating a positive user experience. The Perceived Enjoyment variable proved to be the most influential factor in the continued intention to consume religious content, suggesting that enjoyable experiences can enhance user motivation.

title: Optimizing Electric Vehicle Charging Station Placement Using Jellyfish Search Optimization: A Comparative Analysis
authors: Parth Data, Harshit U Tewari, Alivelu Manga Parimi
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative methodology for Electric Vehicle Charging Station (EVCS) site optimization utilizing the Jellyfish Search Optimization (JSO) algorithm. The research develops a comprehensive multi-objective optimization framework that simultaneously addresses voltage stability, unserved energy minimization, economic considerations, traffic congestion patterns, amenity density, and proximity to generation sources. The methodology employs a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \times 12$</tex> urban grid configuration interfaced with the IEEE 118-bus power system to evaluate JSO performance against established algorithms, including Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Sine Cosine Algorithm (SCA). These determined locations maintain voltage levels close to nominal values, minimize power losses, and feature high amenity density with moderate congestion probability, all strategically positioned near high-capacity generators to ensure reliable power supply while minimizing transmission losses. The JSO algorithm successfully determines optimal EVCS placement achieving to practical constraints like space availability and while demonstrating superior convergence characteristics and solution robustness. Comparative analysis shows JSO performs competitively against PSO and outperforms SCA, with greater robustness This research advances EVCS deployment strategies by balancing technical, economic, and social factors, potentially accelerating EV adoption through more efficient charging infrastructure.

title: Modelling the Integration of Autonomous and Shared Mobility Services in Non-Urban areas to Optimise Transport Equity and Reduce Environmental Impact
authors: Jack McShane, Eoghan Furey, Padraig Gallagher, Marion McAfee, Leo Creedon
abstract: This research paper is a work in progress to establish if Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) is a viable solution to the transport problem of servicing non-regular trips in non-urban areas. Public transport/shared transport and private cars is an important resource for people to get from their origin to their destination or vice versa. These origin-to-destination trips could be for example work commutes or shopping trips. With increased focus on sustainability from environmental and economic standpoints, more innovative means of public transport are being devised. Policies and goals such as the 17 United Nations Sustainable Development Goals have ensured that it is a priority that public transport becomes more sustainable and the level of private car usage decreases. While innovative transport solutions have been applied in urban centres and cities such as MaaS integration, ridesharing, and multimodal solutions, non-urban areas remain under-resourced. There are a few attributed reasons for poor non-urban transport solutions such as a lack of demand, sparsely populated areas, and the travel distances involved in supplying transport. The use of active modes such as walking and cycling is more challenging in non-urban areas due to the travel distances involved. The goal of this research is to develop an agent-based transport model with integrated MaaS services to establish whether MaaS transport could positively impact shared transport uptake in non-urban areas for non-regular journeys which consequently would lead to decreased private car usage, decreased emissions, improved social inclusion, and establishing how sustainable a MaaS solution is in these poorly serviced areas. This research also investigates whether attractive nodes, such as points of interest in the transport network, could also increase the uptake of shared transport.

title: GUI Test Automation Studies: Selenium IDE, Uipath Studio, Katalon Studio
authors: Rizal Broer Bahaweres, Nurul Uswatun Hasanah
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: GUI testing automatically using the capture-replay technique is beneficial in shortening testing time. Some of the automated testing tools that implement this technique are Selenium Ide, Katalon Studio, and Uipath Studio. GUI testing also requires verification for the correctness of each test scenario. We apply the BDD method in two automated test tools: Katalon Studio and UiPath Studio. Katalon Studio applies this method to a scenario consisting of user stories, feature files, and step definitions. NLP algorithms describe and analyze user story data to ensure the proper requirements for writing user stories. Uipath Studio creates an application workflow and test cases using a BDD template. The test application is built based on two different developments: traditional code (XAMPP-PHP) and low code (Oracle Apex and Retools) to enrich the GUI features of the application to be tested. The total points obtained from the three test parameters consisting of test constraints, running tests, and response times are 10 for Selenium Ide, 15 for Uipath Studio, and 10 for Katalon Studio. Eight test cases run on Uipath Studio, while only five run on Katalon Studio and Selenium Ide. Katalon Studio has minor testing constraints with 2 test constraints, and the fastest response time with BDD verification is Uipath Studio, with an average test time of 24.8 seconds.

title: Multi-Objective Approach to Balance Fairness and Accuracy
authors: Zahid Irfan, Róisín Loughran, Muhammad Adil Raja, Fergal McCaffery
abstract: As Artificial Intelligence systems are being deployed in multiple domains, ensuring they exhibit fair and just behaviour is a critical challenge. Multi-objective optimization offers a robust framework for addressing this challenge by simultaneously optimizing conflicting objectives, such as fairness and accuracy. In this work, we leverage causal graphs to model dependencies and identify potential sources of bias. We evolve directed acyclic graphs that represent causal structures, optimizing them for fairness and accuracy using evolutionary computational methods. Our approach employs multi-objective optimization to explore trade-offs between these objectives, enabling the discovery of solutions that balance ethical considerations with performance. Experimental results demonstrate that the multi-objective framework effectively improves fairness while maintaining competitive accuracy alongside building causal graphs. This approach provides a scalable and interpretable solution for mitigating bias in machine learning models, paving the way for more responsible and transparent AI applications.

title: Comparative Analysis of YOLOv8, YOLOv10, and YOLOv12 for Multi-Class Defect Detection in Cans and Plastic Bottles
authors: Candra Hidayattuloh, Rio Ferdinand, Stanley Christian Darmawan, Abdul Haris Rangkuti
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Quality control is a crucial aspect of a factory's product production. Quality control must ensure that product quality meets product standards, is consistent, and reliably as intended. Previously, quality control still used traditional or even manual technology, resulting in slow work speeds, prone to errors, impractical, and less efficient for large-scale production. However, along with the rapid development of technology, computer vision has emerged as a new game changer, giving rise to the idea of creating quality control using computer vision. By considering aspects of image processing and machine learning, quality control using a computer vision system can detect nonconforming bottles and cans quickly and accurately, such as measuring product dimensions, and classifying them into products that must be recycled or unfit for release to the market. This detector uses the YOLOv8, YOLOv10, and YOLOv12 methods. Based on the experiment that YOLOv12 achieved the best accuracy in detecting plastic bottles where mAP50, mAP 50-95 are 92%, 59%, followed by YOLOv8 which is 88% and 61%, However for defect detection in Cans accuracy with mAP50, mAP 50-95 for YOLOv12 is 93%, 86%, followed by YOLOv8 which is 89% and 87%. In general, this research using the YOLO model framework has been successful to detect the Botol Plastic and Kinds of defect Cans.

title: Comparative Study of Machine Learning Algorithms for Sentiment Analysis on the Public Housing Savings Program
authors: Christofer Satria, I Nyoman Yoga Sumadewa, Anthony Anggrawan, Baiq Elsa Virga Dewanti Destiana, Muhamad Azwar, Muhammad Maulana
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of social media users has led to the emergence of various sentiments and opinions related to events, issues, and dilemmas that develop on the platform. In addition, social media has become the primary medium for people to express their opinions, one of which is through Twitter. Given that opinion data on social media can be processed into valuable information through sentiment analysis and data mining methods, this study mines Twitter data to identify and estimate the most dominant sentiments in tweets, including positive, negative, and neutral sentiments. The results of this study provide a solution for analyzing the sentiment of user opinions on Twitter related to the People's Housing Savings program. It is worth noting that sentiment analysis has recently garnered increasing attention from researchers. Therefore, this study aims to conduct sentiment analysis using the classification methods of Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and Naïve Bayes (NB). The study findings reveal that the SVM method achieves the highest accuracy of 84%, followed by RF with 81% accuracy, XGBoost with 78% accuracy, and NB with 75% accuracy in classifying positive and negative sentiments, as well as neutral tweets on Twitter. Likewise, the precision, recall, and F1-score of SVM outperform RF and XGBoost.

title: Net 254 Gb/s IM/DD Transmission in C-Band Over 3.1 km NANF Using Silicon Photonics TW-MZM
authors: Darja Cirjulina, Suttikarn Wantee, Armands Ostrovskis, Hao Liu, Kyle R.H. Bottrill, Gregory T. Jasion, Hesham Sakr, John R. Hayes, Vjaceslavs Bobrovs, Francesco Poletti, Xiaodan Pang, Periklis Petropoulos, Oskars Ozolins
abstract: We demonstrate 90 GBaud PAM8 transmission in the C-band over 3.1 km long nested antiresonant nodeless fiber (NANF) using a Silicon Photonics traveling-wave Mach-Zehnder modulator (TW-MZM). We achieve performance satisfying <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6. 2 5 \%}$</tex> overhead HD-FEC requirements.

title: Representation Learning and Foundation Models for Electroencephalography Analyses: Current trends, fundamental insights, and future directions
authors: Zhe Sage Chen, Bao-Liang Lu, Wei Wu
abstract: Since the first groundbreaking human electroencephalography (EEG) recordings in 1924 <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1" xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[1]</xref>, the past century has witnessed a tremendous growth of EEG applications in cognitive neuroscience, clinical, and engineering applications due to EEG’s low operational cost and mobility <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2" xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[2]</xref>. On the one hand, advances in high-density noninvasive scalp EEG or invasive intracranial EEG (iEEG) have offered both excellent temporal resolution and increasingly improved spatial resolution to study brain functions and their link to emotions, memory, learning, and diseases. EEG-based brain–computer interfaces (BCIs) can offer new dimensions for entertainment, virtual reality, neurofeedback, and closed-loop therapy. On the other hand, recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning have opened new opportunities for analyses of EEG and other neural data <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3" xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[3]</xref>. This article aims at presenting an overview of the cutting-edge machine learning techniques for EEG analyses. By leveraging large-scale EEG data with state-of-the-art representation learning and transfer learning (TL) paradigms, we are empowered to discover latent EEG features that are proved useful for clinical care and BCIs. We discuss some general principles of representation learning and show walk-through practical examples of EEG analysis. The article also aims at highlighting the effort of applying AI models to discover neuroscience insights and linking them to the fundamentals of EEG signal analyses from a signal processing perspective. While our focus is on EEG and iEEG signals, most of the approaches discussed here are generally applicable to other brain signal modalities.

title: Adaptive Oscillators Based Real-Time Estimation of Diving Phase in Flutter Kick
authors: Chenxi Zhang, Rui Yang, Ming Xu, Zhihao Zhou, Qining Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Motion phase estimation is widely used in human biomechanics research and robotic assistance control. In this study, we propose an adaptive oscillators (AOs)-based method to estimate the diving phase for the flutter kick, utilizing the bilateral symmetry in hip flexion-extension coordination. A flutter kick cycle is divided into two adjacent phases of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$[0, \pi)$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$[\pi, 2 \pi)$</tex>, and the estimation algorithm uses dualphase resets triggered at critical motion events of maximum hip flexion (MHF) and maximum hip extension (MHE). Five healthy subjects participated in the underwater diving experiments. The recognition results demonstrated that the proposed method achieved a mean absolute error (MAE) of 0.2157 rad (3.43% of the kicking cycle) at both MHF and MHE events, surpassing the existing single-phase reset process by reducing the MAE across the entire cycle by 22.6%. The algorithm exhibited robustness under variable flutter kick frequencies and minimized sensor complexity (two inertial measurement units). These findings demonstrate promising potential for future application in the assistance control of underwater exoskeletons.

title: ENDC MIMO OTA Testing for 5G User Equipment Using a Symmetric Per-Link Evaluation Methodology
authors: Yuchen Wang, Han Wu, Zhigang Yang, Siyang Sun, Na Wang, Qinjuan Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The expansion of 5G Non-Standalone (NSA) networks has made E-UTRA NR Dual Connectivity (ENDC) an essential capability for user equipment, driving the need for efficient performance evaluation. While Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) Over-the-Air (OTA) testing serves as the standard validation method, existing approaches fail to adequately evaluate ENDC MIMO performance. This is because such assessment typically requires two synchronized channel emulators—a solution that is both complex and costly. This paper introduces a practical Symmetric Per-Link Evaluation (SPLE) method that overcomes this limitation. The approach divides ENDC testing into two phases: the NR link is evaluated firstly under static UMa CDL-C fading using a channel emulator while the LTE link is held stable, then the roles of the two links are reversed. This symmetric solution enables the separate evaluation of MIMO performance for each Radio Access Technology (RAT) using only one channel emulator. The proposed SPLE provides a cost-effective and efficient way for comprehensive ENDC MIMO OTA testing. It delivers critical insights for R&D debugging and performance benchmarking.

title: A Low-Repetition-Rate Broadband Mode-Locked Laser Utilizing Anti-Resonant Hollow-Core Fiber
authors: Laiyang Dang, Xin Zhang, Yinghui Zhuang, Shuyuan Zhu, Wenhao Zhu, Feng Li, Pu Wang, Dongmei Huang
abstract: We propose and demonstrate a novel mode-locking technique using anti-resonant hollow-core fiber to achieve a low repetition rate and broadband spectrum. A spectral bandwidth exceeding 80 nm and a signal-to-noise ratio of up to 85 dB is achieved at a repetition frequency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8. 6 5 ~ M H z}$</tex>.

title: Dynamic Bias Characteristics of InGaAs/INP Avalanche Photodiodes Under Linear Mode Operation
authors: Erum Jamil, Chadi Harmouche, Nicholas Gabaldon, Payman Zarkesh-Ha, Marek Osiński
abstract: Linear mode characteristics of dynamically biased InGaAs/InP separate-absorption-multiplication avalanche photodiodes are investigated. Modulated mean gain and excess noise allow for tuning of the response to maximize the photon detection probability. A novel circuit for implementing dynamic biasing at rates up to 100 Mbp is proposed.

title: Bianisotropic and Anapole-Governed Dielectric Metasurface Under Circularly Polarized Illumination
authors: Monica Pradhan, Shubhanshi Sharma, Shailendra Kumar Varshney
abstract: We present a dielectric metasurface composed of two partial slots in silicon nanodisks, exhibiting multipolar interference and directional asymmetry when circularly polarized light is incident. The designed metasurface supports anapole state and magnetoelectric coupling, illustrating reciprocal bianisotropy behavior, enabling polarization-sensitive light manipulation at the nanoscale.

title: New Computing Model of Machine Learning for Aridity Risk Classification Using Multi-Vegetation Indices and Kriging Interpolation
authors: Khoirudin, Sri Yulianto Joko Prasetyo, Wiwin Sulistyo, Budhi Kristianto
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Monitoring and classifying vegetative drought in tropical agricultural areas requires reliable spatial-temporal indicators and precise predictive modeling. This study presents a new computational approach for aridity classification by combining five satellite imagery-based vegetation indices (NDVI, SAVI, VCI, TCI, and VHI) using machine learning algorithms (KNN and SVM), together with ordinary kriging for spatial interpolation. We use Landsat-8 OLI/TIRS imagery from 2014 to 2018 in Boyolali Regency, Central Java, Indonesia. Pearson correlation analysis showed a robust relationship between NDVI and SAVI (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r=1.000$</tex>) and between NDVI and VHI (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r=0.925$</tex>), while TCI showed a negative correlation with the other two. This predictive modeling produced high accuracy for VCI and VHI, with MAPE values below 7 % for both KNN and SVM. Compared with prior Central Java studies using ensemble trees and IDW, our baseline KNN/SVM with ordinary kriging remains competitive on VCI/VHI (MAPE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=5.55- \mathbf{6. 5 8 \%}$</tex>) across 2014-2018 while enabling LULC-aware interpretation. The predictions are then interpolated via ordinary kriging to obtain spatial drought-risk maps. The results indicate that agricultural and residential areas are most affected by vegetative drought. The proposed machine learning provides a replicable spatial framework for drought monitoring by integrating remote sensing and geostatistics, which can support informed land management and climate adaptation decisions in data-limited tropical regions.

title: Ultra-Low Threshold GeSn-on-Insulator Laser Monolithically Grown by Rapid Melting Technique
authors: M. Chen, Z. Liu, X. Liu, Q. Huang, Y. Zhu, Y. Zuo, Z. Ikonic, B. Cheng, D. Nam, J. Zheng
abstract: We present a defect-free, single-crystal GeSn-oninsulator laser using rapid melting growth. An ultra-low threshold is achieved due to high material quality, strong optical confinement, and tensile strain. This work advances monolithic silicon photonics, enabling applications in interconnects, LiDAR, and quantum technologies.

title: PP-GraspNet: Efficient Per-Point Grasp Generation for Three-Finger Hand in Cluttered Scenes
authors: Shifeng Lin, Yueming Bi, Jingxiang Chen, Chenguang Yang, Ning Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Grasp planning for multi-fingered dexterous hands presents a formidable challenge. Existing mainstream learning-based methods regard the joint angles of the dexterous hand as both the grasp representation and the objective function for optimization. However, the high degree of freedom (DOF) characteristic of multi-fingered dexterous hands allows for multiple joint angle configurations to correspond to the same grasp, which complicates the learning process. Furthermore, the coupling of joint angles can propagate errors during the grasping process, diminishing the grasp success rate. In this work, we have decoupled the mechanical structure of the dexterous hand from its grasp representation. We introduce the circular equation that tend to stable grasping to model the contact points and subsequently employ inverse kinematic (IK) to translate these contact points into the grasp configuration of the dexterous hand. Leveraging this grasp representation, we have developed a fully automated annotation pipeline within a simulated environment and have constructed a dataset encompassing 40 objects across more than a thousand varied scenarios, totaling more than 20K entries. We propose an efficient per-point grasp generation network, PP-graspnet, for collection of multi-fingered grasp points in cluttered scenes. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of our method.

title: Comb Sources with Hybrid Photonic Integration
authors: Stefano Grillanda, Di Che, Mohamad Hossein Idjadi, Cristian Bolle, Rose Kopf, Mark Cappuzzo
abstract: We review our work on comb sources made by large-scale hybrid photonic integration. Our approach integrates 16 gain chips with a passive silica chip, hosting an arrayed waveguide grating and a Sagnac loop, to make a comb source with 16 wavelengths and 100 GHz spacing.

title: Demonstration of 1.024 Tbps Data Transmission Over Field-Deployed Armored Multi-Core Fiber Cable
authors: Sameer Ahmad Mir, Jonaq Niveer Sarma, Annesha Maity, Pramod Mishra, Rachana, Shubham Vasane, Arvind Kumar Mishra, Deepa Venkitesh
abstract: We report the world's first demonstration of 1.024 Tbps data transmission over field-deployed armored 4-core optical fiber cable. The 4 km multi-core fiber cable, comprising 12 four-core and 12 single-mode fibers, is deployed in a trenched underground cable duct in accordance with standard cable deployment practices

title: Urban Transportation Research for Enhancing Sustainable Mobility Systems
authors: Gulammustafa G. Sayyad, Shashikant V. Athawale
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: Today's cities are shaped by urban transportation in many ways, including the economy, society, and environment. With the rapid growth of urbanization and population density, cities face substantial challenges such as traffic congestion, air pollution, inadequate infrastructure, and accessibility problems. As part of this review, we examine current research on urban transportation to identify significant challenges and opportunities for making them more efficient and sustainable. As part of its evaluation of contemporary trends, technological innovations, and policy measures, the study examines intelligent transportation systems (ITS), transit-oriented development (TOD), electric mobility, and autonomous vehicles. In addition to demonstrating successful implementation strategies, the report also highlights research gaps. According to the study, a multimodal transport network, sustainable policies, and cutting-edge technology-driven solutions are key to shaping the future of urban transportation. Researchers, urban planners, and policymakers can use these insights to enhance the sustainability, accessibility, and efficiency of transportation systems.

title: Auto-Design and Prediction of Ultra-Wideband Terahertz Metasurface Absorber Based on Deep Learning
authors: Jinyu Liu, Xiaowei Wang, Kun Zhan, Pin Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this paper, an autoencoder-based neural network model is constructed by integrating automated metasurface pattern modeling with deep learning techniques. In this model, the encoder extracts features from the input matrix elements, while the decoder utilizes these features to establish the mapping between the metasurface patterns and their corresponding absorption spectra. This approach achieves both the automatic design of ultra-wideband terahertz (THz) metasurface absorber patterns and the rapid prediction of their absorption spectra. By circumventing the trial-and-error process inherent to traditional metasurface design, the proposed method serves as an alternative for developing new multifunctional THz devices and offers valuable insights for future research.

title: Spiral-Channeled Sweat Sensor with Double-Spiral Electrodes for Efficient and Accurate Sweat Analysis
authors: Jiacheng Luo, Bingcong Jian, Guangyu Wu, Yuwei Yang, Liangrui Xu, Ying Feng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Sweat capacitive sensors represent a class of advanced biosensors specifically engineered to quantify critical physiological parameters such as the sweating rate and the total sweat volume secreted by the human body. These measurements serve as vital indicators for detecting diverse physiological states or underlying health conditions. The adoption of such sensors offers a multitude of significant advantages, including their inherently non-invasive nature, the capability for continuous real-time monitoring, the potential for miniaturization into wearable formats, and their demonstrated high level of bio-compatibility, minimizing adverse reactions with human tissue. The primary focus of this paper is the design and fabrication of a sweat capacitive sensor based on spiral channels and spiral electrodes. The flow of liquid within the channel was theoretically derived and verified through experiments. By comparing with traditional sweat sensors that use interdigitated electrodes and serpentine channels, the superiority of the spiral sweat capacitive sensor in sweat measurement was verified from both theoretical and experimental perspectives.

title: Trust and Quality in AI-Driven Tools: The Influence on Intention to Use ChatGPT Among University Students in Manila
authors: Lianna Wijaya, Cheng Kin Meng, Lourdes Lasian, Made Irma Lestari, Johannes Widjaja Wahono, Nova Nur Anisa
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Universities are adopting conversational tools for coursework, yet evidence is mixed on what drives students’ intention to use them in higher education, especially in Metro Manila. Prior work rarely integrates credibility factors with belief-based predictors, so we test information quality and source trustworthiness alongside effort and performance expectancy to explain intention. Using a cross-sectional research design, primary data were collected through an online survey distributed via email and WhatsApp to students from Metro Manila. A total of 256 valid responses were analyzed using Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM). The results reveal that source trustworthiness has a significant impact on both effort expectancy and performance expectancy, while effort expectancy has a strong predictive relationship with performance expectancy. In turn, performance expectancy is the most significant predictor of intention to use ChatGPT. However, the study found that information quality does not significantly influence performance expectancy, and effort expectancy does not directly influence intention to use. The study’s novelty is the integrated UTAUT–ELM model estimated on a Manila student sample, clarifying how credibility shapes usefulness beliefs and intention. Practically, instructors should emphasize transparent use, verification scaffolds, and course-aligned examples to raise perceived usefulness and credibility.

title: Servo Tracking Control of Permanent Magnet Linear Motor Based on Inequality Constraints
authors: Qilin Wu, Shaojian Wang, Qiang Qin, Xun Jiang, Kaixuan Yin.
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Permanent magnet linear motors (PMLMs) have significant applications in unmanned ground vehicle swarms, providing accurate power control for unmanned vehicles so that they can respond to commands quickly and precisely to realize vehicle operations such as acceleration, deceleration, and steering. However, the control accuracy of the PMLM system is largely affected by parameter uncertainties, and thus has a great impact on whether the unmanned ground vehicle swarm can respond to commands efficiently and accurately. To address this problem, this paper employs a state transition method that converts bounded states to unbounded states so that the output states of the system are subject to the desired boundary constraints. Subsequently, this paper builds a new robust control strategy. The goal of this control strategy is to ensure that the uncertainty control system has consistent boundedness and consistent final boundedness.

title: Image Oversampling Enhancement Method Using Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks
authors: Fendy Wijaya, Wilbert Yang, Ivan Setiawan, Tjeng Wawan Cenggoro
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: An imbalanced dataset has become a critical challenge to achieving ideal performance in classification. One of the most frequently used methods to overcome this problem is oversampling. In the case of image oversampling, DeepSMOTE was one of the options that has outperformed several GAN-based methods. DeepSMOTE implemented a set of MLP layers for image processing. However, as deep learning capabilities have grown, alternative studies have also emerged, leading to Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KAN), which may replace MLP in some circumstances. This study is intended to integrate BSRBF-KAN as one of the most implemented KANs, in order to solve the imbalanced dataset problem. The conducted experiments showed that BSRBF-KAN is quite comparable with MLP in terms of performance evaluation. Additionally, BSRBF-KAN outperformed MLP in the majority of cases with respect to latent representation size, but remained comparable in terms of number of trainable parameters. Regarding to the experimental results, it can be concluded that KAN can be an analogous architecture to MLP for solving image oversampling problems. The source code is publicly available at https://github.com/vanssnn/DeepSMOTE-BSRBFKAN.

title: Effectiveness of Scrum in Software Development a Bibliometric Analysis
authors: Indrajani Sutedja, Masagus Padadingsiang L Attar, Luthfi Khan Alfaridzzi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: To examine the current research state of SCRUM methodology, this study uses a bibliometric analysis and utilizing VOS viewer. We visualized the connection between key concepts in SCRUM literature, focusing on the impact of SCRUM in productivity, software quality, team collaboration, and customer satisfaction. The visualization resulting in a network with four different clusters. The highlight of our analysis is the centrality of SCRUM effectiveness in literature. While some node like productivity and quality are not present, they are likely to be subsumed under the broader concept of effectiveness. Key findings in this literature include both theoretical foundation and practical implementation of SCRUM. This comprehensive approach in this literature provide insight about SCRUM contribution to its overall impact on software development project. While the analysis provides a high-level overview of SCRUM, further in-depth analysis is needed to justify SCRUM impact on software development. In conclusion, between the identified cluster Scrum have indication that the impact of project outcome can be studied holistically, considering its methodology, framework, practice, and events.

title: Research on the Collaborative Identification Algorithm of Degradation Trend of Distributed Photovoltaic Inverter Group Based on Threedimensional Ranging Technology
authors: Yugang Chen, Xiaoping He, Dalue Xue, Cheng Fang, Tingrui Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: In response to the complex degradation trend of distributed photovoltaic inverters, this study proposes a collaborative recognition algorithm based on 3D ranging technology and deep learning. Obtain inverter deformation data through 3D ranging and generate high-precision point clouds, combined with CNN feature extraction and system dynamics observer, to achieve binary classification and real valued output of degradation trends. The experiment showed that the accuracy of this method reached $96.7 \%$, with an AUC value of 0.979, significantly better than the comparative methods, providing an efficient tool for reliability assessment and preventive maintenance of photovoltaic systems.

title: Research on Typical Digital Twin Scenarios and Simulation Platforms in the Distribution IoT
authors: Boda Zhang, Fuhua Luo, Yunhao Yu, Chameiling Di, Ruibin Wen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Facing the system complexity challenges caused by large-scale user access in the new distribution Internet of Things, this paper focuses on the innovation of twin modeling methods under the digital twin technology system, and proposes a digital twin scene construction scheme that integrates the multi-source energy flow-information flow collaborative mechanism and the behavior mapping of multiple subjects. Based on the dynamic evolution mechanism of the cyber-physical system (CPS), the designed simulation platform breaks through the modeling bottleneck of traditional simulation technology for complex distribution scenarios, and can support functions such as flexible grid structure construction, detailed information process description, system verification under complex cyber-physical interaction and security defense. It builds a digital twin with core functions such as intelligent grid topology reconfiguration, precise mapping of operating status, and embedded security defense mechanisms. A specific case analysis is conducted for a typical cyber-physical interaction scenario of distribution networks with distributed energy access. The simulation results verify the practicality and effectiveness of the proposed simulation platform, providing an innovative technical verification carrier for the construction of the security defense system of the new distribution Internet of Things.

title: A Magnetic Dipole Source Implementation Technique for FCC-FDTD method
authors: Boyan Cui, Guangzhi Chen, Xinsong Wang, Yaru Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This article presents a soft-source modeling technique for the magnetic dipole used for face-centered cubic finite-difference time-domain (FCC-FDTD) method. The updating formulas for magnetic dipole source are derived in detail and incorporated into the FCC grid. With the analytical solution serving as a reference, the proposed magnetic dipole technique is applied to both general and dispersive media, and its accuracy and applicability are rigorously validated. Further, the proposed method is used to simulate the electromagnetic energy absorption of a breast tumour patient model. The numerical results can serve as a reference for bioelectromagnetic protection.

title: Dynamic Formation and Collision Avoidance Control for Differential-Wheeled Mobile Robots
authors: Xiaoli Liu, Jiabao Ni, Qilin Wu, Shi Hu, Shengchao Zhen, Ye-Hwa Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel control framework for differential-drive robotic swarms and Udwadia-Kalaba (UK) dynamics with Lyapunov stability guarantees. Key contributions include:Integrated system architecture with hardwarecommunication co-design;Kinematic-dynamic joint modeling for leader navigation and trajectory tracking, validated through Lyapunov stability and simulations;Leader-follower formation strategy with enhanced artificial potential fields to eliminate local minima in collision avoidance;Dual-control mechanism and adaptive robust control for uncertainty compensation, ensuring uniform boundedness. The proposed methodology advances multi-robot systems in theory and practice, achieving collision-free formations in dynamic environments.

title: Development of Artificial Intelligence for Sentiment Analysis on Social Media in Facing the Impact of Social Media on Education in Indonesia
authors: Kevin Yanuar, Jason Lee, Matthew Christian Hansel Budhiono, Sulistyo Heripracoyo
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: the advancements in Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology and its effects on specific sectors, including education, have received a lot of attention. Users of social media platforms, particularly X/Twitter, have shared their opinions on the effects of AI in education, classifying them as positive, negative, or neutral. To capture their sentiment, this research conducted sentiment analysis on a sample of 11,000 comments from X (Twitter), Instagram, YouTube, and Facebook. A model using a Simple Recurrent Neural Network (Simple-RNN) and bidirectional architecture performed the best in the positive category, achieving precision and recall metrics of 88% and F1-score close to 90%. For the negative category, recall was 84% and precision was 75%. For neutral sentiment, recall dropped to 72%. This suggests the proposed AI model serves well for positive sentiment classification but fails to enhance the detection of neutral sentiment which undermines balanced classification.

title: A Multi-Scale SAR Aircraft Detection Method with Strip Pooling Attention Enhancement
authors: Shuochen Zhang, Xueli Pan, Lixia Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Deep learning-based detectors have emerged as the mainstream approach for the aircraft detection in synthetic aperture radar (SAR). However, due to the varying resolutions and viewing, the target exhibits multi-scale characteristics with discontinuous scattering. Meanwhile, anchor-based detectors often require intensive hyperparameter tuning and introduce redundancy. To address these issues, we propose an anchor-free network for multi-scale SAR aircraft detection method with strip pooling attention enhancement. We employed feature pyramids network to handle the multi-scale nature of aircrafts. Specifically, we designed a multi-scale global feature fusion module (MGFFM) in the neck, which captuers both multi-scale receptive fields and global contextual features. Given the discontinuity of scattering, MGFFM leverages the strip pooling attention to built long-range dependencies, enhancing the global perception ability. Extensive experiments on the public SAR AIRcraft-1.0 dataset demonstrate the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed method.

title: Advancing Automatic Essay Scoring using Synonym-Aware Rabin-Karp Algorithm
authors: Andharini Dwi Cahyani, Ari Basuki, Bain Khusnul Khotimah, Muhammad Yusuf, Ika Suzan Oktavianti, Fifin Ayu Mufarroha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: This study aims to improve Automatic Essay Scoring (AES) accuracy by optimizing the Rabin-Karp algorithm with synonym recognition. AES systems play a critical role in education by providing fast and consistent feedback, yet they face persistent challenges in handling varied vocabulary, often misinterpreting correct concepts expressed with different wording. To address this limitation, the Rabin-Karp algorithm, which applies hashing for efficient text pattern matching, is extended with synonym recognition and systematic parameter tuning. Specifically, the effects of the k-gram value (k) and prime base (b) are analyzed to determine their impact on scoring accuracy. Evaluation using Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) demonstrates that smaller k-gram values, particularly k = 2, consistently deliver superior accuracy. In contrast, larger k-grams reduce reliability due to natural variations in student writing that limit exact sequence matches. The most accurate configurations were k = 2 and b = 7 without synonym recognition, and k = 2 and b = 13 with synonym recognition. These findings highlight the importance of incorporating synonym recognition into AES, as it enables systems to capture conceptual equivalence and provide fairer, more reliable assessments. The results contribute to advancing AES methodologies by demonstrating how algorithmic optimization can enhance semantic sensitivity in automated scoring.

title: Automated Attendance System Using Surveillance Cameras
authors: D. Rajeswara Rao, Prakya Muppavarapu, Hema Nandhini Karra
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Biometric and manual attendance systems are subject to human error, proxy attendance, and issues of hygiene. In order to counter these drawbacks, this paper suggests a contactless, real-time attendance management system that utilizes existing CCTV infrastructure in conjunction with sophisticated face detection and recognition methods. The system utilizes Haar Cascade classifiers for efficient face localization and FaceNet embeddings for strong identity verification, combined with AES-256 encryption and role-based access control for protection and privacy. In contrast to earlier works that are expensive due to the need for special hardware or degrade under realistic conditions, the proposed system is highly robust against difficult situations like low lighting, occlusion, and crowd density. Largescale experiments on more than 2,500 facial images and classroom pilot runs indicate that the system is 96.8 % accurate, 95.1 % precise, and has a mean response time of 1.2 seconds per individual, beating traditional manual, biometric, and webcam-based methods. Through its accuracy, security, and scalability, the suggested system offers a viable solution for large-scale institutions and sets the stage for future extensions like liveness detection, edge deployment, and multi-location synchronization.

title: Si-Based Mid-Infrared Photodetectors Utilizing Strain-Relaxed GeSn Alloys Grown by MBE
authors: Ping-Chien Hsieh, Kuo-Chih Lee, Yue-Tong Jheng, Pavels Onufrijevs, Jun-Yu Ou, Yoshishige Tsuchiya, Hung-Hsiang Cheng, Guo-En Chang
abstract: We present mid-infrared GeSn photodetectors on silicon. The GeSn active layer was grown on Sn composition gradient GeSn buffer layer, aching significant strain relaxation and a high Sn content of 9.1%. The fabricated GeSn metal-semiconductor-metal photodetector exhibits extended photodetection exceeding 2400 nm.

title: Deep Learning and Cloud-Integrated IoT Systems for Early Crop Disease Detection
authors: Suresh Kumar L V, Kuppili Saipraneeth, Bojanki Priyanka
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Crop diseases pose significant challenges to global agricultural productivity and food security, often leading to severe economic and environmental consequences. Leveraging advanced technologies such as deep learning and computer vision offers promising solutions for early detection and effective management of crop diseases. This paper provides a comprehensive review of recent advancements in crop disease detection methods, focusing on state-of-the-art deep learning frameworks like Dense Net. Emphasis is placed on their application to various crops, highlighting the integration of Sensors with Raspberry pi-5 and cloud-based solutions. Key contributions include the synthesis of approaches for disease classification, data augmentation strategies, and the identification of research gaps, paving the way for future innovations.

title: Absorptive Energy Selective Surface Based on Resonant Structure with PIN Diodes
authors: Shangjing Xi, Song Zha, Yanqing Cheng, Yuan Xu, Jijun Huang, Peiguo Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: An absorptive energy selective surface (ESS) based on PIN diodes is proposed for achieving high-power electromagnetic protection and low reflection at the same time. Under a low power incidence, minimal insertion loss (IL) is experienced by transmitted signals. Conversely, when exposed to high power incidence, the bottom ESS is switched to a reflective state. Signals are subjected to multiple internal reflections within the structure, resulting in significant absorption loss and effective high-power microwave (HPM) dissipation. Design results demonstrate that an IL below -1.5 dB is exhibited by the proposed absorptive ESS across its passband from 8.7 to 9.8 GHz. Under HPM incidence, a shielding effectiveness (SE) exceeding 12 dB and an absorption efficiency greater than 85% are achieved simultaneously.

title: 100 Gb/s PAM-4 and Low-Chirp Silicon Photonics SiGe Electro-Absorption Modulator for Short-reach Data Transmission
authors: Ya-Han Chang, Rih-You Chen, Yi-Jen Chiu
abstract: Enabled by s high-speed Si photonics SiGe electroabsorption modulator, we have successfully demonstrated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex> Gb/s PAM-4 modulation over distances up to 4 km optical fiber. A low chirp of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 0. 0 3}$</tex> was achieved for short-reach by setting the EAM's bias at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 5 V}$</tex>.

title: Carbon Dioxide Detection Using Dual-Wavelength FMCW LiDAR Based on an InP Integrated Tunable Laser
authors: Yu Han, Limeng Zhang, Victor Dolores Calzadilla
abstract: We present a dual-wavelength FMCW LiDAR based on an indium phosphide integrated tunable laser and apply it as an integrated path differential absorption LiDAR. Using a carbon dioxide gas cell, we show that the FMCW LiDAR can achieve <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 7 2 \%}$</tex> precision in measuring the absorption of carbon dioxide gas and 5.2 mm precision in distance measurement.

title: The Effect of Hyperparameter Tuning Techniques on the Accuracy of Automated Thyroid Diagnosis
authors: Khasnur Hidjah, Ria Rismayati, Bambang Krismono Triwijoyo, Ni Gusti Ayu Dasriani, Karina Anindita, Dicksa Ananda Christian Tue
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: The performance of machine learning (ML) models like the Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) is critical for medical applications such as thyroid disease diagnosis but is highly dependent on hyperparameter selection. Suboptimal configurations can degrade diagnostic accuracy and reliability, making hyperparameter tuning essential. This study evaluates the impact of the Optuna tuning framework on an MLP model for automated thyroid diagnosis. The methodology involved using a public UCI dataset, data preprocessing, training a baseline MLP, and performing extensive hyperparameter optimization with Optuna to maximize the F1-score. This research provides an empirical evaluation of Optuna's effectiveness, showing that classification accuracy increased by 11.6 percentage points (from 0.837 to 0.954) and the macro F1-score rose by 21.3 percentage points (from 0.721 to 0.933) compared to the baseline model, with a particularly noteworthy improvement in recall for the minority classes. Optuna successfully identified a more complex and effective two-hidden-layer architecture. In conclusion, hyperparameter optimization using Optuna is highly effective for enhancing the accuracy and reliability of MLP models in thyroid diagnosis. This approach overcomes the limitations of suboptimal configurations, affirming that meticulous tuning is a critical step in developing robust clinical decision-support systems.

title: Trajectory Tracking of Unmanned Quadrotor UAVs Under Wind Disturbances Using Time-Varying Terminal Sliding Mode Control
authors: Yu Pan, Ni Li, Peng Xiao, Ban Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: This paper proposes a second-order time-varying terminal sliding mode control method for trajectory tracking control of quadrotor UAVs. The proposed control strategy introduces a novel time-varying sliding surface, which improves convergence speed and minimizes steady-state error. Experimental validation of the controller demonstrates its superior performance in disturbance rejection and stability, showcasing its effectiveness in comparison to conventional control schemes.

title: Design Method of Multi-way Multi-stage Power Divider With Omnidirectional Resistor Based on Graphene Flake
authors: Li Liu, Meng Yang, Fengtao Wu, Junfeng Chen, Long Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A novel design method is presented for the development of a multi-way and multi-stage power divider incorporating an omnidirectional resistor utilizing graphene flake technology. The proposed design is realized on a compact back-to-back double-layer microstrip configuration, featuring a shared ground plane and multiple via holes to minimize the overall footprint. In particular, a piece of a circular graphene flake loaded on a saw-tooth structure is well designed to achieve omnidirectional isolation resistor between arbitrary output ports, avoiding the traditional fussy lumped resistor welding process. Furthermore, a multi-stage architecture is implemented to significantly enhance the operational bandwidth of the power divider. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, a three-way and three-stage power divider is designed, with the operating range from 6.5 to 11 GHz and the transmission level of -10 ± 0.5 dB; the port-to-port isolation is better than 20 dB.

title: Accuracy vs Performance: An abstraction model for deadline constrained offloading at the mobile-edge
authors: Jamie Cotter, Ignacio Castiñeiras, Victor Cionca
abstract: In this paper, we present a solution for low-latency deadline-constrained DNN offloading on mobile edge devices. We design a scheduling algorithm with lightweight network state representation, considering device availability, communication on the network link, priority-aware pre-emption, and task deadlines. The scheduling algorithm aims to reduce latency by designing a resource availability representation, as well as a network discretisation and a dynamic bandwidth estimation mechanism. We implement the scheduling algorithm into a system composed of four Raspberry Pi 2 (model Bs) mobile edge devices, sampling a waste classification conveyor belt at a set frame rate. The system is evaluated and compared to a previous approach of ours, which was proven to outcompete work-stealers and a non-pre-emption based scheduling heuristic under the aforementioned waste classification scenario. Our findings show the novel lower latency abstraction models yield better performance under high-volume workloads, with the dynamic bandwidth estimation assisting the task placement while, ultimately, increasing task throughput in times of resource scarcity.

title: Tuning Photon Number Resolution Via Frequency Adjustment in Sinusoidally Gated Single-Photon Avalanche Diodes
authors: Yi-Shan Lee
abstract: We present an amplitude-resolved photon-numberresolving (PNR) detection using gated-mode single-photon avalanche diodes (SPADs) under sinusoidal gating. By tuning the gating frequency, we achieve flexible control over the effective gate width, enabling precise optimization of detection conditions. Shorter gate widths, achieved at higher frequencies, reduce avalanche carrier generation and suppress noise from dark carriers, thereby narrowing the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of photon peaks. Amplitude histograms clearly resolve multi-photon events. Key PNR performance metrics, such as the 1-photon peak voltage, voltage separation, and FWHM, are extracted and analyzed as a function of frequency. The results demonstrate that while increasing frequency improves resolution and reduces noise, it also reduces detection efficiency and statistical confidence due to fewer detected carriers. This trade-off highlights the advantage of sinusoidal gating for flexible, highresolution PNR detection in practical applications.

title: Disturbance Observer Based Sliding Model Tracking Control for Mobile Robots with Longitudinal and Lateral Slipping
authors: Yichen Huang, Chuanhao Hu, Huazhong Zhu, Andong Liu, Wen-an Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: To address the safety concerns arising from the potential slipping phenomenon of mobile robots in complex environments, this paper presents a robust control method based on a sliding mode disturbance observer(SMDO), aiming to enhance the accuracy of trajectory tracking and boost the robustness of mobile robots in practical applications. Firstly, establish kinematic and dynamic models that incorporate longitudinal and lateral slipping disturbances, and design a disturbance estimation and control strategy. Secondly, devise a SMDO to estimate the slipping disturbances in real-time, assess the total disturbances, and introduce this estimated value into the robust trajectory tracking controller designed subsequently. Ultimately, the effectiveness of the algorithm is verified by means of simulation experiments.

title: Design of a 77-GHz Antenna Array for Automotive Radar
authors: Fukang Wang, Zhongxiang Zhang, Lixia Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A compact low sidelobe series-fed microstrip patch array antenna is presented in this paper. The antenna adopts a microstrip-fed patch, and eight elements are arranged in a linear array. By using a series-feeding method, the array attains a compact structure and low profile, reducing the cost and volume of the feeding network and improving radiation efficiency and space utilization. The simulated results indicate that the antenna achieves a gain of 15 dB and a sidelobe level below –18 dB in the operating band. The antenna can be applied to 77-GHz automotive radar systems.

title: Brightness Temperature Anomalies in Mare Nectaris Using CELMS Data
authors: Jiahui Li, Zhanchuan Cai, Minghao Tong, Renzhang Chen, Zhongchun He
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Mare Nectaris (15.2°S, 34.6°E) is a typical multiring impact basin on the lunar surface. This letter uses data from the Chang’E-2 Lunar Microwave Sounder (CELMS), Clementine UV-VIS, and LRO Diviner to provide insight into the underlying factors responsible for the observed thermal anomalies. The results are as follows: (1) This letter identifies atypical brightness temperature (TB) anomalies in the eastern regions of Mare Nectaris, featuring lower TB during the daytime and higher TB at nighttime. These anomalous areas closely coincide with the distribution of olivine-rich regions. Olivine has a lower dielectric constant compared to its surroundings, and the TB anomalies may be associated with this lower dielectric constant. (2) We identified the distribution and primary causes of typical TB anomalies in Mare Nectaris, highlighting an anomalous region in the northwest. The anomaly in this region is primarily driven by albedo. (3) We also identified cold spots within three impact craters and revealed a correlation between these cold spots and the lunar surface rock abundance (RA) distribution.

title: Integrating Learned Retraction and Model-Based Resection Planning for Automated Central Airway Obstruction Removal
authors: Tanner Watts, Mariana Smith, James Ferguson, Nural Yilmaz, Paul Maria Scheikl, Bao Thach, Brendan Burkhart, Tucker Hermans, Anton Deguet, Axel Krieger, Alan Kuntz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: Surgeon shortages have driven significant recent advances in robotic surgical assistance. To progress toward surgical automation, we address transoral central airway obstruction (CAO) removal, selecting this procedure for its relatively constrained environment and clear clinical objectives. Prior work has demonstrated successful CAO removal with single-port, minimally invasive robotic systems, making it a promising target for autonomy. We present a new autonomous system designed for CAO removal that integrates a learning-based tissue retraction policy with a model-based resection planner, deployed on a bimanual robotic platform with vision guidance. While our long-term motivation is minimally invasive intervention, we evaluate our approach in an open-surgery setting, enabling rapid development and testing. We evaluate our system in 12 ex vivo CAO removal procedures running at three distinct levels of autonomy. Our results indicate that the learned retraction policy performs similarly or better than a manually designed heuristic, with a mean surgeon-rated score (1-10) of 8.0± 1.6 compared to 6.8± 2.5, and a mean percent tumor volume removal of 113.9± 18.8% compared to 111.9± 13.3%. The model-based resections performed best when supervised, resulting in less tissue damage and better cutting accuracy. Furthermore, our approach produced clinically successful outcomes in all eight supervised autonomous trials. Notably, in one case, the system achieved complete tumor removal without any human intervention. Our overall findings underscore the importance of high-level supervision, revealing targets for future automation.

title: Fixed-Time Autonomous Berthing Control of Unmanned Surface Vehicles Under Output Constraints Based on Barrier Lyapunov Function
authors: Qi Wang, Xiaofei Yang, Jiabao Hu, Shihong Ding, Hao Shen, Zhengrong Xiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Autonomous berthing is a critical step in realizing the full autonomy of unmanned surface vehicles (USVs), which can essentially be regarded as a trajectory-tracking task. It can be further transformed into a problem of nonlinear systems with output constraints. This paper proposes a novel adaptive fixed-time backstepping control scheme based on the barrier Lyapunov function (BLF) for autonomous berthing of USVs. Firstly, a new barrier Lyapunov function is designed to solve the output asymmetric constraint requirement of the autonomous berthing system, and it is also adaptive to the unconstrained system without changing the control structure. Secondly, the convergence of adaptive fixed-time control and bounded tracking of BLF are combined to conquer the long convergence time and nonlinear system uncertainty. Finally, simulation and field tests are conducted to verify our proposed scheme’s superiority.

title: Riemannian Manifold Optimization for Amplitude-Constrained Beampattern Synthesis
authors: Jifei Xu, Kai Wang, Yunlong Lu, Zhen Zhang, Lin Mei, Ye Wang, Chaofeng Ding, Ming Yu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: Beampattern synthesis is essential in modern communication, radar, and electronic warfare systems as it enables the design of customized radiation patterns. This letter introduces a method that employs Riemannian manifold optimization to effectively handle both the constant modulus constraint and dynamic range ratio (DRR) control in array beampattern synthesis. A multi-objective optimization function is developed to ensure uniform mainlobe response, ensure smooth beam transitions, concentrate energy at the beam center, and effectively suppress sidelobes. Additionally, log-sum-exp (LSE) smoothing techniques are utilized to convert non-smooth problems into differentiable forms, precise control of the beam direction is achieved through exponential transformations, and a smoothing term based on the Laplacian matrix is introduced to minimize power deviation between beams. In addition, a DRR constraint is constructed using complex circles, ensuring that the constraint remains rigorously maintained throughout the optimization process. This letter demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method through examples of array pattern optimization under amplitude constraints. The results indicate that the proposed method not only achieves precise main lobe performance but also provides effective sidelobe suppression, all while strictly adhering to the amplitude constraints.

title: Predicting the Best of N Visual Trackers
authors: Basit Alawode, Sajid Javed, Arif Mahmood, Jiri Matas
abstract: We observe that the performance of SOTA visual trackers surprisingly strongly varies across different video attributes and datasets. No single tracker remains the best performer across all tracking attributes and datasets. To bridge this gap, for a given video sequence, we predict the “Best of the N Trackers”, called the BofN meta-tracker. At its core, a Tracking Performance Prediction Network (TP2N) selects a predicted best performing visual tracker for the given video sequence using only a few initial frames. We also introduce a frame-level BofN meta-tracker that keeps predicting the best performer after regular temporal intervals. The TP2N is based on self-supervised learning architectures MocoV2, SwAv, BT, and DINO; experiments show that DINO with ViT-S as a backbone performs the best. The video-level BofN meta-tracker outperforms, by a large margin, existing SOTA trackers on nine standard benchmarks – LaSOT, TrackingNet, GOT-10K, VOT2019, VOT2021, VOT2022, UAV123, OTB100, and WebUAV-3M. Further improvement is achieved by the frame-level BofN meta-tracker effectively handling variations in the tracking scenarios within long sequences. For instance, on GOT-10k, BofN meta-tracker average overlap is 88.7% and 91.1% with video and frame-level settings, respectively. The best performing tracker, RTS, achieves 85.20% AO. On VOT2022, BofN expected average overlap is 67.88% and 70.98% with video and frame level settings, compared to the best performing ARTrack, 64.12%. This work also presents an extensive evaluation of competitive tracking methods on all commonly used benchmarks, following their protocols. The code, the trained models, and the results will be made publicly available on https://github.com/BasitAlawode/Best_of_N_Trackers.

title: Temperature-Characteristic Survey of a 1000 W LDMOS Power Amplifier
authors: Qian Lin, Da-an Zhao, Mei-qian Wang, Fei You, Ji-hua Wu, Ying-chun Lv
abstract: To investigate the temperature characteristics of a laterally double-diffused metal oxide semiconductor (LDMOS) 1000 W shortwave solid-state power amplifier (PA), a comprehensive series of tests has been conducted. The results indicate that the output power (Pout), gain, power-added efficiency (PAE), and two-tone power of the PA all decrease significantly with rising temperature. Additionally, both the second and third harmonics increase as temperature rises. Similar trends were observed during temperature cycle testing. Further analysis reveals that high temperatures can dramatically reduce electron mobility and a reduction in scattering between electrons and the lattice, thereby intensifying self-heating effects. Concurrently, high temperatures can also increase thermal resistance (R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>), which in turn reduces the efficiency of the power amplifier. Moreover, both the second and third harmonics increase linearly with rising temperature. To ensure stable performance of the amplifier across different temperatures, a temperature compensation circuit has been proposed to offset the degradation in performance. This study provides an important reference for the reliability design of LDMOS power amplifiers.

title: Insight from Parallel Doctors of Parallel Hospitals: New AI for New Medicine and Health Sciences
authors: Fei-Yue Wang, Jing Yang, Jiaxi Liu, Yongjun Wang
abstract: As Artificial Intelligence (AI) is impacting medical science and practice rapidly and profoundly [1], people wonder what future patients, doctors, treatments, hospitals, and medical colleges would look like after Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI Agents? We would like to share our experiences and thoughts from our projects in parallel intelligence for medicine and hospitals since 2013 [2]–[4].

title: Distributed Estimation under DoS Attacks for Multi-subsystems with Local Constraints
authors: Yang Xu, Xiaohui Hao, Shun Liu
abstract: In this paper, the distributed estimation problem is addressed for multi-subsystem with DoS attacks and local constraints. The local constraint between neighboring modes are only known to each subsystem and distributed iteration is performed to satisfy the constraint of each node. The attacker can launch denial of service (DoS) attacks on the communication channel between neighboring nodes, making it impossible to receive the estimates of the neighbor node for iteration when a DoS attack occurs. Hence, a distributed iterative estimation scheme is constructed under DoS attacks, in which the compensation estimate is designed based on its own estimates and the local constraint. Then the convergence conditions are derived to ensure that the estimation error is monotonic and non-increasing in the distributed iterative process. Finally, the validity of the compensation estimates and the convergence of the distributed iterative updates are demonstrated by a collaborative navigation example.

title: Leveraging Network Structure to Emulate Quantum Memory_supp1-3636661.pdf
authors: Hilal Sultan Duranoglu Tunc
abstract: Quantum memories, which play a critical role in various aspects of quantum networks—such as timing synchronization, fidelity preservation, network performance continuity, and efficient resource management—are not well-suited for practical deployment due to their high cost and complex implementation requirements. For this reason, in our study, we propose a low-cost and easy-to-implement alternative method called soft memory, which does not require any physical quantum memory hardware and is based on a delay-aware routing strategy. Under varying threshold and request time window values, we evaluate two key performance metrics—mean time difference and request success rate—across three types of quantum networks: (i) memoryless quantum networks, (ii) quantum networks equipped with fixed qubit storage time, and (iii) the proposed soft memory architecture. Despite requiring no additional physical hardware, the soft memory approach achieves a request success rate nearly equivalent to that of a quantum memory with 0.15-second storage time, while providing a lower mean time difference.

title: Damping of Low-Frequency Oscillation for Grid-Forming Converters With DC-Link Voltage-Synchronization Control
authors: Xiaokui Liu, Taihang He, Shanxu Duan, Changsong Chen
abstract: Grid-forming (GFM) converters with dc-link voltage-synchronization control (DVSC) are capable of simultaneously regulating dc-link voltage and achieving synchronization with ac grid. However, the interactions between DVSC and dc-link constant power dynamics may lead to low-frequency oscillations (LFOs) of GFM converters. This article develops a dc-link impedance-based equivalent circuit model for GFM converters with DVSC. The analysis reveals that the lack of positive resistance in dc-link impedance leads to LFO instability in GFM converters. To address this issue, a damping method, based on dc-link voltage feedforward (DVF) control is proposed, effectively suppressing oscillations and enhancing dynamic response performances. Theoretical analysis demonstrates that the proposed DVF-based damping method implements an active damper on the dc side and avoids inherent synchronous oscillations. Experimental results validate the theoretical analysis and the effectiveness of the proposed damping method.

title: Continuous Control-Set Model-Predictive Control for a Series-Wound DC Motor Drive
authors: Diego Montoya-Acevedo, Oscar Danilo Montoya, Alejandro Garcés-Ruiz, Catalina González-Castaño, Carlos Restrepo
abstract: This article presents a continuous control-set model-predictive control (CCS-MPC) for speed regulation of a series dc motor powered by a dc–dc converter (buck or boost converter). The proposed control considers the nonlinear structure of the converter-motor system and formulates an optimal control problem that guarantees a unique and global optimum solution in each time step. Furthermore, closed-loop stability is ensured using the discrete-time Lyapunov theory and the Karush–Kuhn–Tucker conditions. A disturbance observer is used to estimate the load torque, enabling precise control and mitigating variations and uncertainties in the parameters. Experimental results in both buck and boost setups demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves faster dynamics, shorter settling times, and more reliable speed regulation compared with traditional methods, for both regulating and tracking speed.

title: A Partly Isolated Three-Port DC–DC Converter With Improved Dual Phase Shift Modulation Strategy for Hybrid Energy Storage Systems
authors: Yushun Zhao, Dongsheng Yu, Qiuyue Zhong, Mingxue Li, Fujiang Chi, Samson S. Yu
abstract: Energy storage converters and their modulation strategies with high adaptability and operation capabilities considering multiinput and multioutput scenarios are important for meeting the needs of hybrid energy storage systems (HESSs), particularly in low-voltage scenarios such as household-scale microgrids and light EVs. By combining the advantages of battery and supercapacitor, this study proposes a novel partly isolated three-port dc–dc converter (PI3DC) for HESS. This converter is designed based on a partly isolated structure by reusing the high-voltage (HV) side switches. An improved dual phase shift (IDPS) modulation strategy is then introduced to suppress the leakage inductance current peaks by modulating the HV side switches and enabling zero current switching (ZCS) of the battery side switches. Experimental results indicate the effectiveness of the proposed topology and modulation strategies. Compared to the existing modulation strategies, the proposed IDPS modulation strategy can reduce the root mean square (rms) of leakage inductance current by 52% and improve system efficiency by nearly 10% under tested conditions.

title: A Bidirectional LLC Resonant Converter With a Variable Inductor and Resonant Frequency Tracking for Wide Voltage Range Operation
authors: Cheol-Hee Jo, Dong-Hee Kim
abstract: This letter proposes a bidirectional LLC resonant converter with a variable inductor and resonant frequency tracking for wide voltage range operation. By adjusting the inductance and tracking the resonant frequency via switching-frequency control, the proposed converter maintains resonant operation in both charging and discharging modes over the entire voltage and load range, significantly enhancing conversion efficiency. In addition, at the resonant frequency, the proposed bidirectional LLC resonant converter enables the magnetizing inductance to be involved in the resonance, which further reduces the current magnitude in each component compared to conventional LLC converters. A 1.5 kW hardware prototype with a 400 V input and a 240–400 V output range was developed to verify the performance. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed converter achieves peak efficiencies of 97.27% and 97.43% in charging and discharging modes, respectively.

title: Joint Beamforming for NOMA Assisted Pinching Antenna Systems (PASS)
authors: Deqiao Gan, Xiaoxia Xu, Jiakuo Zuo, Xiaohu Ge, Yuanwei Liu
abstract: Pinching antenna system (PASS) configures the positions of pinching antennas (PAs) along dielectric waveguides to change both large-scale fading and small-scale scattering, which is known as pinching beamforming. A novel non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) assisted PASS framework is proposed for downlink multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) communications. The transmit power minimization problem is formulated to jointly optimize the transmit beamforming, pinching beamforming, and power allocation. To solve this highly nonconvex problem, both gradient-based and swarm-based optimization methods are developed. 1) For gradient-based method, a majorization-minimization and penalty dual decomposition (MM-PDD) algorithm is developed. The Lipschitz gradient surrogate function is constructed based on MM to tackle the nonconvex terms of this problem. Then, the joint optimization problem is decomposed into subproblems that are alternatively optimized based on PDD to obtain stationary closed-form solutions. 2) For swarm-based method, a fast-convergent particle swarm optimization and zero forcing (PSO-ZF) algorithm is proposed. Specifically, the PA position-seeking particles are constructed to explore high-quality pinching beamforming solutions. Moreover, ZF-based transmit beamforming is utilized by each particle for fast fitness function evaluation. Simulation results demonstrate that: i) The proposed NOMA assisted PASS and algorithms outperforms the conventional NOMA assisted massive antenna system. The proposed framework reduces over 95.22% transmit power compared to conventional massive MIMO-NOMA systems. ii) Swarm-based optimization outperforms gradient-based optimization by searching effective solution subspace to avoid stuck in undesirable local optima.
