title: Beam Expansion for High-Power Transmission in Solid-Core to Hollow-Core Fiber Coupling
authors: V. Mičín, A. Zhong, S. Zvánovec, R. Slavík, M. Komanec
abstract: We increase power-handling capabilities of hollow-core to solid-core fiber connection by expanding the mode-field size at the solid-core to air interface. Using a combination of short segments of coreless and graded-index fibers, we achieve low-loss <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(<0.2 ~\text{dB})$</tex> while expanding the beam to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex>.

title: Study on Remote Sensing Inversion of Subsurface Chlorophyll in the South China Sea Based on Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Yuanzheng Gao, Xiaoling Li, Xiaoyu Liu, Xiang Gong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Understanding the vertical structure of chlorophylla (Chl-a) is essential for assessing ocean primary productivity, biogeochemical cycles, and carbon fluxes, yet this information cannot be directly obtained from satellite observations. In this study, we developed a novel convolutional neural network-based model (CNN-SCMs) to estimate the vertical distribution of subsurface Chl-a concentration from satellite-derived surface parameters. CMEMS Chl-a model data and NOAA OISST data from the South China Sea (SCS) were fused to construct the training dataset. Using only sea surface Chl-a concentration, sea surface temperature, and month as inputs, CNN-SCMs predicts Chl-a profiles within the $0-150 \mathrm{~m}$ depth range. The model achieved an RMSE of $0.11 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$ and a correlation coefficient of 0.84 on the test dataset. Temporal inversion results at the SEATS station and vertical distributions along the $116^{\circ} \mathrm{E}$ and $18^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$ transects further confirmed the model’s effectiveness and accuracy.

title: Unveiling the Critical Role of Extinction Ratio in Four Wave Mixing Generation for GaP-OI Microresonators
authors: Ning Ding, Weiren Cheng, Xucheng Zhang, Xingyu Tang, Naiqin Bu, Zhenyu Liu, Mingjian You, Zhengqi Li, Ziming Zhang, Jiaxin Hou, Junke Zhou, Xingchen Ji, Qiancheng Zhao
abstract: We demonstrate an 11.95 dB enhancement in four wave mixing efficiency for high extinction ratio cavity compared to the low extinction ratio one in the gallium phosphide-on-insulator (GaP-OI) microresonator.

title: A Novel Approach to Enhance Context-Aware Process Mining; Detecting Non-Conformance and Bottleneck Root Causes
authors: Behrang Aghilinasab, Fereidoon Shams Aliee
publish: 2025 9th Iranian Conference on Advances in Enterprise Architecture (ICAEA)
abstract: In today’s world, improving efficiency and reducing costs in logistics services are critical challenges for organizations, as bottlenecks and process non-conformities can significantly disrupt performance and competitiveness. This research, using a process mining approach, aims to identify and analyze these issues in detail. Data related to logistics processes were collected from organizational management systems, and after cleaning, were analyzed using K-Prototype models for clustering, Random Forest Classifier for prediction, and Apriori for discovering association rules. The results indicate that process mining can effectively identify bottlenecks and process inconsistencies, providing innovative solutions to improve operational times, reduce costs, and enhance process alignment with designed models. This study highlights the importance and effectiveness of process mining in improving performance and increasing the competitiveness of logistics services.

title: Multi-motor Synchronous Control Algorithm Based on Single Neuron PID
authors: Guoshan Xie, Lijuan Guo, Yingdong Rao, Jing Mo, Longfei Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: To solve the problem of driving wheel slippage caused by asynchronous speeds of multiple driving motors in the crossarm installation robot for rural distribution networks, and to improve the robot’s pole-climbing stability, this paper proposes a composite control strategy that integrates adjacent cross-coupling control with single neuron PID direct torque control. Firstly, a mathematical model of the brushless DC motor is established, and a multi-motor adjacent cross-coupling structure is designed. By defining tracking errors and synchronization errors, the state correlation between each motor and its adjacent motors is realized. Secondly, a single neuron PID is used to design the error controller, which utilizes the self-learning characteristics of neurons to achieve online tuning of PID parameters, thereby enhancing the antiinterference ability of the system. Finally, a simulation model of the motor synchronization control system is built using Simulink, and the verification is carried out by simulating working conditions with motor parameter differences and sudden load changes. The simulation results show that this strategy can make the motor speed tracking error converge to 0 quickly. When the load changes suddenly, the maximum synchronization error is controlled within $1 \%$ of the speed. Moreover, compared with the ordinary PID, the single neuron PID significantly reduces torque ripple, effectively improving the multi-motor speed synchronization accuracy and system robustness, which provides technical support for the stable operation of the crossarm installation robot.

title: Data-Driven Decision Making with Diverse Temporal Tastes Under Dataset Contamination: A Koopman-Based Approach
authors: Peijiang Liu, Xindi Yang, Hao Zhang, Zhuping Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: This paper investigates data-driven decision making for unknown systems with contaminative datasets, where the objectives exhibit varying performance preferences across temporal scales. Firstly, we present a data-driven framework enhanced by the Koopman operator to extract the system dynamics from contaminative datasets, while diverse temporal preferences are reflected in various discounts on accumulated utility. Since non-exponential discounts break Bellman's Principle of Optimality, we propose temporal equilibrium strategy for performance guarantee. Furthermore, the temporal equilibrium strategy is analyzed with existence and convergence/divergence rate design. Finally, numerical results verify the effectiveness of our framework.

title: Research on the Dielectric Properties of Transformers in Low-Temperature Environments Based on Low-Temperature Detection Technology
authors: Limin Qu, Jingqi Li, Jian Zhang, Shengwei Cai, Dewen Zhang, Guotai Yang, Peng Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Aiming at the problems such as insufficient measurement accuracy and difficulty in data correction in the detection of transformer dielectric properties caused by the lowtemperature environment in alpine regions, this research conducts work from two aspects: equipment improvement and experimental research. The traditional detection device is upgraded for low-temperature adaptability by using a dynamic temperature control display unit, cold resistant cables, high density foam materials, low temperature resistant circuit boards, and wide temperature range electronic components. Experimental verification is carried out in a laboratory low temperature test chamber. The results show that the improved device has stable performance and accurate measurement, and can accurately reflect the dielectric properties of standard parts and transformer models. Based on the on-site measured data in the extremely lowtemperature environment in Mohe, this paper further analyzes the evolution law of the dielectric properties of transformers under low-temperature conditions, providing a reference for on-site tests of coil-type equipment in low-temperature environments.

title: Multiresolution Physics-Informed Deep Learning to Solve Electromagnetic Inverse Scattering Problems
authors: Ji-Yuan Wang, Liang Zhang, Yun-Chuan Wang, Cheng-Tao Zhao, Xin-Yue Lou, Xiao-Min Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A multiresolution physics-informed deep learning (DL) method is proposed to solve electromagnetic inverse scattering problems (ISPs) by embedding the objective function of the traditional full-wave solver into the loss function of the physics-informed neural network (PINN) within a multi-focusing scheme. Numerical experiments are carried out to demonstrate the proposed DL-based method outperforms the traditional full-wave solver in terms of inversion accuracy.

title: Comparison of Deep Learning Models for Early Dementia Diagnosis
authors: M. Rupa, K. Rajkumar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: One of the most common forms of dementia is Alzheimer's disease, which is characterized by progressive brain damage and no cure. Every four seconds, someone around the world is diagnosed with dementia, which can have devastating consequences, including death. Consequently, it is essential to recognize dementia early. Deterioration of cognitive and social capacities, brought on by Alzheimer's disease, reduces a person's ability to live independently and is a major contributor to the worldwide burden of dementia. Dementia patients often experience a gradual erasure of recent memories, which starts in the early stages of the disease and worsens over time. For improved care, a prompt diagnosis is crucial. Determining if a person has mild, moderate, or no dementia is possible with the use of brain MRI imaging. For this classification, this study suggests a model that uses a comparison analysis of multiple deep learning architectures, such as ResNet50, Inception V3, Inception ResNet V2, DenseNet, and MobileNet.

title: All-metal Corrugated Horn Antenna with Out-of-Band RCS Reduction
authors: Zhuqiong Lai, Guanghua Liang, Yaxin Xu, Wei Han, Yuan Zhou, Jianxing Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper proposes an all-metal corrugated horn antenna featuring low out-of-band radar cross section (RCS), achieved through phase cancellation mechanism. To realize RCS reduction performance, the corrugated horn is divided into eight identical sections with three distinct height differences among these sections. The reflection phase cancellation can be attained through the path difference introduced by a designed height step among different regions. Simulation results demonstrate that the monostatic RCS of the proposed horn is reduced by more than 10 dB across the frequency bands of 8.4-12.2 GHz and 8.1-12.2 GHz under normal incidence for x- and y-polarization, respectively. Furthermore, the proposed horn maintains excellent broadside radiation characteristics from 2.4 to 3.5 GHz, gain up to 11.3 dB, with a gain variation of less than 0.8 dB.

title: Application of GoogLeNet Architecture (Inception-V3) for Rice Seed Image Classification
authors: Kurniawan Eka Permana, Iwan Santosa, Abdullah Basuki Rahmat, Nurhaliza
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Rice variety classification plays a strategic role in ensuring seed purity, increasing agricultural productivity, and supporting food quality assurance. This research proposes a GoogLeNet-based model (Inception-V3) to classify five rice varieties, namely Arborio, Basmati, Ipsala, Jasmine, and Karacadag, by utilizing gray-scale images. Preprocessing was performed through image resizing, data augmentation, and pixel normalization, with evaluation using classification report and confusion matrix. Experimental results demonstrate that GoogLeNet consistently achieves high accuracy, ranging from 98% to 99.4%, across a range of hyperparameter settings, confirming its robustness and adaptability. The model performs particularly well in classifying Ipsala and Jasmine varieties, with minimal misclassifications observed in the best-performing configurations. Compared to other deep learning models such as CNN, VGG19, and ResNet50, GoogLeNet exhibits superior accuracy and greater stability under parameter variations. Benchmarking against traditional classifiers and recent studies further reinforces its effectiveness, showing consistently high performance across five rice varieties: Arborio, Basmati, Ipsala, Jasmine, and Karacadag. Furthermore, this research supports Sustainable Development Goal 2 (SDG 2) by enhancing agricultural productivity through the precise classification of rice varieties. By ensuring seed purity and optimizing farming inputs, the proposed model contributes to higher crop yields and sustainable food production, addressing global food security challenges.

title: Design of a Triple Band Near Perfect Terahertz Absorber for 6G Communication Systems
authors: Md. Moniruzzaman, Md. Imtiaz Uddin, Mohamed Ouda, Md. Hasenur Rahman Asu, Md. Golam Rabbani, Mandeep Singh, Mohammad Tariqul Islam
abstract: This work demonstrates a triple-band metamaterial absorber achieving near-perfect absorption at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.87,5.50$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.38 \text{THz}(99.3-99.6 \%)$</tex> using tungsten resonators on FR-4. The symmetrical design exhibits polarization independence (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-90^{\circ}$</tex>) and angular stability (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-60^{\circ}$</tex>) with negligible cross-polarization. These qualities make it suitable for 6G and sensing.

title: Nonlinear Switching and Discrete Solitons in Femtosecond Laser-Inscribed Photonic s-p Orbitals
authors: Gayathry Rajeevan, Sebabrata Mukherjee
abstract: We develop femtosecond laser-fabricated asymmetric couplers and one-dimensional zig-zag arrays of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$s-p$</tex> orbitals consisting of resonant single-mode and two-mode waveguides. We demonstrate all-optical nonlinear switching and highly localized discrete solitons, spectrally residing in the photonic band gap.

title: Electro-Optic Modulation Comb at Telecommunications Wavelengths Using Multi-Stage Silicon Modulators
authors: Tatsuto Okubo, Haruki Yaguchi, Guangwei Cong, Rai Kou, Yamato Kitamura, Xuejun Xu, Kenichi Hitachi, Junia Nomura, Noritsugu Yamamoto, Katsuya Oguri, Koji Yamada, and Atsushi Ishizawa
abstract: We demonstrate electro-optic (EO) comb generation using a silicon modulator in the telecommunications wavelength band at a repetition rate of 1.25 GHz. Furthermore, we achieve supercontinuum generation employing a silicon nitride waveguide. The proposed method realizes a broadband EO comb in a shortened optical path.

title: The Electromagnetic Pulse Coupling Characteristics of Aircraft Electronic Equipment Cable
authors: Chunyong Han
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The coupling interference of electromagnetic pulses (EMP) on aircraft cables can easily lead to the malfunction or paralysis of onboard electronic equipment, severely threatening the survivability and operational effectiveness of the aircraft. Directed irradiation tests were conducted on the aircraft from the left and front using an EMP simulator. The results indicate: (1) When irradiating from the left, there is a positive correlation between the EMP irradiation electric field strength and the oscillation amplitude of the induced current in the cable, regardless of horizontal or vertical polarization. However, no significant positive correlation exists between the peak induced current and the EMP irradiation intensity. (2) When irradiating from the front, the peak induced current in the cable is positively correlated with the EMP irradiation intensity. The induced current exhibits small oscillation attenuation and rapidly returns to a stable state, with similar oscillation durations across different irradiation intensities. The variation in induced current is minimal when the irradiation intensity increases from E1 to E2. (3)The peak induced current from left-side irradiation is significantly higher than that from frontside irradiation. When the irradiation intensity increases from E1 to E2, the oscillation amplitude of the induced current is much greater for left-side irradiation compared to front-side irradiation. These findings provide a basis for assessing the EMP protection capabilities of aircraft electronic equipment and hold significant engineering importance.

title: Single to Quad-Motor Architectures in Battery Electric Vehicle Using MATLAB/Simulink
authors: Praveenkumar, Bansilal Bairwa, Krishna, Veena
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: This paper presents a MATLAB/Simulink-based simulation study analyzing five distinct motor architectures in Battery Electric Vehicles (BEVs): single-, dual-, tri-motor (front and rear-mounted), and quad-motor configurations. Using a fixed 100 kWh battery pack, performance parameters were evaluated under the New European Driving Cycle (NEDC). Metrics include energy consumption, range, SOC profiles, and 0–100 km/h acceleration. Results show a rise in energy consumption from 21.2 to 24.4 kWh/100 km and improved acceleration from 8.7 s to 5.8 s from 1M to 4M configurations. Estimated range drops as motor count increases, with 1M reaching 4716.98 km and 4M limiting to 4098.36 km. The simulation identifies energy-performance trade-offs that guide optimal powertrain design for future BEVs.

title: The Ranging Method of LFMCW Radar Based on the Improved Rife Algorithm
authors: Zhenyu Li, Yuting Huang, Peihu Cong, Fusheng Zhao, Xingwen Zhao, Xiangdong Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: In the LFMCW (Linear Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave) radar system, the frequency estimation of beat frequency signals is of vital importance for the ranging accuracy. However, the traditional Rife algorithm, due to the misjudgment of the interpolation direction, will generate significant errors in the noisy environment, especially when the real frequency is close to the quantization frequency point. To address these limitations, a novel PD-I-Rife algorithm is proposed. This algorithm first calculates the phase difference between the maximum amplitude spectral line and the adjacent maximum value to determine the interpolation direction. Then, based on the I-Rife algorithm, for different regions where the real frequency is located, it uses more accurate frequency shift factors for interpolation calculation to estimate the frequency value. Theoretical analysis and simulation verification show that the proposed algorithm achieves higher estimation accuracy near the quantization point and maintains stable performance under low SNR conditions, confirming its effectiveness in radar applications.

title: Combination Decoupling for Adjacent Antenna Elements Using Dual SRRs and T-Slot
authors: Kai Fei, Shengyuan Luo, Dmitry Kholodnyak, Xiwen Fu, Bowei Zhou, Yingsong Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Densely integrated microstrip patch arrays require high isolation without sacrificing radiation performance, even at extreme element spacings. Here, two adjacent patches are placed with an inter element center to center spacing of just 0.06  λ₀ (λ₀ referenced to 5.96 GHz), a regime in which mutual coupling is typically severe. We introduce a single layer composite decoupling structure that integrates dual split ring resonators (SRRs) on the radiator with a T-shaped slot in the ground plane. The SRRs elevate the odd mode impedance and suppress surface wave driven coupling, while the T slot increases the shunt surface impedance and disrupts return currents; their co tuned resonances form a hybrid stopband aligned with the operating band. Full wave simulations (CST) show that at 5.96 GHz the inter port isolation improves from −10.6 dB to −41.2 dB, while the input reflection reaches −46.7 dB. The H plane pattern remains essentially unchanged, and the E plane main beam level increases from 5.71 dB to 6.88 dB with sidelobe/backlobe suppression. Even at a spacing of only 0.06 λ₀, the fabrication friendly structure markedly enhances isolation without degrading radiation.

title: A Dual-Polarized Omnidirectional Stepped Dielectric Resonator Antenna with Enhanced Gain and Bandwidth
authors: Bohao Yu, Zhanjun Lai, Kwok Wa Leung, Guosheng Su, Jianzhang Liang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A dual-polarized omnidirectional stepped cylindrical dielectric resonator antenna (DRA) with enhanced gain and bandwidth is proposed for WiFi applications. A planar patch excites the TM01δ+4 mode for vertical polarization, and a loop excites the TE01δ+5 mode for horizontal polarization. These high-order modes are used to obtain high gain in both polarizations. Air regions are introduced in the stepped DRA to reduce the quality factor and improve the bandwidth, while the feed modes combine with the DR modes to further widen the bandwidth. Simulated results show an overlapping bandwidth of 15.55% (5.10–5.96 GHz), covering the 5.2- and 5.8-GHz WiFi bands, with a peak gain of 5.06 dBi.

title: Digital Health Challenges and Opportunities for Health-Care IT Professionals
authors: Vinaytosh Mishra, Deepika Saxena, Ashutosh Kumar Singh
abstract: Digital health technologies can address perennial problems associated with availability, accessibility, and affordability and help achieve universal health coverage in resource-constrained health systems. These benefits can be leveraged if we address key digital health implementation challenges. This article outlines six challenges and six opportunities related to digital health. The proposed study provides an implementation framework for digital health in a resource-constrained health system by prioritizing these identified challenges utilizing the Delphi Analytical Hierarchy Process. The results of this study concluded and suggested that technological- and infrastructure-related bottlenecks must be addressed before regulatory and human resources issues to enhance the digital health facilities in developing countries.

title: AI Tactics, Now
authors: Stephen J. Andriole
abstract: This article discusses the tactical steps organizations should take to apply artificial intelligence effectively. The focus shifts from high-level strategy to ground-level implementation. The first step requires the establishment of an artificial intelligence (AI) governance framework, which includes internal policies, regulatory compliance, oversight mechanisms, and documentation requirements. Next, organizations must build out a small, rapid prototyping squad to work on quick, high-impact pilot projects. This squad should use process mining to identify specific, broken internal processes that need fixing. The team should then select the appropriate AI tool based on the broken process’s need: machine learning for prediction, generative AI for creation, or an AI agent for autonomous actions. Success is measured via prototypes by assessing performance versus the human baseline.

title: Study of Lightning Response Characteristics of Lightning Arrester Based on Equivalent Circuit Model

title: Scalable Photonic Neurons for High-Speed Automatic Modulation Classification
authors: Yuxin Wang, Weipeng Zhang, Eric C. Blow, Joshua C. Lederman, Bhavin J. Shastri, Paul R. Prucnal
abstract: Automatic modulation classification (AMC) is becoming increasingly critical in the context of growing demands for ultra-wideband, low-latency signal intelligence in 5G/6G networks. Photonics-based AMC addresses the bandwidth and real-time adaptability limitations faced by traditional radiofrequency (RF) electronics. This paper presents the first experimental photonic implementation of AMC, achieved through a fully functional photonic neural network built from scalable microring resonators that co-integrate electro-optic modulation and weighting. This work also represents the first system-level deployment of such compact photonic neurons in a real photonic neural network, demonstrating the significant potential of photonic computing for large-scale, complex RF intelligence in next-generation wireless communication systems.

title: Enhanced Flatness in 25 GHz Electro-Optic Frequency Combs via Precision Bias Control
authors: D. Pavitra Varsha, Mandeep Singh, Deepa Venkitesh
abstract: We demonstrate a 25 GHz -spaced optical frequency comb using cascaded modulators and a dither-free bias controller that compensates for bias drift with 0.5 degree precision, improving comb flatness. Despite the RF power limitations, we obtained 13 lines within 5 dB, achieving an OSNR of 40 dB that closely aligns with simulation results.

title: Design of a Dual-Market Electricity Trading Mechanism for New Power Systems with High Share of Renewable Energy
authors: Jiajing Pan, Zhaoxia Jing, Keyi Yin, Yuxuan Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: The high penetration of intermittent renewable energy has brought significant challenges to wholesale electricity markets. However, The centralized bidding and clearing mechanism based on short-run marginal costs (SRMC) fails to adequately reflect the system regulation value of conventional energy units in new power systems, thereby makes the full recovery of their operating costs difficult. To address this issues, this paper proposes a dual-market trading mechanism. First, a dual-market bidding framework is proposed that incorporates supply-demand uncertainty, where the value of energy products from different market participants is assessed and categorized along three dimensions: energetic attributes, spatio-temporal controllability, and stochasticity. Next, a dual-market trading mechanism is developed by establishing controllable and uncontrollable energy markets with customized pricing and clearing rules. Finally, case studies are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed mechanism.

title: AI-Driven Smart Traffic Management: Enhancing Urban Mobility with Predictive and Adaptive Intelligence
authors: Sunkavilli Vijaya Nirmala, Subhani Shaik, Yalla Venkateswarlu
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Urban traffic congestion continues to pose challenges to mobility, productivity, and sustainability in smart cities. Traditional traffic control systems, based on fixed-time schedules, cannot dynamically adapt to fluctuating traffic conditions. This paper presents a dual-layer intelligent traffic signal control framework that integrates deep learning-based traffic flow prediction with reinforcement learning-driven adaptive signal optimization. Short-term traffic flow is predicted using CNN and RNN models trained on the PeMS dataset, while real-time detection of vehicles and emergency prioritization is enhanced through GPS and audio-based sensing. The reinforcement learning layer, implemented with DQN and PPO agents, optimizes traffic light phases using reward signals that balance wait-time reduction, flow efficiency, and emergency vehicle passage. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed system reduces average waiting time from 120 s to 84 s, improves flow efficiency from 65 % to 88 %, and increases emergency prioritization accuracy to 92 %. The framework, deployed on real-world data streams, highlights the potential of combining predictive deep learning with adaptive reinforcement learning for scalable and sustainable urban traffic management.

title: A Gamified Training System for the Attention Network with Broad Transfer Benefits
authors: Shaodi Wang, Xingke Wang, Heng Gu, Qunli Yao, Chao Yang, Jiahui Yu, Zhaojie Ju, Gaoxiang Ouyang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: To investigate the effects of targeted training on attentional neuroplasticity, this study developed a training system with adaptive difficulty that acts on the three attentional subsystems: alerting, orienting, and executive control. Through a rigorous controlled experiment, we collected participants' electroencephalography (EEG) data and behavioral performance on a battery of standard paradigms (including ANT, Stroop, etc.) before and after training. The core neurophysiological finding, derived from the analysis of event-related Global Field Power (GFP), was that the training group displayed a more robust, cross-task neural activation pattern within critical post-stimulus processing windows compared to the control group. This result provides direct evidence that the training can reshape the neural underpinnings of attention. Crucially, this neural gain successfully transferred to a complex human-machine operation task, in which trained participants achieved significant improvements in both operational precision and response efficiency. In summary, this research demonstrates that the training system can effectively induce dual gains at both the neural and behavioral levels, which possess broad transfer value.

title: Photonics-Driven Terahertz Communication Systems Based on SiC/Si Platform Technologies
authors: T. Nagatsuma, W. Gao, Y. Kawamoto, H. Ito, T. Ishibashi
abstract: This paper presents our recent development of 300-GHz-band photodiodes and mixers using SiC- and Si-based platforms and demonstrates photonics-driven wireless communication systems.

title: Compression Feedback Control Design for an Origami-Inspired Soft Robotic Arm
authors: Shiqiang Li, Bingcong Jian, Haisheng Xia, Zhijun Li, Ying Feng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: To address the control challenges in flexible manipulator systems due to high-dimensional nonlinear dynamics, this study proposes a novel solution integrating compressed sensing and non-vector space control methods. Firstly, adaptive dimensionality reduction of manipulator sensing data is achieved via compressed sensing, effectively reducing computational complexity and enhancing real-time control performance. Subsequently, a nonlinear controller is designed based on nonvector space theory, and system stability is proven through the construction of Lyapunov functions, addressing the control accuracy deficiencies of traditional vector space methods in strongly coupled flexible arms. The simulation experiment results demonstrate the precise convergence and stability of the proposed controller, meeting the requirements of highprecision image alignment tasks in robotics and mechatronics applications.

title: Denoise and Attend: An AE-Transformer Approach to EEG Emotion Recognition
authors: Muhan Luo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Emotion recognition is valuable for mental-health assessment, intelligent healthcare, and human-computer interaction. However, approaches based on facial expressions or speech are vulnerable to intentional masking and environmental noise. This paper targets electroencephalography (EEG)-based emotion recognition and addresses two challenges: (i) limited discriminability and generalization of hand-crafted features, and (ii) high computational cost and low accuracy in classifying highdimensional representations. We propose a lightweight hybrid framework that fuses EEGNet with a Transformer encoder. EEGNet extracts emotion-related frequency, spatial, and temporal features using depthwise-separable convolutions and spatiotemporal fusion, improving feature expressiveness while keeping the parameter count low. An autoencoder (AE) then performs dimensionality reduction and denoising. Finally, a Transformer with multi-head self-attention and positional encoding models long-range temporal dependencies for global context. Experiments on the SEED dataset demonstrate that the baseline EEGNet achieves 83.65% accuracy for emotion classification, and incorporating the AE-Transformer module increases accuracy to $91.03 \%$, outperforming conventional methods. The results indicate that combining lightweight feature extraction with global temporal modeling is effective for highprecision EEG-based emotion recognition, with potential applications in mental-health monitoring and intelligent interaction. Future work will focus on improving real-time performance and evaluating cross-scenario generalization.

title: Digital Technology Integration Gaps in the Adoption of Briquettes for Sustainable Energy
authors: Roy Rizky Purba, Eriana Astuty, Kurniadi Kurniadi
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The gap between the enormous potential of coconut shell briquettes as an eco-friendly fuel, the abundance of coconut production waste in Indonesia, and the high levels of air pollution raises the research problem of “how to increase the intention to adopt coconut shell briquettes as a sustainable alternative fuel in Indonesia?” Therefore, based on the theory of planned behavior, this study aims to confirm the antecedents of the triggers for the intention to adopt coconut shell briquettes as a sustainable alternative fuel. This study uses a mixedmethods approach with a sequential explanatory research design. Online questionnaires were distributed cross-sectionally in March-July 2024 through a purposive sampling technique to obtain quantitative data, followed by in-depth interviews with briquette entrepreneurs in Bandung. The results show that the predicted adoption of coconut shell briquettes as an alternative fuel in Indonesia is relatively low, at only 30.9%. It is related to the weak use of digital technology to support this initiative. Therefore, it is essential to enhance the integration of digital technologies, including the use of artificial intelligence and blockchain-based supply chain systems. This study provides valuable insights for the government, coconut plantation managers, entrepreneurs, and the community in supporting the SDGs program, particularly in the context of responsible production and consumption in Indonesia.

title: DFB fiber laser line narrowing due to self-injection locking in a hybrid cavity with random reflector
authors: Mikhail I. Skvortsov, Kseniya V. Kolosova, Sofia R. Abdullina, Zhibzema E. Munkueva, Alexander V. Dostovalov, Evgeniy V. Podivilov, Sergey A. Babin
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: The effect of an additional random reflector providing self-injection locking of an erbium fiber DFB laser on linewidth narrowing is studied. In a hybrid cavity comprising a short artificial fs-inscribed random reflector in combination with a natural Rayleigh reflector in the form of 100-m SMF fiber connected to the DFB laser the effect is greatly enhanced. The instantaneous linewidth narrowing by 2 orders is demonstrated which is in approximate agreement with theoretical estimation. For the long-term linewidth, the narrowing of approximately 3 orders of magnitude is observed. Thus, a compact and stable single-frequency laser with quite narrow linewidth (<5 Hz long term) for a wide range of application has been developed.

title: Slack Federated Adversarial Training
authors: Jianing Zhu, Bo Han, Jiangchao Yao, Quanming Yao, Tongliang Liu, Jianliang Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Security and privacy concerns in real-world applications have led to the development of adversarially robust federated models. Previous works mainly target overcoming the adaptability constraints regarding communication and computation costs. However, the straightforward combination of adversarial training and federated learning might lead to undesired robust accuracy degradation emerging at later training stages. We reveal that the attribution behind this phenomenon is that the generated adversarial data could exacerbate the data heterogeneity among local clients, making the wrapped federated learning perform poorly. To deal with this problem, we introduce an $\alpha$-slack mechanism to relax the original learning objective of federated adversarial training, and propose a novel framework called Slack Federated Adversarial Training (SFAT) to combat the intensified heterogeneity. By assigning the client-wise slack during aggregation, SFAT realizes a weighted aggregation that alleviates the optimization bias induced by the local adversarial generation. We further extend to a more general setting, permitting both clients trained by standard/adversarial training in a unified framework, and propose SFAT* with a hierarchical aggregation schema for this scenario. Theoretically, we analyze the convergence of our method to properly relax the learning objective. Experimentally, we verify the rationality and effectiveness of our methods on various benchmarked and real-world datasets with different adversarial training and federated optimization methods.

title: An Exact Analytical Method for Arbitrary Matter-Waveform Generation in Optical Lattices
authors: Pradosh Basu, Sriganapathy Raghav, Utpal Roy
abstract: Generation and control of waveforms is a versatile tool for advanced technologies. Quantum arbitrary waveform generator is also in place by exploiting the quantum state of coherent light. Motivated by the high coherence and tunability of the trapped ultracold matter waves, which may offer a platform for arbitrary waveform generation with atoms, we present an exact analytical approach for designing the first atomic arbitrary waveform generator. Our method considers the dynamics of an one-dimensional Bose-Einstein condensate in a quantum simulation environment with a moving bichromatic optical lattice. Functional expressions and parameter regimes are derived for engineering some of the fundamental waveforms, including sinusoidal, sawtooth, triangular and square profiles. In addition, compound waveforms, such as step-sawtooth, triangular-square, slanted-square, and slanted-step-square are also constructed. A numerical stability analysis is explicated in support of the experimental feasibility of the reported atomic waveform generator.

title: Path Weaver ORAM: Improving ORAM Throughput via Random Path Scheduling
authors: Siyuan Ma, Taoteng Liao, Wei Shi, Yanlong Wen
abstract:
Oblivious RAM (ORAM) hides memory access patterns but imposes high bandwidth and latency overheads. Prior work (e.g., Hitchhiker) introduced path diversion to serve multiple logical requests in one traversal, yet diversion rarely triggers because it requires requests to lie on the same ancestor–descendant chain.

We present Path Weaver, an ORAM that turns diversion into the common case via random-path scheduling. Instead of a rigid root-to-leaf path, each traversal selects one uniformly random bucket per level; the controller then “stitches” per-level picks so different outstanding requests can be satisfied at different levels of the same traversal. A Tail-Widening scheme fetches a few additional buckets at the dense bottom levels, substantially increasing match opportunities with constant overhead. To keep hardware small, Path Weaver uses a compact position map and regenerates per-level choices on the fly with a pipelined pseudorandom function (PRF) overlapped with DRAM access; we micro-profile these stages to quantify their cost. The design targets random-access main memory (DRAM) and requires no changes to the software stack.

Path Weaver preserves the Path-style invariant of one legitimate bucket per level, thereby retaining indistinguishability and the same stash-overflow guarantees as Path ORAM. Evaluated in gem5 on SPEC CPU 2017, Path Weaver processes 2.32× more requests per traversal than Hitchhiker, reduces single-core ORAM latency by 2.1×, and accelerates four-core workloads by 3.3×. By making path diversion a core architectural feature, Path Weaver brings ORAM significantly closer to practical, ’deployonce” secure memory.

title: Performance and Complexity Analysis of RSMA in Asymmetric Mixed FSO/mmWave-RF Systems
authors: Akhilesh Kumar Savita, Anshul Jaiswal
abstract: This paper presents two asymmetric one-way full-duplex (FD) cooperative communication systems that incorporate advanced multiple access schemes. Both systems are formed using a mixed free-space optical (FSO)/millimeter wave (mmWave)-radio-frequency (RF) configuration, where the first hop employs a hybrid FSO/mmWave and the second hop utilizes RF links to support mobile connectivity for multiple users. The first system employs rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) to minimize successive interference cancellation (SIC) operations, termed the FD asymmetric cooperative-RSMA (C-RSMA) system. In contrast, the second system adopts quadrature RSMA (QRSMA) to eliminate SIC, termed the FD asymmetric C-QRSMA system. For comprehensive analysis, the FSO, mmWave, and RF links are modelled using Málaga-M distribution with pointing error, Nakagami-m, and κ − μ fading, respectively. Unlike existing works that focus on sum rate or signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio, this study derives outage probability, coverage probability, average sum rate, and energy efficiency. These metrics, derived in multi-user environments with imperfect SIC and signal space diversity, are validated through Monte Carlo simulations. Finally, the proposed systems are compared with state-of-the-art schemes, revealing that the systems not only enhance spectral efficiency but also significantly reduce system complexity.

authors: Xianfeng He, Yuze Li, Guowu Tang, Qijun Sun, Xingui Tang, Dan Zhang, Wei Zheng
abstract: Multifunctional optoelectronic logic gates (OELGs) hold significant promise for high-speed and high-security data processing applications. In this work, a Pt/Ga<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>/GaN heterojunction device is fabricated to implement multifunctional logic operations by leveraging a bias- and wavelength-selective competitive current mechanism. At 0-V bias, the device exhibits a significant pyro-photoelectric coupling effect, which markedly enhances the transient photoresponse to both 254- and 365-nm illumination. Under forward bias (0.55–2 V), 365-nm illumination simultaneously induces competing photogenerated current and recombination current, resulting in a net photocurrent under 254- and 365-nm co-illumination that is lower than that under 254-nm illumination alone. In contrast, under reverse bias, the photocurrent under dual illumination exceeds that under single-wavelength illumination. title: Towards Enhanced Precision Positioning with Parallel Intelligence and Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces
authors: Shuangshuang Han, Fei-Yue Wang, Yuhang Liu, Guiyang Luo, Fengzhong Qu
abstract: Dear Editor, As the Internet of things (IoT) and autonomous driving continue to evolve, positioning technology faces increasing demands for higher accuracy and reliability. Traditional positioning methods often struggle in complex signal environments with multipath interference and non-line-of-sight (NLOS) conditions. Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS), an innovative technology that can flexibly control signal propagation, offer new possibilities for positioning systems. To fully harness the potential of RIS, the concept of parallel intelligence becomes crucial. With parallel intelligence, artificial models run alongside real systems, enabling real-time monitoring and RIS optimization. This letter introduces a parallel intelligence-based RIS-aided positioning framework, designed to improve positioning accuracy and adaptability. The proposed approach introduces a system framework where artificial and physical systems interact for continuous RIS optimization. The technique holds significant potential in various applications, including smart transportation, autonomous driving, and industrial IoT.

title: Quantum-Inspired Trust Scoring for Zero Trust Security: Concepts, Models, and Research Directions
authors: Shengjie Xu, Yi Qian
abstract: This article explores the intersection of quantum computing and Zero Trust security by presenting a quantum-inspired trust scoring framework for modern networks. We introduce the key concepts underpinning quantum-inspired trust, including superposition, entanglement, and quantum measurement, and show how these principles enable the modeling of dynamic, contextual, and uncertain trust relationships. Our modular system architecture and simulation results demonstrate the advantages of quantum-inspired trust evaluation in terms of granularity, adaptability, and the modeling of complex interdependencies. Beyond implementation, we articulate a comprehensive research agenda, highlighting open challenges and future directions such as quantum algorithms for trust evaluation, quantum machine learning for trust pattern recognition, quantum-resilient Zero Trust architectures, and the integration of contextual factors. This work lays a foundation for advancing trust evaluation in Zero Trust systems and preparing cybersecurity for the emerging quantum era.

title: Mask: An Efficient And Tunable Volume-pattern Hiding Algorithm
authors: Kai Fan, Shiyuan Ji, Yaxin Sun, Hui Li, Yintang Yang, Lianhai Wang
abstract: We present Mask, an efficient and tunable algorithm for hiding volume patterns in multi-maps. Volume-pattern leakage, referring to the observable size of data returned by a query, enables adversaries to infer sensitive dataset information, posing severe privacy risks in multi-map scenarios. Designed to address this issue, Mask focuses on balancing storage/query overhead and privacy (a key trade-off in this field), allowing users to define parameters for random data distribution across buckets to realize fine-grained control over storage and query performance, integrating Bloom filters with a bounded cache for efficient indexing (optimizing performance under skewed query workloads); extended to MaskIO for reduced client-side storage, it obfuscates query indexes and uploads them to the server, achieving constant-bounded client storage overhead, and experiments show Mask outperforms the bucket-based peer Veil with 2–4 × higher performance and a lower stash ratio.

title: Zero-Shot Anomaly Segmentation via Query-Level Uncertainty Analysis
authors: Kimin Yun, Yuseok Bae
abstract: We propose a training-free method for anomaly segmentation that leverages the internal signals of pretrained transformer-based segmentation models. Unlike prior approaches that rely on retraining, auxiliary outlier data, or external supervision, our method identifies out-of-distribution (OOD) regions by analyzing query-level behaviors. Specifically, we suppress confidently predicted inliers while amplifying uncertain predictions through entropy-guided selection and spatial consistency analysis. To improve spatial coherence, we introduce an object-aware refinement step that enforces consistency within class-agnostic segments, yielding anomaly maps that align more closely with object boundaries. Our approach operates in a strictly zero-shot setting and requires no modification of the base model. Experiments across standard benchmarks, including SMIYC, Fishyscapes, and RoadAnomaly, demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance among zero-shot approaches and narrows the gap to training-based methods, while providing interpretable insights into model uncertainty. This competency-driven framework demonstrates that robust anomaly segmentation can be achieved without retraining or external data, making it suitable for practical real-world deployment.

title: Anti CSI-Based Sensing During Communication: Performance Modeling and Comparison of Using RIS and Private Precoding
authors: Lihua Ruan, Limeng Dong, Hongyi Zhu
abstract: This letter presents a comparative study of leveraging reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) or private precoding (PP) to counteract potential malicious sensing using channel state information (CSI) by a user device (UD) during communication. RIS and PP recently have emerged as two distinct approaches to address the growing concern of environment information leakage from CSI. Although both have demonstrated effectiveness, their theoretical performance and, more importantly, a comprehensive understanding of their comparative abilities in supporting a UD communication meanwhile anti its sensing remain underexplored. In this letter, we model the CSI-based sensing and communication performance of a UD controlled by RIS and PP in multi-antenna system contexts, respectively. Towards enhancing communication while restricting the sensing accuracy, we derive the exact optimal PP performance case and RIS performance bounds over feasible configurations. By analyzing the derived results, we draw insights into the characteristics of RIS and PP in influencing environment privacy and the UD communication, answering when RIS or PP is preferable. The theoretical results are verified in simulations.

title: Voltage Regulation Enhanced Volt/VAR Control With Discretization-Timescale-Dependent Stability Condition in Active Distribution Networks
authors: Qilin Hou, Qifan Yang, Xin Jin, Ningyi Dai
abstract: The increasing penetration of distributed energy resources (DERs) introduces significant voltage fluctuations in distribution networks. While their inverter-based nature offers Volt/VAR control capabilities to mitigate these issues, existing frameworks typically model and operate local control at second-level timescales, overlooking millisecond-level power electronics settling dynamics. This oversight restricts the tuning of control parameters: conservative droop gains lead to limited performance, while aggressive parameters may induce instability. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a Discretization-Timescale-Dependent Volt/VAR Control (DTD-VVC) framework that explicitly incorporates inverter dynamics in local control rule design. We first derive a stability condition for the Volt/VAR controller, demonstrating that a millisecond-level discretization timescale can potentially enhance stability. These insights reveal that steeper gains can be safely accommodated under a millisecond-level discretization timescale, thereby improving voltage regulation performance while guaranteeing stability. By embedding this stability condition as a constraint, we formulate a convex optimization framework to design millisecond-level local control rules that jointly minimize power loss and voltage deviations under uncertainties. Extensive validation on an RTDS–Python co-simulation platform demonstrates that the proposed millisecond-level DTD-VVC scheme substantially outperforms in both voltage regulation performance and stability.

title: A Structure-Preserved Control Approach for Dynamic Load-Altering Attacks in Power Systems
authors: Komeil Nosrati, Aleksei Tepljakov, Eduard Petlenkov, Elinor Ginzburg-Ganz, Yoash Levron, Juri Belikov
abstract: Dynamic load-altering attacks (D-LAAs) pose a significant threat to power systems and demand response programs by destabilizing the grid through the manipulation of vulnerable, controllable loads. Despite the development of various detection, protection, and mitigation strategies, the majority of them are based on transforming descriptor-type power systems into ordinary differential equations, which often introduce challenges that limit their effectiveness, particularly under constraint violations. In this paper, we present a novel linear-quadratic regulator (LQR) control method that directly addresses the D-LAA problem, which happens at multiple points, without relying on transformations to any restricted system equivalence. First, we model the under-attack power system as a cyber-physical power system (CPPS) to establish conditions for solvability and admissibility based on the topological structure. Next, we utilize a regularized least-squares framework to generate a quadratic cost function, which we then connect to a constrained recursive minimization problem to develop an LQR algorithm through dynamic programming. To accomplish this, we employ the derived algorithm on CPPS to mitigate D-LAAs and stabilize the system. We validate the proposed approach using the IEEE standard test systems as case studies, demonstrating the feasibility of an effective mitigation strategy against D-LAAs.

title: A Survey on Stream-Based Architectures: From Accelerators to CPUs
authors: Luís Crespo, Nuno Neves, Pedro Tomás, Nuno Roma
abstract: In the past few years, there has been a renewed effort to advance general-purpose architectures. In particular, to deliver performance and energy efficiency advantages, several techniques have been applied based on new forms of specialization while maintaining usability. As a result, data movement and communication have become the primary bottlenecks in computer systems. To overcome this, one of the most recent breakthroughs has been the introduction of data streaming mechanisms, just like those used in accelerators, into modern general-purpose processors (GPPs). This article comprehensively reviews stream-based architectures, tracing their development from accelerator solutions to their recent adoption in GPPs. This survey starts by introducing the fundamental principles of stream specialization, followed by a taxonomy for memory accesses, and formal mathematical models to represent them as data streams. Then, it categorizes different topologies of data stream specialization and examines them from a compiler’s perspective. Some of the most representative architectures proposed in the past few years, including instruction set architecture (ISA) and streaming engines, are described, followed by a comparative analysis that highlights their key features and presents quantitative evaluations. Then, we discuss some open challenges and suggest directions for future research in stream-based architectures.

title: Optimal Slew Rate Design of Power Modulation for DC Series Arc Fault Detection and Extinguishing
authors: Wan Kim, Hwa-Pyeong Park
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: DC series arc faults in photovoltaic (PV) systems pose a risk of reignition during the extinguishing process because the outcome depends on the system impedance. In addition, the rapid decrease in current needed for arc suppression can induce large overvoltage through the line inductance, leading to additional hazards such as equipment damage. However, most conventional arc-fault approaches focus only on detection and cannot address these extinguishing issues. Even when power-modulation-based methods attempt suppression, the risk of extinguishing failure remains if the slew rate is not designed with respect to the system impedance, resulting in arc reignition or line-inductance-induced overvoltage. Therefore, this paper proposes power modulation for arc fault extinguishing with an optimal slew rate design and considering system impedance, which prevents reignition and overvoltage conditions. Experimental results verified the performance of the series arc fault detection and extinguishing according to the optimal slew rate and system impedances.

title: A Blockchain-Envisioned Mailing System
authors: Liang Zhang, Haibin Kan, Jiheng Zhang, Kexin Li
abstract: Traditional email systems rely on centralized servers for message storage and routing, making them vulnerable to single points of failure and privacy breaches. While blockchain technology has emerged as a decentralized alternative for internet infrastructure, its application to email systems remains underexplored. This paper fills the gaps by proposing a blockchain-based mailing system that eliminates trusted intermediaries while enhancing privacy. Our approach integrates four key components: (1) the ECIES scheme to ensure end-to-end confidentiality of email content, (2) BIP-32-derived addresses to achieve sender anonymity, (3) stealth addresses to provide receiver k-anonymity, and (4) a broadcast encryption scheme to enable efficient broadcast messaging. Moreover, our design allows the sender to prove membership in the broadcast mailing while preserving anonymity. Further, the proposed system introduces an incentive mechanism that allows recipients to charge fees for incoming emails, effectively discouraging spam. We present a proof-of-concept implementation on the Ethereum blockchain and evaluate its on-chain performance in terms of gas consumption. Experimental results demonstrate the practicality and efficiency of the proposed system.

title: Resource Management in LoRaWAN with Interpretability
authors: Arshad Farhad, Muhammad Khurram Ehsan, Ali Hassan Sodhro, Huawei Huang
abstract: Long Range Wide Area Network (LoRaWAN) has become a practical communication layer for large-scale Internet-of-Things and industrial monitoring systems where battery-powered devices must transmit data reliably over long ranges. Selecting the right spreading factor (SF) remains critical for maintaining link quality and power efficiency, yet existing adaptive data-rate methods often fail under dynamic interference and mobility. This paper presents XSF, an interpretable machine-learning framework that predicts the optimal SF for each device using lightweight multilayer perceptrons (MLP) and majority voting. The model combines physical-layer indicators and device location to adapt transmission settings without changing the LoRaWAN protocol. In this paper, first, a one-time dataset has been generated using ns-3, and five MLP were trained on the dataset. Then a majority voting was employed to choose the best SF. Finally, we utilized SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) analysis for interpretability for SF classification. Furthermore, the pre-trained model was then utilized in ns-3 on the end devices for efficient SF allocation based on newly generated data during simulation. The proposed XSF achieved an average classification accuracy of 85%, with up to 10.7% and 6.0% higher packet success ratio in mobility and static scenarios, respectively, while reducing energy consumption by 33.6% and 20.6% compared with the state-of-the-art baseline AI method.

title: Sliding mode control as an efficient method of synchronization of high-stability oscillators with 1 PPS signals
authors: Paweł Kubczak, Mieczysław Jessa, Jakub Nikonowicz
abstract: Clock steering with a one pulse per second (1 PPS) signal is crucial for many modern telecommunication systems to provide high-performance time and frequency signals. In most telecom applications, the reference 1 PPS signal originates from an external source, typically the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS). Signals from GNSS are noisy, not always stationary, and can be disturbed intentionally or unintentionally by the operation of other devices, systems, or malicious attacks. In this paper, we propose the use of the Sliding Mode Control (SMC) algorithm for frequency and phase synchronization of a local oscillator, which has not been considered in telecommunications applications so far. The significance of our research lies in its ability to provide a practical and computationally efficient solution to oscillator synchronization, overcoming the complexity and high theoretical demands associated with existing optimal control techniques for high-stability oscillators. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm was demonstrated for three types of generators used in telecommunication systems.

title: MicroEdge: An Online Optimization Framework for Cost-Efficient Microservice Orchestration in Edge Native Applications
authors: Weihan Zeng, Kongyange Zhao, Jianxiong Liao, Zhi Zhou, Deke Guo, Xu Chen
abstract: The rapid proliferation of edge computing infrastructure has significantly accelerated the adoption of edge-native applications, ranging from autonomous vehicles to augmented reality and real-time analytics. Microservice, renowned for its lightweight, loosely coupled, and modular architecture, has emerged as the de-facto standard for developing edge native applications. However, the resource scarcity and heterogeneity, coupled with request dynamics in edge environments, pose substantial challenges for effective microservice orchestration. To address these challenges, we propose MicroEdge, an online optimization framework designed for cost-efficient microservice orchestration in edge-native environments. MicroEdge employs a multi-level optimization approach by strategically coordinating four key dimensions: microservice placement, layer placement, layer pulling, and user request scheduling. The framework confronts two fundamental challenges in solving this joint optimization problem: (1) the time-coupled nature of long-term holistic cost minimization, and (2) the NP-hardness of the underlying problem. MicroEdge tackles these dual challenges by integrating a regularization method for online algorithm design and a dependent rounding technique for approximation algorithm design. Both rigorous theoretical analysis and extensive simulations driven by realistic Alibaba microservice workload traces validate the efficacy of MicroEdge.

title: A3-TTA: Adaptive Anchor Alignment Test-Time Adaptation for Image Segmentation
authors: Jianghao Wu, Xiangde Luo, Yubo Zhou, Lianming Wu, Guotai Wang, Shaoting Zhang
abstract: Test-Time Adaptation (TTA) offers a practical solution for deploying image segmentation models under domain shift without accessing source data or retraining. Among existing TTA strategies, pseudo-label-based methods have shown promising performance. However, they often rely on perturbation-ensemble heuristics (e.g., dropout sampling, test-time augmentation, Gaussian noise), which lack distributional grounding and yield unstable training signals. This can trigger error accumulation and catastrophic forgetting during adaptation. To address this, we propose A3-TTA, a TTA framework that constructs reliable pseudo-labels through anchor-guided supervision. Specifically, we identify well-predicted target domain images using a class compact density metric, under the assumption that confident predictions imply distributional proximity to the source domain. These anchors serve as stable references to guide pseudo-label generation, which is further regularized via semantic consistency and boundary-aware entropy minimization. Additionally, we introduce a self-adaptive exponential moving average strategy to mitigate label noise and stabilize model update during adaptation. Evaluated on both multi-domain medical images (heart structure and prostate segmentation) and natural images, A3-TTA significantly improves average Dice scores by 10.40 to 17.68 percentage points compared to the source model, outperforming several state-of-the-art TTA methods under different segmentation model architectures. A3-TTA also excels in continual TTA, maintaining high performance across sequential target domains with strong anti-forgetting ability. The code will be made publicly available at https://github.com/HiLab-git/A3-TTA.

title: A Stability-Enhanced Feedback-Based Readout Circuit for Active-Matrix Resistive Sensor Arrays
authors: Seong-Ro Lee, Myeong-Cheol Hyun, Inhee Lee, Jong-Seok Kim
abstract: Active-matrix (AM) resistive sensor arrays are widely used because they suppress the crosstalk currents that plague passive matrices. In conventional feedback-based readout circuit (FBROC), the static voltage-drop error across the pixel switch is cancelled; however, as the pixel-transistor on-resistance (RON) is increased to shrink switch size and raise pixel density, parasitic capacitances push the feedback loop’s poles to lower frequencies, degrade phase margin, and induce oscillation—producing large sensing errors and limiting accuracy. This work proposes a stability-enhanced FBROC that augments the conventional architecture with a single RC compensator placed outside the array. The compensator introduces tunable zeros in the loop transfer function, restoring phase margin and suppressing oscillation without any in-pixel modification. Simulation and measurement results show that the proposed FBROC maintains a phase margin greater than 50° and reduces RERROR from 1393.2% to less than 0.1% under worst-case conditions. The allowable RON increases by a factor of ten, enabling smaller pixel switches (higher pixel density) and scaling to larger row/column counts while keeping higher accuracy despite increased parasitic capacitances. Because the compensator is passive and placed outside the array, the approach is simple, area-efficient, and compatible with existing AM sensor array implementations—breaking the device-size/loop-stability trade-off and supporting higher-resolution resistive sensing.

title: PMLDU-Net: a deep learning based method for identifying plastic-mulched landcover using optical and SAR remote sensing images
authors: Xiaoxiao Jiang, Yanxia Wang, Xiaoshuang Ma
abstract: The utilization of plastic mulch has facilitated the rapid advancement of agricultural practices. However, the extensive utilization of plastic mulch has also given rise to environmental concerns. Timely and accurate monitoring of plastic mulch is important for a comprehensive understanding of the pattern of plastic mulch and for the formulation of agricultural policies. The development and validation of advanced Plastic-Mulched Landcover (PML) detection algorithms are currently restricted due to the limited availability of publicly available datasets. To address this critical gap, this study introduces a novel and challenging benchmark dataset for PML detection. This dataset was constructed using co-registered Sentinel-2 and Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery and encompasses complex agricultural landscapes. Secondly, we propose a PML detection method based on deep learning model and utilizing multi-source remote sensing images. The proposed PML Detection U-Net (PMLDU-Net) model is a U-Net architecture with an added attention mechanism, designed to effectively utilize the complementary spectral and polarimetric scattering features from these multi-source data. The PMLDU-Net was rigorously bench-marked on the new dataset and its results were compared with several models. The results show that the proposed model achieves the best performance, with an overall accuracy (OA) of 95.08% and the mean intersection over union (mIoU) of 86.17%. The resulting prediction map is more continuous, and the boundaries between PML and the background better align with the actual situation. We also demonstrate the promising generalization capability of the proposed model in a different region. To reproduce our work, we provide the PML detection dataset at https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/jiangxiaoxiao1014/plastic-mulched-landcover-detection-dataset.

title: Multipath-Enhanced Directional Modulation for Secure mmWave On-Body Communication
authors: Wasi Ur Rehman Khan, Max J. Ammann, Hossein Raghib Hokmabadi, William Scanlon, Adam Narbudowicz
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper proposes Directional Modulation (DM) for secure millimeter-wave (mmWave) on-body communication, where security is enhanced by leveraging multipath propagation. The double two-ray ground reflection model is employed to analyze a two-antenna Multi-Input Single-Output (MISO) system placed on human skin. The system operates at 24 GHz with polarization tangential to the skin. Key parameters such as antenna-separation, antenna-to-skin spacing and phase difference between transmitter antennas are varied to analyze the resulting path gain. The results obtained from analytical model are experimentally validated using Yagi antennas placed over a forearm phantom. Based on the findings, the DM technique is implemented. The results demonstrate successful demodulation at the intended receiver location with Bit error rate (BER) <10-4, while at the eavesdropper’s location the BER >0.2 for all investigated transmitter–receiver antenna separations. The experimental results confirm the effectiveness and validity of the proposed concept.

title: Complementary Online Learning Network for Probabilistic Load Forecasting Against Extreme Weather
authors: Rui Huang, Pengfei Zhao, Di Cao, Weihao Hu, Qi Huang, Zhe Chen
abstract: Extreme weather events, such as heatwaves, cold snaps, and storms, frequently cause sudden and unpredictable shifts in electricity consumption, significantly complicating accurate load forecasting. Existing forecasting methods, predominantly offline-trained deep learning models, struggle to rapidly adapt to these abrupt changes due to limitations in real-time processing and the issue of catastrophic forgetting, and they rarely capture the uncertainties inherent in load predictions under extreme weather conditions. To overcome these challenges, this study proposes a novel complementary online learning network (COLNet) explicitly designed for probabilistic load forecasting during extreme weather events. The key innovations of COLNet include the following: first, a fast adaptation mechanism to rapidly assimilate new load patterns; second, an associative memory module to preserve historical load information and mitigate catastrophic forgetting; finally, a weather-aware gating mechanism that dynamically incorporates real-time meteorological variables, enhancing the model's sensitivity and forecasting robustness. Extensive comparative evaluations using real-world hourly datasets from the 2022 Australian floods, covering three affected regions over about 14 months, and from the 2021 Texas cold snap, comprising statewide load over about 24 months with a test set covering the mid-February event, are conducted. These evaluations confirm that COLNet substantially outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving mean absolute percentage error of 3.205%, 2.457%, and 4.882% during the flood period and 0.84% on the Texas event, corresponding to an average reduction of about 21% in point error relative to the strongest baselines and about 19% in probabilistic error, thereby improving both accuracy and uncertainty quantifications.
