title: Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis of Indonesian ChatGPT Reviews with Multinomial Naive Bayes
authors: Luh Kesuma Wardhani, Muhammad Rizki Fadhillah, Imam Marzuki Shofi, Nenny Anggraini, Nashrul Hakiem, Nadya Kharima
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: This study aims to perform aspect-based sentiment analysis on Indonesian-language user reviews of the ChatGPT application obtained from the Google Play Store. A total of 3,183 reviews were collected through web scraping and processed using preprocessing steps such as case folding, tokenization, stemming with Sastrawi, and sentiment analysis with the InSet lexicon. Aspect identification was conducted using Word2Vec, while sentiment classification employed the Multinomial Naive Bayes algorithm. The results show that the model achieved an accuracy of 0.629, precision of 0.855, recall of 0.725, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex>-score of 0.784 in aspect prediction, with the best performance in the functionality aspect <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(F 1=0.895)$</tex> and performance aspect <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(F 1=0.873)$</tex>. Sentiment classification produced an average score of around 0.805 across all metrics, with the accuracy aspect obtaining the highest score (0.904). These findings indicate that simple algorithms such as Multinomial Naive Bayes, when combined with localized resources, can deliver competitive results. This research contributes to the growing body of literature on aspect-based sentiment analysis in the Indonesian context and offers practical implications for the development and improvement of conversational AI services like ChatGPT.

title: Detecting Image Manipulation Using a ResNet50– SVM Hybrid Model
authors: Miftakhurrokhmat Miftakhurrokhmat, Robi Wariyanto Abdullah, Tinuk Agustin, Ina Sholihah Widiati, Febrianta Surya Nugraha, Shofiyati Nur Karimah
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: The development of the digital world brings new challenges in distinguishing original photos from edited photos, especially on social media and other digital sites. The spread of fake images that are difficult to recognize directly becomes a serious problem because they can be used for purposes that are detrimental to many people. This study proposes the use of the Residual Network 50 (ResNet50) architecture with a Support Vector Machine (SVM) approach to detect changes in digital images. ResNet50 functions as a model to extract important features from images, while SVM functions as a classification algorithm to distinguish between original images and edited images. The dataset used consists of two categories, namely original images and edited images, evaluated under three scenarios: Scenario 1 with 700 images (350 original and 350 modified), Scenario 2 with 1,400 images (700 original and 700 modified), and Scenario 3 with 2,100 images (1,050 original and 1,050 modified). All images were taken from the Kaggle platform, where edited images were created using Photoshop with several editing variants and exported as PNG files sized 256×256. Testing of the model was carried out to assess the performance of the detection system that has been created. The highest accuracy, 84%, was achieved in Scenario 2 (1,400 images) using ResNet50 feature extraction combined with an SVM classifier with an RBF kernel. This configuration achieved a precision value of 0.85, a recall value of 0.82, F1-score of 0.83 in the original image class and a precision value of 0.83, recall value of 0.85, and an F1-score of 0.84 in the edited image class. These findings indicate that the proposed model is a promising and effective solution for the automatic detection of fake images across various digital platforms.

title: Design and Analysis of BIC-based High Quality Factor Planer Laser Cavity
authors: Shashwat Tripathi, Aryan Pandey, Rahul Kumar, Ankit Arora
abstract: We report a bound-state in continuum (BIC) based multi-resonance photonic crystal with quality factor ~10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</sup> near the zero-momentum point. The crystal was designed to give resonances at absorption and emission wavelengths of Rhodamine 6G, hence can be used to give the photoluminescence enhancement and lasing.

title: Vertically Integrated Deep Ultraviolet Micro-Led Array With Photodetector for Stable and Compact Maskless Photolithography
authors: Yang Kang, Huabin Yu, Jikai Yao, Muhammad Hunain Memon, Xin Liu, Wei Chen, Haiding Sun
abstract: Inspired by silicon-based integrated circuits, we vertically integrate micro-LED arrays with photodetectors on a transparent sapphire substrate. Downward photons are captured by backside PDs, and a feedback circuit stabilizes light output for compact maskless lithography, advancing integrated photonics.

title: Shortest Path Planning for Fleets of Delivery Drones: Evaluating the Benefit of Including a Temporal Dimension in the Routing Network
authors: Conor Nolan, Paul Cuffe
abstract: As the commercial deployment of drone delivery services accelerates worldwide, efficient airspace utilisation has emerged as a key challenge for urban logistics. This paper examines the limitations of purely spatial two-dimensional networks for drone routing purposes and evaluates the efficacy of adding a temporal dimension to enhance available airspace capacity. With multiple operators seeking to deploy drone fleets in crowded airspace, simplistic spatial routing approaches risk congestion and reduced service reliability. Our simulations compare spatial and spatio-temporal approaches using sequential drone delivery routing scenarios, demonstrating that temporal networks significantly reduce path deviations and eliminate logjamming effects. Additional simulations evaluate how varying edge lengths affect spatio-temporal network performance, revealing tradeoffs between granularity, capacity, and computational requirements. Results indicate that selecting between spatial and spatiotemporal networks involves balancing computational cost against achievable network capacity. Spatial networks offer simplicity and low computation complexity, while spatio-temporal networks provide superior capacity at greater computational expense. These findings provide valuable guidance for the development of scalable drone traffic management systems as aerial delivery services expand in urban environments.

title: Novel Orientation Design and Jointly Optimal Resource Allocation for Mobile Receivers in MIMO-VLC-NOMA Systems
authors: Yuyu Wang, Feiyu Jiao, Yansong Du, Yuting Zhou, Jian Song, Xun Guan
abstract: This study proposes a dynamic optimization framework for MIMO-VLC-NOMA systems to address user mobility, multi-resource allocation, and receiver alignment. By integrating K-means-initiated Stackelberg game for user grouping, cooperative receiver alignment, and dual-objective power allocation, it significantly improves both throughput and fairness.

title: Observer-Based Consensus Control for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems With Time-Delay: Theory and Air-Ground Platform Validation
authors: He Li, Xiuyu Zhang, Yue Wang, Peng Ge
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Addressing the consensus control problem in heterogeneous multi-agent systems with time delays, this study develops an observer-based cooperative control framework. A novel state observer architecture is constructed through integration of the finite cover lemma with radial basis function neural networks (RBFNNs), enabling simultaneous estimation of unobservable states and compensation for delay-induced disturbances. Experimental implementation on the QUANSER multi-agent platform confirms the proposed method's effectiveness in attenuating temporal delay characteristics.

title: From Geospatial Patterns to Ancient Signals: A Signal Based Framework for Archaeological Machine Learning
authors: Dylan Foley, Dr. Eoghan Furey
abstract: To enable machine learning in archaeology, data must encode both observed traces—what we detect on Earth’s surface today—and their inferred past states. We propose a signal-based framework where archaeological features are treated as degraded spatiotemporal signals emitted by past human activity, and archaeology becomes a form of inverse signal reconstruction. Unlike traditional typological or period-based models, this approach models each site’s history as a vector in a unified 3D spatial manifold with temporal relationships anchored to a fixed reference (J2000), enabling integration with astronomical models and signal processing techniques.Applying this to northwest Ireland, we test signal correlations between archaeological distributions and hypothesised territorial boundaries circa (t<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>+400) (1600 CE). Using contiguity matrices, kernel density estimation, and K-nearest neighbor graph analysis, we find significant alignments between spatial signal clusters and historic boundaries across a 6,000-year span. This suggests that we can greatly increase the scope, resolution, and accuracy of our temporal pattern analyses even in noisy, incomplete data.By framing archaeology as an inverse signal reconstruction problem, our model aligns with broader signal science paradigms, including SETI’s search for technosignatures. It enables scalable, quantitative inference of long-term human territorial behavior and is extensible to other domains dealing with temporal degradation.

title: Structural Damage Identification via DTAAD with Multi-Vibration Sensors
authors: Yang Qiong, Qin Xianrong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: To address the limitations of single-sensor data in structural damage identification, this study proposes a multisensor structural damage identification method based on the DTAAD (Dual TCN-Attention Networks For Anomaly Detection) model. The method extracts structural health features from both local and global perspectives using dual TCNs, while employing a Transformer to capture correlations and temporal dependencies among multivariate vibration data, enabling precise damage identification. Experimental validation using a three-story frame structure dataset demonstrates that the DTAAD model achieves an F1-score of 0.995 while maintaining 100% recall, significantly outperforming conventional methods. This approach provides an efficient and reliable solution for structural health monitoring in practical engineering applications.

title: A Machine Learning Approach to Predict and Analyze Student Academic Performance Using Random Forest and SVM with SMOTE for Imbalanced Data Handling
authors: Ni Luh Gede Pivin Suwirmayanti, Ricky Aurelius Nurtanto Diaz, Putu Adi Guna Permana, Dian Pramana, I Gde Agus Satya Pratama, Adolf Christian Pardomuan Siregar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Education plays a crucial role in shaping the quality of human resources. One of the indicators of the effectiveness of the learning process is the academic achievement of students. Educational Data Mining (EDM) uses an algorithm-based analytical approach that utilizes machine learning to evaluate and predict learning outcomes with higher objectivity than traditional methods. The purpose of this study was to compare the performance of two classification algorithms, Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Random Forest (RF), in predicting students' academic achievement. To overcome the problem of data imbalance between classes, an oversampling approach using the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) was applied. The data used were obtained from both academic and non-academic sources, which we collected independently. The results show that the SVM algorithm exhibits stable performance in terms of accuracy and is effective in classifying the majority class, whereas the Random Forest is more effective in classifying the minority class. The application of the SMOTE technique helps to improve the balance of predictions between classes, although it does not necessarily improve overall accuracy. These findings suggest that SVM is better suited for use when overall accuracy consistency is a priority, whereas Random Forest is more effective at improving classification performance in minority classes under conditions of unbalanced data distribution.

title: Commutation Failure Prevention Strategy of Inverter Side based on Controllable Capacitor
authors: Jinchan Zhu, Wenhao Lu, Zhicheng Pan, Jun Deng, Mingchun Hou, Xiaoxing Wei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: In the line-commutated high voltage direct current (HVDC) system, commutation failure (CF) at the receiving end occurs in the case of AC faults, leading to shutdown of the DC link and seriously threatening the safety and stability of the power grid. In this paper, a controllable capacitor commutated converter (CCCC) structure is proposed to prevent CF, and the control system is designed based on the artificial neural network (ANN). Specifically, the CCCC can automatically determine a suitable capacitance value according to the prediction result of fault severity by ANN, which not only can prevent the occurrence of the CF but also makes the voltage stress applied on commutation valves at a low level. To increase the accuracy of the prediction of the fault severity, the genetic algorithm (GA) is utilized to optimize the structure of the ANN. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy, a monopolar 500 kV and 1000 MW HVDC system is built in PSCAD/EMTDC software as the test network. The simulation results indicate that the regression mean square error of the fault severity predicted by the GA-optimized ANN is low as $\mathbf{0 . 0 0 6 4 7 0}$, and for the simulated $\mathbf{2 4 6 0}$ kinds of faults, $\mathbf{9 7 . 1 \%}$ are eliminated successfully by the CCCC.

title: Research on Improved BlazePose based Bone Recognition Method for Power Operators
authors: Jinshuo Kang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of complex power operation environment and difficult real-time analysis of personnel’s action postures by traditional monitoring, this paper proposes an improved BlazePose-based dynamic spatiotemporal feature enhancement network for skeleton recognition and abnormal posture monitoring of power operation personnel. Based on the MediaPipePose algorithm, this method introduces the SE attention mechanism to narrow the recognition range to reduce background interference and achieve accurate positioning of 33 human key points. The experimental results show that the model performs excellently in 4 groups of power operation case videos. The skeleton recognition accuracy rates of cases $\mathbf{1}-\mathbf{3}$ are all above $\mathbf{9 0 \%}$. Due to the shooting range limitation (only below the legs) in case 4, the overall accuracy rate is $60 \%$, but the recognition accuracy rate in the effective area still exceeds $90 \%$. The video frame rate (FPS) is stable at about 30, meeting the requirements of real-time monitoring. This research provides efficient and reliable technical support for the safety monitoring of power operation personnel.

title: Exploring the Utilization of Perplexity AI for Academic Information Retrieval with Valid References Sourcing: A Study on Bina Nusantara Students
authors: Sharon Levina Saputra, Jane Safirin Yusri, Angelina Fredlin, Sulistyo Heripracoyo
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) has transformed academic information retrieval, yet many students still face challenges in efficiently finding credible references. This study examines the use of Perplexity AI, a generative artificial intelligence tool, for academic information retrieval among students at Bina Nusantara University. The respondents consisted of 100 active undergraduate students who had prior experience using Perplexity AI in academic contexts. The questionnaire instrument demonstrated strong construct validity, with Average Variance Extracted (AVE) values above 0.5 and Composite Reliability (CR) values between 0.806 and 0.905. Reliability analysis using Cronbach’s Alpha ranged from 0.652 to 0.860, confirming acceptable internal consistency. Using the IS Success Model and a quantitative approach with questionnaires, 100 respondents and PLS-SEM analysis, the research evaluates the effects of information quality, service quality, and system quality on usage intention, user satisfaction, and perceived benefits. Results show that information quality, service quality, and user satisfaction significantly influence usage intention and perceived benefits. System quality affects user satisfaction but has no significant impact on usage intention. These findings highlight the importance of reliable content and responsive service over technical system aspects in encouraging AI tool adoption in higher education.

title: Research on Grid-Connected Photovoltaic Inverters with Active Filter Functionality
authors: Xinxiang Han, Zhigao Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: To enhance the utilisation rate of grid-connected photovoltaic inverters and improve power quality within photovoltaic grid-connected systems, this study investigates gridconnected inverters incorporating active filtering capabilities. Without substantially increasing system hardware costs, both grid connection and active filtering functions are simultaneously realised. The system operates across three distinct modes: standalone PV grid connection, standalone active filtering, and combined grid connection with active filtering. It facilitates flexible mode switching according to operational requirements. Key analyses focus on PV-side maximum power point tracking, harmonic detection, and current tracking control. Finally, a system was constructed using MATLAB/SIMULINK, with simulations verifying its feasibility and practicality. The system demonstrates the capability to compensate for harmonic currents whilst maintaining grid connection.

title: CLIP-Grasp: Multi-Modal Object Grasping Based on Language and Vision Integration
authors: Yunxin He, Jie Gao, Mingqiang Geng, Dongyuan Zheng, Zhou Zhao, Jing Luo, Lu Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Robotic grasping tasks face key challenges such as insufficient multi-modal perception and difficulty in semanticspatial alignment in unstructured and complex scenes. Traditional unimodal methods rely on visual or tactile information and have difficulty in parsing the semantic intent of language instructions. Existing language-guided grasping frameworks mostly adopt cascade design or simple feature splicing, resulting in error accumulation and low modal coordination efficiency. This paper proposes CLIP-Grasp: a multi-modal grasping framework based on deep language-vision fusion, which realizes semantic-guided refined grasping decisions through dynamic feature modulation and hierarchical decoding mechanism. This method encodes language instructions into semantic priors of visual features through the conditional feature modulation (FiLM) module, and extracts cross-modal context information in combination with a multi-scale Transformer decoder, and simultaneously optimizes grasping parameters. The experimental results demonstrate that CLIP-Grasp achieves 85.12 % top1 and 90.66 % top-5 grasping accuracy on the OCID-VLG dataset, outperforming the CROG model by 7.92 % and 2.96 % in top-1 and top-5 accuracy, respectively, while utilizing only 156 M parameters. At the same time, verified by simulation experiments, our method has low-latency real-time reasoning and high robustness.

title: IoT Cybersecurity Risk Perception and Response Strategies Among Tech Startups in Saudi Arabia: A Data-Driven Study
authors: Safar Albaqami, Maziar Nekovee, Imran Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: The use of Internet of Things (IoT) devices by startups in Saudi Arabia brings both innovation and increased cybersecurity vulnerabilities. This study examines the level of cybersecurity awareness amongst startups and investigates their perceptions of blockchain as a potential cybersecurity solution. We conduct cross-sectional surveys using online questionnaires. Data is analyzed using the SPSS tool, employing descriptive statistics and inferential methods, including Pearson correlation and variance analysis. The results from the survey indicate lack of awareness, budget constraints, training limitations, and lack of clear policy at organizational level as the most outstanding challenges in the startups. Only a minority of respondents encountered cyberattacks, although concern levels for them were high. There is a need for structured training and strategic investment in cybersecurity among startups. The results also show the potential of Blockchain but lack a broad perception of feasibility.

title: Wet Etching of Low Loss Lithium Tantalate Waveguides and Heterogeneous Lithium Tantalate Integration
authors: Patrick Nenezic, Jorik Withouck, Tom Vandekerckhove, Margot Niels, Valeria Bonito Oliva, Maximilien Billet, Bart Kuyken
abstract: A new wet etching process is developed for lithium tantalate waveguide fabrication and propagation losses are measured. With such process, low loss structures can be fabricated without requiring etching machinery. Furthermore, it opens possibilities in realizing heterogeneously integrated lithium tantalate modulators using waveguides.

title: Telecoms Latency Analysis for Electrical Utility Applications including PTP
authors: David Laverty, John O’Raw, Danny McFadden, David Andrew, Donal Cunningham, David Malone, Scott McClelland
abstract: This paper presents a study of telecommunications latency relevant to wide-area communications in electrical utility applications, with a particular focus on Precision Time Protocol (PTP) synchronisation. The increasing deployment of distributed energy resources, remote substations, and wide-area monitoring systems has elevated the importance of reliable and low-latency communication networks in modern power systems. Experimental latency measurements were collected over several weeks using low-cost Raspberry Pi nodes deployed across a range of delivery technologies, including consumer GPON fibre, enterprise-grade optical networks, fixed wireless access (both licensed and unlicensed), and public cellular networks (4G/5G). The latency data was analysed using Python to fit statistical models, including normal, lognormal, and extreme value distributions, providing a quantitative characterisation of each technology's performance. These models inform the design of a WAN simulation platform used to prototype and evaluate the robustness of PTP implementations under realistic network conditions.

title: An AI-Based Framework for Scalable IPv4 Address Allocation in Large-Scale Fleet Networks
authors: Murali Prasath Arumugam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: The explosive growth of connected fleets and telematics systems continues to strain the limited IPv4 address space [1]. Although IPv6 offers a long-term solution, its adoption remains hampered by cost and backward compatibility issues, making optimized IPv4 allocation a critical near-term requirement. This paper proposes a machine learning–enabled IPv4 allocation framework that dynamically resizes subnets and aggregates supernets based on vehicle mobility patterns, thereby improving utilization and routing efficiency in fleet networks. The framework employs a multistage clustering pipeline comprising Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP) for dimensionality reduction, HDBSCAN [2] for density-based cluster detection, Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) for probabilistic refinement, and hierarchical clustering for macrozone aggregation with Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) support. Building upon these adaptive zones, Variable Length Subnet Masking (VLSM) assigns address blocks proportional to density, while a random forest predictor achieves 94.1% precision in forecasting subnet transitions for proactive allocation. Experiments on more than 5.2 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> GPS records demonstrate significant gains in utilization efficiency, routing scalability, and adaptability compared to static subnetting schemes. The novelty and inventiveness of this approach have been confirmed by an independent patent search report, which highlights the unique integration of multi stage clustering, CIDR-based macrozone aggregation, and density-aware VLSM allocation. The method has been formally filed as a provisional patent application with the Indian Patent Office (Application No. 202541079985, filed on 22 August 2025). This work therefore provides a practical, patent backed and standards-compliant solution that extends the viability of IPv4 in fleet telematics while offering a scalable pathway toward intelligent address management in next-generation connected mobility.

title: Control Panels in Hazardous Locations Compliance, Construction, and Protection Methods
authors: Zaneer Iqbal, Yu Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - (SPCE Portland)
abstract: Control panels are considered essential equipment in industrial automation, providing centralized control over electrical processes. In hazardous locations, these panels must be designed per stringent safety standards to help minimize risks of ignition of explosive atmospheres. This paper explores applicable key standards, classifications, design criteria, and protection methods.

title: Dual-Band Decoupling Network for Two Compact Antennas Based on a Combination of Hybrid Coupled Resonator and Transmission Line
authors: Hairong Deng, Qi Yu, Jianmin Zhang, Luyu Zhao, Yingsong Li, Adrian Bekasiewicz
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this work, a method for decoupling ports of two closely spaced dual-band antennas dedicated to operate within 5G new radio (NR) bands is presented. The proposed circuit integrates coupled resonators and transmission lines (CR-TL-DN) to simultaneously suppresses transmission between the feeding ports at both 3.5 GHz and 4.8 GHz frequencies. Simulation results demonstrate that the network enhances port-to-port isolation from 10 dB to over 20 dB, while improving radiation efficiency and reducing the envelope correlation coefficient (ECC).

title: Sentence Similarity Task Performance with Data Augmentation and Pre-trained Transformers
authors: Andrea Stevens Karnyoto, Mahmud Isnan, Gregorius Natanael Elwirehardja, Fitya Syarifa Mozar, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: In Natural Language Processing (NLP), especially for data retrieval and text mining, the task of sentence similarity is crucial. To improve sentence similarity, this paper examines how our approach integrates text augmentation and Transformers. Additional training examples are generated through text augmentation, which involves various transformations such as random swapping, synonym replacement, random deletion, and random insertion of the original sentence or text. By expanding the dataset, we aim to capture a wide variety of sentence variations. We used 1,800 pairs of human-written English sentences were obtained from two testing datasets, namely The Stanford Natural Language Inference (SNLI) corpus (version 1.0) and the Sentences Involving Compositional Knowledge (SICK). The Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) model, which is very effective in NLP, employs a self-attention mechanism to collect contextual data. To encode the input sentence into a high-dimensional representation, this paper uses a pre-trained transformer model. As a first step, we extend the original sentence pair by adding part of the text using easy data augmentations. Then, we calculate the similarity between sentence transformation and sentence embedding using sentence BERT (SBERT). We found that random swap augmentation achieved the highest F1-score in the all-MPNET-base-v2 model; however, for the experimental group using the all-roberta-large-v1 model, random insertion achieved the highest F1-score.

title: Autonomous Driving Using Spiking Neural Networks on Dynamic Vision Sensor Data: A Case Study of Traffic Light Change Detection
authors: Xuelei Chen, Sotirios Spanogianopoulos
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Autonomous driving is a challenging task that has gained broad attention from both academia and industry. Current solutions using convolutional neural networks require large amounts of computational resources, leading to high power consumption. Spiking neural networks (SNNs) provide an alternative computational model to process information and make decisions. This biologically plausible model has the advantage of low latency and energy efficiency. Recent work using SNNs for autonomous driving mostly focused on simple tasks like lane keeping in simplified simulation environments. This paper studies SNNs on photo-realistic driving scenes in the CARLA simulator, which is an important step toward using SNNs on real vehicles. The efficacy and generalizability of the method will be investigated.

title: Application of Fuzzy Logic Mamdani to Optimize Traffic Light Timing at Intersections
authors: I Kadek Defa Danuarta, Dustin Manuel, Christian Jodi Wisnuwardana, Bakti Amirul Jabar, Jurike V. Moniaga
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Traffic congestion is a significant challenge in many cities in Indonesia, driven by rapid urbanization and the increasing number of private vehicles. It reduces productivity and worsens the environment through increased air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. Automated traffic systems have been implemented to optimize signals, regulate flow, and provide real-time updates. However, they often face challenges from irregular vehicle movements, weather changes, and accidents. A Mamdani fuzzy logic approach enables intelligent decision-making under uncertain traffic conditions. By processing real-time vehicle counts (from camera feeds via YOLO), the Mamdani controller optimizes signal timing based on traffic density and queue length, improving traffic flow. In simulations, the proposed fuzzy-vision controller significantly outperforms a fixed-time signal on three metrics. On average, waiting time decreased by 28.7%, delay by 34.1%, and queue length by 8.4%. Overall, the Mamdani fuzzy logic system yields lower congestion and faster throughput than conventional timing.

title: A novel FDTD-PE-FDTD method for prediction of echo signals from maritime target
authors: Linchun Zhong, Yongqin Yang, Ting Su, Fuliang Zhong, Kuo Chi
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A novel hybrid model is proposed for predicting the echo of maritime target in complex emission environments. This approach divides the problem of echo prediction into three components: electromagnetic modeling of the emission environment, electromagnetic wave propagation and scattering. The finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method is employed for precise modeling of complex emission source region and distant target, while the parabolic equation (PE) method is utilized for long-range propagation. Through a typical case example, the proposed method is validated against traditional FDTD approaches, demonstrating its accuracy. The results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively predicts echo of maritime target in complex emission environments.

title: From Scenario to Case Model: Generating CMMN Models from Natural Language with Large Language Models
authors: Kheira Cherad, Imen Benzarti, Abderrahmane Leshob, Hafedh Mili
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Translating rich, user-centric narratives into formal process models remains a major challenge in model-driven engineering, particularly for flexible and adaptive workflows. This paper introduces a novel two-step method that leverages GPT4.0 to first enrich natural language scenarios with behavioral design principles and then generate executable CMMN models. We evaluate four prompt strategies across diverse e-commerce cases. Findings show that role-playing prompts effectively guide scenario enrichment, while a combined strategy integrating full guidance, few-shot examples, and role-playing produces the most accurate and semantically aligned CMMN models. This work lays the groundwork for LLM-driven, human-centric modeling and opens new directions for integrating cognitive insights into automated model synthesis.

title: Retrofitting a Pepper Robot with Flownetwork*
authors: Giovanni De Gasperis, Daniele Di Ottavio, Sante Dino Facchini, Luigi Iaconi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: The adoption of Generative Artificial Intelligence techniques is rapidly increasing in robotics, particularly for ob- ject recognition and learning tasks. While these approaches yield highly effective results, they also have significant computational demands, leading to substantial energy consumption. This paper proposes a retrofitting approach to implement a navigation task on a Pepper robot, integrating Cognitive Artificial Intelligence methods and FlowNetwork, a lightweight framework designed to enhance efficiency while minimising computational overhead. We will also compare the system on a different virtual platform using a Pioneer 3-DX robot, applying similar features to speed up the robot's decision-making while navigating near real-time scenarios.

title: Broadband Conformal Dual-polarized Phase-Reconfigurable Meta-atom
authors: Jiachen Li, Hongyu Zhang, Haifan Li, Dao Lin Fu, Wei Xiong, Yongjin Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper presents a broadband conformal dual-polarized phase-reconfigurable meta-atom(BCDPM). Four varactor diodes are integrated into the BCDPM. By dynamically adjusting the effective capacitance of each varactor diode, the proposed structure achieves continuous control of the reflection phase within the 2.06-3.23 GHz band (44.2% relative bandwith), with a phase tuning range exceeding 270°. Meanwhile, the use of thin PMI provides this metasurface with broader application potential in conformal integration with carriers. Such meta-atom provides a practical approach for broadband scattering-spectrum stealth.

title: Experimental Investigation of Compact Electro-Optic Modulators Based on Meandered Thin-Film Lithium Niobate Waveguides
authors: Jungwoo Lee, Min-Suk Kwon
abstract: We experimentally investigated a compact MachZehnder modulator based on folded thin-film lithium niobate (TFLN) waveguides with crossings and a lumped electrode. The fabricated device features a footprint of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.41 \times 0.38 ~\text{mm}^{2}, V_{\pi}$</tex> of 4.1 V, and a 3 dB bandwidth exceeding 1 GHz.

title: 2D Spatial Phase-Resolved Optical Coherence Microscopy for Extended Depth Ocular Tissue Imaging
authors: Shrivatsan Rajagopalan, Ansel Chen, Jun Song, Shuichi Makita, Yoshiaki Yasuno, Joanne Matsubara, Sonia Yeung, Pierre Lane, Myeong Jin Ju
abstract: The inherent phase stability in self-referenced interferometry enables the application of phase-sensitive computational refocusing to 3D volumes acquired with pointscanning optical coherence microscopy system without any phase stabilization. Effective depth of focus extension was demonstrated through imaging ex-vivo human retina.

title: Normalized Intrusion Convolution Kernel for Smart Perimeter Detection Using Mach-Zehnder Interferometer Fiber Sensors
authors: M.F.F. Pradipta, B. Pamukti, S. Afifah, S. -K. Liaw, A. M. Hatta, F. -L. Yang
abstract: We present a convolutional neural network-based intrusion detection method called the normalized intrusion convolution kernel, integrated with a Mach-Zehnder Interferometer Optical Fiber sensor. By normalizing vibration signals and applying a convolutional architecture, the system achieves over 99.6% accuracy for real-time smart perimeter intrusion classification.

title: Effective Numerical Aperture of Antiresonant Hollow Core Fibers
authors: Charu Goel, Trivikramarao Gavara, Wonkeun Chang
abstract: This work presents a framework for understanding light coupling characteristics of antiresonant hollow-core fibers (AR-HCFs) in terms of an effective numerical aperture. We have validated the hypotheses by selectively exciting hollow-core modes in an AR-HCF and measuring the far-field numerical aperture using mode divergence angles.

title: Signal Integrity and Power Integrity Simulation Optimization for High-Density SiP Packaging Products
authors: LI Zhenchao, He Peng, Zhang Shuye
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper presents a systematic simulation workflow for signal and power integrity (SI/PI) in high-density SiP design. Through a case study, key techniques including reflection, crosstalk, IR drop, PDN impedance, and electro-thermal co-simulation are employed. The results demonstrate that this method effectively evaluates substrate performance, guides design optimization, and ensures design targets are met, thereby reducing development time and cost.

title: Assessing the Success of Chatgpt in Higher Education: an Empirical Study of the Benefits and Impacts
authors: Herlino Nanang, Husni Teja Sukmana, Yusuf Durahman, Dewi Khairani, Viva Arifin, Faraditya Praba Saputrie
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: ChatGPT is an artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot that uses natural language similar to humans to answer questions correctly. Chat GPT can help people understand human language better and produce more natural responses. In its implementation, Chat GPT is used in various applications, such as virtual assistants, chatbots, and customer service. ChatGPT is an OpenAI development that has been used by millions of people worldwide. Although it has been widely adopted, it is necessary to carry out a systematic evaluation and assessment of its success using ChatGPT. The DeLone and McLean information system (IS) success model (D&M model) and the technology acceptance model by Davis are used to assess the success of IS because this model is a model used to test the success of a system. To test the benefits of using the system, five variables adopted from the two theories are used. This study empirically examines the model to measure the success of the Artificial Intelligence tool, namely ChatGPT, the extent of the benefits obtained, and what factors influence it. Data were collected from 100 users consisting of lecturers and students who use ChatGPT in their activities. Two direct variables, namely perceived usefulness and user satisfaction, have a direct influence on perceived benefits. The findings of this study can be used to assess the success of ChatGPT from the perspective of its users.

title: Dynamic performance evaluation of test site turntable using time-domain analysis
authors: Tieying Feng, Qiang Cui, Pinzhang Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: To effectively evaluate the performance of Site Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (SVSWR) at test site under dynamic conditions of turntable within 1 GHz ~ 18 GHz, this paper proposes a time-domain measurement method based on the time-gating technique of Vector Network Analyzer (VNA). Measurement program was designed to verify SVSWR results under dynamic conditions of test site turntable. Experimental results show that VNA time-domain method can effectively quantify the interference of turntable's dynamic process on the SVSWR performance of test site. This approach overcomes the limitation of the frequency-domain method specified in the CISPR 16-1-4 standard, which is only applicable to static measurement scenarios of test site turntable, thereby more comprehensively and accurately reflecting the performance of test site.

title: Real-time Power System Graph Recommendation Technology Based on Machine Learning
authors: Xiongwei Bao, Weirui Yue, Peisen Lv, Haiyang Wang, Lulu Li, Hua Xu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: With the unceasing progress of machine learning technology, its applications in the field of recommendation have become increasingly extensive. Recommendation systems can be seen everywhere in our daily lives. This paper leverages the historical operation logs of the human-machine cloud terminal in the real-time power system and incorporates information such as user types. By means of data mining and machine learning, a graphic browser graph recommendation technology based on machine learning is put forward. Specifically, first, the historical operation behaviors of the graphic browser in the human-machine cloud terminal are collected and analyzed periodically. Subsequently, through log analysis and data mining techniques, the user's historical browsing behaviors are excavated. Finally, by integrating the random forest classification algorithm, predictions are made to present the graph information that is most likely to be browsed based on the current graph. Through multiple experimental validations of this technology, the experimental results demonstrate that the technology proposed in this paper can recommend the graph information that users may browse during specific task operations. This effectively reduces some redundant operations when users utilize the human-machine cloud terminal to monitor graphs, thereby enhancing the efficiency of human-computer interaction.

title: Advanced Computational Models for Precision Agriculture: Deep and Reinforcement Learning for Predictive Soil Nutrient Management
authors: Pidugu Nagendra, Ch. Venkata Ramana Reddy, K. Pradeep Reddy
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: This research introduces an advanced framework for precision agriculture that integrates deep learning (DL) with reinforcement learning (RL) for predictive soil nutrient management. By leveraging real-time data from IoT sensors in conjunction with high-resolution satellite-derived indices, the system provides accurate estimations of essential soil nutrients. The proposed approach achieved over 93% accuracy in predicting nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium levels, validated through statistical significance testing to ensure robustness. In addition to improving crop yield and resource efficiency, the framework demonstrates practical feasibility by addressing challenges such as model latency, computational demand, and deployment in low-connectivity rural environments. This dual emphasis on predictive accuracy and real-world scalability positions the model as a promising solution for sustainable agricultural resource management.

title: An Effective UAV Complete Coverage Path Planning Method for Arbitrary Urban Environments
authors: Peng Xiao, Ni Li, Changyin Dong, Yu Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: In UAV-based urban search and reconnaissance tasks, effective area coverage is essential. Grid-based methods offer greater adaptability than cell decomposition; however, they often fail to ensure full coverage near obstacle boundaries, potentially leading to the omission of critical information. To address this limitation, a grid-based complete coverage path planning method is designed for arbitrary irregular obstacles. This approach begins by assigning values to grid cells, which allows to transform the coverage path planning (CPP) problem into a line coverage problem. Based on this, a path points generation algorithm that guarantees full area coverage is developed. To further enhance efficiency, an integer linear programming (ILP) model is formulated to minimize turning angles, reducing unnecessary maneuvers and improving UAV flight efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively generates full coverage paths while minimizing the number of turns. Additionally, it exhibits adaptability for multi-UAV systems.

title: Adaptive Polarization Alignment for Polarization-Independent Gain in OPAs Using SPGD
authors: Joydip Dutta, Geethakrishnan Purushothaman, Jonaq Niveer Sarma, Deepa Venkitesh
abstract: We present an automatic polarization aligner using the SPGD algorithm to achieve polarization-independent gain in an optical parametric amplifier (OPA). The polarization state of the input pump is adjusted automatically and a gain error of < 0.07 dB between orthogonal signals is achieved within 25 seconds.

title: Development of Distance Measurement Estimation Model for Specific Objects
authors: Herdianto Herdianto, Poltak Sihombing, Fahmi Fahmi, Tulus Tulus
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Soccer robots are one of many mobile robots that can move in all directions and are equipped with humanlike abilities as soccer players. To achieve the standards of a soccer robot, the robot must possess the abilities of a soccer player in detecting objects, measuring distance, moving left and right, stopping, and so on. Currently, this robot is still in the development stage, such as in distance measurement. Several studies have been conducted on measuring the distance of objects using cameras, one of which uses the Complex Log Mapping (CLM) method. Although CLM can be used, this method still has weaknesses in measurement time. Therefore, this study improves the measurement model, formula, and algorithm, and the results show that the distance measurement time is faster than the CLM method.

title: Ultra-Wideband Signal Receiver Front-End Based on Modulated Wideband Converter Technology
authors: Meiling Chen, Wei Li, Mingliang Xie, Jiahao Zhang, Binbin Su, Lei Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The increasing signal bandwidth in complex electromagnetic environments poses significant challenges for signal reception and processing. To overcome the bandwidth limitations imposed by the Nyquist sampling theorem, this paper proposes an ultra-wideband signal reception architecture based on the Modulated Wideband Converter sub-Nyquist sampling technique. An optimized mixing sequence strategy is designed to substantially enhance hardware efficiency. The proposed sub-Nyquist receiver architecture with optimized mixing sequences demonstrates excellent reception performance for wideband dual-tone signals.

title: Waveguide Grating on Lithum Niobate on Insulator for Electrically Modulated Filter
authors: Zhibo Li, Xiao Sun, John H. Marsh, Lianping Hou, Anthony E. Kelly, Marc Sorel
abstract: Side-wall Bragg grating optical filters fabricated on the lithium niobate on insulator platform had been demonstrated. The grating performance had been studied under various design parameters, with 30 nm stopband width, 25 dB resonance extinction ratio and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$22.4 \text{pm} / \mathrm{V}$</tex> electro-optic tuning capability are reported.

title: Experimental Investigation on No-Load Excitation Characteristics of Transformers under Dynamic Stray Current
authors: Zhuohong Pna, Bichuan Xu, Wei Shen, Lin Geng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Dynamic stray currents generated during the operation of subway systems cause DC bias hazards in grounded power transformers within urban power grids. This paper established a test platform for investigating the no-load excitation characteristics of transformers under dynamic stray current conditions and conducted corresponding experiments. The study analyzed the impact of dynamic stray currents on the no-load excitation currents in each transformer winding. Due to the influence of dynamic stray currents, the DC bias characteristics of the transformer also exhibit dynamic behavior. The severity of transformer DC bias does not strictly synchronize with the instantaneous magnitude of the stray current and is correlated with the saturation state of the transformer core. Experimental results demonstrate that the core saturation level in the center phase leg is less pronounced than in the other two phases, resulting in lower consumption of both active and reactive power. The findings of this paper reveal the dynamic DC bias characteristics of transformers, providing valuable insights for risk analysis associated with dynamic stray current intrusion.

title: Classification of Autism in Children Based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) Using Support Vector Machine (SVM)
authors: Avinda Nur Azizah, Siti Ummi Masruroh, Neneng Tati Sumiati, Husni Teja Sukmana, Saepul Aripiyanto, Esa Adnin Safara Ersanemora Siregar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Autism is a developmental disorder that affects a child's ability to communicate and interact socially. Early diagnosis is crucial to prevent delays in treatment; however, there is a lack of parental awareness of early symptoms, and currently, no classification tool is available to identify the severity level of autism based on DSM-5 criteria. This study aims to classify autism in children based on DSM-5 criteria using the Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm with a CRISP-DM approach, and to address data imbalance using the SMOTE oversampling technique. The dataset consists of children's symptom data labeled as ASD (ASD 1, ASD 2, ASD 3) and Non-ASD. Evaluation results show that the SVM model without SMOTE achieved the best performance with an overall accuracy of 98.77%, along with high and balanced precision, recall, and F1-scores. Meanwhile, the application of SMOTE increased sensitivity for minority classes but reduced the accuracy to 90.12%. Therefore, the SVM model without SMOTE is considered the most effective. This model has potential as an early diagnostic aid but still requires further clinical validation.

title: Study of Crosstalk Prediction Method for High-Voltage and Low-Voltage Wire Harnesses Considering Electromagnetic Parameter Dynamic Variations
authors: Hao Zhang, Changsong Cai, Junhua Wang, Yanpu Zhao, Xiaolong Jia, Jiaji Yang, Wen Xiang, Leke Wan, Zhaoyang Yuan, Wenfang Li, Liwei Feng, Yiting Wang, Xiaolin Lian
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Aiming at the crosstalk prediction problem of high and low voltage multi-stranded stranded wire harness in new energy vehicle electrical system, this paper proposes a crosstalk prediction method of multi-stranded wire equivalent to single stranded wire. The method reduces the complexity of the simulation model by analyzing the change rule of the distribution parameters of the multi-stranded wire harness in a wide frequency range, combined with the geometrical mapping relationship of the stranded wire structure, and simplifying the multi-stranded wire harness equivalent to a single-stranded wire harness model. On this basis, HFSS software is used to establish a parametric wire harness model, which makes the distribution parameters of the equivalent single-stranded wire consistent with the multi-stranded wire harness by customizing the material frequency properties. Finally, based on the synergistic integration of the equivalent model and the frequency-variable parameters, the efficient and accurate prediction of broadband crosstalk response is realized.

title: Fuel-saving potential of a retrofitted diesel hybrid dual-mode train
authors: Ayoub Aroua, Walter Lhomme, Clément Depature, Philippe Adam, Matthieu Renault
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Vehicular Technology
abstract: This paper investigates the fuel-saving potential of a retrofitted diesel hybrid dual-mode train based on energy management optimization and different railway operation scenarios. Dual-mode trains offer high operational flexibility by operating on both electrified and non-electrified tracks. The presented investigation begins with experimental campaigns on real trains currently operating in France. The results revealed a 22% to 25% reduction in fuel consumption for the retrofitted hybrid train compared to its conventional counterpart. These outcomes, accomplished using a rules-based energy management strategy following a charge-sustaining concept, reflect a suboptimal utilization of the hybridization potential. To fully exploit this potential, the energy management is herein optimized through the dynamic programming method, following a charge-depleting concept. This permits leveraging different factors, such as the large size of batteries afforded by the retrofitting procedure, the recharging opportunities provided by the rail electrical infrastructure, the knowledge of the track characteristics, and the daily operational missions. This approach is analogous to the operational logic of on-road plug-in hybrid electric vehicles. The optimization is conducted on daily rail operational schedules under three real-world scenarios, which vary based on their authorization of intermediate recharging using the catenary as well as the online transition from catenary-free to catenary-powered operation. On average, the optimization results, over the daily schedules and the defined scenarios, reveal that the fuel saving ranges from 4% to 37% relative to the charge-sustaining. When compared with the conventional version of the train, this translates into a fuel-saving of 25% to 51%.

title: A Highly Sensitive Sensor Based on Micro-Porous MOF for Detecting Humidity
authors: Yatong Ren, Jie Xiong, Wen Zhang, Ying Zhang, Zhicheng Zhang
abstract: This article presents a humidity sensor based on a micro-porous metal-organic framework (MOF) KAUST-7. A series of sensing-test experiments were performed and the results demonstrated that the sensor has promising sensing performance with fast response-recovery speed (6/12 s), high linearity (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.992) and good stability in a wide relative humidity range. Most notably, the micro-porous structure and fluorine clusters play a supporting role in the ad-desorption process of water molecules. The humidity sensing mechanism was analyzed by complex impedance spectrum and theory calculation. These results indicated that micro-porous KAUST-7 is a potential candidate for constructing a humidity sensor with high performance.

title: Slope-Adaptive Gait Planning for the Powered Lower Limb Prosthesis: GRU-Based Coordination Mapping and its Application
authors: Yang Lv, Xiaoxu Zhang, Run Zhou, Wen Zhang, Chaoyu Song, Chao Chen, Chang Lu, Jian Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: This study aims to develop a real-time, slopeadaptive gait planning method for powered knee-ankle prostheses to improve natural gait coordination in transfemoral amputees across variable speeds and slopes. A lightweight gated recurrent unit (GRU) network is proposed, leveraging motion-lagged hip angle, current hip angle, and slope angle as inputs. The system requires only two inertial measurement units (mounted on the socket and prosthetic foot) and a force sensor (at the ankle joint). Network regularization and hyperparameter optimization were applied to enhance computational efficiency, and subject-specific fine-tuning was used for personalized adaptation. The optimized GRU framework achieved high prediction accuracy with a prediction time of <0.007 s, enabling real-time deployment. Experiments with an amputee participant demonstrated seamless adaptation to variable slopes and speeds, improved gait symmetry, and reduced compensatory behaviors in the residual hip and intact ankle. The proposed method enables natural and adaptive gait coordination for transfemoral amputees using a computationally efficient, sensor-minimized approach. This work advances intelligent prostheses toward more natural locomotion in daily environments by improving adaptability to real-world terrain variations.

title: Active Suspension Hydraulic Systems with Noise and Disturbances: A Novel Finite Time Variable Gain Control Method
authors: Shaomeng Gu, Yuejun Wang, Shuang Liu, Min Yan, Dingxuan Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: In this paper, a finite-time variable gain control method is proposed to address noise and disturbances in active suspension hydraulic systems (ASHS). The proposed method integrates error-driven variable gains to dynamically enhance transient performance and steady-state performance, includes a finite-time variable gain tracking differentiator (FTVGTD), a finite-time variable gain extended state observer (FTVGESO) and a finite-time variable gain controller (FTVGC). The FTVGTD is designed to accurately extract differential signals from measured displacement signals with noise. Inspired by super-twisting theory, the FTVGESO is developed to estimate unknown states and disturbances in finite-time, while mitigating chattering during the estimation process. Based on the power integral technique, the FTVGC is proposed to compensate the disturbances in real time, thereby improving system robustness. For convergence analysis of the proposed method, robust analysis techniques and Lyapunov methods are utilized to address the non-Hurwitz characteristic of variable gain matrices, and the disturbance rejection capability is analyzed theoretically. Finally, simulation and experiment results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method for active suspension hydraulic systems.

title: SWONA: Small World Inspired Optimal Neural Architecture for Smart Neuropsychiatric Diagnostics
authors: Shubham Dwivedi, Om Jee Pandey, Rajesh M. Hegde
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease (AD), Schizophrenia (SCZ), and Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) pose significant challenges to global healthcare due to their rising prevalence and diagnostic complexity. Early and accurate detection is critical to improve treatment outcomes for these neuropsychiatric disorders. While existing learning models offer some success, they often fall short in scalability, adaptability, and diagnostic precision. Recent efforts lack mechanisms to dynamically optimize network structure for complex clinical data, limiting their real-world application. This paper addresses this gap by introducing a novel neural architecture search strategy inspired by the small world network concept, resulting in the Small World Optimal Neural Architecture (SWONA). SWONA enhances learning by establishing optimal links between non-adjacent layers, mirroring the high clustering and short path lengths of small world networks. It dynamically determines key parameters such as layer connections, count, and network depth, resulting in an adaptive and efficient model suitable for clinical and wearable diagnostic settings. Evaluated on 7 standard benchmark datasets, SWONA consistently outperformed both traditional and state-of-the-art methods across multiple neuropsychiatric disorders and evaluation metrics. These findings highlight SWONA’s potential as a reliable clinical tool, supporting early diagnosis and enabling more personalized treatment strategies.

title: Low-Cost, High-Throughput Magnetic Characterization Tool for Irregular Soft Magnetic Specimens
authors: Stefan Colton, Andrew Kustas, Jesse Adamczyk, Aaron Stebner
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The characteristics of soft magnets are major drivers of the performance of electrical machinery. To better enable the rapid optimization of these properties relative to material or manufacturing changes, high-throughput characterization techniques are desired. In this work, a methodology for measuring the magnetic properties of soft ferromagnetic samples is developed. The proposed methodology utilizes an inexpensive desktop instrument designed to be amenable to automation. The use of the newly designed hardware and requisite data analysis methodology is validated and shown to have acceptable accuracy and repeatability for screening purposes; saturation magnetization is typically accurate to 1% and repeatable to 0.2%, while coercivity is repeatable to 20–30 A/m. The measurement time per specimen is under 20 seconds, with an architecture that allows for significant further improvement. No post-processing of samples is required, nor precise geometries. These characteristics are compared to existing techniques and shown to represent a favorable tradeoff for many screening applications.
