title: Enabling Cost-Efficient LLM Inference on Mid-Tier GPUs With NMP DIMMs
authors: Heewoo Kim, Alan La, Joseph Izraelevitz
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) require substantial computational resources, making cost-efficient inference challenging. Scaling out with mid-tier GPUs (e.g., NVIDIA A10) appears attractive for LLMs, but our characterization shows that communication bottlenecks prevent them from matching high-end GPUs (e.g., 4×A100). Using 16×A10 GPUs, we find the decode stage—dominant in inference runtime—is memory-bandwidth-bound in matrix multiplications, I/O-bandwidth-bound in AllReduce, and underutilizes compute resources. These traits make it well-suited for both DIMM-based Near-Memory Processing (NMP) offloading and also communication quantization. Analytical modeling shows that a 16×A10 with NMP DIMMs and INT8 communication quantization can match 4×A100 performance at 30% lower cost and even surpass it under equal cost. These results demonstrate the potential of our approach for cost-efficient LLM inference on mid-tier GPUs.

title: Strategy-Proof Cost-Sharing Mechanism for Dynamic Adaptability Service in Vehicle Computing
authors: Xi Liu, Jun Liu, Weidong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Vehicle computing has emerged as a promising paradigm for delivering time-sensitive computing services to Internet of Things applications. Intelligent vehicles (IVs) offer onboard computing and sensing capabilities for delivering a wide range of services. In this paper, we propose a dynamic adaptability service model that leverages the swift mobility of vehicles to adjust the distribution of IVs to users’ dynamically changing locations. There are two types of areas in our model: the user area and the parking area. The former is where services are provided, while the latter serves as the preparation zone for backup IVs. IVs in the parking area are dispatched to service areas, where existing vehicle resources cannot meet user demand, and they return to the parking area after delivering the service. Multiple users share sensing resources, and our model allocates the costs among them. To ensure strategy-proofness, we introduce the concepts of no additional cost and allocation stability. We propose a strategy-proof cost-sharing mechanism for dynamic adaptability service. The proposed mechanism achieves no positive transfers, voluntary participation, individual rationality, consumer sovereignty, budget balance, no additional costs, and allocation stability. Moreover, the proposed mechanism’s approximation performance is analyzed. We further use comprehensive simulations to verify the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed mechanism.

title: Model Predictive Control for Energy-Efficient Path Following Control of AUVs
authors: Chao Shen
abstract: This article studies the path following (PF) control problem for an autonomous underwater vehicle. To improve the endurance, the energy management is seamlessly integrated into the PF control with the proposed multiobjective model predictive control (MOMPC) approach. In the MOMPC PF control, two control objectives, the path convergence and the energy efficiency, are considered simultaneously. The path convergence is identified as the primary task which must be guaranteed, while the energy efficiency should be improved provided the guaranteed path convergence. To accommodate the prioritized PF control objectives, the lexicographic ordering method is applied to solve the MOMPC problem. With an appropriate reference augmentation and well-designed optimization formulations, the path tracking error can be guaranteed to converge to zero, and the recursive feasibility of the MOMPC algorithm is further proved. The thrust allocation subproblem is addressed within the MOMPC PF control. Extensive simulation studies demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach and show that the MOMPC presents a flexible framework to perform the energy-efficient PF control.

title: Modeling Mad Classification in Holy Quran Recitation Using MFCC Extraction Feature and CNN Algorithm
authors: Nenny Anggraini, Zulkifli, Yusuf Rahman, Achmad Nizar Hidayanto, Husni Teja Sukmana
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: This research aims to classify mad recitation in Surah Al-Fatihah using Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficient (MFCC) feature extraction and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) algorithm. Learning mad is very important to ensure proper pronunciation and understanding of the correct meaning in Quranic verses, as the law of reading the Qur'an correctly is considered an obligation for every Muslim. Currently, there is no standardization that regulates the length of mad recitation. To address this gap, this study introduces a pioneering model using one of the reading tempo standards, namely slow tempo (Al-Tahqiq), offering a novel approach in this field. The chosen algorithms, CNN combined with MFCC feature extraction, have not been specifically used in prior research for creating a mad reading classification model, marking a unique contribution. The research process began with a comprehensive data collection from literature study and dataset accumulation, followed by the development of a model capable of classifying mad tajweed readings. The development process included preprocessing steps like cutting the audio according to specified verse beheadings and adding noise to enhance dataset robustness. Feature extraction was performed using MFCC, and the resulting data was used to create a classification model with the CNN algorithm. Testing was carried out across 10 scenarios, with Scenario 5 yielding the highest results: 98.25 % training accuracy, 92.00 % validation accuracy, and 96.00 % testing accuracy. Compared to a previous study that applied an LSTM-based model with a smaller dataset and achieved a maximum testing accuracy of 90.0 %, the CNNbased model proposed in this research demonstrates superior performance in classifying madd tajwid. These results not only demonstrate the suitability of the CNN and MFCC for madd tajweed classification but also position this research to potentially set a precedent for further studies, aiming to establish standardized methods for madd recitation in Quranic reading.

title: Smartwatch-Based Unobtrusive Continuous Anxiety Tracker for Evaluating Post-Stroke Patients' Quality of Life
authors: Sanghoon Choi, Woo-Keun Seo, Jin-Man Jung, Seongho Park, Hyo-Chang Seo
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Post-stroke Anxiety (PSA) affects 20–30% of stroke survivors and significantly impacts their quality of life (QoL) and rehabilitation outcomes. Traditional emotion assessment methods rely on subjective self-reports, which have a limited ability to capture real-time fluctuations in emotional states. This study proposes a self-supervised learning (SSL) framework combined with a transformer-based emotion classification model to enable continuous anxiety tracking in patients with stroke using smartwatch-derived photoplethysmography (PPG) signals. The SSL model was pretrained on the VitalDB dataset using R-peak-to-peak intervals (RRIs) extracted from electrocardiography (ECG) signals. The pretrained encoder is then integrated into a transformer-based classifier trained on the Psycho-physiology of Positive and Negative Emotions POPANE dataset containing labeled emotional responses. Finally, the trained model was applied to smartwatch-derived pulse peak intervals (PPI) from patients with stroke, and the predictions were applied to Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7) scores and we evaluated it against GAD-7 scores using both group-level and 90-day longitudinal analyses, alongside on-device feasibility on a Galaxy Watch6. Over the 30 days preceding the second survey, between-group differences were significant by Welch's t-test (p = 0.0086), and discrimination reached AUC 0.859 with a 95% confidence interval of 0.664–0.992. In 90-day monitoring, generalized estimating equations (GEE) showed persistent divergence when groups were defined by the second survey, with significant differences across multiple weeks preceding the survey, consistent with the retrospective GAD-7 window. These findings indicate that ECG-pretrained cardiac representations can be translated to smartwatch PPG to support unobtrusive, continuous anxiety tracking in stroke. Results constitute feasibility-level evidence and motivate multi-site external validation, larger cohorts with clinician-rated assessments, and prospective studies toward clinical deployment.

title: Simulation of DC MRI Coils Using 2G HTS Tapes by the J-A Formulation
authors: Rafael N. de Souza, Bárbara M. O. Santos, Gabriel dos Santos, Flávio G. R. Martins, Guilherme G. Sotelo
abstract: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a technique that generates high-resolution volumetric images of the human body using a strong magnetic field. The image quality is directly dependent on the homogeneity of this field. Commercial superconducting magnets typically achieve field homogeneities below two parts per million (ppm) and are based on Nb-Ti conductors, which require cooling to 4 K. Maintaining this temperature is costly and demands two-stage cryocoolers. Second-generation (2G) high-temperature superconducting (HTS) tapes offer a promising technical and economic alternative, as they operate at higher temperatures (20–77 K), where it is possible to use a one-stage cryocooler. However, their performance is sensitive to magnetic fields. In this study, the objective is to investigate the use of 2G HTS tapes in a DC MRI magnet cooled by helium gas, aiming to reduce cryogenic costs in installation and operation. A 0.5 T magnet with a 700 mm patient bore was simulated, accounting for the space required by the gradient and RF body coils at different operating temperatures. The magnet is modeled using the J-A formulation alongside the power law to simulate the DC coil behavior, incorporating angle-dependent critical current and n-value characteristics. This initial study focuses on the achievable homogeneity of the applied field, with an ideal field distribution where the effects of screening currents are not considered in the final homogeneity assessment. The final design achieves a magnetic field homogeneity better than 3 ppm within a 10 cm diameter spherical volume (DSV).

title: Wireless Channel Parameter Estimation for Millimeter-Wave Hybrid Beamforming Systems
authors: Nigus Shimuye, Claude Oestges, François Quitin
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper proposes a sub-antenna array beamsteering-domain channel estimation framework for millimeter-wave (mmWave) systems with hybrid beamforming. Unlike conventional array-domain methods that require access to per-antenna baseband, the proposed approach leverages joint transmitter (Tx) and receiver (Rx) beamsteering observations to enable high-resolution, digital-beamforming-like parameter estimation under practical hardware constraints. A generalized signal model is developed that incorporates measured beam patterns, including sidelobe and phase effects, ensuring a practical representation of hybrid transceivers. Building on this model, we adapt the classical SAGE and MUSIC algorithms to operate in the beamsteering domain, allowing accurate estimation of multipath angle and delay parameters without relying on discretized angular grids. The proposed methods are evaluated through extensive Monte Carlo simulations across different SNR levels, array configurations, and beamsteering resolutions, and are further validated on a 28 GHz hybrid beamforming testbed. Results demonstrate that the beamsteering-based SAGE achieves superior resolution in dense multipath environments, while beamsteering-based MUSIC provides robustness under reduced beamsteering diversity. These findings establish the proposed framework as a practical and effective solution for accurate mmWave channel parameter estimation with hybrid beamforming architectures.

title: Superior FeFET Reliability and Memory Window by Hybrid Solid-Solution/Superlattice HfZrOₓ and Interface Engineering
authors: Tsen-Hsiang Pan, Yu-Cheng Lin, Yung-Hsien Wu
abstract: HfO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>-based ferroelectric FETs (FeFETs) have emerged as promising candidates for embedded non-volatile memory (NVM). However, achieving a wide memory window (MW) without compromising endurance remains a key challenge, particularly for enabling triple-level cell (TLC) operations in high-density applications. To address this, we propose a hybrid HfZrOₓ (HZO) stack that combines solid-solution (SS-HZO) and superlattice (SL-HZO) structures, integrating their respective advantages, namely, a higher coercive field (Ec) and a reduced concentration of oxygen vacancies (Vo). This design effectively optimizes the trade-off between MW and endurance. Additionally, interface engineering is employed, including NH₃ plasma treatment to form a high-k, high-quality interfacial layer that improves the MW, and microwave annealing (MWA) to suppress Vo generation and enhance endurance. The proposed devices achieve a large MW of 2.7 V, with stable endurance up to 10⁷ cycles for single-level cell (SLC) operation and 10⁴ cycles for TLC operation, demonstrating strong potential for reliable, high-density NVM applications.

title: 3 nm CFET Process Design Kit for Advancing MOL-Aware Modeling for Precise Circuit Performance Analysis
authors: Seong-Ji Min, Sang-Pill Kim, Jun-Hyeok Lee, Seung-Geun Jung, Sung Kyu Lim, Hyun-Yong Yu
abstract: Complementary field-effect transistors (CFETs) improve integration density through vertical stacking, but dense middle-of-line (MOL) routing introduces significant parasitics that affect circuit performance. This work presents an MOL-aware compact modeling framework for 3-nm CFETs, where MOL-related capacitances are analytically captured using conformal mapping and calibrated with TCAD extraction. The resulting compact model is implemented in a customized PDK based on the BSIM-CMG formulation and supports layout-aware circuit evaluation. Including MOL parasitics increases the total parasitic capacitance by approximately 20%. Post-layout analysis of a 5-stage ring oscillator shows that the MOL contribution to frequency behavior grows with fan-out, while capacitance analysis indicates that the MOL domain accounts for more than half of the total parasitics in low-fan-out conditions. These results demonstrate that MOL effects form a major performance bottleneck in vertically stacked CFETs and highlight the importance of MOL-aware modeling for accurate circuit prediction and design optimization in advanced technology nodes.

title: A Quasi-Linear Harmonic Balance Model for Studying the Performance of Sideband-Separating SIS Receivers
authors: David Monasterio, Joseph Lambert, Philip Dindo, Claudio Jarufe, Pablo Astudillo, Kamaljeet Saini, Patricio Mena, Alessandro Navarrini
abstract: We present a novel modeling technique to accurately simulate the gain, single-sideband noise temperature, and image rejection of a sideband-separating superconductor-insulator-superconductor (SIS) heterodyne receiver. We provide details of the modeling of all relevant receiver components, featuring a novel quasi-linear approach which combines the nonlinear Harmonic Balance method and Tucker’s quantum theory of SIS mixers. To enhance accuracy, the modeling technique utilizes full electromagnetic simulations or S-parameter measurements for all the other receiver components, depending on availability. The model also accounts for sideband noise contributions from various sources, including the local oscillator and internal terminations. To illustrate its capabilities, we applied the technique to a developmental receiver for the upgraded Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) Band 6. A rigorous comparison between simulation and measurement results from a single polarization channel prototype receiver demonstrates excellent accuracy. This agreement is evidenced across the entire frequency range by the small difference in noise temperature values (less than 10%) and the low difference in the number of frequency points that fall below an image-rejection threshold of 15 dB (8%). The proposed model also allows the identification of various noise and image rejection features and enables improvement by re-optimization of components. This generalized modeling technique is applicable to any SIS sideband-separating receiver.

title: Robust Channel Estimation for Noncoherent Magnitude-Based MIMO in Low-Cost Massive Machine-Type Communications
authors: Yuqing Guo, Xufeng Guo, Ying Wang
abstract: Noncoherent magnitude-based MIMO (NMB-MIMO) has been envisaged as a promising architecture for the low-cost implementation of massive machine-type communications (mMTC). Nevertheless, the existing channel estimation methods are not applicable to NMB-MIMO due to its unique magnitude-only detection mechanism. This paper introduces an innovative channel estimation framework specifically designed for NMB-MIMO systems. Initially, we deploy a local oscillator (LO) to transmit known reference signals, and the NMB-MIMO channel estimation is formulated as a compressive phase retrieval problem by leveraging the inherent angular-domain sparsity of wireless channels. To address the proposed problem, we subsequently develop an efficient universal compressive phase retrieval (UCPR) algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate the robustness of the proposed UCPR approach, validating its effectiveness in accurately reconstructing NMB-MIMO channels.

title: High-Efficiency Broadband Continuous Class-F Power Amplifier Using an Independent Harmonic Termination Load Network
authors: Dana Moon, Juntaek Oh
abstract: This study developed a new design for a high-efficiency broadband continuous class-F (CCF) power amplifier (PA) that employs an independent harmonic termination load network (IHTLN) to simplify impedance matching in a compact structure. In the CCF operation, the developed IHTLN provides independent, sequential matching at the second- and third-harmonic frequencies while maintaining a robust performance under load impedance variation. The design optimizes transmission line widths to achieve the desired CCF mode impedances at these harmonics, thereby eliminating the need for additional matching stages, minimizing the losses, and reducing the form factor by re-utilizing harmonic networks. To validate the approach, a high-efficiency CCF PA featuring the developed IHTLN was designed, fabricated, and evaluated. The experimental results showed that the fabricated PA achieved a peak power added efficiency (PAE) greater than 50% in the range of 1.85–2.7 GHz, a saturated output power of 40.6–42.5 dBm, and a large-signal gain of 12.1–16.5 dB. Moreover, it realized a peak drain efficiency of 85.8% and a peak PAE of 75.6% at 2.4 GHz. The developed design effectively simplifies broadband impedance matching while precisely controlling harmonic impedances, thereby achieving enhanced efficiency at a targeted frequency without narrowing the bandwidth.

title: Structured Data Extraction Method for Key Documents in Power Operation Sites
authors: Wei Sun, Jiajie Jin, Jinfei Qin, Shaorui Qin, Tao Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: With the continuous expansion of power system construction and maintenance, both the volume and variety of onsite operation documents are rapidly increasing. Typical examples include work permits, safety disclosure cards, the “three measures and one plan,” and field survey records. These documents appear in heterogeneous formats such as scanned images, PDFs, and Word files, posing significant challenges for review and crossverification. Conventional OCR-based methods often fall short in terms of accuracy and robustness, making it difficult to meet the requirements of safety supervision platforms for efficient and precise auditing. To address this issue, this study introduces a structured data acquisition approach grounded in end-to-end visual document understanding. The method is built around the KOSMOS-2.5 model and proceeds through three main stages: document input and preprocessing, semantic feature modeling, and structured data generation and storage. Experiments conducted on safety disclosure cards and the “three measures and one plan” documents demonstrate that the proposed approach can reliably extract key fields and produce unified structured outputs. The results significantly enhance the automation and accuracy of document processing, thereby offering technical support for intelligent auditing and safety supervision in power operation sites.

title: Study on High-Q Nonlinear Metasurfaces Based on Symmetry-Breaking-Induced Quasi-BIC
authors: Qun Ren, Yu Liu, Xiuyu Wang, Hao Huang, Yongshan Liang, Jianquan Yao, Yongjing Dang, Qiwen Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Metasurfaces revolutionize nonlinear optics by enabling nanoscale control and enhancement of nonlinear effects, yet metallic ohmic loss limits conversion efficiency. BIC-based nonlinear metasurfaces boost Q-factor to overcome this. This paper presents a triple-capacitor-like metasurface supporting symmetry-protected quasi-BIC, creating high-Q resonant peaks. In multi-channel systems, perfect and quasi-bound states correspond to electromagnetic wave storage and release. The structure's resonant frequency and amplitude are independently tunable, enabling flexible control over SFG and DFG. In short, this metasurface has great value for nonlinear optical devices, multi-channel optical communication, and optical storage.

authors: Li-Hua Wang, Chang-Jiao Duan, Bao-Feng Cao, Peng Li, Ying-Song Li, Adrian Bekasiewicz
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this work, a dual-band pattern diversity all-textile antenna dedicated to on-/off-body applications within industrial, scientific, and medical (ISM) bands centered around 2.4 GHz and 5.8 GHz frequencies is proposed. The structure is implemented on a stack of two felt-based substrates. Its metallization layers comprise (from top to bottom) a microstrip-fed rectangular patch, a top-coupled square patch, and a ground plane. Off-body behavior (unidirectional radiation) is achieved by excitation of a TM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</inf> mode at the top patch, whereas on-body (omnidirectional) operation stems from shorting the top patch to the middle and bottom metal layers resulting in excitation of a TM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">00</inf> mode. Compared to other radiators from the literature, the presented antenna features a simple topology while enabling independent tuning of both resonant frequencies. The simulation results show that the structure offers 30 MHz (i.e., from 2.46 GHz to 2.49 GHz) and 580 MHz (5.52 GHz to 6.1 GHz) bandwidths (at the –10 dB level) around the lower and upper resonant frequencies, respectively.

title: Hybrid Fuzzy-RL Framework for Intelligent Customer Targeting in E-Commerce
authors: Darwin Tandi, Rashawn Yashadhana, Jason Loren, Azani Cempaka Sari
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Understanding and predicting customer behavior is essential for developing effective personalized marketing strategies in the digital economy. However, traditional segmentation techniques such as k-means or rule-based models struggle to handle the ambiguity and evolving nature of real-world customer data. This paper presents a hybrid framework that integrates Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) clustering with Weighted Interval-Valued Dual Hesitant Fuzzy Sets (WIVDHFS) and Deep Q-Network (DQN)-based reinforcement learning to enable adaptive and interpretable customer targeting. Using a cleaned version of the publicly available Online Retail dataset from the UCI Machine Learning Repository, customers are segmented via a weighted RFM (Recency, Frequency, Monetary) model, and a hesitancy score is derived from fuzzy membership uncertainty. These segments inform a reinforcement learning agent that selects optimal marketing actions—such as discounts, cross-selling, waiting, or reordering— based on customer state and context in a simulated environment. Experimental results show that fuzzy clustering achieved a Fuzzy Partition Coefficient (FPC) of 0.6423, indicating robust segmentation with moderate overlap. Among nine reinforcement learning models tested, those prioritizing inventory efficiency (w<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> = 0.7) achieved the highest average reward of 73.0, consistently favoring a waiting strategy. This outcome highlights the framework’s ability to generate strategic, context-aware marketing decisions based on revenue and inventory which demonstrates a path toward intelligent marketing automation. The main limitation of this work is that it has only been validated in a simulated setting, and results may differ in real-world deployment.

title: Detection of Hazardous Materials in Skin Care Products Based on Product Packaging Label Images Using a CNN Model
authors: Bambang Krismono Triwijoyo, Dian Syafitri, Anthony Anggrawan, Husain, Agus Pribadi, Nurul Indriani
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Advances in image processing technology have enabled automation in various aspects of life, including the safety of cosmetic products. This study aims to develop a hazardous ingredient detection system in cosmetic products through label image pattern recognition using deep learning methods. The dataset consists of 500 cosmetic label images containing ingredients, which are then processed using Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to extract text. A deep learning model based on Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is developed to identify hazardous ingredient keywords in accordance with the regulations of the Indonesian Food and Drug Administration (BPOM) and international organizations such as the FDA and the European Union Cosmetic Regulation. Experimental results show that the proposed model has an accuracy rate of 91.2% in detecting hazardous content compared to conventional text-matching-based methods. This study provides a fast and accurate automated solution to improve consumer safety against cosmetic products containing hazardous ingredients.

title: 3D Photonic-Electronic Computing
authors: S. J. Ben Yoo
abstract: We will discuss a new computing paradigm enabled by co-designed 3D photonic and electronic integrated circuits (3D EPICs) architected for hierarchical learning. The proposed 3D EPICs consist of spiking photonic neural networks and electronic neural networks to pursue best-of-both-worlds' benefits from photonic and electronic computing.

title: Semiconductor Laser with Mode-Locking and Single-Longitudinal Bifunctional Operation
authors: Xiao Sun, Yiming Sun, Zhibo Li, John H. Marsh, Stephen. J. Sweeney, Anthony E. Kelly, Lianping Hou
abstract: We demonstrate a novel <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 5 0 n m}$</tex> AlGaInAs semiconductor laser with dual-mode operation; a mode-locked pulsed mode at 17.7 GHz with a timing jitter of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.3 \text{ps}(10 \text{kHz}-100$</tex> MHz) and an RF linewidth of 22 kHz, and a single-wavelength continuous-wave mode with a 33 dB side-mode suppression ratio.

title: Cognition-Inspired Radar Jamming Identification and Suppression Technology
authors: Jiahao Zhang, Jiaxiang Wang, Xi Yu, Jundi Wang, Wantian Wang, Wei Li, Jin Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In complex electromagnetic environments, radar anti-jamming capability is crucial for ensuring normal detection and tracking. With the rapid development of semiconductor technology and artificial intelligence (AI), advanced jamming techniques, such as cognitive jamming, are continuously evolving, posing higher requirements for radar anti-jamming performance. To address this need, a cognitive-empowered radar anti-jamming technology is proposed. This technology converts the received temporal radar signals into time-frequency 2D data. A lightweight visual neural network is proposed to achieve accurate recognition of radar jamming styles and parameters. Based on a priori knowledge of jamming, multiple jamming suppression methods are proposed. In complex electromagnetic environments, the recognition accuracy for typical jamming types reaches no less than 90%.

title: Research on Optimization Method for Low-Frequency Harmonic Suppression of Inverters Based on Random PWM
authors: Donghao Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: This paper addresses the waveform distortion caused by concentrated and distributed harmonics in traditional PWM systems by proposing an optimized low-frequency harmonic suppression method for inverters based on random PWM. By introducing random carrier frequency and dynamic perturbation strategies, a mathematical model is constructed and experimentally validated. Results demonstrate that random PWM effectively reduces specific harmonic amplitudes by dispersing harmonic energy, achieving superior harmonic suppression performance compared to conventional PWM. Experiments show voltage waveforms approaching ideal sine waves (peak 220 V), stable currents (peak $\sim \mathbf{1 0 0 A}$), significantly reduced total harmonic distortion, uniform spectral energy distribution, and markedly enhanced system power quality and stability.

title: Research on Regional Distributed Photovoltaic Meteorological Information Calculation and Power Prediction Technology Based on Grid Division
authors: Hai Zhou, Nan Wang, Yifei Guan, Yuhang Wang, Honglu Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: To address insufficient meteorological data, low-quality power data, and regional-level prediction difficulty under high distributed photovoltaic (PV) penetration, this paper proposes an integrated technology combining grid division, multi-source information fusion, and deep learning. First, the study area is gridded at 30 km intervals, and power data of incomplete sites is reconstructed via an adaptive weighting algorithm using adjacent complete sites’ data. Second, an LSTM meteorological element calculation model is built with reconstructed power and ECMWF/NASA numerical weather prediction (NWP) data to achieve high-precision temperature/irradiance modeling. Finally, a TCN-BiLSTM joint model is designed for grid-level power prediction, taking grid total power, NWP at grid intersections, and calculated meteorological elements as inputs. Experiments on 162 distributed PV sites ($1-38.1 \mathrm{MW}$) and 1 centralized site in a Chinese city show: the meteorological model has temperature MAE $\mathbf{0. 1 1}-\mathbf{0. 5 1}{ }^{\circ} \mathbf{C}$ (correlation 0.92-0.98) and irradiance MAE 3.01-26.11 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (correlation $0.97-0.99$); the TCN-BiLSTM model has MAE 3.50 MW, RMSE 5.56 MW, R ${ }^{\mathbf{2}} \mathbf{0. 9 8 8}$, with MAE/RMSE reduced by $16.67 \%-33.46 \% / 13.93 \%-20.80 \%$ vs. LSTM/GRU/CNN. This method supports refined dispatching and safe grid connection of regional distributed PV

title: Model Predictive Control Strategy with Adaptive Weight Adjustment in Humanoid Robots
authors: Silong He, Mingchao Li, Kangxing Huang, Kui Xiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Model Predictive Control (MPC) has been shown to enhance the stability and robustness of humanoid robot systems. However, conventional MPC methods typically employ fixed weight matrices, which lack the capability to adapt to environmental changes in real time. To address this limitation, a novel MPC strategy with adaptive weight adjustment is proposed in this study. The proposed approach initializes the weight matrix based on the robot velocity and subsequently adjusts the optimization weights in real time by comparing the robot current state with the reference state. This adjustment allows for task-specific and environment-sensitive behavior optimization, thereby improving the robot ability to handle complex scenarios and enhancing the overall control performance. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to traditional MPC, the adaptive-weight MPC adjustment reduces the variation in the center of mass (CoM) height by 2.5 %, decreases the maximum roll angle by 0.2°, and mitigates pitch angle oscillations. Additionally, it effectively suppresses velocity deviations, leading to a significant improvement in stability during the early walking phase.

title: Aging Evaluation of Transformer Oil-Immersed Insulation Combining Frequency Domain Spectroscopy and Support Vector Machine
authors: Qianyue Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: Traditional FDS techniques struggle to accurately assess the aging state of oil-immersed paper insulation under high moisture conditions. This study proposes a novel method combining frequency domain spectroscopy (FDS) and SVM to address the aging-moisture synergistic effect. In this work, the oil immersed pressboard samples are prepared for collecting their FDS data. Then, the feature parameters were extracted from FDS data of samples with varying aging/moisture states, and a fitting database was constructed via multiple regression analysis to train the SVM model. The model achieves accurate aging evaluation under different damp conditions, with an average classification accuracy exceeding 99.7%.

title: Neuro-Adaptive Backstepping Control for Accurate State of Charge and State of Health Estimation in Lithium-Ion Batteries
authors: Priyaa Vaishnavi H S, Nandika P S, Surekha Paneerselvam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: Accurate State of Charge (SOC) and State of Health (SOH) estimations are critical for optimizing performance, longevity, and safety of Li-ion batteries in electric vehicles and renewable energy systems. The study introduces a Neuro-Adaptive Backstepping (NAB) controller, leveraging neural networks and backstepping techniques to address the nonlinear dynamics and uncertainties in Li-ion batteries. The NAB controller is evaluated against Non-Neuro Adaptive Backstepping (NNAB) and Fuzzy Logic Controllers (FLC) using a 3RC equivalent circuit model in MATLAB. Performance metrics, including ITAE, ITSE, and IAE, demonstrate The NAB controller’s superior accuracy and robustness, with the lowest error metrics (MAE = 0.0115, RMSE = 0.0806) and the fastest convergence, making it ideal for dynamic battery management systems.

title: Computer Vision-Based Pose Estimation for Student Engagement Detection: Trends and Challenges
authors: Gabriel Asael Tarigan, Gregorius Natanael Elwirehardja, Kuncahyo Setyo Nugroho, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Engagement reflects a student’s interest, interaction, and effort in learning activities that foster persistence and successful task completion. Despite its importance, current engagement detection systems often suffer from limited dataset diversity, high annotation costs, and difficulty capturing body pose cues in complex classroom environments. This systematic literature review addresses these challenges by identifying and analyzing recent computer vision-based pose estimation trends for student engagement detection. Existing methods were categorized into object detection, pose estimation, and hybrid approaches. YOLO-based object detection emerged as the most widely adopted method, showing strong robustness in complex scenarios. CNN-based methods demonstrated high data efficiency and adaptability for smaller datasets. Key challenges identified include extensive manual annotation requirements, dataset imbalance, and reduced accuracy under occlusion or in crowded settings. Opportunities for future research include efficient data collection, multimodal fusion, and deployment of lightweight models for real-time engagement monitoring.

title: Impact of Centrelink Recipients in Loan Eligibility Prediction Using ML Model
authors: Md Kamruzzaman, Ripon K. Chakrabortty, Pankaj Sharma, Hamed Aboutorab, Mohammad Nuruzzaman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Access to affordable credit remains a significant challenge for low-income individuals, particularly those reliant on government welfare payments such as Australia's Centrelink benefits. Traditional credit scoring systems often disadvantage Centrelink recipients due to their reliance on employment status and historical credit data, which may not reflect their financial stability. This study investigates the role of Centrelink-related features such as Centrelink income, other income, expenses and demographics in improving loan eligibility predictions for Centrelink recipients. Using a realworld dataset of 554 loan applicants, we evaluate machine learning models (including XGBoost, Random Forest, Adaboost, Gradient Boost and Decision Trees) to enhance fairness and accuracy in loan approval decisions. The XGBoost model achieved the highest accuracy (94.59%) and was further analysed using SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations) to interpret feature influence and detect potential biases. Results indicate that while Centrelink income is a significant predictor, its association with loan approval is nuanced, revealing potential biases against welfare-dependent applicants. The study underscores the need for inclusive, data-driven credit assessment models that account for the unique financial profiles of Centrelink recipients, promoting equitable access to credit and aligning with global financial inclusion efforts.

title: Bending Effect of Imaging Fiber Bundle Bending on Image Contrast in High-Resolution Microendoscopy (HRME)
authors: Anjanaa S, Karthika J, Sreelakshmi Pyarilal, Sreelakshmi Sreekumar, Arpitha Anantharaju, Uttam M. Pal
abstract: High-resolution microendoscopy (HRME) was evaluated for spatial resolution using the 1951 USAF Resolution Chart. The setup examined contrast and resolution across chart angles from 0° to 60°, confirming HRME's capability for detailed imaging in diagnostic applications.

title: Media Clock Recovery with Combination of Hardware and Software based Approach
authors: Manoj Kumar, Chen Fei, Fan Qiuyu, HariKrishna Valluru
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: AVB is a real time protocol and now a days it is preferred in Automotive world in Infotainment ECUs for Audio communication over Ethernet as it insures low latency and real time aspects while Audio data transmission over Ethernet. Media clock recovery is a mechanism for achieving a glitch-free audio experience over Ethernet. A complete software-based MCR mechanism requires a lot of Software tuning and is prone to system latencies, whereas a hardware-based MCR requires costly electronic components. The proposed Media clock recovery mechanism in this study combines both hardware and software-based media clock recovery (MCR) mechanisms. The hardware part consists of a clock multiplier, which can be considered as a PLL but lacks phase alignment, effectively making it a frequency syntonization. Therefore, using software components, this phase alignment is achieved, making it a complete frequency synchronization. Keywords— Automotive AVB, Ethernet, MCR, Hardware-Software Co-design

title: A Spoof Surface Plasmon Polariton Duplexer for K/Ka-band Satcom
authors: Zhongxian Zheng, Guanghua Liang, Yaxin Xu, Wei Han, Yuan Zhou, Sifan Wu, Jianxing Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper presents a millimeter-wave waveguide duplexer utilizing the spoof surface plasmon polariton (SSPP) structure. An in-depth analysis of the SSPP unit cell and its cut-off characteristics informed the design of the millimeter-wave waveguide duplexer. The lower and higher working frequency ranges of the duplexer are 17.7 to 21.2 GHz and 27.4 to 31.0 GHz, respectively. Simulated results indicate that the duplexer operates with the return loss better than 17.5 dB. Benefiting from the SSPP configuration, the designed duplexer attains a low insertion loss below 0.35 dB, alongside a high isolation of over 83 dB between its output ports. The simulated results indicate that the duplexer possesses high isolation, low insertion loss and good impedance matching.

title: Man-in-the-Middle Attack Testing for PPTP VPN Security in an Intranet Setup
authors: Feri Fahrianto, Defiana Arnaldy, Muhammad Faizal, Siti Ummi Masruroh, Hendra Bayu Suseno, Victor Amrizal
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The internet has both positive and negative aspects, with cybercrime being one of its most concerning negative consequences. As cybercrime continues to pose a significant threat, measures have been developed to mitigate these risks. One such measure is the use of Virtual Private Networks (VPNs). However, vulnerabilities still exist in certain VPN protocols, particularly PPTP VPN, which relies on client authentication using MS-CHAPv2. This authentication method is susceptible to attacks, including the theft of VPN user login passwords. Such password theft can be accomplished through brute-force attacks, assisted by tools like Asleap on Backtrack. This study investigates the effectiveness of these attack techniques by applying them to a VPN server and analyzing the data obtained from victims to determine whether passwords can be successfully stolen. The research utilizes Ettercap for ARP poisoning, Asleap for generating challenge-response values, and Wireshark for packet capture. The study applies the Security Policy Development Life Cycle (SPDLC) method to analyze the results. The findings reveal that PPTP VPN with MS-CHAPv2 authentication on Windows OS remains vulnerable to password theft through brute force and assisted techniques using Backtrack's Asleap tool. A potential solution to prevent such password theft is upgrading the client operating system to latest OS version.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Reserved Instances vs. Spot Instances in DevOps Cloud Workflows
authors: Darshan Gowda Anamanahalli Ramesh, Ruth G. Lennon
abstract: The optimization of cloud resources stands essential for DevOps workflows, yet companies face difficulties when maintaining reliability at affordable costs. The research explores AWS environments to analyze the implementation of Reserved Instances together with Spot Instances when addressing cost-reliability trade-offs. A combination of Reserved Instances with Spot Instances which provides stable production workload coverage and fault-tolerant capabilities produces substantial cost savings without unacceptable MTTR increases according to real-world experimental analysis. Technical solutions for this implementation consist of load balancers that provide failover capabilities and checkpointing methods that preserve state information while EC2 Auto Scaling automates instance recovery processes. The analysis demonstrates that excessive Reserved Instance procurement results in underutilized resources and Spot Instance testing interruptions create longer recovery durations. Hybrid models solve deployment problems while they enhance high deployment speeds through reduced lead time variations. The research investigates machine learning technologies and multi cloud solutions as potential strategies for optimizing dynamic resource utilization in the future. The research discovers practices that support operational leaders in adjusting their cloud resource utilization per organizational requirements.

title: RF Energy Harvesting and Management for Autonomous Battery-free Wireless Microrobot
authors: Qiang Fu, Ruoyu Jia, Yuxuan Deng, Hao Zhang, Ying Wang, He Guan
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Wireless microrobot plays an important role in unmanned system. However, it suffers from battery limitations to shrink operational time. In this work, radio frequency (RF) energy harvesting and management is introduced to facilitate wireless battery charging and high pulse voltages generation. A low temperature co-fired ceramic (LTCC) process is employed for antenna in package (AiP), which helps to realize miniature integration. A flexible printed circuit (FPC) process is adopted for Class-E inverter, transformer and voltage multiplier, which achieves low weight and profile driver for a future piezoelectric actuator. Both simulations and measurements of antenna and driver agree well, which provides a potential for autonomous battery-free wireless microrobot.

title: Modelling Medical Students with Engineering Students: Addressing the Knowledge Gap in User Studies
authors: Alessandro Iop, Mario Romero
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Engaging Critical Workforce In co-Design aNd Assessment (ECWIDNA)
abstract: Recruiting medical students for user studies is a challenging task. They usually have overflowing schedules and often limited experience using advanced prototype applications, which entails complex scheduling challenges and extended introduction and training periods. Among potential solutions to this challenge is the recruitment of engineering students to model of medical students’ skills and knowledge. We believe that wider, more easily accessible pools of study subjects may effectively model more valid — albeit less available — subjects, particularly in early validation and testing studies in preparation for more detailed and mature on-the-field experiments. This is because, through careful and controlled transfer of knowledge and mental models, the gap between medical and engineering students can be effectively bridged. In this paper, we delve into some of the pros and cons of recruiting among the latter students rather than the former, and propose an approach based on estimating to what degree one can leverage engineering students as suitable mental models (ESAMMs). Additionally, we advocate for the need of a more systematic analysis and comparison of these two populations, especially in the context of XR for medical education.

title: Radial Basis Function-Based Deadbeat Predictive Current Control of Brushless Dual Rotor Machines
authors: Hui Wu, Shuangxia Niu, Zekai Lyu, Mingyuan Jiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Brushless dual rotor machines (BLDRM) hold significant potential in many fields due to multiple motion units and higher integration. It is essential to boost performance for their drive systems in both dynamic transitions and steady conditions. Firstly, this paper introduces deadbeat predictive current control (DPCC) to both regular windings and modulation windings in the BLDRM drive system to achieve rapid response. To further improve the accuracy of current prediction, the paper proposes a radial basis function (RBF) based DPCC to suppress the harmonic currents by incorporating an RBF neural network for model compensation. The RBF has a strong fitting capability for nonlinear functions. Utilizing rotor position as a continuous input, online disturbance estimation can be achieved due to RBF's characteristic of fast convergence. Besides, prior knowledge of harmonic orders is not required, and harmonics across multiple frequencies can be suppressed effectively, making it particularly suitable for BLDRM. Finally, the capability of the proposed control scheme is demonstrated by the simulation. Periodic and non-periodic disturbances can be observed by RBF, significantly reducing the total harmonic distortion in two sets of windings.

title: Improved YOLOv8-based crack detection model for road bridges
authors: Xiangyu Li, Liang Chen, Haiyang Zhang, Jian Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: As road bridges enter the manual operation and maintenance stage on a large scale, traditional crack detection methods for road bridges usually rely on manual inspection and visual inspection. However, manual inspection of road and bridge cracks is time-consuming and unsafe. In order to identify and detect cracks efficiently, accurately, and without contact, a road and bridge crack detection model based on improved YOLOv8 is proposed; the method introduces both ResBlock_CBAM and BiFPN to the Head part based on YOLOv8, and dynamically adjusts different The method is based on YOLOv8 and introduces both ResBlock_CBAM and BiFPN to the Head part, which improves the model's representation of crack features by bi-directional connection and dynamically adjusting the importance of features with different resolutions; and enhances feature extraction by adaptively focusing on key features and suppressing irrelevant information. The results show that the accuracy P, recall R, mean average precision mAP50 and mAP50-95 of the improved model are improved by 0.28%, 6.03%, 2.82% and 1.87% compared with the original YOLOv8 model. This shows that the improved model can detect road and bridge cracks in complex environments more efficiently, which can provide a part of ideas for industrial target detection.

title: Active Frequency Selective Surface with Tunable and Switchable Characteristics in Dual Bands
authors: Huaibin Wang, Haobin Yang, Yefeng Tong, Chong-Zhi Han, Ying Huang, Jian Shu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper designs a dual-band broadband tunable active frequency selective surface (AFSS), which utilizes PIN diode switches to efficiently switch between two operating frequency bands. Combined with varactor diodes, precise dynamic tuning is achieved. Simulation results verify that the tuning range for the low-frequency band is 3-8.1 GHz with a relative bandwidth of 91.8%, while the high-frequency band can be adjusted between 12.6-15.7 GHz with a relative bandwidth of 21.8%.

title: Decoupled MPC with Constrained Optimization for Enhanced Robot Manipulator Trajectory Tracking
authors: Mohamed Sedki Limam, Gilde Vanel Tchane Djogdom, Andre Gallant
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: The growing requirements of Industry 4.0 and the healthcare sector are driving the need for ever-greater precision in robotic control. Model Predictive Control with Decoupling (MPC-Decoupling) is emerging as an effective solution to meet this challenge while optimizing system performance. Ensuring precise tracking of position, velocity, and acceleration is crucial for these applications. This paper introduces an innovative MPC-Decoupling approach that significantly reduces errors in these variables while integrating acceleration constraints to further enhance performance. Simulations conducted on the UR5e manipulator using the Pinocchio library reveal notable improvements: a 48 % reduction in position error and a 92 % decrease in velocity error compared to conventional MPCDecoupling position-tracking methods. Moreover, incorporating acceleration constraints further refines accuracy, yielding errors on the order of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10^{-6}\text{rad} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$</tex>.

title: Research on Condition Monitoring Method of Power Equipment Based on Infrared and Visible Image Fusion
authors: Wei Wu, Anguo Zhang, Xuan Song, Jie Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: This paper addresses the issue of image blurring and detail loss caused by light interference in the infrared monitoring of electrical equipment by proposing an infrared-visible image fusion algorithm based on wavelet transform. By comparing the noise reduction effects of mean filtering, bilateral filtering, and median filtering, and conducting fusion experiments using pixel-weighted averaging, Laplace pyramid, and wavelet transform methods, the superiority of wavelet transform in preserving temperature information and enhancing image details is verified. This approach significantly improves the accuracy of image recognition and provides new insights for the intelligent monitoring of electrical equipment in complex lighting environments.

title: Application of A Parallel hp-Adaptive FEM Solver for Radiation Problems in Antennas with Radome
authors: Yan-Nan Liu, Wei-Jie Wang, Jing-Jie Xu, Shao-Liang Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Solving radiation problems of antennas with radome using finite element method (FEM) is a difficult task due to the electrically large region, complex structures and drastic changes of electromagnetic field. The hp-adaptive approach ensures efficient resolution of the solution domain and retaining high accuracy in critical local features, thus it will be a powerful tool to solve this problem. To achieve an efficient and effective simulation, a parallel hp-adaptive FEM solver is proposed, which is developed based on JAUMIN framework. This parallel hpadaptive FEM solver is employed to simulate the radiation problems of integrated antenna and radome structures, numerical results show that the proposed solver is superior to traditional pure h- or p-refinement in efficiency.

title: Polarization-Aware Modular IR Apertures for Interference Mitigation in Multi-User Indoor Networks
authors: S. Gunathilake, A. Nirmalathas, K. Herath, M. Premaratne
abstract: A polarization-aware method improves modular clustered IR optical apertures to mitigate inter-user interference in multi-user near-field indoor networks. Assigning orthogonal polarization with aligned receivers enhances SINR and leads to a 77% reduction in average BER, confirming improved reliability.

title: A Switched-Capacitor Compute-in-Memory Ising Hardware Annealing Accelerator
authors: Ariane Hannon, Viet Nguyen, R. Bogdan Staszewski
abstract: Ising hardware accelerators are needed to efficiently solve the pervasive real-world combinatorial optimisation problems (COPs) that would otherwise be intractable to solve using brute-force approaches on a traditional computer. The Ising model abstracts a COP to the interactions between a network of binary spins, which can be solved by annealing. This work presents a novel mixed-signal Ising accelerator capable of highly efficient annealing. The switched-capacitor (SC) network implemented with high-precision metal-oxide-metal capacitors solves Ising problems with 8-bit coefficients and an all-to-all interaction matrix, allowing for the flexible representation of a diverse range of COPs. Highly accurate, energy-efficient, fully-parallelised, analogue computations are carried out at high speeds using a 2.5GHz clock. At this frequency, a 16x16 SC network consumes 11.6mW average power using a supply voltage of 0.8V. The area-efficient modular structure maintains accuracy even at 4-bit ADC resolution, enabling scalability to thousands of spins.

title: Integrated Plasmonic Digital-to-Analog Converter, Using Broadband Low-Loss Electro-Absorption Hybrid Plasmonic Switches
authors: Rajib Ratan Ghosh, Anuj Dhawan
abstract: In this work, we present the design and numerical modeling of plasmonic digital-to-analog converter, using broadband low-loss electro-absorption hybrid plasmonic switches having near-epsilon-zero nonlinearity of TCOs, in a silicon photonics platform. The electro-absorption switch used in this plasmonic digital-to-analog converter consists of a hybrid plasmonic waveguide having a thin layer of ITO. The optical losses in the plasmonic waveguide are controlled by changing the carrier concentration in ITO. The free carrier density tunability effect in the metal-oxide-semiconductor (MOS) capacitor structure can be realized by applying an external voltage. The hybrid plasmonic waveguide-based electro-absorption switch shows very low insertion loss, high extinction ratio, high 3-dB bandwidth, ultra-compactness, low power consumption, very low-temperature sensitivity, and broadband optical operation. We demonstrate a plasmonic digital-to-analog converter with high sampling rates, high nonlinearity, high resolutions, high precision, and low operating power.

title: Nanocavity-Engineered 2D Perovskite High-Speed Photodetectors with Robust Ambient Stability
authors: Murali Gedda, Qiaoqiang Gan
abstract: Advancements in photodetector technology are vital for optical communication and imaging systems. To meet these demands, we have developed high-speed and ultrastable photodetectors using ultrathin 2D metal halide perovskites and planar nanocavity. Our method overcomes traditional thicknessabsorption trade-off, thereby optimizing device speed.

title: A Study on Association Analysis of Electric Power Service Requests Based on Multimodal Semantic Similarity and Prompt Engineering for Large Language Models
authors: Shan Chen, Huijun Hong, Yiru Yang, Zhengcheng Min, Xiaohui Chen, Fei He, Qiyang Ruan, Shanshan Yu, Tianyuan Ma, Weifeng Zeng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: We propose an association-analysis method for electric-power service tickets that combines multimodal semantic similarity with prompt engineering for large language models, addressing challenges like vague addresses, missing fields, and duplicate complaints. The workflow includes text normalization, hierarchical address mapping, and timestamp alignment. SBERT embeddings are fused with one-hot administrative codes and geolocation features. GPT-4 is guided by zero-shot, few-shot, and chain-of-thought prompts to generate confidence scores. These are linearly fused to enable accurate address-to-feeder matching and duplicate detection. Experiments on 45 outage tickets show a 3.9point F1-score improvement over single-path baselines and strong robustness in ambiguous cases, validating both the effectiveness and interpretability of the method.

title: Prototype for System Dynamics and Control Demonstration using a Setpoint Tracking Controller
authors: Matheus Costa, Seamus McLoone, Erivelton Nepomuceno
abstract: System dynamics and control theory play a major role in a variety of modern engineering applications. In the Engineering curriculum, simulation and experiment-based content is a common practice to improve the comprehension and adhere to best practices in system analysis and design. Despite these practices courses still rely mostly on the mathematical theory of these topics in itself, creating challenges in student’s understanding of these topics. This leads to a gap in which more intuitive and educational devices could be employed to demonstrate the connection and interplay between theory and practice. This work presents a position tracking controller with four user inputs designed to aid in the demonstration of system dynamics and control system concepts. The system is not dependent on licensed software and is built at a reduced cost compared to commercial solutions. The device is designed to align with the syllabus presented in first, second and third-year courses in the undergraduate Electronic Engineering degree at Maynooth University. The system is initially tested and feedback from different users is collected.

title: Towards Transparent Cyber Threat Detection : A Systematic Literature Review on the Role of Explainable AI (XAI) in Information Security Risk Management (2018-2025)
authors: Fathoni Mahardika, Ema Utami, Kusrini, Ferry Wahyu Wibowo
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: As Machine Learning (ML) models become increasingly integral to Information Security Risk Management (ISRM), their inherent complexity often results in a “black-box” problem, hindering trust, accountability, and adoption by stakeholders. This lack of transparency is a critical barrier in high-stakes environments like cybersecurity. Explainable AI (XAI) has emerged as a crucial field to address this challenge by making model decisions interpretable to humans. This paper conducts a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) following the PRISMA framework to investigate the role and application of XAI in the context of ISRM. We analyze existing literature to identify commonly used XAI techniques, primary application domains, documented benefits, and persistent challenges. Our findings reveal a growing trend in applying methods like SHAP and LIME for interpreting threat detection models, yet a significant gap remains in their integration into holistic, realtime risk management frameworks, particularly within specific institutional contexts such as higher education. This review maps the current research landscape and proposes a forwardlooking agenda for developing transparent, trustworthy, and actionable cybersecurity intelligence systems.

title: A Blockchain-Based Reputation Borrowing Model to Address the Cold Start Problem for New Users in Real Estate
authors: Abdulmajeed A. Alyoubi, Abdullah J. Abualhamayl, Mohanad A. Almalki, Yasir D. Alyoubi, Firas Al-Doghman, Farookh Khadeer Hussain
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Reputation significantly influences trust in online platforms, notably in real estate. New users face cold start challenges due to a lack of initial reputation scores, limiting their potential transactions. This paper introduces a conceptual blockchain-based model for reputation borrowing, enabling new users to acquire reputation scores from established users, thus enhancing their credibility. The model incorporates a decay mechanism to illustrate how reputation decreases over time and establishes incentives for timely repayments alongside penalties for late repayments.

title: Shielding Characteristics of Aircraft Electronic Equipment Compartment Against Electromagnetic Pulse
authors: Chunyong Han
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Electromagnetic pulses (EMP) can easily cause malfunction or failure of aircraft electronic equipment, posing a serious threat to flight safety. The shielding capability of the electronic equipment compartment is crucial for ensuring the normal operation of electronic devices. In this study, directional irradiation tests were conducted on an aircraft from the left side and the front using an EMP simulator. The electric field strength inside the electronic equipment compartment was measured using horizontally and vertically polarized electric field sensors. The shielding effectiveness of the compartment was calculated and analyzed. The results show that When the aircraft is exposed to either horizontally or vertically polarized electromagnetic pulses, the oscillation decay trend and decay time of the electric field waveform within the electronic equipment cabin remain consistent. Notably, as the irradiation intensity increases from E1 to E2, the oscillation amplitude of the horizontally polarized electric field exhibits a more pronounced variation. In contrast, the oscillation amplitude of the vertically polarized electric field shows a consistent level of change. The maximum difference in shielding effectiveness under varying EMP peak intensities, polarization modes, and irradiation directions was 3.3 dB, with the variation in shielding effectiveness remaining consistent. The shielding effectiveness is closely related to the materials and structure of the aircraft body but is largely independent of the EMP irradiation intensity, polarization mode, and irradiation direction. These findings provide a basis for evaluating the EMP protection capability of aircraft electronic equipment compartments and have significant engineering implications.

title: Experimental Investigation on Temperature Compensated High Spatial Resolution Distributed Strain Measurement for Pipe Monitoring
authors: Hailiang Zhang, Zhaowen Xu, Hui Dong, Yixin Wang, Varghese Paulose, Dora Juan Juan Hu
abstract: Temperature-compensated, high-spatial-resolution distributed strain measurements were experimentally investigated using a four-point bending test as preparation for pipe monitoring applications. A 10,000-cycle loading verified the reliability of the system.

title: Adaptive Timed Elastic Band-Yolo Local Path Planning for Ackermann-Steered Robots in Dynamic Unstructured Environments
authors: Chongxiao Liu, Jinjin Wang, Renhui Ying, Yanan Li, Bao Kha Nguyen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Autonomous robots require efficient local path planning capabilities to handle complex dynamic obstacles in unstructured environments. However, traditional methods, such as Timed Elastic Band (TEB) local path planning, rely on static parameter settings, making them less adaptable to environmental changes and reducing their effectiveness in dynamic scenarios. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an adaptive TEB-based local path planning algorithm optimized using the Adaptive Moment Estimation (Adam) optimizer. The approach integrates <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 6}$</tex>-line LiDAR, RGB-D cameras, and YOLO-based obstacle detection to identify different obstacles. Based on obstacle type and distance, the algorithm applies gradient-based tuning to key TEB parameters, improving obstacle avoidance under dynamic field conditions. The algorithm was tested in dynamic scenarios, and the experimental results indicate that the proposed method improves path planning efficiency while maintaining a safe distance from obstacles.

title: Sentiment Analysis of Electronic Voting on Indonesia Election Using Machine Learning with Deep Learning Approach
authors: Darren Christian, Ahmad Nurul Fajar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: E-Voting was a digitization of conventional or traditional voting that used a ballot paper to vote. In Indonesia e-voting is rarely used in elections or in other events, e-voting has many benefits that can be achieved by using it, such as cutting the cost or efficiency in vote counting even giving the ease of use to the e-voting user to give their suffrage. Implementing e-voting can be hard because of the negative citizen sentiment about e-voting. Fraud that often happened in election process trigger citizen perception to negative, the same happened as the e-voting method that have negative sentiment on citizen point of view. Cyber-attack possibilities made another reason to questioning about e-voting safety and security. This study purpose is to analyze the Indonesian citizen sentiment on X social media using machine learning with deep learning, sentiment about e-voting in Indonesian citizens can be useful to implement e-voting in Indonesia, especially the word the used in sentiment analysis can give an insight to better improvement. BERT as deep learning model was use in this study to ensure its performance and accuracy. CRISP-DM was used as the methodology of this study as the standard process of data mining process. The result of e-voting sentiment analysis in Indonesian citizens was visualized with chart to made better readability for this study. After a certain process of analyzing and gathering the sentiment data, the result was mostly negative sentiment. With the most appeared word represent lack of trustworthiness in e-voting.

title: Research On High Relative Permeability Compression Higher-Order Mode Dipole
authors: Yangkun Song, Yu Luo, Ningning Yan, Kaixue Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A higher-order mode dipole based on high permeability compression is proposed in this paper, and its radiation performance is systematically investigated. The variation in relative permittivity and relative permeability affects the phase constant, thus affecting the far-field electric field distribution of the antenna. This paper investigates the changes in the radiation performance of a higher-order mode dipole antenna by changing the relative permittivity and relative permeability of the dielectric substrate. The result shows that higher-order mode dipoles exhibit higher gain performance on dielectric substrates with high permeability.

title: Buckling and Stress Controlled RF MEMS Structures Using Annealing
authors: Khushbu Singh Raghav, Amit Kumar, Prashant Sharma, Prateek Kothari, Mahesh Angira, Deepak Bansal
abstract: Micro-Electro-Mechanical System (MEMS) devices show better performance as compared to solid-state devices in terms of radio frequency (RF) response, like insertion loss and isolation. However, MEMS devices face reliability issues, and stress is one of the main concerns. MEMS devices involve many non-traditional fabrication steps, like releasing hanging structures. Released MEMS structures show built-in stress from the fabrication process. This stress can cause them to bend, curl, or buckle. Especially in the case of Radio Frequency (RF) MEMS switches, curling buckling increases the pull-in voltage. In the literature, to address stress-related buckling, thermal annealing was applied at different temperatures after release. However, post-release annealing reduces the stress and results in curled-up and unstable structures. The present paper explores a novel and innovative method for thermally annealing structures at an appropriate stage to reduce stress and buckling in released cantilever structures. Annealing at the appropriate step results in a significant reduction in cantilever bending and warping, indicating effective stress relaxation and yielding straight, mechanically stable cantilevers. After controlling the stress and buckling, the pull-in voltage is reduced to 40 V, which is in close agreement with the simulated results. The measured insertion loss of the switch is -0.4 dB, and isolation is -22 dB for the DC to 20 GHz frequency range.
