title: Accelerating the Iterative Solution for Multi-Angle Monostatic RCS via an AR Model-Based Initial Guess Prediction Method
authors: Fan Gao, Xinlei Chen, Zhiwen Dong, Changqing Gu, Zhuo Li, Wu Yang, Weibing Lu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: Efficient computation of multi-angle monostatic radar cross section (RCS) using the method of moments (MoM) is hindered by the need to restart the iterative solution process for each incident angle due to the changing excitation. To mitigate this burden, this letter proposes an autoregressive (AR) model based method for predicting improved initial guesses to accelerate convergence. The AR model parameters are estimated using the Burg algorithm. Predicting each initial guess incurs only (N) computational complexity, which is lower than the (N2) cost of a single iteration in the iterative solver. Compared with those from the conventional phase-corrected initial guess method, the initial guesses predicted by the proposed method are closer to the converged solution. The proposed method effectively reduces the number of iterations, particularly under stringent convergence criteria. Numerical results demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed method.

title: Prescribed-Time Trajectory Tracking and Optimization for QUAVs Subject to Asymmetric Global Performance Constraints and Disturbances
authors: Ce Wang, Zhengguo Huang, Jing Wang, Hao Shen, Ju. H. Park
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Inthis paper, a prescribed-time fuzzy optimized control scheme is developed for quadrotor uncrewed aerial vehicles (QUAVs) under asymmetric global performance constraints and disturbances. Firstly, a prescribed-time fuzzy optimized controller for QUAVs is designed based on the actor-critic architecture. In this approach, the fuzzy logic system is employed to approximate unmodeled dynamics, while the critic network evaluates performance indexes, and the actor network executes control actions. Furthermore, by constructing a piecewise continuous function, the controller not only drives the QUAV to achieve prescribed-time tracking, but also ensures asymmetric global prescribed performance, which eliminates the initial conditions of tracking errors. Moreover, a prescribed-time disturbance observer is designed to compensate for the effect of external disturbances. Different convergence rates are set for the attitude loop, position loop, and observers by adjusting the prescribed times. In addition, a second-order command filter is adopted to avoid direct differentiation of virtual control laws. Theoretical analysis demonstrates that, under asymmetric global prescribed performance constraints and external disturbances, all error signals of QUAVs satisfy practical prescribed-time stability, while minimizing the cost index. Finally, a simulation validates the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy.

title: AC Losses in Striated REBCO Stacked Tape Cables
authors: X.Y. Tan, S.Y. Gao, X.S. Yang, H. Zhang, J. Jiang, J.M. Zhu
abstract: Stacked high-temperature superconducting (HTS) cables, with their high current-carrying capacity and high structural strength, show significant advantages in strong electric applications. However, in an alternating magnetic field environment, the conductors will generate AC losses, which can cause local overheating. Filamentary technology can effectively reduce the AC losses. This work investigates the magnetization and transport losses of stacked HTS cables based on multi-filamentary REBCO tapes. Results directly demonstrates the fact of the multi-filamentary structure in reducing magnetization loss. As the twist angle increased, magnetization losses first decreased and then stabilized. At low magnetic fields, the difference in magnetization loss between the original cable and the multi-filamentary cable is relatively small. Under higher magnetic fields, the magnetization loss of the original cable is significantly higher than that of the multi-filamentary cable. The transport losses of the multi-filamentary cable are always lower than those of the original cable. The optimization effect of filamentization on magnetization losses is significantly stronger than that on transport losses.

title: Novel Compact Tactile Stimulator With Sensing: Designed for Individuals With a Brain Injury and MRI
authors: Nahid Kalantaryardebily, Anna C. Feldbush, Ardalan Kahak, Suyi Li, Netta Gurari
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: Existing tactile assessments indicate that greater than half of individuals living with a brain injury experience tactile impairments, which impede their recovery. Yet, these tactile assessments lack sensitivity, reliability, and ergonomic compatibility for the millions of individuals who experience a clenched hand posture following their brain injury. We present a novel compact, automated tactile stimulator with real-time force estimation, which we designed for use in brain injury and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The system interfaces with the finger through a compact-sized stimulator (9 mm height -18 mm outer diameter) that uses pneumatic actuation to inflate a silicone membrane. The membrane indents a Kirigami cut-out, maintaining a constant 6 mm contact area on the finger and enabling precise force application down to 0.01 N with increments as low as 0.01 N. Integrated fiber optic displacement and pressure sensors provide real-time measurement of the indentation of the skin and estimation of forces applied. A physical model and a neural network each estimated the applied forces, with the latter achieving higher accuracy. This novel tactile stimulator system addresses critical limitations of existing devices, enabling accurate, low-force tactile stimulation and measurement, while maintaining a compact size to investigate the neural processes governing tactile perception, including following a brain injury.

title: Robust Dynamic Control With Null-Space Compliance Using a Disturbance Observer for Surgical Robot
authors: Siqin Yang, Chunheng Lu, Junchen Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: In robotic surgery, secure and precise operation in collaborative human-robot tasks is critical, underscoring the need for robust dynamic control strategies tailored to such scenarios. To address the challenge of precise control under uncertain external disturbances, we propose a method utilizing null space control of a redundant robotic manipulator integrated with a nonlinear disturbance observer (DO). This approach extends the classical DO by decoupling the compensation of disturbances in the task space and the null space, ensuring task-space precision while preserving null space compliance. Experimental comparisons with existing methods demonstrate superior tracking accuracy and disturbance rejection under unknown external interactions. Finally, to simulate human-robot collaboration (HRC) in robot-assisted minimally invasive surgery scenarios, remote center of motion (RCM) constraint trajectory tracking experiments under external disturbances show that this method effectively balances motion constraint precision and system resilience against disturbances.

title: DGNMF: Dynamic Diffusion Graph Nonnegative Matrix Factorization
authors: Chenxi Tian, Wenming Wu, Licheng Jiao, Lingling Li, Xu Liu, Fang Liu, Wenping Ma, Shuyuan Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: In feature learning (FL), structural information shows advantages in retaining information and maintaining stability. Graph diffusion, a graph learning method that can focus on neighborhood structure and transmit information, has great research potential. In this study, a novel dynamic diffusion graph nonnegative matrix factorization (DGNMF) method is proposed, which uses a diffusion graph to improve the performance of FL and further enhances the effectiveness and stability of downstream classification tasks. DGNMF aims to mine and retain structural information more deeply in FL to build a more powerful and stable FL method. First, the model embeds graph learning into FL to obtain features containing structural information. Second, dynamic diffusion graph learning is used to mine deeper and more global structural information. Finally, we construct an updateable indicator matrix to enhance the discriminability of features. The classification experimental results of DGNMF on six databases demonstrate its advantages, verify its effectiveness and stability, and prove the importance of diffusion graph in improving FL.

title: Response of Boost Converters Under Fission-Spectrum Neutron and Gamma Radiation
authors: M. Niichel, T. Miller, B. Jowers, R. Cooper, S. Chatzidakis
abstract: Radiation testing of microelectronics remains essential for ensuring reliability in environments such as space and nuclear power systems. One critical component found in many systems is the metal oxide semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET). While work has been conducted on early MOSFET designs, there remains a gap in three key areas: testing modern power MOSFETs, collecting live test data, and evaluating components in combined radiation environments. Using modern components ensures that systems currently in use, both public and private, are better protected against radiation damage. Live monitoring allows observation of single-event effects and transient behavior not detectable through post-irradiation analysis. Additionally, conducting experiments in fission-spectrum neutron and gamma environments better replicates real-world conditions. While the literature addresses each of these topics separately, this work combines them by live-testing a boost converter circuit composed of a MAX1932 gate driver and a BSS119N N-type MOSFET under both neutron and gamma radiation. Testing was performed at the Purdue University Reactor Number One (PUR-1) and the Hopewell cobalt-60 irradiator, evaluating the circuit’s response to gamma total ionizing dose (TID) and thermal neutron-induced transients. Live monitoring displayed real-time transients, degradation, and recovery behavior. Results indicate gamma radiation plays a dominant role in circuit degradation. However, when considering the dose-dependent degradation, the combined radiation environment of PUR-1 induces failure with 34.8% less dose when compared to the Co-60. Suggesting neutron activation is contributing to secondary gamma dose or boron-10 (n,α) reaction damage. While Co-60 testing remains critical, thermal neutron facilities may offer a useful, cost-effective screening method for identifying gamma-sensitive components.

title: The Asymptotic Behaviour of Information Leakage Metrics
authors: Sophie Taylor, Praneeth Kumar Vippathalla, Justin P. Coon
abstract: Information leakage metrics quantify the amount of information about a private random variable X that is leaked through a correlated variable Y. They can be used to evaluate the privacy of a system in which an adversary, from whom X should be kept private, observes Y. Global information leakage metrics quantify the overall information leaked upon observing Y , whilst their pointwise counterparts define leakage as a function of the particular realisation Y = y, and thus can be viewed as random variables. We consider an adversary who observes many conditionally independent identically distributed realisations of Y. We formalise the essential asymptotic behaviour of an information leakage metric, considering in turn what this means for pointwise and global metrics. With these requirements in mind, we take an axiomatic approach to defining a set of pointwise leakage metrics, and a set of global leakage metrics constructed from them. The global set encompasses many known measures including mutual information, Sibson mutual information, Arimoto mutual information, maximal leakage, min entropy leakage, f-divergence metrics, and g-leakage. We prove that both sets follow the desired asymptotic behaviour. Finally, we derive composition theorems quantifying the rate of privacy degradation as an adversary is given access to many conditionally independent observations of Y. We find that, for pointwise and global metrics, privacy degrades exponentially with increasing observations, at a rate governed by the minimum Chernoff information. This extends the work of Wu et al. (2024), who derived this result for certain known metrics, including some from our global set.

title: POF+MADER: Trajectory Planner in Dynamic Environments with Improved Collision Avoidance
authors: Syed Izzat Ullah, José Baca, Pablo Rangel, Tianxing Chu, Carlos Rubio-Medrano
abstract: Trajectory planning in dynamic environments is crucial for safe and efficient navigation of UAVs, particularly in scenarios involving unknown dynamic obstacles. The Trajectory Planner in Multiagent and Dynamic Environments (MADER) algorithm has been successfully used for this purpose; however, it assumes perfect knowledge of the future trajectories of the dynamic obstacles. In practical scenarios, the future trajectory of the obstacles may not be known in advance. To address this limitation, we propose POF+MADER, an enhanced version that integrates a probabilistic obstacle filter with adaptive prediction horizons based on obstacle velocity. Our approach integrates a decentralized real-time Kalman Filter-based trajectory estimation with MADER’s planning core, eliminating the need for perfect a priori knowledge. We validate our approach through simulations with sensor noise (σ = 0.2 − 0.5m) to simulate realworld localization uncertainty, with performance benchmarked against the MADER, Robust-MADER, and Ego-Swarm planner baselines. To further demonstrate its practical applicability, we conducted real-world experiments on the Crazyflie UAV platform, comparing its performance to the original MADER algorithm. Results show a 38.75% collision rate reduction in simulation and a 25% reduction in real-world experiments, without a significant increase in average navigation time. Furthermore, even in the presence of real-time sensor-induced noise in obstacle position measurements, our approach consistently outperforms the baseline planners, demonstrating its robustness in trajectory planning under perception uncertainty.

title: A Social Network-Based Algorithm for Crowdsourcing Task Diffusion
authors: Yueran Yu, Bing Shi, Yan Lu, Jiashang Chen
abstract: With the widespread adoption of mobile smart devices and the Internet, a new paradigm known as Mobile Crowdsourcing (MCS) has emerged, which can provide efficient execution of large-scale tasks. However, it faces challenges due to an insufficient number of crowdsourcing participants. Existing works primarily focus on increasing participants’ willingness to engage, without addressing the issue of a limited user pool. In this paper, we incentivize users to diffuse the task within their social networks through financial rewards in the task duration, thereby recruiting additional social neighbors, expanding the user pool, and maximizing task completion. Specifically, we propose a Dynamic Reward Update and User Selection under the Diffusion (DRUUSD) algorithm for social network diffusion scenarios, given a budget constraint. The algorithm dynamically updates the task diffusion reward and task execution reward based on the current recruitment, while selecting users with the highest utility whose activated social neighbors can contribute more to task completion to diffuse tasks. Through multiple time steps of user selection and reward updates, the algorithm aims to recruit more participants and maximize task completion. We run extensive experiments to evaluate the proposed algorithm against four benchmark methods. The experimental results show that under the same total budget constraint, our algorithm can recruit more mobile users and achieve higher task completion compared to other benchmark algorithms.

title: Physio-BP: Physiologically-Guided Dual Radar System for Continuous Blood Pressure Estimation
authors: Zhenzhen Cao, Zhi Lu, Yang Hu, Yan Chen
abstract: Continuous blood pressure (BP) estimation remains a significant challenge in non-contact hemodynamic monitoring, where existing methods struggle to strike a balance between clinical accuracy and usability. We present Physio-BP, a physiologically-guided dual-radar system enabling calibration-free, continuous tracking of systolic (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) by integrating spatially resolved vascular dynamics. Unlike conventional single-waveform radar approaches, Physio-BP synchronously captures mechanical signals from the heart and pulse waves from the carotid artery, allowing precise measurement of pulse arrival time (PAT) and inter-beat intervals (IBI). To enhance signal quality, we introduce a novel joint signal selection algorithm that optimizes feature extraction across dual radars, effectively addressing the inherent signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) disparities between the chest and neck monitoring sites. To validate our system, an extensive dataset exceeding 50 hours was collected under diverse conditions, including different seasons, times of day, body postures, and radar devices, ensuring comprehensive coverage. Experimental results on the dataset confirm that Physio-BP enables continuous and precise SBP and DBP tracking, a capability not achieved by current baseline methods, thereby advancing non-contact sensing for hemodynamic monitoring.

title: Single-Feed Multifunctional Reflectarray Enabling Quad-Polarization Switching and Wide-Angle Scanning
authors: Guowei Li, Yuehe Ge, Ziheng Zhou, Zhechen Zhang, Jiade Yuan, Zhimeng Xu, Zhizhang David Chen
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter presents a reconfigurable reflectarray (RRA) capable of generating quad-polarization scanning beams with a fixed linearly polarized (LP) feed. Each element integrates four PIN diodes, providing 1-bit phase control for LP waves and 2-bit control for circular polarization (CP) waves. Using a beam-coding strategy inspired by Pancharatnam–Berry (PB) phase manipulation, the reflectarray can switch among LP, cross-LP, left-hand CP (LHCP), and right-hand CP (RHCP) states. Notably, distinct 1-bit and 2-bit phase compensations are employed for the LP and CP modes, respectively. A 16 × 16 Ku-band prototype was fabricated and experimentally characterized. Measurements demonstrate beam scanning up to ±60°, with peak gains exceeding 21 dBi and 3-dB gain bandwidths of 19.0% in LP mode, 19.5% in cross-LP mode, and 16.9% in both CP modes. Compared with prior works, the proposed design achieves wider bandwidth and quad-polarization reconfigurability with a structurally simpler single-feed configuration, making it attractive for polarization-diverse applications such as satellite communications, airborne platforms, and emerging wireless systems.

title: Adaptive Power Control Based on Interference Suppression for LEO Mega-constellation System
authors: Xu Ma, Haijun Zhang, Huan Peng, Yasenjiang Abudureheman, Shichao Jin, Zhihui Liu, Victor C.M. Leung
abstract: The low earth orbit (LEO) mega-constellation system is widely recognized for its potential to shape the evolution of mobile networks. Over the past several years, numerous LEO satellites have entered orbit to support networking capabilities and initiate operations. At present, LEO communication services mainly focus on Ka/Ku frequency band. Multiple systems, large scale, and limited frequency bands will bring great spectrum pressure to the geostationary orbit (GSO) system. An adaptive centralized power control method for mega-constellation satellite communication system is proposed, aiming to maximize the average capacity of LEO satellites subject to interference limit imposed on GSO system and the restriction of feeder link quality of service in the article. The adaptive centralized power control problem with constraints based on disturbance is modeled as a nonconvex nonlinear problem. Then, it is reconstituted into a number of nonlinear convex problems by the quadratic transformation. The adaptive centralized power control problem is addressed by optimizing iterative convex problems, achieving convergence at a stationary point and reaching the optimal solution. Finally, the performance of this algorithm is verified by simulation. Utilizing this method can reduce 8.62% of the total amount of interference from mega-constellation system while improving 0.49% of the average satellite capacity of mega-constellation system when the limit is equal to -140 dBw.

title: Asymptotic Phase Synthesis by Transport Maps -Part I Theory and Irrotational Linear Maps
authors: Piero Angeletti, Giovanni Toso, Raffaele Vitolo
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: The paper addresses the problem of phase synthesis of apertures with assigned amplitude. Applying the method of stationary phase it will be shown that the asymptotic solution satisfies a Monge–Ampère partial differential equation (PDE) with appropriate boundary value conditions. In agreement Chu’s energy mapping principle for reflector shaping, the Monge–Ampère PDE can solved identifying an irrotational transport map from the source aperture to the target beam. After a description of the general theory, the paper focuses on irrotational linear maps associated to quadratic phase solutions demonstrating the possibility of obtaining beams of the same shape of the source aperture, a result only observed for circular and square apertures. Exploiting a polar decomposition of the affine transformation matrix, it will be also demonstrated the possibility of rotating the beam, a result reported (to the best knowledge of the authors) for the first time. In a companion paper, the general problem of finding a solution to the Monge–Ampère PDE via irrotational transport maps will be addressed by mean of the theory of “optimal transport”.

title: Virtual-Real Integration in Unmanned Systems: Emerging Technologies, Applications, and Future Trends
authors: Xinyan Chen, Peng Hu, Zhongpan Zhu, Shumaila Javaid, Bin Cheng, Wei Li, Bin He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: The integration of virtual and real environments is driving transformative advancements in unmanned systems, offering new avenues for intelligent collaboration and adaptive deployment. This survey presents a comprehensive framework for virtual-real integration centered on unmanned systems, aiming to unify fragmented research efforts and guide future exploration. By adopting both global and local perspectives, the framework facilitates a cohesive understanding of system components, their interactions, and the structural relationships that underpin seamless coordination. This is further complemented by an application case study and a synthesis of the current limitations. To operationalize this framework, the paper systematically examines enabling technologies, existing constraints, and the collaborative architecture that supports dynamic interaction across physical and virtual domains. It further outlines the evolving trends and construction requirements of practical application scenarios. Finally, key challenges and emerging research opportunities are discussed to inform future work and encourage deeper exploration of this rapidly developing field.

title: TEXterity: Tactile Extrinsic deXterity_supp1-3644808.mp4
authors: Sangwoon Kim
abstract: We introduce a novel approach that combines tactile estimation and control for in-hand object manipulation. By integrating measurements from robot kinematics and an image-based tactile sensor, our framework estimates and tracks object pose while simultaneously generating motion plans in a receding horizon fashion to control the pose of a grasped object. This approach consists of a discrete pose estimator that tracks the most likely sequence of object poses in a coarsely discretized grid, and a continuous pose estimator-controller to refine the pose estimate and accurately manipulate the pose of the grasped object. Our method is tested on diverse objects and configurations, achieving desired manipulation objectives and outperforming single-shot methods in estimation accuracy. The proposed approach holds potential for tasks requiring precise manipulation and limited intrinsic in-hand dexterity under visual occlusion, laying the foundation for closed-loop behavior in applications such as regrasping, insertion, and tool use. Please see supplementary multimedia for videos of real-world demonstrations.

title: Graphene for Computing: Devices to Architectures
authors: Konstantinos Rallis, Georgios Kleitsiotis, Athanasios Passias, Evangelos Tsipas, Theodoros Panagiotis Chatzinikolaou, Karolos Tsakalos, Antonio Rubio, Sorin Cotofana, Ioannis Karafyllidis, Panagiotis Dimitrakis, Georgios Ch. Sirakoulis
abstract: Graphene has long been considered a revolutionary material for the field of electronics due to its remarkable set of electronic properties, standing as a very promising candidate for the post-silicon era. However, it is not just a silicon replacement, but rather an enabling material for different computing paradigms. In this work, we investigate the use of graphene in devices and circuits that are employed for the realisation of computing architectures and systems. More specifically, we focus on impactful key applications such as conventional computing and Boolean logic, high-radix computing and multi-valued logic, memristive devices and in-memory-computing, neuromorphic applications, quantum computing and photonics. Additionally, taking into consideration the state-of-the-art as well as the existing graphene-related challenges that are still present, this work attempts to assess the possible future development of graphene-based devices, circuits and systems in each of the aforementioned fields and to propose a coarse yet directive roadmap for the material's future in computing architectures.

title: Implementation of the UTAUT Model to Analyze Factors Influenching the Preservation of Local Language Using the CHATGPT Application
authors: Asep Saeppani, Irfan Fadil, E. Sulyati, Nurhasanah, Thesa Izfadllillah, Kuswara
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The ChatGPT is one of the applications that utilized artificial intelligence (AI) technology developed by OpenAI. This application is designed to recognize and generate text naturally, enabling a more human interaction between users and machines. The application, developed by OpenAI, was released on November 30, 2022. This initial version was a part of the development of a larger language model and had undergone various updates afterwards. This study was intended to analyze the factors influencing the use of the AI Chat GPT. UTAUT (Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology) model, which has been widely used to measure the level of users' acceptance of the application as well as the intensity in using the technology, was used to collect the data. Its variables, namely Performance Expectancy, Effort Expectancy, Social Influence, Facilitating Condition, Behavioral Intention, and Use Behavior, were expected to reveal the factors influencing the acceptance and the use of the AI Chat GPT application. The results of this study exhibited a significant relationship between the variable ‘Effort Expectancy’ with ‘Behavioral Intention’, ‘Facilitating Condition’ with ‘Use Behavior’, and ‘Social Influence with Behavioral Intention’ with each achievement value of EE- > UB with P values 0.046, FC- > UB with P values 0.043, and SI- > with a value of 0.082. Other variables did not show sufficient significance to reject the null hypothesis. Therefore, there was no sufficient evidence to support the hypothesized relationship.

title: Ultrawide Bandgap Corundum-Structured Iridium Gallium Oxide via Pulsed Laser Deposition
authors: A. Alquwayzani, T.K. Ng, B. Ooi
abstract: We synthesized crystalline corundum iridium gallium oxide via sequential binary oxide pulsed laser deposition using corundum gallium oxide as a buffer layer. Optical and electrical characterization revealed ultrawide bandgap and p-type conduction. The presented growth method enables the development of bipolar ultrawide bandgap optoelectronic devices.

title: Design and Verification of a Cage Antenna Based on Transient Metal Jet
authors: Yuhao Cai, Xuchao Pan, Yifan Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Addressing the stringent requirements of electromagnetic pulse weapon systems for ultra-wideband (UWB) and dynamically reconfigurable antennas, this paper proposes a cage antenna based on a transient metal jet. By integrating the shaped metal jets with the ultra-wideband advantages of cage antennas, it resolves the bandwidth limitations of traditional shaped-charge jet antennas. Simulation results show that at time 5 and time7 of jet formation, the antenna achieves ultra-wideband impedance matching with $\mathrm{S} 11\lt -10 \mathrm{~dB}$ in the $2-12 \mathrm{GHz}$ frequency band, with a peak gain of 8 dBi at 9 GHz. Although experimental measurements indicate gain attenuation due to machining errors and poor feed contact, the impedance matching performance remains significantly superior to traditional structures. This validates the enhancement effect of the dynamic reconfiguration scheme on UWB antenna performance.

title: Design of a Flexure-based Vibratome for Precision Tissue Cutting and Organ-Wide Imaging
authors: Ruiheng Xie, Jianwei Chen
abstract: Cutting tissues into slices with submicron precision is highly desired in sectioning-based organ-wide imaging. Here, we design a precision vibratome based on a paired double parallelogram (DP-DP) flexure. Microscopic imaging results prove that precision tissue cutting can be adapted to microscopic imaging with submicron precision.

title: A Solution Method for Target Near-Field Electromagnetic Scattering in an Infinite Medium
authors: Miaomiao Li, Yu Cheng, Jingli Guo, Jie Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Based on a previously proposed method that utilizes the equivalence principle to solve near-field scattering of objects in free space, this paper extends the approach by introducing approximations to simplify the computational burden, making it applicable to targets in an infinite medium. The feasibility of the method is validated through full-wave simulations on typical targets. This extension broadens its potential applications, providing a novel approach for the detection of near-ground targets, such as in vehicle-mounted radar systems.

title: Electromagnetic scattering from random rough spherical surfaces
authors: Jingyu Zhang, Peng Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this paper, a numerical Maxwell’s model is developed to investigate the radar cross section (RCS) from random rough spherical surfaces with Gaussian correlation functions. The RCS numerical simulations are illustrated at 5, 10, and 18 GHz, respectively. The results indicate that the RCS from rough spherical surfaces is larger than that of smooth spherical surfaces, and the influence of spherical surface roughness on RCS becomes more pronounced with increasing frequency. The simulation results offer deeper insights: as the operating frequency increases, the impact of surface roughness on RCS becomes non-negligible even for seemingly smooth spherical surfaces.

title: Integrating Quadriwave Lateral Shearing Interferometry and Multielectrode Array for Studying Cardiac Cell Function
authors: Jun Xie, Louis Hanqiang Gan, Hui Xie, Tong Ling
abstract: This study combines quantitative phase imaging and microelectrode array systems, using quadri-wave lateral shearing interferometry for real-time, label-free QPI and synchronized MEA at 10 kHz framerate. This integrated approach maps cellular mechanical deformation and extracellular electrical fields, offering a powerful platform for studying cellular functions and complex biological systems.

title: Real-Time Interactive Web-Based Dashboard for Researcher Network Visualization and Intellectual Property Reporting Using the Streamlit Framework
authors: Ahmad Mukhlis Jundulloh, Siti Ummi Masruroh, Esa Prakasa, Khodijah Hulliyah, Dewi Khairani, Nafdik Zaydan Raushanfikar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN) plays a vital role in managing and reporting intellectual property achievements and researcher collaboration networks. However, BRIN currently lacks an integrated and effective system for presenting these reports in real-time. Existing data is still managed through static spreadsheet tables, which are less interactive and do not adequately support comprehensive analysis or monitoring. This study focuses on designing and implementing a real-time web-based interactive dashboard for visualizing researcher networks and intellectual property reports. The dashboard leverages the Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) method for topic modeling and the ForceAtlas2 algorithm for network visualization. Developed using the Streamlit framework, the dashboard includes features such as bar charts, pie charts, network graphs, word clouds, and filtering options to enhance data accessibility and analysis. The system development follows the Rapid Application Development (RAD) methodology to ensure a structured and efficient process. The results demonstrate that the dashboard provides an innovative solution for BRIN by enabling dynamic visualization and analysis of researcher networks and intellectual property. This approach improves data transparency, accessibility, and usability for stakeholders while significantly enhancing the efficiency of reporting <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1, 1 \%}$</tex>. Furthermore, the system showcases the potential for broader applications of similar technologies in supporting data-driven decision-making.

title: The Role of Explainable AI in Knowledge Graph-Based Drug Repurposing: Bridging Trust and Discovery
authors: Marwa Mustafa, Firas Al-Doghman, Farookh Hussain, Mohamed Awadallah, Mohammed Ali
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Drug repurposing presents a cost-effective and accelerated alternative to traditional drug development. With Knowledge Graphs (KGs) structuring biomedical relationships and AI models performing predictive link analysis, Explainable AI (XAI) emerges as a critical enabler for interpretability, transparency, and trust. This paper explores the central role of XAI in enhancing the reliability, ethical transparency, and regulatory compliance of AI-powered, KG-based drug repurposing. One of XAI's most important contributions is its ability to explain why a drug is predicted to treat a particular disease - by revealing key features, paths, or biological relationships that support the prediction. This allows researchers and clinicians to verify the biological plausibility of AI-driven suggestions, which is crucial for preclinical validation and clinical decision-making. The paper also discusses key XAI techniques - including feature attribution, counterfactual analysis, and path reasoning - and the challenges and ethical implications tied to biomedical use cases.

title: Enhanced Receiver Operating Characteristics in Entanglement-Assisted LiDAR
authors: Georgios Papangelakis, Amr S. Helmy
abstract: We use fractional Fourier domain time-frequency correlations achieved through a nonlocal dispersion protocol to improve the receiver operating characteristics of Entanglement-Assisted LiDAR, with 10s of dBs of improved detection rates.

title: Simultaneous Decoupling of Temperature, Pressure, and Refractive Index via Tilted Fiber Bragg Grating Written by Femtosecond Laser
authors: Simeng Li, Yuting Zhou, Yuxuan Liu, Yansong Du, Feiyu Jiao, Qiang Jin, Yuyu Wang, Xun Guan
abstract: We present, for the first time, a single standalone Tilted Fiber Bragg Grating (TFBG) sensor capable of simultaneously measuring and decoupling temperature, refractive index (RI), and pressure. The sensor features a tilt angle of 10° and is fabricated using high-precision femtosecond laser. The experimental results confirm the high sensitivity of the TFBG sensor, achieving temperature, RI, and pressure sensitivities of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12.86 \text{pm} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 2.08 ~\text{nm} / \text{RIU}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-1.18 ~\text{dB} / \text{kPa}$</tex>, respectively, with corresponding low errors all below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.070^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 0.005917 \text{RIU}$</tex>, and 0.021 kPa. Featuring a standalone design that requires no coatings, splicing, or additional components, the single sensor offers simple fabrication and excellent precision, making it ideal for multi-parameter monitoring applications.

title: Analysis of RCS Scattering Characteristics of Wind Turbine
authors: Fugui Zhang, Sen Zhang, Pengju Chen, Jing Li, Yuan Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper primarily investigates the radar cross section (RCS) of wind turbine and its interference with radar systems. Using electromagnetic simulation software based on physical optics method, a wind turbine model composed of a mast and three blades is constructed to analyze its RCS variations in S, C, and X frequency bands under a 90° elevation angle. This study compares RCS characteristics of blades made of perfect electric conductor and glass fiber composite materials, finding that composite materials can reduce RCS peak values. Results show that RCS exhibits consistent variation trends with incident angles across all bands, with significantly higher RCS values observed in the S-band.

title: Research on The Optimal Configuration and Operation Mode Assessment of Integrated Energy Systems
authors: Jian Liu, Hongjun Cui
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: Under the background of the "dual carbon" goals and ongoing energy transition, the Integrated Energy System (IES) has emerged as a promising pathway to achieve multi-energy complementarity and high-efficiency utilization. By coordinating and optimally allocating electricity, heat, cooling, gas, and energy storage, IES can enhance energy efficiency, reduce operating costs, and mitigate carbon emissions. However, the inherent uncertainties in energy supply and demand, the complexity of multi-energy coupling, and the trade-offs among economic, energy, and environmental objectives pose significant challenges to system optimization. To address these issues, this study develops a multi-attribute optimization model to systematically evaluate the performance of IES under different operation modes. The results provide insights into the economic, energy, and environmental impacts of various operation strategies, offering theoretical guidance and practical reference for the planning and optimization of low-carbon IES.

title: Optimization and analysis of energy storage capacity for high percentage wind power system based on CPLEX
authors: Qi Wang, Penghui Xi, Zheng Wang, Shaoyi Ren, Jun Wu, Rui Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: To address the issue of wind power consumption and power generation economics in high percentage wind power electric systems, this paper analyzes the energy storage capacity configuration and cost of this system based on CPLEX. The method takes a new energy base as the research object, and through the CPLEX optimization solver and the optimal power supply cost model, it takes into account the thermal power operation cost, the carbon capture cost, the wind power operation and maintenance cost, the wind energy loss cost, the load loss cost, and the energy storage construction cost, allocates a reasonable capacity of the energy storage device to the system, and analyzes the power supply economy before and after its allocation. Through comparative analysis, the model can configure the optimal energy storage capacity, effectively deal with wind power consumption, and optimize the total cost of power generation of system to improve the stability and economy.

title: Robust Verification Methodology for Radar-Based Rear Safety Automotive Functions
authors: Tanmay Lata, Shradha Veeranna Hulamani, Milind Anant Kulkarni, Philipp Baust, Tobias Paust
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: Validating radar-based rear safety functions such as Blind Spot Detection (BSD), Occupant Safe Exit (OSE), etc. in real-world conditions poses numerous challenges for e.g. ghost objects, mirror objects and radar sensor behavior being influenced by differing traffic densities and reflective surfaces across urban and highway environments and subject to variation across projects and regional requirements. A critical obstacle encountered during real-world testing is the establishment of a reliable ground truth and the formulation of a robust test strategy through which both validation and verification of algorithm performance can be ensured. In this paper, methods are explored for leveraging radar data in combination with labeled object information to enable the development of more resilient test cases. Additionally, a human-in-the-loop verification mechanism is proposed to refine test results, thereby introducing a second layer of validation

title: Design of an X-Band Quadrupler Chip with High Fundamental Suppression Based on CMOS Process
authors: Luqi Tu, Zezheng Li, Dongwei Pang, Shiwei Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of wireless communication technologies, the demand for higher frequency bands has increased, placing greater requirements on frequency multiplication techniques. Conventional frequency multiplier systems based on discrete components suffer from low integration, large size, and high cost. On-chip frequency multipliers, however, often face challenges such as complex circuit designs, low multiplied output power, poor harmonic suppression, and limited operational stability. To address these issues, this paper proposes an X-band quadrupler circuit, chip, and implementation method based on CMOS process. The design achieves high fundamental suppression and substantial quadrupled output power on a silicon-based chip. The circuit features a simple structure, strong scalability, compact chip area, and low power consumption, offering significant application potential and research value.

title: Integrated, Heat Resistant, Glass Waveguides with 0.01 \text{dB}/\text{cm}$ Bend Loss for $50-\mu \mathrm{m}$ Pitch Conversion in High-Density Optical Interconnects
authors: Jorge A. Holguín-Lerma, Lars Brusberg, Matthew Dejneka, Lucas Yeary, Betsy J. Johnson, Chad C. Terwilliger, Charisse Spier, Jonathan E. Walter, Qiumei Bian, Katerina Rousseva
abstract: We demonstrate record low bend loss <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0.01 ~\text{dB} / \text{cm}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}>6 ~\text{mm}, \lambda=1310 ~\text{nm}$</tex>) ion-exchanged glass waveguides for high-density fiber-to-chip pitch conversion (from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$250 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex>) in optimized glass with ultra-low ion diffusivity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 5 \mathrm{E}-22 ~\mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>) resulting in an estimated heat-resistant lifetime of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>5$</tex> years at 110° C for high-performance co-packaged optics (CPO) applications, having <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<0.3 ~\text{dB}$</tex> fiber coupling loss per facet, and 0.04 dB/cm propagation loss.

title: Acoustic Signal Encryption Using Binary Polarization States of Light Beam
authors: Allarakha Shikder, Sudheesh K. Rajput, Naveen K. Nishchal, Osamu Matoba, Yasuhiro Awatsuji
abstract: In this study, we present an optical audio encryption technique that uses the polarization property of light. Unlike conventional digital techniques, the proposed method utilizes physical keys and other features of optical beam, making it highly secure and fast.

title: Design of a Protocol for Biomechanical Analysis of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Patients: an Exoskeleton-Based Study
authors: Raffaella Mancino, Aldo Smaldone, Mariarosaria Meola, Marco Caianiello, Raffaele Dubbioso, Giovanni Berselli, Fanny Ficuciello
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: As the global population ages, the incidence of neurodegenerative diseases such as Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is increasing. With no cure and unpredictable course, ALS presents two major unmet challenges: the need for effective treatment strategies and objective, quantitative methods to assess disease progression. This study addresses these challenges by designing and validating an experimental protocol for collecting key biomechanical parameters, which facilitates a standardized evaluation of ALS. The protocol involves acquiring data from both healthy and ALS subjects to refine patient assessment and evaluate the advantages of exoskeleton use. The protocol was validated using a passive upper limb exoskeleton on five healthy subjects and two ALS patients with varying severities of the Flail Arm phenotype. Analysis of key performance indicators, extracted from electromyographic signals and inertial measurement unit during selected tasks, showed a reduction in the average Root Mean Square and integrated EMG values for healthy subjects, which confirms the effectiveness of the protocol in evaluating the benefits of the exoskeleton. In ALS patients, not only were similar benefits seen, but differences between the different stages of the disease were also highlighted. The results obtained provided the basis for further improvements in some protocol specifications.

title: Effect of Ground Plane Size on the Radiation Pattern of Dielectric Resonator Antenna
authors: Shaofeng Bi, Kwok Wa Leung, Bohao Yu, Liwen Huang, Guosheng Su
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The ground plane plays a crucial role in antenna performance. Variations in ground plane size can significantly alter the radiation pattern, affecting parameters such as gain, beamwidth, and axial ratio. This can pose challenges, for instance, in circularly polarized antenna arrays where individual elements may exhibit excellent circular polarization on a small ground plane but degrade when integrated into a larger array. In this paper, we use the dielectric resonator antenna (DRA) as an example to propose a method that renders the antenna insensitive to ground plane size variations. This approach is effective for both linearly polarized and circularly polarized antennas, with potential applications in array design and automotive antennas.

title: Dynamic Traffic Status Classification and Monitoring in Indian Metro Cities Using Edge-AI Computation
authors: Syed Thouheed Ahmed, Kore Ranga Akshaya, Harini Vattikuti, L Sai Pavan Preetham, Rahul Kumar Dutta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: This study unveils a real-time traffic analysis system employing the YOLO object detection algorithm to monitor and categorize traffic conditions from live video streams. The core aim is to identify and track vehicles in real time while classifying road segments based on traffic dynamics. A detailed, annotated dataset of traffic videos was compiled to train the YOLO model, ensuring robust performance. Roads are segmented into three zones to depict traffic flow: Red Zone, marking heavy congestion with immobile or crawling vehicles; Orange Zone, indicating moderate congestion with sluggish movement; and Blue Zone, representing smooth traffic with negligible delays. By evaluating vehicle speeds and motion patterns, the system dynamically labels road sections, enabling the detection of traffic bottlenecks and supporting efficient urban traffic management. This work showcases the transformative potential of deep learning and computer vision for smart city infrastructure.

title: Coherent Control of Ultrafast Currents for Terahertz Magnetic Fields
authors: Kamalesh Jana, Yonghao Mi, Shima G. Mirzaei, Dong Hyuk Ko, Shawn Sederberg, P. B. Corkum
abstract: We investigate ultrafast THz magnetic field generation using spatially structured bichromatic femtosecond laser pulses. These pulses induce and control transient currents in GaAs, producing THz magnetic fields with rapid rise times. Such ultrafast magnetic fields have potential applications in controlling magnetic materials, imaging, and spintronics.

title: Energy Consumption and Anti-Interference DualObjective UAV Path Planning Algorithm Based on A*
authors: Zhenlei Sun, Longquan Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) energy consumption determines operational range, so mainstream path planning algorithms focus on shortest paths. Yet UAVs face growing electromagnetic interference during flight, risking navigation failure or loss of control. To address the issue that traditional algorithms fail to consider energy consumption and anti-Interference, an A*-based dual-objective UAV path planning algorithm is proposed. First, key factors of UAV energy consumption and interference are analyzed, and corresponding calculation models are built. Second, energy and interference penalties are added to the traditional $A^{*}$ s cost and heuristic functions to form a dual-objective optimization function. Finally, MATLAB simulations compare the proposed algorithm with traditional A*. Results show it effectively balances UAV energy consumption and anti-interference capabilities.

title: Controller Area Network (CAN) Sniffing and Mobile App Based Control of Vehicular Subsystems
authors: Steven J Alappat, Sai Pranav, Parag Jose C, Yong Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: Modern vehicles use Controller Area Network instead of the traditional wire to wire connections for enabling simultaneous data exchange among all the electronic control units (ECU’s). CAN lacks inherent security features making it susceptible to attacks like spoofing and unwanted command injections. This project makes a low budget and scalable system that helps in CAN sniffing and enabling remote control of a vehicle through a mobile application. A CAN sniffing tool is used to map the data form the car. An Arduino board, wifi shield, mcp2515 and an On-Board Diagnostics tool (OBD II) are connected in a setup in order to inject the messages into the car. The connections support both monitoring and message injection allowing users to control in vehicular functions. The proposed setup offers a tool for diagnosing, testing and vehicular controlling by highlighting cybersecurity implications in automotive networks.

title: Implementation of Support Vector Machine and Ensemble Random Forest Methods With Voting Classifier for Student Learning Style Classification “(Case Study : MAN 3 Padang Lawas)”
authors: Esa Adnin Safara Ersanemora Siregar, Siti Ummi Masruroh, Viva Arifin, Husni Teja Sukmana, Avinda Nur Azizah, Doni Febrian
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Learning style is an important factor that influences the effectiveness of the learning process, because each student has unique preferences in receiving and understanding information. This study aims to classify students' learning styles at MAN 3 Padang Lawas using a combination of Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Ensemble Random Forest methods with a Voting Classifier approach. The CRISP-DM method was used as the research framework, covering the stages of business understanding, data understanding, data preparation, modeling, and evaluation. Data were collected through a VAKbased questionnaire (Visual, Auditory, Kinesthetic) completed by 224 students. SVM was used to detect optimal margin-based patterns, while Random Forest improved accuracy through a combination of several decision trees. The prediction results of both models were combined using a Voting Classifier to maximize performance. Evaluation using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score metrics showed that the combination of SVM and Random Forest with Voting Classifier produced higher accuracy than either method alone. These findings are expected to help teachers adjust learning strategies according to student needs, thereby improving learning effectiveness at MAN 3 Padang Lawas.

title: Recursive Digital Predistortion With Data-Driven Behavioral Modeling
authors: Pengle Wen, Xiong Chen, Kaiming Ding, Bin He
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This work proposes a digital predistortion (DPD) approach in which the power amplifier (PA) is represented by a memory polynomial model identified from input–output data, and its inverse is derived analytically in a recursive manner to compensate for the nonlinearity of the PA system. A closed-form memory polynomial model of the PA is derived from input–output data, accurately representing the PA system function and overcoming the limitations of conventional methods that rely on linear approximations of the PA system. In addition, a recursive formulation is employed to perform precise predistortion at each sample, effectively addressing the problem arising from the possible non-existence of a universal inverse of the PA system function. The simulation results confirm that the proposed DPD scheme achieves orders-of-magnitude reductions in amplitude and phase errors and achieves a maximum ACLR improvement of 3.26 dBc, demonstrating better performance and robustness across different input amplitude ranges.

title: Porcine Hind Leg X-Ray Segmentation Network Based on Two-Channel Multiscale Feature Enhancement
authors: Xueyong Li, Chen Cai, Lei Cai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: The accuracy of automated hind leg bone segmentation in swine slaughtering and processing is currently insufficient. Several challenges contribute to this issue, including the small grayscale difference between the bone marrow cavity and soft tissues in X-ray images, as well as blurred joint edges resulting from insufficient cartilage calcification. These factors lead to low deboning efficiency and a high rate of misjudgment in the bone marrow region, which directly impacts the standardization of meat quality grading and the profitability of industrial production. In response to the previously described challenges, this work presents a segmentation network for X-ray images of porcine hind legs, which employs a dualchannel architecture for multi-scale feature enhancement. The framework of this network consists of two main modules working in tandem: an image edge texture feature enhancement module and a global information feature fusion module. By utilizing a combination of local texture enhancement and an attention mechanism, this first module substantially improves edge definition in areas with poor contrast. Subsequently, the designed global information feature fusion module integrates the preliminary segmentation results with the edge-enhanced features to consolidate global image contextual information. By integrating multi-scale feature fusion with attention mechanisms, the network is able to generate consistent and highly accurate segmentation paths for porcine hind leg bones in X-ray images. Quantitative analysis demonstrates that, in comparison to LinkNet and DeepLabV3Plus, the proposed approach enhances the F1 Score (FS) by 4.5 % and 1.08 %, and Accuracy (Acc) by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 1 3 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 7 8 \%}$</tex>, effectively boosting both segmentation accuracy and stability.

title: Testing the Phasor Measurement Unit Using Archival Data
authors: David Laverty, Harold Kirkham
abstract: The data from phasor measurement units is proving to be of value in power system planning and operation. Verifying their performance is rendered unnecessarily challenging by the way the relevant documentary standard is written. Although much of the content of the latest standard describes testing (the words "test" or "testing" occur more than 160 times) a good deal of the material is either irrelevant or confusing. The PMU is a representational measurement, and for this kind of measurement, it is appropriate to test performance (but it is not appropriate to specify a measurement method, as the standard does). This paper proposes a testing solution based on archiving real world data. It would permit testing of both existing and proposed equipment, with both "synthetic" waveforms and real-world recordings. Cooperation between users and developers would be encouraged, and is expected to lead to further advances in the field of synchronized measurement.

title: Vision Based Pothole Detection In Challenging Scenario
authors: Suresha R, Harshitha K M, Rachana, Nirmitha S K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: On Indian roads, potholes are a serious hazard that frequently results in accidents and vehicle damage, underscoring the necessity for precise, real-time detection systems. Problems like small pothole sizes, inconsistent weather and lighting, and several potholes close together cause existing solutions to frequently fail. To overcome these obstacles, this study suggests a YOLOv11-based strategy, more especially the YOLO11n variant. Real-world complexities such as tiny, overlapping potholes, shifting light levels in the morning, evening, and night, and unfavourable weather conditions like rain were all included in the real-time dataset used to train the model. By combining attention-enhanced, anchor-free detection with multi-scale feature extraction, YOLO11n allows for accurate pothole localization in a variety of situations. With 96.6% mAP@50, 93.5% precision, and 90.6% recall, the model produced exceptional results, proving its usefulness for real-time applications. this research reduces vehicle damage by early detection of road hazards and enhances road safety by pothole detection on above challenging scenario.

title: A Blockchain-Based Framework for Evaluating User Identity Trustworthiness in Real Estate
authors: Mohanad A. Almalki, Abdullah J. Abualhamayl, Abdulmajeed A. Alyoubi, Yasir D. Alyoubi, Firas Al-Doghman, Farookh Khadeer Hussain
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Reliable identity verification is a cornerstone of secure digital transactions, particularly in the real estate sector where ownership authenticity is essential. Traditional systems that rely on centralised authorities often face challenges related to inefficiency, fraud risk, and lack of transparency. Blockchain technology offers a decentralised, tamper-resistant alternative that can enhance trust in identity systems. This paper presents a blockchain-based framework for evaluating user identity trustworthiness through a weighted trust score algorithm based on document assurance levels, inspired by governmental standards. The main contributions include the design of a documentweighted trust algorithm, deployment on Ethereum's Sepolia testnet where smart contracts manage user registration and trust score computation based on uploaded documents, as well as a detailed performance analysis focused on gas usage, transaction times, and scoring validity.

title: A Tunable Frequency W-Band RF Unit for Spaceborne Applications
authors: Xuzhuang Zhi, Wenxi Chen, Xiangyang Chen, Shanyu Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: This study presents a satellite-borne, frequencyagile W-band radio frequency ($R F$) unit, featuring a modular architecture with independent sampling, comprising an up/down conversion assembly and a microwave front-end. The up/down conversion assembly adopts a dual-frequency mixing scheme to enable frequency translation among the L -, X -, and W -bands. The microwave front-end integrates a power amplifier, a low-noise amplifier, and cavity filters, providing signal amplification and out-of-band suppression. The proposed RF unit achieves an output power of 35.1 dBm, an out-of-band suppression of 55 dB, and an image-frequency suppression of 25 dB, with a total mass of 3 kg and a power consumption of 62 W. Designed for spaceborne applications, the unit meets stringent technical specifications while ensuring environmental adaptability and reliable, stable operation in orbit.

title: Implementation of PytoVHDL Framework for Automatic Code Transliteration and Acceleration of FPGA-based SoC Design
authors: Yevhenii Holopotyliuk, Vladyslav Romashchenko, Michael Brutscheck
abstract: The development of multiple projects and hardware prototypes frequently requires collaboration between software and hardware teams, who are focused on a certain programming languages. This can result in communication challenges during sharing ideas and solutions. It leads to integration difficulties by the fundamentally distinct nature of the programming languages. Also, knowledge gaps may arise, increasing the risk of code failures and extending of development timelines. In such scenarios, teams often need specialists in both software and hardware description languages. In case, if it can be complicated, developers and researchers have created the frameworks such as MyHDL, HDPython, AmaranthHDL etc. Using the Python syntax and decorators on the top-layer, the frameworks can convert Python source-code into VHDL instructions, initiating further FPGA-Prototyping. In parallel, recent achievements in Large Language Models (LLMs) like CodeT5, CodeBERT have introduced new functionality for automating code transliteration tasks. The mentioned models are pretrained by Go, Java, PHP and Python languages, which are quite common for software developers. However, the support of hardware languages such as VHDL or Verilog needs additional investigations. Due to the following fact, the proposed investigations, represent an investigation and realisation of PytoVHDL framework. Inspiring by MyHDL, AI-HDLCoder, the framework aims to bridge the gap between Python and VHDL programmers. Making numerous experiments with middle layer interface, the proposed work shows conversion results for systems that include combination logic or can be sufficient for digital signal processing.

title: MXene Aerogel-Filled Honeycomb Structures for Broadband Absorption
authors: Bowen Tan, Denglin Wang, Shuaijie Liu, Nannan Chen, Le Cao, Xuqing Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This study presents the preparation and performance evaluation of aramid/nanocellulose-MXene aerogel-filled honeycomb absorbers for enhanced microwave absorption. Compared to traditional honeycomb absorbers with conventional fillers, the proposed structure achieves a reflection loss (RL) of -38.37 dB and an effective absorption bandwidth (EAB) of 11.8 GHz. These results demonstrate the excellent broadband absorption capability of the designed absorber. Furthermore, this study provides a valuable design paradigm for broadband absorption materials and contributes to the advancement of research and development in broadband honeycomb absorbers.

title: Construction and Application of Offline Testing Environment for Power Dispatching System
authors: Zhen Yan, Jun Hu, Kun Ji, Minyu Chen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: This article introduces the offline environment construction and testing of the power grid dispatch system, and explains the importance of module dependencies and indirect effects. The overall system testing ensures seamless integration and collaborative work of subsystems, modules, and components, covering functional testing, performance testing, reliability testing, stability testing, and upgrade rollback testing. The testing methods include manual testing and automated testing, using various testing tools such as interface testing frameworks, avalanche testing tools, fault injection tools, etc. Using core functional modules such as basic platform, FES, and SCADA as test cases, to guide the effective implementation of offline environment testing work.

title: Design of a three-dimensional nonorthogonal light field array based on Dammann gratings and Fresnel phase shifts
authors: Yang Li, Yahui Su
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Dammann gratings are typical binary phase diffractive optical elements with broad application prospects in optical communications and laser parallel processing. In this paper, we propose a design method for three-dimensional nonorthogonal array light fields based on a Dammann grating splitter. Orthogonal and non-orthogonal arrays are first constructed by rotating and superimposing one-dimensional Dammann grating phase patterns. Subsequently, a Fresnel phase modulation is introduced to realize axial focal-plane shifting. By further combining two sets of holographic patterns through strip-segmentation integration and applying Debye vector diffraction theory for numerical simulations, a three-dimensional nonorthogonal Dammann array distribution is generated within a single coordinate system. This approach provides a flexible way to construct multilayer two-dimensional light field distributions in three-dimensional space, showing potential applications in high-speed parallel femtosecond laser micro-nano fabrication, three-dimensional optical field control, and optical micromanipulation.

title: Monolithic GaSb-Based Waveguides for PICs at Mid-Wave Infrared Wavelengths
authors: Md Saiful Islam Sumon, Sk Shafaat Saud Nikor, Arnob Ghosh, Grayson Ullman, G Sai Sri Prabhat, Imad I. Faruque, Sarvagya Dwivedi, Shamsul Arafin
abstract: We present a monolithically integrable GaSb-based passive photonic platform for short- to mid-infrared applications. The fabricated waveguides exhibit smooth, vertical sidewalls with low-loss potential, establishing a promising foundation for fully integrated GaSb-based photonic circuits in the MWIR regime.
