title: Spatiotemporal Attention with Conditional Feature Modulation for Satellite-Based Solar Irradiance Prediction
authors: Hanwool Kim, Junhan Jeon, Jieun Wie, Jongmin Yeom, Gwangsu Kim
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Accurate short-term solar irradiance forecasting is critical for grid stability, yet existing deep learning models often struggle to capture complex dynamics over longer horizons. In this paper, we propose the Attention-Contextual U-Net (AC U-Net), a new architecture for multi-step solar irradiance map prediction using GK-2A satellite imagery over the Korean Peninsula. The proposed model enhances a standard U-Net by integrating spatiotemporal attention and a Feature-wise Linear Modulation (FiLM) layer. This layer injects high-level contextual information directly into the model’s bottleneck, allowing for dynamic feature adaptation. Experiments demonstrate that AC U-Net outperforms not only the persistence baseline but also deep learning-based competitors such as ConvLSTM and HRNet. Our work demonstrates that conditioning on contextual features is a powerful strategy for improving long-range forecasting accuracy.

title: All-Metal Ka-Band Dual-CP Antenna With Wide-Band and Low-Profile Characteristics for High-Speed Aircraft Applications
authors: Ming Cheng, Xiao Ma
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times 2$</tex-math></inline-formula> Ka-band dual-circularly-polarized antenna for high-speed aircraft applications is proposed. It simultaneously achieves a broadband and a low profile in an all-metal structure. The antenna comprises three key components: (1) a compact dual-linearly-polarized power divider for broadband impedance matching and a stable <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula> or <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$-180^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula> phase difference, (2) differential phase shifters to achieve a wideband <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$90^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula> phase difference and a low profile, and (3) quadruple-ridged horns for high aperture efficiency and a further reduced profile. The antenna features an overall low profile of only 2.9 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$ \lambda _{0}$</tex-math></inline-formula> (free-space wavelength at the center frequency). Simulated and measured results show that the antenna achieves a 3-dB gain bandwidth of 29.6%. Within this bandwidth, the reflection coefficients of both ports are below <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$-10$</tex-math></inline-formula> dB; the port isolation exceeds 20dB; the axial ratio (AR) is below 1.9dB; the peak gain reaches 14.2 dBic; and the peak aperture efficiency is 49%.

title: Open-Circuit Fault Diagnosis Method for Dual Three-Phase PMSM Drives Based on Common and Distinctive Features of Improved Fault Indices
authors: Lei Chen, Min Chen, Bodong Li, Xinnan Sun, Feng Jiang
abstract: Fault diagnosis is crucial for ensuring fault-tolerant control in multiphase motors, necessitating an accurate, simple, and robust fault diagnosis technique. However, current multiphase fault diagnosis methods face several challenges, such as susceptibility to interference in fault indices, difficulty in diagnosing multiple open-circuit faults (OCFs), high computational complexity, and lack of universality. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a robust, easy-to-implement, and broadly applicable multiphase diagnostic scheme. The proposed algorithm first identifies the faulty phase, then pinpoints the faulty switch within the faulty phase, and finally diagnoses the open-phase faults (OPFs). To suppress misdiagnosis caused by interference, a virtual dc component is introduced to improve the calculation of fault indices, and indices for the same fault types are unified and normalized. Subsequent normalization attenuates the influence of speed and load variations. By extracting the commonalities and differences of the improved fault indices across various OCFs, newly binary fault indices for OCFs are derived from common features to identify the faulty phase, and newly binary fault indices for open-switch faults (OSFs) and OPFs are derived from distinctive features to locate the faulty switch and diagnose OPF. The proposed approach significantly reduces computational burden while enabling the identification of multiple open-circuit faults. Experimental results under different nonideal conditions verify the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method.

title: Optimizing RSU Deployment in VANETs: A Branch-and-Benders Decomposition Approach Considering Information Timeliness Requirements
authors: Bingjie Liang, Xinyue Xu, Wenqi Lu, Bin Ran
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs) hold significant potential for enhancing road safety and traffic efficiency. The performance of VANETs heavily relies on the strategic deployment of roadside units (RSUs), which gather and disseminate critical information. A key challenge is that different types of information possess varying timeliness requirements, rendering delayed information ineffective. However, this crucial aspect has not been sufficiently addressed in the existing RSU deployment literature. To bridge this gap, we first classify operational scenarios based on discretized traffic flows and information types, analyzing their corresponding transmission time constraints. We then formulate an RSU deployment model that explicitly incorporates these heterogeneous timeliness requirements. To solve this complex problem, we develop a Branch-and-Benders decomposition (BBD) algorithm, which partitions the problem into a master problem for determining RSU locations and multiple subproblems for allocating vehicle communication demands in each scenario. The master problem is solved using a branch-and-cut procedure. Upon finding an integer feasible solution, the dual subproblems are solved to generate optimality and feasibility cuts that are dynamically added to the master problem. Furthermore, we introduce valid inequalities to accelerate convergence. Numerical experiments demonstrate that the proposed BBD algorithm can efficiently generate provably high-quality solutions.

title: Separating Individual Respiration From Entangled WiFi Signals for Multi-User Authentication
authors: Yao Wang, An He, Haibin Zhang, Tao Gu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: User authentication is a critical component of IoT environments, serving as the security bridge between users and devices to safeguard data transmission and prevent unauthorized access. While WiFi-based authentication via motion recognition has shown potential in single-user scenarios, its effectiveness diminishes significantly in multi-user environments. Detecting subtle movements, such as breathing, from multiple users simultaneously poses a significant challenge, pushing the capabilities of current WiFi authentication systems to their limits. In this paper, we present BreathEye, a multi-user authentication system that leverages only a pair of commercial WiFi devices to detect and authenticate the subtle respiratory patterns of multiple individuals simultaneously. The core insight of our approach lies in exploiting the inherent variability in individual breathing patterns, which manifest in short-term energy fluctuations and long-term dependencies within the breathing signals. To this end, we propose a dual-attention fusion mechanism that captures these subtle differences, enabling the effective disentanglement of individual breathing signals from overlapping multi-user data. To further enhance practicality, BreathEye incorporates a few-shot learning framework to minimize user registration time and reduce system training overhead by analyzing independent breathing signals for authentication. Extensive experiments demonstrate that BreathEye achieves authentication accuracies of over 99%, 92%, and 87% in single-, two-, and three-user scenarios, respectively, highlighting the system's effectiveness.

title: Hydra: Support Dynamic BFT with Weaker Assumptions and Explicit Request Handling
authors: Xuyang Liu, Zijian Zhang, Zhen Li, Haibo Sun, Meng Li, Jing Sun, Jiamou Liu, Yong Liu, Lei Xu, Jincheng An, Qi Sun, Liang Huang, Mauro Conti, Liehuang Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: This paper presents Hydra, a dynamic BFT protocol that allows replicas to join and leave the system dynamically. It addresses the limitations of traditional static BFTs in managing membership changes and can be used to simplify the implementation of many features in modern blockchain applications. Hydra relies on weaker assumptions to achieve standard properties compared to the existing solution Dyno and introduces a configuration auto-transition protocol to ensure liveness. Through temporary configurations and explicitly defined replica responsibilities for request handling, Hydra pipelines membership requests alongside regular requests and realizes clarity, achieving a more efficient and smoother configuration transitions. It also employs a non-blocking configuration discovery mechanism, enabling new replicas to participate in consensus quickly. We formally prove Hydra's correctness under the dynamic BFT model. Experimental results demonstrate Hydra's ability to maintain throughput fluctuations within 5% during various replica join and leave scenarios, outperforming Dyno and existing BFT system supporting reconfiguration in both stability and efficiency. Hydra effectively manages scenarios that Dyno circumvents with stronger assumptions and quickly restores throughput to normal levels.

title: MASCLoc: Multi-modal Adaptation with Signal Consistency for Localization
authors: Eric Hsueh-Chan Lu, Yu-Jung Chen
abstract: With the rapid development of smart buildings and Internet of Things (IoT) applications, indoor positioning technology plays an essential role in smart environments. However, wireless fingerprinting often suffers from signal distribution shifts caused by dynamic changes and device heterogeneity in real-world settings, which significantly affects localization accuracy and generalization ability, limiting its practical use. To address the challenge of adapting to new environments without the need for additional data labeling, this study proposes MASCLoc (Multimodal Adaptation with Signal Consistency for Localization), an innovative indoor localization framework based on wireless fingerprinting that combines multi-modal feature representation and regression-based domain adaptation. MASCLoc integrates multiple modalities, including received signal strength (RSS) vectors, relative fingerprint gradients (RFG), and radio maps, and employs a spatial embedding strategy to enhance cross-modal semantic integration. It further extends the adversarial learning framework by incorporating cosine similarity and Pearson correlation losses. This design not only improves feature alignment across domains but also ensures greater physical consistency and stability in the predicted results. Experiments conducted on a longterm, cross-month dataset validate MASCLoc’s performance under various data scales and environmental changes. Results show that MASCLoc maintains an average localization error (ALE) below 3 meters, demonstrating strong adaptability and generalization capability. Overall, this research presents a highly practical unsupervised indoor localization solution that reduces labeling costs and supports efficient long-term deployment in real-world applications.

title: Research on the Power-Handling Capability of Latching Non-reciprocal Ferrite Phase Shifters
authors: Xianggang Hu, Jiancang Su, Yue Ying, Mei Li, Rui Li, Jie Cheng, Shaotong Wu, Min Guo, Haichuan Zhang, Qi Wang, Fengzi Liu
abstract: The ferrite phase shifter (FPS) is a microwave device that utilizes the gyromagnetic properties of ferrite materials to achieve phase shift. It offers advantages such as fast switching speed, low insertion loss, and high reliability, making it widely used in phased array antenna systems. However, the power handling capability of Ku-band FPSs remains inadequate, limiting their application in high-power microwave phased array systems. Based on the theory of ferrite gyromagnetism and the structure of the latching non-reciprocal FPS, this paper derives a transcendental equation for the phase constant of the device. Expressions for the internal field distribution and power distribution are obtained. The interrelationships among phase-shifting efficiency, power handling capability, and various structural parameters are analyzed, leading to recommended value ranges for the structural parameters of high-power FPSs, thereby providing a theoretical foundation for phase shifter design. The ferrite material is another critical factor influencing the power handling capability. The high-power quality factor of the ferrite material is introduced, serving as a criterion for material selection. On this basis, the design, optimization, and development of a latching non-reciprocal double-toroid FPS have been completed. Through appropriate selection of structural parameters, improvement of ferrite material properties, and enhanced integration techniques, the power handling capability of the Ku-band FPS has been increased to over 500 kW, with an insertion loss of less than 1.3 dB and a maximum differential phase shift of approximately 400°.

title: Active RIS-Aided Anti-Jamming Wireless Communications: A Stackelberg Game Perspective
authors: Xiao Tang, Zhen Ma, Bin Li, Cong Li, Qinghe Du, Dusit Niyato, Zhu Han
abstract: The pervasive threat of jamming attacks, particularly from adaptive jammers capable of optimizing their strategies, poses a significant challenge to the security and reliability of wireless communications. This paper addresses this issue by investigating anti-jamming communications empowered by an active reconfigurable intelligent surface. The strategic interaction between the legitimate system and the adaptive jammer is modeled as a Stackelberg game, where the legitimate user, acting as the leader, proactively designs its strategy while anticipating the jammer’s optimal response. We prove the existence of the Stackelberg equilibrium and derive it using a backward induction method. Particularly, the jammer’s optimal strategy is embedded into the leader’s problem, resulting in a bi-level optimization that jointly considers legitimate transmit power, transmit/receive beamformers, and active reflection. We tackle this complex, non-convex problem by using a block coordinate descent framework, wherein subproblems are iteratively solved via convex relaxation and successive convex approximation techniques. Simulation results demonstrate the significant superiority of the proposed active RIS-assisted scheme in enhancing legitimate transmissions and degrading jamming effects compared to baseline schemes across various scenarios. These findings highlight the effectiveness of combining active RIS technology with a strategic game-theoretic framework for anti-jamming communications.

title: Pixel-Based CF-mMIMO: Addressing the AP Cooperation Cluster Formation in Fronthaul-Limited O-RAN Architectures
authors: Dariel Pereira-Ruisánchez, Michael Joham, Óscar Fresnedo, Darian Pérez-Adán, Luis Castedo, Wolfgang Utschick
abstract: This paper investigates access point (AP) cooperation cluster formation in user-centric cell-free massive MIMO (CF-mMIMO) communication systems characterized by fronthaul links with capacity restrictions. Specifically, we consider an open radio access network (O-RAN) architecture that, although it favors the deployment of ultra-dense networks, is constrained in the number of APs that can be active simultaneously. In this context, we propose an innovative framework termed pixel-based CF-mMIMO, which enables efficient control of both the AP activation and cooperation cluster formation. Recognizing the parallels with pixel-based reconfigurable antennas, the proposed framework allows dynamic reconfiguration of the network coverage map with reasonably low computational cost. The high scalability and performance of the framework are mainly supported by a learning model based on graph neural networks (GNNs) that effectively exploits the existing graph-like structures in CF-mMIMO systems. Extensive simulation experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves competitive spectral efficiency (SE) in challenging scenarios with dense AP deployments and numerous user equipments (UEs).

title: PRO-GO: Reference-Guided Protein Sequence Generation using Gene Ontology Terms
authors: Darren Tan, Ian McLoughlin, Aik Beng Ng, Zhengkui Wang, Abraham C Stern, Simon See
abstract: Protein sequence generation models aim to produce valid protein candidates on demand, however, controllably generating protein sequences with specified target functionalities remains difficult. The few existing models able to controllably generate protein sequences are limited to broad classes. We present a novel method for general controllable protein sequence generation that leverages reference sequences to guide generation, and specifies target characteristics through Gene Ontology (GO) terms. We design an evaluation pipeline based on a Top-TM-score target metric that prioritizes closest-shape matching with ground truth exemplars. We evaluate the effectiveness of this reference-guided controllability approach for protein design across various models and a diverse range of GO term combinations. We formalize controllable protein sequence generation as: given GO control termsGand reference sequencesR, generate a sequence s that maximizes structural consistency with a target fold while satisfying G. Across targets, the Top-TM-score count at thresholds ≥ 0.8 is within 3.5% of the benchmark protein count.

title: Pinching-Antenna Systems For Indoor Immersive Communications: A 3D-Modeling Based Performance Analysis
authors: Yulei Wang, Yalin Liu, Yaru Fu, Zhiguo Ding
abstract: The emerging pinching antenna (PA) technology has high flexibility to reconfigure wireless channels and combat line-of-sight blockage, thus holding transformative potential for indoor immersive applications in 6G. This paper investigates Pinching-antenna systems (PASS) for indoor immersive communications. We construct a 3D spatial model to characterize the distributions of users, waveguides, and PAs, and develop a general theoretical framework for analyzing PASS downlink successful transmission probability by capturing random user interference and spatial coupling effects between PAs and users, as well as critical system parameters’ impacts. Comprehensive numerical evaluations validate the analysis and provide practical guidelines for optimizing PASS deployments.

title: EvoREP: Evolving Reliable Ensemble of Proxies for Zero-Shot Neural Architecture Search
authors: Junhao Huang, Bing Xue, Yanan Sun, Mengjie Zhang, Gary G. Yen
abstract: Zero-shot neural architecture search (NAS) offers a significant boost to the efficiency of automated network design, where zero-cost proxies play a key role in evaluating the quality of candidate networks without training. However, most existing proxies measure network capability by a single specific characteristic, which is insufficient to achieve a high correlation with the final performance. Although some studies attempt to use multiple proxies for better estimation performance, they often fall short in considering the inherently multi-dimensional properties of neural networks and/or rely on simple combinations of these proxies. This work presents an effective nonlinear ensemble method to aggregate nine representative zero-cost proxies aiming at various network characteristics for comprehensive network evaluations. To obtain a reliable aggregation of proxies on a given task and efficiently utilize candidate base proxies, a diversity-aware adaptive particle swarm optimization (DAA-PSO) approach is developed to evolve the ensemble proxy. DAA-PSO maintains a pool of best solutions with varying sparsity levels to enhance the diversity of particles and employs an adaptive solution sparsification strategy to effectively identify the most suitable base proxies for the ensemble. The proposed method, named EvoREP (evolving reliable ensemble of zero-cost proxies), can efficiently discover the best ensemble proxy for the target task. Extensive experiments on popular NAS benchmarks and open-domain search spaces demonstrate the effectiveness and promising transferability of EvoREP in evolving ensemble proxies, exhibiting remarkably high correlation with test accuracy.

title: Monitoring and Evaluation of Energy Efficiency Measures on an Industrial AHU Using Portable Data Logging
authors: Christopher Flynn, Trevor Murphy, Daniel Riordan
abstract: This study investigates the energy performance of an industrial Air Handling Unit (AHU) through the implementation and evaluation of targeted energy efficiency measures. A portable data logger equipped with Rogowski coil sensors was used to monitor the AHU’s three-phase electrical consumption across multiple intervention scenarios. Three strategies were tested sequentially: volumetric flow rate reduction, scheduled volumetric flow rate cycling based on operational hours, and air filter replacement. Each intervention was followed by a dedicated monitoring period, during which energy consumption, cost, and CO₂ emissions were recorded and compared against a baseline configuration. Results showed that initial volumetric flow rate reduction achieved a modest 9.37% decrease in hourly energy consumption, while the combination of filter maintenance and programmed cycling yielded the most substantial reduction of 79.75%. This study highlights the effectiveness of low-cost monitoring tools and simple control modifications in improving the energy efficiency of legacy Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) systems. These findings support scalable retrofitting strategies for commercial and industrial facilities seeking to reduce operational energy use and carbon impact.

title: Transforming Microgrid Flexibility Through a Dynamic and Modular Scalability Framework for Diverse Energy Applications
authors: Ponaganti Rajendar, Ch Venkateswara Rao, D Srinivas
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Microgrids are becoming integral to maintaining consistent and eco-friendly power systems, especially in regions where centralized power systems are either inefficient or unable to reach. However, current designs of microgrids are not very adaptable and therefore do not perform well in different settings with different energy needs. This research proposes a novel Dynamic and Modular Scalability Framework which microgrids can adapt to different contexts and transitions, from rural isolated areas to intricate metropolitan structures. The Dynamic and Modular Scalability Framework microgrid model features real-time data analytics and predictive control algorithms to enable comprehensive remote reshaping of distributed energy resources, storage systems, and prioritized loads. The advanced method offered highlighted significant advantages in comparison to traditional systems after being tested with both rural and urban case studies. The results also indicate a decrease in operational costs by 32 percent, a 38 percent drop in carbon emissions, and a 25 percent improvement in certain resilience metrics like critical load support, fault recovery speed, and uninterrupted supply. The advanced method's capacity to easily and rapidly adapt to new resources with little to no manual systems intervention showcases the method's versatility. This research microgrid method also concentrates flexibility on contextual adaptability as well as scalability.

title: Hybrid CNN-Swin Framework for Detection and Classification of Potato Leaf Diseases
authors: Hager Saleh, Michael McCann, Ross Creaven, John G. Breslin, Shaker El-Sappagh
abstract: Timely and accurate identification of plant diseases is essential for sustainable agricultural practices and food security. This study presents a deep learning-based diagnostic framework capable of classifying seven potato leaf conditions: healthy, early blight, late blight, brown spot, target spot, bacterial wilt, and leaf curl. Despite significant progress in plant disease detection using convolutional neural networks (CNNs), existing approaches often struggle with inter-class similarity and lack generalization across variable imaging conditions. To address these limitations, we propose a hybrid model that integrates a CNN architecture (i.e., EfficientNetB0) with the Swin Transformer, leveraging their complementary feature representations. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed hybrid model outperforms individual baselines, achieving an accuracy of 91.734%, precision of 92.204%, recall of 91.734%, and F1-score of 91.71% across all seven classes. These findings highlight the model’s robustness and its potential to support scalable, real-time disease monitoring in precision agriculture.

title: Implementation of Load Balancing on a Quiz Web Application Using the Least Connection Algorithm with Reverse Proxy Technique
authors: Danang Haryo Sulaksono, Citra Nurina Prabiantissa, Rinci Kembang Hapsari, Latiful Sirri, Djuniharto, Dwi Yulian R.L.
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: The growing demand for scalable web-based applications requires efficient load balancing to sustain performance under varying traffic loads. This study using the Least Connection algorithms implemented via Nginx reverse proxy in a networked quiz application used for Jaringan Komputer laboratory sessions at ITATS. The system architecture comprised one reverse proxy server and two backend servers, with Apache JMeter simulating 100, 300, and 600 HTTP requests per second, each repeated three times. Key metrics—average response time, throughput, CPU and memory usage, bandwidth, and error rate—were monitored using Nginx-UI. For Testing we compare the Least Connection And Round Robin Algorithm, and results show Least Connection consistently achieved lower response times (1,100 ms, 3,335 ms, 6,333 ms) and higher throughput (40.5, 43.5, 46.0 req/s) than Round Robin, but required more CPU resources. Round Robin maintained lower CPU usage and slightly higher inbound bandwidth. The novelty lies in a real-world, metric-based comparison within an educational environment, offering practical insights for algorithm selection based on performance or resource efficiency.

title: Utilizing the C4.5 Algorithm to Evaluate Public Satisfaction for Village Administration System using Client-Server Based
authors: Goenawan Brotosaputro, Rahmat Sulaiman, Tri Sugohartono, Bambang Adiwinoto, Agustina Mardeka Raya
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: This study applies the C4.5 Algorithm in deciding public satisfaction with the services received at the Village Office. The C4.5 Algorithm is a classification algorithm with a well-known decision tree technique and is favored because it has advantages. These advantages include being able to process numeric and discrete data, being able to handle missing attribute values, producing rules that are easy to interpret and the fastest. This type of research is classification with the concept of data mining involving 20 community questionnaire data at the Village Office which are categorized as: cheap, expensive, appropriate, inappropriate, fast, long, comfortable, uncomfortable. There are four attributes that affect public satisfaction, including: handling costs, service procedures, handling time and comfort. From the results of the research that has been conducted by the researcher, it can be concluded. Service satisfaction at the Office can be predicted and evaluated by utilizing data mining techniques using the C4.5 Algorithm to predict public satisfaction with services at the Village Office. the results of this study are that there is an increased level of accuracy from before. The results demonstrate that the C4.5 algorithm is effective in identifying critical attributes that impact satisfaction, thereby providing actionable insights for improving public service delivery at the village level.

title: The Role of AI-Driven MIS in Enhancing Strategic Management and Operational Efficiency in the Healthcare Industry
authors: Bedour Almudaiheem, Nada Alshamrani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: This study examines the impact of AI-enhanced MIS on healthcare management in Saudi Arabia, by investigating the interrelationships among three perceived dimensions of AI integration-strategic decision-making, operational efficiency, and administrative automationwithin healthcare organizations. Using a quantitative research approach and a cross-sectional descriptive survey, the study found that AI significantly improve efficiency, reduce costs, and enhance long-term strategic planning. However, challenges such as regulatory constraints, data security risks, integration complexities, and the need for AI-specialized expertise remain significant barriers to widespread adoption. To address these, the study advocates for government-backed AI implementation strategies, specialized MIS training programs, and interdisciplinary collaboration to support sustainable AI-MIS integration in healthcare. As the first study of its kind in Saudi Arabia, this research highlights the transformative potential of AI-enhanced MIS, not only in operational efficiency but also in long-term strategic decision-making within the healthcare industry. Furthermore, it calls for policy reforms, structured AI implementation frameworks, and robust data governance protocols to enable effective AI adoption within healthcare management.

title: High-Efficiency Graphene Electro-Absorption Modulator on Silicon Nitride Photonic Platform
authors: Ashraful Islam Raju, Pawan Kumar Dubey, Rasuole Lukose, Daniele Capista, Anna Peczek, Aleksandra Kroh, Christian Wenger, Andreas Mai, Mindaugas Lukosius
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate a silicon nitride waveguide-coupled double layer graphene electro-absorption modulator achieving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>7 ~\text{dB}$</tex> modulation depth and up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.2 ~\text{dB} / \mathrm{V}$</tex> modulation efficiency at 10 V. The device features a bandwidth exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 ~ G H z}$</tex> for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0} \boldsymbol{\mu}$</tex> m device length.

title: Bow-Tie Cavity Realization for Power Enhancement of the Excitation Laser in Photoacoustic Spectroscopy
authors: Savda Sam, Johannes P. Waclawek, Harald Moser, Iskander Gazizov, Liam O'Faolain, Bernhard Lendl
abstract: In photoacoustic spectroscopy, a powerful technique for trace gas sensing, the induced signal increases with the optical excitation power. We report a bow-tie cavity designed to deliver the power enhancement and stable beam waist for methane detection in the near-infrared region.

title: $\text{TE}_{40}$-Based Multimode Interferometer for Optical Refractive Index Sensors
authors: Freddy Jara-Poma, Luana De-Moraes, Ten Salinas, Ruth Rubio-Noriega, Maria Armas-Alvarado, Yuri Hayashi Isayama, Hugo E. Hernandez-Figueroa
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate the robust and selective excitation of the higher-order mode <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TE}_{40}$</tex> in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Si}_{3} ~\mathrm{N}_{4}$</tex> multimode interferometer (MMI), aiming to enhance evanescent field interactions for refractive index sensing. Through output intensity monitoring and the integration of a microfluidic module, the sensor demonstrates a bulk sensitivity of 780 RIU <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$^{-1}$</tex> and a detection limit of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.2 \times 10^{-5}$</tex> RIU. These results highlight the potential of high-order-mode photonic sensors for compact and highly sensitive refractive index detection.

title: Power Station Overvoltage Prediction based on Heterogeneous Spatiotemporal Networks
authors: Defu Dong, Cuiting Li, Xiaojian Bao, Lei Kong, Lei Guo, Yuzhi Bian, Kai Liang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: In photovoltaic (PV) power generation systems, traditional overvoltage prediction methods struggle to effectively handle the complex spatiotemporal coupling characteristics and multi-source heterogeneous data of power plants, while lacking quantitative assessment of prediction uncertainty. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a deep learning-based framework for PV power plant overvoltage prediction. First, we design a Heterogeneous Spatio-Temporal Graph Encoder (HSTGE) that models PV plants as heterogeneous graph structures, simultaneously capturing plant topology features and electrical temporal dynamics through spatiotemporal graph convolution operations, and introducing an adaptive graph structure learning mechanism to reflect dynamic electrical coupling relationships under different operating conditions. Second, we propose a Cross-Modal Attention Fusion mechanism (CMAF) that employs multi-head attention and hierarchical fusion strategies to achieve adaptive deep fusion of spatiotemporal features with multi-source heterogeneous information including meteorological and operational status data. Finally, we construct a Probabilistic Hierarchical Prediction Head (PHPH) that simultaneously accomplishes three tasks through a hierarchical prediction structure: normal voltage regression, overvoltage risk classification, and extreme event detection, while providing prediction uncertainty quantification based on mixture density networks and Bayesian inference. Experimental results demonstrate that compared to existing state-of-the-art baseline methods, our approach improves the F1-score for overvoltage prediction by $7.2 \%$. Additionally, ablation experiments confirm the effectiveness of the proposed modules.

title: Miniaturized Spectrometer with Angle Retrieval Ability Using CMOS-Compatible Metasurface Filters
authors: Ram Prakash S, Mondher Besbes, Henri Benisty
abstract: We present a miniaturized spectrometer using CMOS-Compatible metasurface-type generalized Fabry-Perot resonators for simultaneous spectrum and angle retrieval. The design combines high- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Q$</tex> angle-tolerant and low- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Q$</tex> angle-sensitive filters. Multiplexing both enables both accurate reconstruction of chlorophyll fluorescence spectra and precise angle of incidence determination better than 1°.

title: Comparion of Source-Selection Between KNN-TDS Method and Median Z-Score in Multi-Source Cross-Project Defect Prediction Using Neural Network
authors: Rizal Broer Bahaweres, Nabila Fatia Kasmizar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Software defect prediction is a critical activity in software development. this work was continuous work from our research road map. Historical data is required to predict software defects, but such data is not always available for every project. In cross-project prediction, data availability is not a problem as data from other projects is available, for example, in repositories like PROMISE. However, this technique has a limitation in that the differences between the source and target projects can affect the accuracy of the predictions. Therefore, multi-source cross-project defect prediction has been developed to combine data from multiple sources to reduce the impact of domain differences between source and target projects. Previous studies have shown that appropriate selection of training data can improve cross-project defect prediction quality. In this study, we propose a distance-based strategy for selecting training data based on the distributional characteristics of available data. We evaluated the proposed strategy in a large case study with 11 datasets from different projects. We compared two source selection methods, namely KNN-TDS and median z-score, to obtain the best performance. Finally, we used the Neural Network algorithm to train the training data. The results showed that the average F1-score of the KNN-TDS method was 6% higher than the median z-score method.

title: Broadband and Low-Loss Silicon Polarization Splitter-Rotator Based on All-Rib Waveguides
authors: Yuki Ueda, Takanori Sato, Taichi Muratsubaki, Kunimasa Saitoh
abstract: An all-rib waveguide silicon polarization splitter-rotator is demonstrated, offering compact footprint and broadband operation with <1.4 dB insertion loss across 150 nm, covering the S, C, and L bands.

title: Development of an Intelligent Autonomous Rover with Distributed Sensors for Speed Control and Obstacle Avoidance
authors: Udith Chandra Prasad P, Veerendernath P, Vinodh Kumar Minchula
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: This paper presents a low-cost ESP32-based rover designed for safety monitoring in homes, vehicles, and small industries. The system operates in two modes: manual control through Bluetooth HC-05 and autonomous navigation with selfspeed regulation. Obstacle detection combines an ESP32-CAM streaming video to a PC running YOLOv8 for object recognition with a servo-mounted HC-SR04 ultrasonic radar that doublechecks short-range hazards, ensuring reliable collision avoidance. An MQ-6 sensor continuously monitors LPG levels, using calibrated thresholds for early gas leak detection. Real-time data, including gas levels, obstacle distance, and system status, display on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16 \times 2$</tex> LCD and upload every 5 seconds to ThingSpeak through the ESP32 DevKit V1 for remote monitoring and alerts. Experimental validation showed 86% obstacle detection accuracy and a mean stop latency of 180 milliseconds, while gas detection reliably flagged LPG above 350 ppm with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 5 {\%}$</tex> deviation from a reference. The rover focuses on low cost, reproducibility, and multi-sensor fusion, making it a scalable safety solution for homes, vehicles, and industrial use. Note: The design is intentionally low-cost and multi-purpose, built from off-the-shelf modules to enable practical deployment for household, vehicle, and small-industry monitoring.

title: Systematic Study of Sin Films Towards Cost-Effective and Low-Loss Photonic Applications
authors: Landobasa Y M Tobing, Yanmei Cao, Chen Lau, Peng Liu, Yat Fung Tsang, Binni Varghese, Minghua Li, Yeow Teck Toh, Steven Hou Jang Lee, Jae Ok Yoo, Xianshu Luo
abstract: We demonstrate wafer-level comparison of SiN films of various deposition methods. Deuterated SiN emerges as an excellent candidate for ultralow loss photonics (<0.2 dB/cm), with large thickness and low stress, all of which are realizable by a simple 200-mm process with low thermal budget.

title: Design and Implementation of a Hybrid Solar-Grid Charging Infrastructure with IoT-Based Control
authors: Devanarayanan M. Kurup, Rohith Ayinkalath, Tom Augustine, Elwin I. S., Haneesh K. M.
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: The rapid growth of e-bikes and e-scooters is straining conventional, fossil-fuel-intensive power grids and exposing a critical gap in urban charging infrastructure. In this work, a fully modular hybrid station that synergistically couples three energy vectors—photovoltaics, second-life Li-ion battery packs, and the utility grid—via an intelligent, sub-50 ms source-arbitration network. The power-conditioning front end employs a flyback-derived SMPS delivering five tightly regulated outputs (5 V, 12 V, 37 V, 48 V DC; 230 V AC) at 92–95% efficiency, while a bidirectional synchronous boost stage attains 94–97% efficiency and future-proofs the system for vehicle-to-grid operation. End-to-end power quality is preserved with < 5% total harmonic distortion under dynamic loads. An ESP32-centric IoT stack with LoRaWAN back-haul furnishes kilometre-scale telemetry, secure billing, and over-the-air firmware updates, whereas a BiLSTM-assisted battery-management layer enables real-time state-of-charge and state-of-health tracking of repurposed EV modules—extending their usable life and anchoring circular-economy objectives. By fusing high-efficiency power conversion, adaptive energy-source orchestration, and cloud-native intelligence in a compact footprint, the proposed platform sets a scalable blueprint for low-carbon, resilient charging ecosystems that can keep pace with the next wave of urban micro-mobility.

title: An Investigation on Composite EM Scattering by MoM-SBR-PTD Hybrid Technique
authors: Yu-Lu Biao, Juan Li, Wei Meng, Jin-Peng Xiong, Chu-Yu Duan, Yong-Ji Xi
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper combines the Method of Moments (MoM) with the Shooting and Bouncing Rays (SBR) method (MoM-SBR) to calculate and study the electromagnetic (EM) scattering characteristics of electrically large objects with fine structures. Moreover, Physical theory of diffraction (PTD) is combined for the edge diffraction field. The combination method (MoM-SBR-PTD) aims to precisely consider the mutual coupling and influence between objects. In the same space, different methods are used to calculate EM scattering for different objects: SBR-PTD for large-sized objects and MoM for fine structures. By combining the advantages of different methods, the overall calculation speed is improved while ensuring calculation accuracy.

title: Analysis of Frame Current Protection in Case of Frame Leakage on AC Side of Rectifier
authors: Yujuan Liu, Tao Ding, Huili Lin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: Based on the introduction of the principle of the six pulse full wave rectifier bridge, this paper analyzes the waveform and magnitude of the leakage current when a frame leakage fault occurs on the AC side of the rectifier, and investigates the collection and processing capabilities of the frame leakage protection device. After using MATLAB simulation and laboratory experiments, it was finally concluded that the frame leakage protection current element can protect the AC side frame leakage fault of DC equipment.

title: Best Practice for Mechatronics Curriculum Development: A Project-Based Learning Approach
authors: Guoyuan Li, Robert Skulstad
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on E-Learning in Industrial Electronics (ICELIE)
abstract: Mechatronics curriculum development should keep pace with technological advancements and evolving industry needs. In this paper, we propose a project-based learning (PBL) approach for developing such a curriculum. First, project selection is guided by institutional strengths and local industry interests. Next, the selected project is divided into sub-projects, each aligned with a core course. Each core course not only introduces the necessary techniques but also concludes with a corresponding sub-project that includes prototyping and experimental verification. Finally, course evaluation is conducted via a student survey to foster continuous curriculum improvement. Through a best practice of unmanned surface vehicles project, we verify the effectiveness of the proposed PBL approach.

title: A Distributed and Scalable Testbed for Developing Intelligent UAV Swarm Controllers Based on Curiosity-Driven Machine Learning
authors: Jawad Mahmood, John Loane, Muhammad Adil Raja, Fergal McCaffery
abstract: This research project developed a novel distributed networking-based Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) intelligent system to enable real-time swarm UAV target tracking. The Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) model, along with Intrinsic Curiosity Module (ICM), was developed and integrated with JSBSim for controlling Reinforcement Learning (RL) agents in the simulated environment of FlightGear. The PPO-ICM model was interfaced with the testbed’s Asynchronous Advantage Actor-Critic (A3C) model, facilitating the control of multiple tracking UAVs as a coordinated swarm. The target UAV, in contrast, is operated by the Advantage Actor-Critic (A2C) model. This study incorporates a distributed framework that enables parallel execution of an experimental simulation across multiple systems interconnected via computer networking. The effectiveness of this approach is demonstrated using four interconnected systems, ensuring efficient UAV coordination and scalability. This methodology has overcome the problem of policy degeneration of RL agents. The graphical results evaluate the performance of PPO-ICM, showing significant improvements in scalability, adaptability, and computational efficiency. This research presents a novel scalable and distributed system for swarm UAV target tracking by applying novel Machine Learning (ML) techniques in dynamic and distributed environments.

title: Difference Between Characteristic Mode Theory and Cavity Mode Theory for Square and Circular Microstrip Antennas
authors: Hao Deng, Xingyue Guo, Yuanan Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper presents the differences between characteristic mode theory (CMT) developed from mixed-potential integral equation (MPIE) and cavity mode theory in calculating the resonance frequency and electric field distribution of single-layer rectangular and circular microstrip antennas. In the MPIE-based CMT, the dielectric substrate is considered to extend infinitely in the transverse directions. In contrast, cavity mode theory models the top and bottom surfaces as electric walls and the side walls as magnetic walls. The results demonstrate that both MPIE-based CMT and cavity mode theory calculate resonance frequencies are close to the full-wave analysis. However, regarding electric field distribution, the MPIE-based CMT reveals additional degenerate modes not captured by cavity mode theory, thereby providing deeper insights.

title: Analyzing the Impact of Pre-training Data Domain and Scale on Cross-Domain Performance in wav2vec 2.0 Model
authors: Davoud Shariat Panah, Andrew Hines
abstract: Models based on self-supervised learning (SSL), such as wav2vec 2.0, have demonstrated strong performance in various speech tasks by learning from unlabeled audio data. However, their effectiveness depends on the alignment between pre-training data and the downstream task, as well as the scale of the pre-training data. While previous work examined domain mismatch in speech tasks, the impact of domain alignment and pre-training data scale when the acoustic modalities differ between pre-training data and the downstream task remains unclear. This study trains and evaluates wav2vec 2.0 on diverse acoustic modalities to analyze the influence of these factors. The results indicate that more pre-training data leads to higher performance if the pre-training domain is closely aligned with the downstream task. However, when domain alignment is weak, downstream performance is more influenced by shared acoustic structural properties between the pre-training and fine-tuning data than by the scale of the pre-training dataset.

title: Porosity Meets Plasmonics: A Novel Route to High-Q Mechanical Nanoresonators
authors: J. I. Sangiorgio, C. Borrazás, J. Mascarenhas, N. Roqueiro, E. Cortés, M. C. Fuertes, G Grinblat, A. V. Bragas
abstract: We investigate the mechanical response of gold plasmonic nanoantennas on mesoporous silica substrates, revealing enhanced quality factors and tunable resonance frequencies. Mesoporous material reduces substrate-induced damping, improving energy confinement without requiring full suspension. Ultrafast pumpprobe spectroscopy shows that both frequency and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Q$</tex> are sensitive to environmental humidity due to water adsorption in the pores. Our results demonstrate a scalable approach to engineer high-f*Q nanoresonators and suggest a path toward tunable and low-loss nanomechanical systems for sensing and nanophotonic applications.

title: A Review of Open Access High-Resolution Data for Machine Learning-Based Landslide Susceptibility Mapping
authors: Yurio Windiatmoko, Arief Setyanto, Kusrini, Andi Sunyoto
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: This study examines how artificial intelligence techniques integrate with freely available high-resolution spatial datasets for predicting landslide-prone areas. By analyzing 48 research papers, we categorize open geospatial data sources (including Sentinel imagery, elevation models, and LiDAR), data preparation approaches, and AI model implementations used in susceptibility assessments.

title: Laser Vision: Haptic Navigation System for The Blind
authors: Ivan Alexander, Marcel Saputra, Matthew Filbert Tander
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Independent and safe navigation is a significant challenge for people with visual impairments, especially due to the limitations of traditional aids such as white canes and guide dogs. This research aims to develop an innovative navigation aid called laser vision, which uses a TOF200C-VL53L0X sensor and a vibration motor to provide accurate haptic feedback. The laser vision device is designed with an ESP32 microcontroller as the main controller, a lithium-ion battery for longer usage life, and a lightweight and environmentally friendly polylactic acid waterproof case. Laser vision provides real-time distance information through vibration patterns calibrated based on object distance, allowing users to understand their surroundings more intuitively. Based on testing, the device can detect objects with an average error margin of 3.7% within a distance range of 5 cm to 150 cm. In addition, the device has a battery life of up to 9.37 hours of use. With a compact, efficient design and resistance to environmental conditions, Laser Vision provides an effective and sustainable solution to improve the independence of individuals with visual impairments.

title: Thermo-Fluid Coupling Analysis and Optimization for a Single Guide Ring Electromagnetic Heater
authors: Feng Zhou, Zhenyang Wen, Yuxiang Zhao, Zixuan Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: To address issues of non-uniform heating and low efficiency caused by fluid instability in pipeline electromagnetic heating (EMH) devices, this paper proposes a novel powerfrequency EMH apparatus incorporating guide rings. Considering factors of magnetic leakage and material dimensional constraints, the device employs a dual heating mode utilizing both the outer wall and the guide rings. This design satisfies four distinct input power requirements based on load demands, achieving efficiencies consistently above $90 \%$. For structural optimization, a coupled thermo-fluid analysis was performed to investigate the influence of the clearance between the outer wall and guide rings on flow velocity and heating efficiency. Results indicate that adjusting the clearance to approximately 7.5 mm allows the heating efficiency to reach its peak value. This research provides a theoretical basis and optimization pathway for high-efficiency electromagnetic heating system design.

title: Radar HRRP Generation Using a Scattered Echo Calculation Model Based on the Generalized RCS
authors: Chen Guan, Shigang Zhou, Haitao Mi, Jie Ma, Wentao Mei
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper proposes a method for generating radar high-resolution range profile (HRRP) using a scattered echo calculation model based on generalized radar cross section (GRCS). The results from this method are compared with those from the scattering center model (SCM). The method first uses the scattered echo calculation model to generate echo data in the near-field at different frequencies, then uses an inverse discrete Fourier transform (IDFT) to image the target. The results show that the proposed method produces more accurate and realistic imaging results.

title: Research on Accurate Extraction of Partial Discharge Signals in Distribution Switchgear Based on Partial Discharge Sensors and Digital Twin Technology
authors: Dongyi Huang, Chuang Sun, Zhe Li, Ye Kuang, Junhong Lin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: This study proposes an accurate extraction method for partial discharge (PD) signals in distribution switchgear based on PD sensors and digital twin technology. The approach combines wavelet packet transform (WPT) and sample entropy (SampEn), integrating local peak analysis and Kalman filtering to accurately extract key features from PD signals, particularly in complex noisy environments. Furthermore, a deep learning model combining convolutional neural networks (CNN) and long short-term memory networks (LSTM) is used to classify the extracted features, significantly improving the diagnostic accuracy of PD faults. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieved a classification accuracy of $95 \%$, precision of $92 \%$, recall of $91 \%$, F1 score of $93 \%$, and AUC value of $96 \%$ on real-world datasets, which far outperform traditional machine learning methods. The experimental validation demonstrates the potential application of this method in PD signal monitoring for distribution switchgear, effectively enhancing the automation and robustness of fault diagnosis.

title: Flexible Transparent Broadband Absorber Enabled by Cu(S,I) Gradient-Impedance Films
authors: Xiangchuan Zheng, Xiaojian Chen, Yifan Xiao, Yuxi Liu, Le Cao, Chang Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: To address the limitations of conventional absorbers in optical transparency, mechanical flexibility, and absorption bandwidth, this study presents a flexible transparent microwave absorber based on gradient-impedance Cu(S,I) films for ultra-broadband applications. The proposed structure achieves an absorption band from 8.4 GHz to 25.68 GHz with over 80% optical transmittance. It also exhibits polarization insensitivity and high angular stability under wide incident angles. Moreover, the absorber provides a maximum radar cross-section (RCS) reduction exceeding 20 dB across the operating band. These advantages underscore its promising applications in flexible radar stealth coatings, 5G/6G electromagnetic compatibility, and wearable electronics requiring microwave suppression.

title: Research on the Mode Purity of Frequency-Dependent Vortex Electromagnetic Waves Generated by UCA
authors: Jingcan Ma, Jiazhen Cai, Yufei Fu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Vortex electromagnetic waves have broad prospects in radar imaging and wireless communication due to their spiral phase wavefronts and orthogonality between modes. However, in practical applications, different modes of vortex electromagnetic waves are required to achieve high imaging resolution and large-capacity information transmission. This letter studies and analyzes a novel method for generating frequency-dependent vortex electromagnetic waves based on a uniform circular array (UCA), which employs stepped-frequency signals and time delay units. The orbital angular momentum (OAM) spectrum analysis method verifies that the wave generated by this scheme has high mode purity.

title: Electronic-Photonic Co-Design for All-Optical Signal Processing and Computing
authors: Francesco Zanetto, Alessandro di Tria, Emanuele Sacchi, Samuele De Gaetano, Monica Crico, Francesco Morichetti, Andrea Melloni, Giorgio Ferrari, Marco Sampietro
abstract: Analog signal processing and computing performed in the optical domain with programmable photonic chips require a dedicated electronic control layer to set and dynamically reconfigure the circuit functionality at runtime. Here, we present recent advances in electronic-photonic co-design, enabling successful operation of large-scale photonic processors.

title: Explaining Gender Bias in Machine Learning Hiring Systems: An XAI-Based Impact Assessment
authors: Davita Khowati, Erik Sanjaya, Alexander Agung Santoso Gunawan, Rilo Chandra Pradana
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Machine learning-based hiring systems are increasingly adopted in recruitment due to their efficiency. However, the systems can inadvertently introduce or amplify biases, particularly gender bias, leading to ethical and legal concerns. This study aims to detect gender bias in AI-based hiring systems through the application of Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) techniques. A controlled bias-perturbation framework is implemented using a job application dataset, where progressively imbalanced training sets favoring male candidates are generated. Two classification models–logistic regression and XGBoost–are trained and evaluated. SHAP (SHapley Additive Explanations) and LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations) are utilized to analyze the decision-making processes of AI models and interpret feature contributions under different bias conditions. The analysis indicates that SHAP provides more reliable and interpretable insights into model behavior compared to LIME. Additionally, XGBoost exhibits greater robustness to biased data than logistic regression, maintaining relatively consistent accuracy and interpretability. These findings demonstrate the vulnerability of hiring models to gender-related bias and underscore the importance of integrating XAI tools to enhance transparency and fairness in AI-driven recruitment systems.

title: Optimization of Cross-Polarization Level in Circularly Polarized Antenna Arrays Based on Rotated-Element Modeling
authors: Minwei Deng, Jun Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: To address the challenge of cross-polarization level (XPL) suppression in circularly polarized (CP) antenna arrays, this paper proposes a novel optimization strategy based on element rotation. Initially, a neural network is employed to establish the mapping relationship between the rotated elements and its active element pattern (AEP). The features of the rotated element are determined by its own rotation angle and the states of its adjacent elements. Then, the radiation pattern of the full array can be calculated by superimposing the AEPs of each array elements so that we can obtain desired XPL by optimizing rotation angles of the array elements using optimization algorithm like Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). To validate the proposed method, two cases for synthesizing pencil beam and flat-top patterns are conducted. The results show that the optimized patterns agree well with full-wave simulations and achieve an extremely low XPLs.

title: Design, Integration and Testing of a GSM Enabled Solar E-Bike for Sustainable Transportation
authors: Bhavani Dhanla, Aruna Bharathi Mathangi, Sushama Malaji, Anji Reddy Ookanti, Mukhesh Kumar Nalla, Vinay Puneeth Kumar Dasam
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Learning to drive is vital for independence, but traditional vehicles lack features for disabled individuals. This project aims to create a solar-powered vehicle prototype for people with limb impairments, allowing independent travel. Interest in sustainable mobility is rising due to carbon emissions, climate change, and fuel depletion. Solar energy offers environmental improvements, including minimized pollution and greenhouse gas emissions, promising long-term protection. Portable mobility devices are significant for the elderly and disabled, but cars can be costly. This project aims to develop an affordable, user-friendly solar electric vehicle for those with disabilities, ensuring comfortable travel and living. Solar energy is gaining attention due to pollution, fuel costs, and limited conventional energy sources. It's expected to become a major primary energy source. The solar car includes advanced features for independence and GSM technology for remote monitoring, providing notifications for unusual activities and enabling global remote monitoring.

title: Design and Analysis of Online Monitoring Device for Galloping of Transmission Lines
authors: Lei Nie, Yishan Zhang, Chong Guan, Xu Yang, Junfang Chen, Weitao Zhong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: As a crucial component of the power system, transmission lines undertake the key task of electrical energy transmission. Their safe and stable operation is directly related to national energy security and socio-economic development. Transmission lines are prone to low-frequency, large-amplitude oscillation under wind loads or mechanical vibrations. Intense conductor galloping not only causes wear of hardware fittings, conductor breakage and tripping, but may even lead to tower collapse accidents, resulting in large-scale power outages. Traditional monitoring methods are unable to timely capture the dynamic process of galloping and fail to meet the needs of refined power grid operation and maintenance. To detect the galloping of transmission lines in a timely manner, this paper conducts research on the design of an online monitoring device for transmission line galloping. The hardware system of the device mainly includes sensors, an information wireless transmission and processing module, and a power supply module. The software part mainly realizes functions such as data acquisition control, real-time data processing, and local alarm. This system can accurately monitor the conductor displacement, acceleration, angle, and other parameters, providing a reference for the formulation of galloping prevention and control strategies.

title: RF Current Distribution Measurement based on Fourier Space Reconstruction for PCB Interconnect Structure
authors: Xie Yusong, Zhou Yangyang, Qiu Jian, Han Peng, Cheng Yiqiang, Shao Weiheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This work implements the Fourier method for non-contact regional radiofrequency current imaging of microstrip structures on PCBs. Simulations and near-field scanning experiments demonstrate accurate current structure reconstruction and basic accurate current amplitude.

title: Multi-Robot Defense with Visibility Constraints: A Relay-Based Approach for Guarding Multiple Targets
authors: Haiyan Zhao, Yong Wang, Rongxin Cui, Yongkang Wang, Weisheng Yan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: This paper addresses the multi-player, multitarget guarding problem, where multiple robots with limited visibility defend several targets against a single intruder. The intruder selects a target and attempts to infiltrate, while the defenders aim to intercept it. We propose a semi-cooperative defense strategy that relies solely on relative position to address this challenge. First, we partition the state space of the multiplayer system and design relay defense strategies based on initial conditions. Second, we introduce a multi-target allocation scheme, incorporating risk metrics and a nonlinear feedback control strategy that adapts to different state spaces. Finally, we provide sufficient conditions for the defenders to successfully intercept the intruder, considering their capture radius. The effectiveness of our approach is validated through theoretical analysis and experiments with ground mobile robots.

title: Digital Twin Models for Key Components of Heavy-Duty Diesel Vehicles
authors: Zhenyi Xu, Jiaren Li, Jun Huang, Xihong Fei
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are the main emissions from heavy-duty diesel vehicles. Although the NOx concentration downstream of the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system in the exhaust after-treatment system can be directly measured by sensors, the measurement results may have significant errors due to the sensitivity to external environmental factors, driving styles, and road conditions. Therefore, it is necessary to model the key components of diesel vehicles to improve the accuracy of online measurement of diesel vehicle emissions. This study integrates digital twin technology with the Deep Forest regression algorithm to develop a comprehensive state prediction model for key components of heavy-duty diesel vehicles. The model encompasses predictions for NOx levels both before and after Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) treatment. Among the models compared, this approach yields the smallest prediction errors. Additionally, the Random Forest regression algorithm is employed to construct an engine speed model, which also demonstrates the lowest error rate when juxtaposed with other models. Furthermore, the ElasticNet regression algorithm is utilized to build an engine coolant temperature model, again achieving the smallest model error in comparative analyses. Through the development of these datadriven digital twin models, a robust digital twin framework for heavy-duty diesel vehicles is established. This framework provides a reliable basis for real-time NOx emission optimization, facilitating effective and rational NOx emission control strategies for heavy-duty diesel vehicles.

title: Low-Cost and Modular Broadband Light Sources for Fluorescence Microscopy
authors: Rachel Duff, Igor Roszczyk, Mahin Rahman, Yidan Zhang, Aone Mogorosi, Amanda Foust, Akhil Kallepalli
abstract: A modular light source system for fluorescence microscopy is developed utilizing interchangeable light-emitting diode (LED) modules, evaluated through neuronal cell fluorescence microscopy. The design is open source and low cost, reducing reliance on expensive light sources, to improve global accessibility.

title: Validation of Spatially Offset High-Resolution Microendoscopy (HRME) for Visualization of Cellular Morphology
authors: Anjanaa S, Karthika J, Sreelakshmi Pyarilal, Sreelakshmi Sreekumar, Milind Lal, Arpitha Anantharaju, Aravind Krishnamurthy, Uttam M. Pal
abstract: High-resolution Microendoscopy (HRME) is valuable for real-time, in vivo imaging of epithelial tissues. This study tests and validates a novel spatially offset HRME (SOHRME) system, enhancing imaging depth and contrast by capturing scattered light from deeper tissue layers and improving subsurface abnormality detection

title: An Ultra-Sparse MIMO Radar Array Topology Using Redundancy and Utilization of Elements
authors: Yu Zhang, Xinquan Wang, Kai Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this paper, based on the principles of array optimization, an optimization of Ultra-Sparse MIMO radar arrays is proposed, which is simultaneously considers array Redundancy and the Utilization of virtual elements. Simulation results validate that this method achieves better suppression of the peak side lobe level (PSLL) compared to uniform array and minimum redundancy array.

title: Circularly Polarized Beam-Scanning Leaky-Wave Antenna Based on Etched Asymmetric Circular Patch Fed by Spoof Surface Plasmon Polaritons
authors: Zhang Wen Cheng, Meng Wang, Hui Feng Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper proposes a single-layer leaky-wave antenna (LWA) capable of circularly polarized (CP) beam-scanning radiation. The antenna employs several asymmetrically etched circular patches on the bottom ground plane and is fed via a spoof surface plasmon polariton (SSPP) transmission line using a coupling-fed mechanism. The introduction of a periodically perturbed structure enables the antenna to satisfy the condition for periodic modulation, thereby facilitating beam-scanning leaky-wave radiation. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed LWA achieves desirable dual CP radiation over the beam-scanning range from -22° to 41° and -158° to 139°, respectively. Compared to existing designs, this LWA features a low-profile, single-layer structure, offering advantages of ease of fabrication and reduced manufacturing cost.
