title: Hybrid Learning-Based Resilient Formation Control for Multi-Vehicle Systems Under Distributed Denial-of-Service Attacks
authors: Jia-Xiu Yang, Yong Xu, Zheng-Guang Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper investigates secure formation control for unknown networked multi-vehicle systems under denial-of-service (DoS) attacks. Unlike most existing studies that assume a unified attack model across all inter-vehicle communication channels, we propose an asynchronous, distributed DoS attack strategy targeting individual communication links. Specifically, we develop a resilient distributed observer capable of withstanding multi-channel asynchronous DoS attacks. This observer simultaneously provides both specific secure state estimation and output tracking references for each vehicle by introducing the concept of channel-dependent decay rates. Building upon the estimated information, we introduce a novel hybrid policy learning algorithm that combines off-policy and on-policy learning mechanisms. This hybrid approach enables data-driven derivation of decentralized formation control policies while overcoming key limitations of traditional methods, including the requirement for initial stabilizing policies and limitations in dynamic optimization capabilities. Finally, numerical simulations of networked multi-vehicle systems demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed methodology.

title: Enhanced Masking-differential Prompting (MDP): Defending Backdoor Attacks for Pre-trained Language Models under Few-shot Learning
authors: Xingwei Zhong, Kar Wai Fok, Vrizlynn L. L. Thing
abstract: Pre-trained language models (PLMs) have gained significant attention in natural language processing (NLP) area recently. While providing notable benefits, PLMs are still vulnerable to security threats, such as backdoor attacks. In particular, the output of the backdoored PLMs can be manipulated by specific triggers in inputs. The traditional fine–tuning defense methods, which can only effectively mitigate the backdoor attack with the full dataset, become impractical. Therefore, the development of the defense method under the prompt–based, few-shot learning is necessary. In this paper, we propose two methods to enhance the existing defense method, masking–differential prompting (MDP), designed for the prompt-based paradigm under the few–shot learning. When the distribution of the anchor set information approaches zero (i.e., exhibits insufficient density), the Kullback–Leibler (KL) divergence tends to infinity. To mitigate this issue, we adopt the Jensen–Shannon (JS) divergence, which remains finite and is able to more effectively exploit the anchor set information. Furthermore, the conventional manual threshold selection method (the ROC curve (AUC)) typically requires substantial computational resources. To address this limitation, we propose an adaptive threshold method to search for the threshold automatically based on the false rejection rate (FRR) allowance to overcome the high–cost manual threshold search method. Evaluation results demonstrate our proposed method can achieve better defending performance against all the typical backdoor attacks on benchmark datasets of the text classification and generation tasks.

title: Decoding of Intuitive Motor Imagery Paradigm Based on Frequency-Band Double-Branch Network
authors: Lizhi Pan, Diyi Liu, Jinhua Li, Jianmin Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: Motor imagery (MI) based brain-computer interfaces hold significant promise in assistive control and rehabilitation applications. However, conventional paradigms face critical limitations: multi-dimensional MI paradigms based on spatial separability suffer from non-intuitive control mechanisms and high user learning costs, while unilateral limb MI paradigms exhibit limited classification accuracy, failing to satisfy practical requirements. To address these challenges, this study proposes an intuitive MI paradigm that integrates the spatial separability of neural activity in limbs. The proposed paradigm includes four distinct MI movements: left hand abduction (leftward movement), right hand abduction (rightward movement), bilateral upper limb elevation, and bilateral upper limb depression. Ten subjects were recruited for data collection. A frequency-band double-branch network (FBDBNet) was developed to enhance decoding performance, which is a hybrid architecture combining multi-frequency band segmentation, double-branch (spatiotemporal and time-frequency) feature extraction, and a one-dimensional channel attention mechanism. Comparative analysis demonstrated that FBDBNet can achieve superior classification accuracy (p<0.05, Wilcoxon signed rank test) compared to existing advanced models, significantly improving MI recognition efficiency. In addition, the time-frequency characteristics of the collected data were analyzed to validate the novel paradigm. This investigation provides foundations for advancing brain-computer interface technology toward broader applications in neurorehabilitation and control.

title: Insider Threat Detection Using GCN and Bi-LSTM with Explicit and Implicit Graph Representations
authors: Rahul Yumlembam, Biju Issac, Seibu Mary Jacob, Longzhi Yang, Deepa Krishnan
abstract: Insider threat detection (ITD) remains a significant challenge in cybersecurity due to the concealed nature of malicious activities by trusted insiders. This paper introduces a novel post-hoc ITD framework that enhances detection capabilities by integrating explicit and implicit graph structures with a temporal component to analyse user behaviour effectively. We construct an explicit graph using predefined rules that capture user activities within an organisation’s network, providing insights into explicit relationships between actions. To address potential noise and sub-optimality in the explicit graph, we complement it with an implicit graph derived from feature similarities using the Gumbel-softmax trick, which refines the structure by leveraging underlying patterns. Both graphs are processed through separate Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) to produce node embeddings, which are then concatenated and refined using an attention mechanism to emphasise critical features for threat detection. These refined embeddings are subsequently fed into a bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) network to capture the temporal dynamics of user behaviour. The model flags activities as anomalous if their probability scores fall below a predefined threshold. Extensive evaluations on two CERT datasets, r5.2 and r6.2, demonstrate that our framework significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods. On the r5.2 dataset, our model achieves an Area Under the Curve (AUC) of 98.62, a perfect Detection Rate (DR) of 100%, and a low False Positive Rate (FPR) of 0.05. For the more challenging r6.2 dataset, the model achieves an AUC of 88.48, a DR of 80.15%, and an FPR of 0.15. These results illustrate that combining explicit and implicit graph representations, along with advanced sequential modelling, leads to a robust ITD solution capable of effectively distinguishing between normal and abnormal activities, even in complex scenarios.

title: MambaJSCC: Adaptive Deep Joint Source-Channel Coding with Generalized State Space Model
authors: Tong Wu, Zhiyong Chen, Meixia Tao, Yaping Sun, Xiaodong Xu, Wenjun Zhang, Ping Zhang
abstract: Lightweight and efficient neural network models for deep joint source-channel coding (JSCC) are crucial for semantic communications. In this paper, we propose a novel JSCC architecture, named MambaJSCC, that achieves great performance with low computational and parameter overhead. MambaJSCC utilizes the visual state space model with channel adaptation (VSSM-CA) blocks as its backbone for transmitting images over wireless channels, where the VSSM-CA primarily consists of the generalized state space models (GSSM) and the zero-parameter, zero-computational channel adaptation method (CSI-ReST). We design the GSSM module, leveraging reversible matrix transformations to express generalized scan expanding operations, and theoretically prove that two GSSM modules can effectively capture global information. We discover that GSSM inherently possesses the ability to adapt to channels, a form of endogenous intelligence. Based on this, we design the CSI-ReST method, which injects channel state information (CSI) into the initial state of GSSM to utilize its native response, and into the residual state to mitigate CSI forgetting, enabling effective channel adaptation without introducing additional computational and parameter overhead. Experimental results on different devices, including IoT device JETSON AGX ORIN, show that MambaJSCC not only outperforms existing JSCC methods (e.g., SwinJSCC) across various scenarios but also significantly reduces parameter size, computational overhead, and inference delay. We have released our code and pre-trained models at https://github.com/Wireless3C-SJTU/MambaJSCC, allowing full reproduction of our results.

title: Trajectory Planning in Narrow Environments by Integrating Enhanced Target-Tree and Hybrid A* for Automated Parking Systems_supp2-3642158.mp4
authors: Ge Guo - SENIOR EDITOR
abstract: This article proposes a novel automated parking trajectory planning algorithm for automated parking systems (APSs) based on the enhanced target-tree and hybrid A* to address parking challenges in narrow environments. Firstly, the node cost function of hybrid A* is improved with a series of penalties to optimize the generation of smoother parking paths, specifically targeting vehicle direction, turning, and heading constraints. Secondly, to streamline planning time and complexity in narrow spaces, one parking target in hybrid A* is substituted with a set of reverse parking paths, i.e., target-tree; concurrently, the issue of curvature discontinuity in the original target-tree is addressed using a cubic parabola method. Thirdly, the optimal node for the shortest maneuvering time path is selected from the predefined obstacle-avoided target-tree, through which the improved hybrid A* and target-tree are smoothly integrated to find shorter paths in less time. Finally, based on both simulation and real-world experiments, the feasibility and effectiveness of our algorithm are validated; meanwhile, our algorithm is also superior to hybrid A* variants and other algorithms, as it enables more efficient and rapid acquisition of the shortest continuous curvature paths while achieving higher success rates in APSs.

title: Joint Design for IRS-Assisted Integrated Radar and Communication Systems: Multi-Target Detection and Multi-User Interference Management
authors: Junhui Qian, Zhuoran Sun, Yuhang He, Xin Zhang, Zhengru Fang, Jingjing Wang, Chunxiao Jiang
abstract: This paper considers a passive intelligent reflecting surface (IRS)-assisted integrated radar and communication system for multi-target detection and multi-user communications. To balance the communication and sensing performance, we propose an alternating optimization algorithm to optimize the worst-case weighted sum of the radar waveform minimum mean square error (MSE) and Multiuser interference (MUI) in Communication, under the spectrum compatibility and power constraints. The proposed algorithm utilizes a novel Tchebycheff optimization framework that decomposes the multi-objective optimization problem into three subproblems by optimizing the radar transmitted sequences, communication transmitted sequences, and IRS phase configuration. We propose an alternating optimization algorithm which incorporates alternating direction penalty method (ADPM) and element-wise block coordinate descent (E-BCD) frameworks to efficiently solve the optimization problem. Extensive numerical simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, demonstrating significant performance improvements in both minimizing radar MSE and communication MUI and better convergence speed.

title: A High-Stability Real-Time Simulation Model for DC–AC Power Electronic Converters and Digital Twin Applications
authors: Mingwang Xu, Wei Gu, Keyan Liu, Fei Zhang, Wei Liu
abstract: Real-time simulation (RTS) of large-scale power electronic converter systems is often hindered by the heavy computational burden associated with high-dimensional, time-varying matrices. Digital twin (DT) technology, as an extension of RTS, enables continuous system monitoring and optimization throughout the lifecycle, offering a more accurate representation of real-world dynamics. In this article, an RTS model for power electronic converters that guarantees high stability is proposed. Besides, a DT platform is developed to validate the RTS model, integrating a physical controller, a three-phase dc–ac power electronic converter prototype, and high-speed I/O interfaces on RT-LAB. The proposed model ensures high stability, featuring without interface time delay, constant admittance matrices, and low-dimensional nodes, offering significant advantages over existing models. Embedded within the DT platform for application, the model enables efficient and reliable digital replication of the physical power electronic converter. Comprehensive RTS and DT experiments across multiple scenarios validate its superior dynamic performance and accuracy.

title: Integrating metal-hydride and gas-detector for tritium gas detection
authors: Matthew Van Zile, Jacob Sklebar, Minjung Kim, Anne C. Co, Shang Zhai, Praneeth Kandlakunta, L. Raymond Cao
abstract: Detection of trace amounts of environmental tritium is a challenging problem, driving the need for field-deployable systems that offer high sensitivity, selectivity, and minimal false positives. We present a technique for high-sensitivity, high-selectivity tritium measurement, which integrates metal-hydride and gas-detector concepts into a compact field-deployable tritium sensor. A hydrogen-storage metal embedded in a gas proportional counter selectively absorbs protium (<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>H) / tritium (³H) which are subsequently released into the counter volume with a reduced radiation background. Ionizations induced by ³H beta particles are then measured in proportional counting mode achieving high detection efficiency. Preliminary studies conducted with palladium (Pd) thin films coated on stainless-steel substrates demonstrated ³H absorption and metal-tritide formation, followed by ³H desorption upon heating the metal-tritide. These processes were confirmed using activity concentrations measured by a commercial tritium monitor and pulse height spectra acquired from a custom-built detector.

title: Joint Power Allocation and Reflecting-Element Activation for Energy Efficiency Maximization in IRS-Aided Communications Under CSI Uncertainty
authors: Christos N. Efrem, Ioannis Krikidis
abstract: We study the joint power allocation and reflecting-element (RE) activation to maximize the energy efficiency (EE) in communication systems assisted by an intelligent reflecting surface (IRS), taking into account imperfections in channel state information (CSI). The robust optimization problem is mixed-integer, i.e., the optimization variables are continuous (transmit power) and discrete (binary states of REs). In order to solve this challenging problem we develop two algorithms. The first one is an alternating optimization (AO) method that attains a suboptimal solution with low complexity, based on the Lambert W function and a dynamic programming (DP) algorithm. The second one is a branch-and-bound (B&B) method that uses AO as its subroutine and is formally guaranteed to achieve a globally optimal solution. Both algorithms do not require any external optimization solver for their implementation. Furthermore, numerical results show that the proposed algorithms outperform the baseline schemes, AO achieves near-optimal performance in most cases, and B&B has low computational complexity on average.

title: Local Community Detection in Complex Networks: A Brief Survey and an Algorithm Based on Identifying High-quality Core Region
authors: Qianqian Cai, Tong Wang, Mali Xing, Yanyan Ye, Minyue Fu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Community detection is capable of uncovering the inherent structure and functional organization within complex networks by analyzing multi-scale topological features. According to the brief survey, local detection methods demonstrate notable strengths, but challenges persist in selecting suitable seeds, identifying community cores, and precisely extending communities. Therefore, in this paper, a local community detection algorithm based on identifying high-quality core region is proposed. Specifically, at the seed selection stage, a core cohesiveness index is constructed to quantify the node importance, with two-step filtering strategy implemented to refine the selection of suitable seeds. After that, a hierarchical affinity evaluation mechanism is proposed on the basis of node-core affinity values to ensure the formation of high-quality core region (i.e., high-quality initial community). Community extension is then achieved by using the enhanced objective function combined with an incremental update strategy, it preserves structural cohesion and reduces computational costs. Finally, the membership assignments of the remaining nodes will be further processed through community optimization to refine community boundaries. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed algorithm outperforms other community detection algorithms with relatively low time complexities across multi-scale real-world and synthetic networks.

title: Nanosecond Laser Damage Morphology in Silica Gratings: A Thermal Stress Analysis
authors: Yuan Li, Guoliang Yang, Junhong Su
abstract: The laser-irradiated grating exhibits a unique damage morphology, and its surface geometry and period distribution significantly affect the laser-induced damage threshold (LIDT). Understanding the formation mechanism of this damage morphology can help in achieving higher LIDT gratings. The laser-induced damage threshold (LIDT) of the grating was measured to be 15.3 J/cm² under 1064 nm, 10 ns pulsed laser irradiation according to the ISO 21254 standard. Through finite element analysis, we simulated the ensuing temperature and thermal stress fields. The results identify interfacial thermal stress as the primary driver of damage. The model qualitatively reproduces the characteristic hexagonal damage morphology observed in experiments, revealing a thermo-mechanical shaping process. These findings provide critical insight into the damage evolution in nanostructured surfaces and offer guidance for the design of high-LIDT optical gratings.

title: Closed-Loop Probabilistic Forecasting Method of Short-Term Spatial Load Considering Corrupted Data and Field Verification
authors: Siyi Wang, Wanxing Sheng, Yuwei Shang, Qing Duan, Haotian Ma, Shuning Wu
abstract: The rapid development of flexible load technologies brings new challenges to short-term spatial load forecasting (SSLF) in distribution networks (DNs). Conventionally, as an open-loop method, SSLF is unable to dynamically improve the forecast results. However, the nonstationary and volatility features of loads reduce the accuracy of the SSLF, the errors caused by load data loss and distortion further reduce the robustness of the forecasting. In this paper, we propose a closed-loop probabilistic forecasting method for the SSLF by integrating the modified Spatio-Temporal Graph Convolutional network (ST-GCN) and the statistical load baseline profile (SLBP). The modified ST-GCN consists of GCN-Gate Recurrent Unit (GCN-GRU) and GCN in parallel to simultaneously learn the spatio-temporal correlation of loads. To capture the uncertainty of the SSLF, the concrete dropout enabled Bayesian neural networks are applied. The SLBP, which is calculated by statistical method, is used to extract the periodicity of the load and mitigate the impact caused by corrupted data. The closed-loop forecasting architecture is devised to integrate the modified ST-GCN and SLBP by the dynamic clustering technique, to in turn improve the accuracy and the robustness of the forecasting results. Numerical tests are conducted using the real load data of DNs in China. Test results confirmed the superiority of the proposed method.

title: Ori-YOLO: Detection of Astronaut Body Parts on the Space Station Based on Orientation-Invariant Convolution
authors: Haoan Liu, Xianfeng Cheng, Zhaojie Ju, Qing Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: The detection of astronaut body parts on the space station is of great significance for astronaut behavior safety monitoring, state assessment, and interaction optimization. It is a key technology for improving mission efficiency and ensuring astronaut safety. However, there are two major challenges in achieving high-precision astronaut body part detection in microgravity environments: first, there is a lack of largescale, well-annotated dedicated datasets; second, astronauts in microgravity environments lack fixed directional orientation, which increases detection difficulty. To address them, we have constructed the first space station astronaut body part detection dataset, AstroBodyParts, which includes 10,048 images and 67,180 annotation boxes, covering fine-grained body part classifications and hierarchical relationship annotations, providing important data support for future research. Additionally, we have proposed a novel baseline method, Ori-YOLO, which is an improvement based on YOLOv5. By introducing orientation-invariant convolution and a spatial dimension auto-alignment module, the model's ability to model rotating targets is enhanced, making it particularly suitable for microgravity environments. Our method effectively solves the complex problems in microgravity and achieves end-to-end astronaut body part detection. Both the codes and dataset are publicly available (https://github.com/saber778899/Ori-YOLO).

title: Meta-Operators for All-Optical Image Processing
authors: L. Yu, H. J. Singh, J. Pietilä, H. Caglayan
abstract: All-optical image processing enables ultrafast, energy-efficient computation by exploiting the parallelism of light. However, existing approaches often rely on bulky optics or are limited to single operations. We present a metasurface-based platform-meta-operators-that performs arbitrary image transformations in a compact, passive format. By integrating double-phase encoding and polarization multiplexing, we realize diverse analog operations including first- and second-order differentiation, cross-correlation, and high-fidelity 3D holography, all at visible wavelengths. This scalable design establishes a versatile framework for real-time optical computing, intelligent vision systems, and compact volumetric displays.

title: Photonic Ising Machine Based on Second Harmonic Generation
authors: Wujie Fu, Xiaodong Shi, Lei Shi, Di Zhu, Aaron Danner
abstract: Photonic Ising machines show strong potential for solving hard optimization problems, but integrated all-optical embedding remains challenging. We demonstrate an on-chip nonlinear Ising activation function based on second-harmonic generation in periodically poled lithium niobate nanophotonic waveguides, enabling efficient and reliable Ising optimization for photonic computing.

title: Individual Rate-Guaranteed Noma/Oma Switching Mechanism and Multi-Resource Allocation Optimization for Sipm-Based Vlc Systems
authors: Feiyu Jiao, Yansong Du, Yuting Zhou, Yuyu Wang, Yuxuan Liu, Bangyao Wang, Jian Song, Xun Guan
abstract: This paper investigates the nonlinearity-induced performance degradation and proposes an individual rateguaranteed adaptive NOMA/OMA switching mechanism for SiPM-based VLC systems. Besides, a two-stage resource allocation optimization strategy is designed for achieving Pareto-optimal trade-off between sum rate and transmission coverage ratio.

title: Thermal Crosstalk in a 6×6 Photonic Multiplier
authors: Anagha Gayathri, Jayaharish R, GopalaKrishnan, Gao Yuan, Aaron Danner, Anil Prabhakar
abstract: The paper discusses the detailed characterization of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 6$</tex> Photonic Integrated Circuit (PIC) based on the Clements mesh architecture by evaluating the performance of thermal phase shifters and the overall optical response. Furthermore, we study the effect of thermal cross talk and fabrication-induced errors in the chip.

title: The Impact of AI-Based Personalization Services on Customer Experience, Customer Satisfaction, and Customer Loyalty in E-Commerce
authors: Felix Yeriko, Leo Andri Yulius Caesar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: This study examines the impact of AI-based personalization services on Customer Experience (CX), Customer Satisfaction (CS), and Customer Loyalty (CL) in e-commerce. The increasing adoption of AI in this sector-through tools such as chatbots, recommendation systems, and virtual assistants-is transforming how businesses communicate with consumers. This paper highlights how these AI-powered services enhance consumer experience, leading to greater satisfaction and loyalty. Using Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) with Partial Least Squares (PLS) as the analytical approach, the study demonstrates that AI personalization has statistically significant effects on CX, which in turn directly influence both CS and CL. The findings further indicate that AI personalization fosters customer stickiness and long-term loyalty through effective and engaging interactions. This research provides valuable insights for e-commerce platforms in optimizing the ethical application of AI to strengthen consumer engagement and loyalty.

title: Ln-Sin Hybrid Microring Resonators for Nonlinear Applications
authors: Md Saiful Islam Sumon, Samir Ghosh, Artem S. Vorobev, Nicola Maraviglia, Fatih Bilge Atar, Ganga Chinna Rao Devarapu, Chiranjeevi Maddi, Imad I. Faruque, Sarvagya Dwivedi, Robert Bowman, Liam O'Faolain, Brian Corbett, Shamsul Arafin
abstract: We present transfer-printed LN-SiN hybrid racetrack microring resonators for nonlinear photonic applications. As a demonstration, green light is generated via frequency conversion using modal phase matching. Large-area LN transfer printing forms the hybrid platform, enabling nonlinear interactions for scalable, CMOS-compatible applications.

title: Design of a circularly polarized antenna with enhanced wide beam
authors: Chengjun Xiao, Nengwu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper introduces a circularly polarized (CP) antenna, which is composed of two crossed dipoles. A Bow-tie resonator was used to achieve an wide impedance matching bandwidth of 2.6GHz to 2.9GHz. Additionally, the vertical additional metal sheets at the ends of the resonators and the four vertical ground monopoles arranged around the active resonators were used to broaden the half-power beamwidth of the antenna, ensuring a good circular polarization operation state in an angle range of 98°. The gain pattern was corrected by individually adjusting the lengths of each vertical ground monopole, resulting in a 3dB axial ratio beamwidth of 109° and a coverage of the half-power beamwidth. The wide beamwidth circular polarization performance and gain of this antenna meet the requirements of applications such as satellite communication.

title: Structures and Microwave-Absorbing Properties of Graphene Aerogels
authors: Wang Maotang, Wang Shuo, Chen Gang, Zhao Lei
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: With the rising concerns of electromagnetic pollution, the development of lightweight and broadband microwave absorbing materials has become crucial. In this study, the reduced graphene oxide (rGO) aerogels were synthesized using graphene oxides as the precursor. The aerogel exhibited an ultralow density of 0.016 g/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, featuring a porous and wrinkled 3D structure that effectively prolonged the propagation path of electromagnetic waves and enhanced energy dissipation. Electromagnetic absorption tests showed that the aerogel achieved a minimum reflection loss (RL) of -30.51 dB with the absorption band ranging from 7.17 to 9.19 GHz at a thickness of 3.5 mm. When the thickness decreased to 2.5 mm, the effective absorption bandwidth (EAB) reached 7.21 GHz. These results demonstrated that the as-prepared rGO aerogels offered twofold advantages of ultralightweight and broadband absorption, making them promising candidates for microwave absorption applications.

title: 2D Engineering Drawing Information Detection Based on Improved RT-DETR
authors: Zhongpeng Li, Xinyan Lu, He Liu, Guanghui Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: D engineering drawings play an irreplaceable role in mechanical manufacturing area. Engineers need to read such drawings and extract information consistently for cost analysis, quality control, design optimization and some other work. To automate this extracting process while ensuring both efficiency and accuracy, this paper proposes an improved model based on RT-DETR for information detection in 2D drawings. First, a backbone network combining partial convolution (PConv) with efficient multi-scale attention (EMA) is used to reduce model parameters and obtain more detailed image features. Second, deformable attention is used to take the place of multi-head attention in the AIFI of original model to improve recognition accuracy for objects of different sizes. The experiment results show that improved RT-DETR increases precision by $6.43 \%$, increases recall by $14.26 \%$, increase mAP @ 50 by $13.35 \%$ compared to the base model, while requiring less inference time compared to other models. The algorithm demonstrates faster arithmetic speed and higher precision in the real-time detection of 2D engineering drawings.

title: Symmetry-Protected Dual Bound States in Continuum Metasurfaces for Terahertz Photonic Applications
authors: Qun Ren, Zhiyi Cheng, Qiwen Wu, Minxue Wang, Yan Chen, Kaiwen Zou, Yongshan Liang, Munan Wang, Sheng Jia, Hao Huang, Xiuyu Wang, Jianquan Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel Symmetry-Protected Dual Bound States in Continuum (BIC) Metasurface for advanced optical computing applications. The proposed architecture simultaneously supports two distinct symmetry-protected quasi-BICs, generating multiple high-Q resonances that enhance light-matter interactions and electromagnetic field confinement at the nanoscale. Theoretical modeling demonstrates that this dual-BIC structure significantly improves nonlinear optical conversion efficiency while maintaining compact dimensions. The metasurface’s ability to support multiple high-Q resonances enables parallel information processing and multi-channel modulation—critical requirements for next-generation photonic computing systems. We establish the fundamental electromagnetic properties that position this dual-BIC metasurface as a promising platform for integrated optical computing applications.

title: Target Vulnerability Analysis of Radar Position Based on Entropy Weight-TOPSIS Methodology
authors: Bingjie Hu, Mingxue Bi, XinYing Wang, Yan Cheng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: By analyzing the target characteristics of the radar position, the key indicators affecting the target vulnerability of the radar position are identified: radar subarray destruction rate, power supply power loss rate, effective cooling time retention rate, and electronic equipment work efficiency ratio. Taking these four indices as the core of the comprehensive evaluation system, the comprehensive evaluation model of radar position target vulnerability was constructed, and the radar position vulnerability was divided into three grades. A comprehensive evaluation model of radar position target vulnerability was constructed based on the entropy weight-TOPSIS method. Different destruction scenarios were simulated using the Python programming language, and the vulnerability grades derived from the comprehensive evaluation model were compared with the preset vulnerability grades. The simulation results show that the overall accuracy of the comprehensive evaluation model of the entropy weight-TOPSIS method is $96.44 \%$, which proves that the method is feasible.

title: A Monolithically Integrated GaN Comparator with Depletion-Mode Input for Power Converter Applications
authors: Fahd A. Shiwani, Pradeep Chandrasekar, Leonard Shtargot, Séamus O’Driscoll, Kevin G. McCarthy
abstract: The comparator is a vital block in any integrated DC-DC power converter for both control and protection functions. Monolithic GaN HEMT power converters offer superior power switching performance with lower on-resistances and capacitances, however they suffer from poor analog performance due to their lack of complementary devices and poor device mismatch as well as a limited range of devices. This paper presents the design of a depletion-mode input pair based regenerative comparator monolithically integrated on a GaN-on-Si process. This paper aims to investigate and demonstrate the input-referred offset performance of such a comparator. The structure delivers a transistor level simulated 1-σ input-referred offset of 3.6 mV without the use of any offset cancellation techniques. It achieves rising and falling propagation delays of 29 ns and 22 ns, respectively with a 100 mV overdrive and 1 pF load capacitance. The comparator occupies an area of approximately 0.055 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and has a quiescent current consumption of 63 μA.

title: Dynamic Control of Carrier Sense Threshold and Transmission Power in Dense WLAN Deployments
authors: Muhammad Huseen Khan, Mark Davis
abstract: In dense wireless local area networks (WLANs), nodes may experience a higher channel access time due to contention and interference caused by channel sharing among neighboring nodes. To address this challenge, the IEEE 802.11ax standard introduced the overlapping basic service set packet detection (OBSS PD) based spatial reuse (SR) mechanism to increase simultaneous transmissions in the network. However, the performance gain under OBSS PD is uncertain and depends on the network topology. In this paper, we propose an algorithm that dynamically adjusts the Carrier Sense Threshold (CST) and transmission power (TP) of a node based on interference and contention level to minimize the channel access time. We developed a simulator in Python and evaluated the performance of the proposed algorithm using the average number of transmission opportunities, frame error rate (FER) and channel access time under saturated network conditions. Simulation results demonstrate that our algorithm provides consistent performance under different network topologies and reduces the average channel access time by 28.1% and 42.1% compared to the conventional CSMA/CA and the OBSS PD mechanism, respectively.

title: Design and Implementation of a Broadband Balun Using LTCC Technology
authors: Shengping Huang, Jing Meng, Zhi Xu, Kanglong Zhang, Yi-Feng Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper introduces a Marchand Balun structure that employs low-temperature co-fired ceramic (LTCC) technology, which has been meticulously designed, simulated, and fabricated. The experimental results demonstrate a strong correlation with the computer simulation outcomes. The balun is produced using commercially available LTCC processes. Within the frequency range of 367 to 884 MHz, the measured insertion loss is below 1.5 dB, the return loss is greater than 10 dB, the amplitude imbalance is under 0.26 dB, and the phase balance is maintained within 180° ± 7.8°. The overall dimensions are minimized to 2 mm × 1.25 mm × 0.9 mm.

title: Bloch Surface Modes Propagating at the Surface of 1D Photonic Crystals for Label-Free and Fluorescence Detection of Biomarkers in Human Serum
authors: A. Occhicone, A. Sinibaldi, A. Gaganina, F. Michelotti
abstract: We report on biosensors based on Bloch surface modes sustained by 1D photonic crystals. Molecular association is detected both in a label-free manner and by resonant fluorescence excitation/emission of labels.

title: Wideband Circularly Polarized Magneto-Electric Dipole Antenna for Millimeter-Wave Communications
authors: Ting Wu, Chen Zhang, Jian-Zhuang Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper presents a compact magneto-electric (ME) dipole structure-based wideband circularly polarized (CP) antenna for millimeter-wave communication. The antenna introduces a pair of center-symmetric L-shaped radiating strips on the basis of the traditional linearly polarized ME dipole structure, achieving efficient CP radiation characteristics by generating a rotating electric field with a 90° phase difference. A microstrip line feeding structure is adopted, and a center-symmetric matching stub is introduced on the narrow and long coupling slot to efficiently excite the radiating patch. To achieve a wider bandwidth, a parasitic structure is introduced at the top layer, ultimately realizing an Axial ratio (AR) bandwidth of 15.8% (24.37-28.47 GHz). Compared with the traditional CP ME dipole antenna, the AR bandwidth of this design is wider.

title: A Fast Line-Overload Mitigation Scheme via BLS N-1 Predictive Sensitivity Analysis
authors: Chaoyang Lu, Peijie Li, Yude Yang, Chunhua Huang, Caihao Zhai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: Sensitivity analysis methods are widely applied in line overload correction, as they can eliminate overloads without solving complex optimization problems. However, whenever an N-1 contingency occurs in a power system, the node-to-branch sensitivity factors change with the altered topology. Thus, how to quickly solve the new node-to-branch sensitivity factors after an N-1 contingency has become a critical challenge. To address the difficulty of calculating these sensitivities, this paper proposes a sensitivity prediction method between lines and generator outputs based on a Broad Learning System (BLS) model, which enables sensitivity prediction under multiple topologies. Simulations on the IEEE 30-bus system demonstrate that this method can accurately calculate sensitivity values; using these sensitivity values to construct a linear correction model can effectively eliminate line overloads.

title: Wideband Dual-Polarized Filtering Antenna with Wide Out-of-Band Suppression
authors: Ziyang Huang, Zhiyi Liu, Changfei Zhou, Yingsong Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A wideband dual-polarized cross-slot antenna (CSA) with deep out-of-band suppression is initially proposed. By tuning the cross-slot lines to operate at half-wavelength resonance, a radiation null is generated at the low frequency. To improve the selectivity in the upper stopband, four V-shaped slots are etched under the feeding lines, introducing four independently controllable radiation nulls. Without employing any additional filtering circuits, the dual-polarized CSA achieves a wide impedance bandwidth (IMBW) of 1.60-2.95 GHz (59.34%), while maintaining an out-of-band gain lower than -11.4 dBi over 3.20-9.12 GHz (up to 4.01 f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>). For experimental validation, a filtering antenna prototype is fabricated. The measured results show good agreement with the simulations.

title: Securing AI and Agentic Systems in Medical Devices: Methods, Risks, and Defenses
authors: Saurabh Malpure, Rajesh Kanungo, Benjamin R. Loomis, S M Salim Reza
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Integrating AI and agentic systems into medical devices significantly enhances healthcare by enabling autonomous diagnosis, personalized treatment, and real-time monitoring. However, this advancement introduces complex security challenges, including risks related to autonomous decision-making, multi-agent coordination, and AI-specific attacks that can jeopardize patient safety. This whitepaper outlines a framework for securing AI-enabled medical devices, focusing on critical vulnerabilities and risk prioritization, while proposing multi-layered defense strategies based on established cybersecurity principles. It systematically addresses security risks throughout the AI system lifecycle using FDA guidance, EU regulations like GDPR and the AI Act, and the MITRE ATLAS framework. The paper concludes with a case study on implementing this framework in an AWS healthcare AI system, showcasing its practical application.

title: Betel Leaf Disease Classification Using EfficientNet-B7 Architecture With Triplet Attention
authors: Rima Tri Wahyuningrum, Nurul Faizah, Irmalia Suryani Faradisa, Indah Agustien Sirajuddin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Traditional medicine is a medical practice that has been passed down from generation to generation, which uses natural herbal ingredients. In Indonesia, there are various forms of traditional medicine, one of which is the use of betel leaves. Betel leaf is one part of a traditional medicinal plant that is still popular today because it has various benefits in preventing and treating various diseases. One part of the betel plant that is often affected by pest attacks is the leaves. As an alternative, the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) method of EfficientNet B7 architecture and EfficientNet B7 combined with Triplet Attention is used in image classification. Using the EfficientNet B7 architecture, the MBConv architecture which originally used the Squeeze-and-Excitation module was changed to use the Triplet Attention module. In this study, using a dataset of 4000 images that have been divided into four classes, namely Healthy Green betel leaf, Anthracnose Green, Rust Green, Healthy Red. The dataset division is 80% for training data and 20% for testing data. The training data is evaluated by dividing the system performance into training data and validation data using k-fold = 5, learning rate = 0.01, epoch = 50. Based on the trial, the best results using the EfficientNet B7 model combined with Triplet Attention resulted in 70.62% accuracy, 71.60% precision, 70.62% recall and 70.13% F1-Score with a time of 18.11 seconds.

title: A Photographer Guided Framework for Web Image Falsification Detection Using Vision Language Models and Segmentation Tools
authors: Aldi Muhamad Fitrah, Nanang Husin
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: While Multimodal Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems can assess basic caption image consistency, they lack the visual understanding required to detect complex forgeries. This research used a pipeline that combines a ViT-based anomaly triage and a visually grounded dialogue using an LLaVA family VLM with SAM-based masking based on photographer-guided experience. The proposed model integrates the perceptual expertise of a photographer with the analytical power of modern Vision Language Models (VLM) and Segmentation Tools to facilitate an interactive, evidence-based analysis. The data taken from CASIA v2.0 and COVERAGE evaluation shows novice accuracy improving from 48% (unaided) and 55% (basic multimodal) to 85% with the proposed framework. This photographer-guided approach improves the ability of non-experts to detect and articulate image manipulations compared to both unaided analysis and basic automated multimodal methods.

title: Energy Optimization of HESS Integrated DCMG: PSO Based Approach
authors: Sujatha Banka, D. V. Ashok Kumar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy sources, particularly photovoltaic (PV) systems, has accelerated the deployment of DC microgrids (DCMGs) as reliable and efficient energy networks. However, the intermittent nature of renewable generation and the dynamic load variations impose challenges on bus voltage regulation, state-of-charge (SoC) management, and optimal coordination of hybrid energy storage systems (ESS). This paper presents a Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO)-based Energy Management System (EMS) for a 4 bus DCMG comprising PV arrays, batteries, and supercapacitors. The proposed controller dynamically allocates charging and discharging commands among the distributed storage devices to minimize voltage deviation, power mismatch, SoC imbalance, and excessive supercapacitor usage. A detailed simulation study is carried out in MATLAB/Simulink, considering irradiance variations and sudden load changes. Results demonstrate that the PSO-based EMS effectively maintains DC bus voltage stability, ensures real-time power balance, and reduces stress on batteries by optimally utilizing supercapacitors for transient compensation. The proposed method enhances system reliability and extends the lifetime of storage devices, making it a promising solution for next-generation DC microgrids.

title: Low-Cost and High-Efficiency Electromagnetic Near-Field Scanning System Based on AI-Enabled Visual Manipulator
authors: Wenting Liu, Yushi Deng, Zimeng Zeng, Shizhan Jiang, Da Yi, Ming-Chun Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This work proposes a low-cost, high-efficiency electromagnetic near-field scanning system based on a visual robotic arm. The overall expense is reduced by integrating low-cost robotic arm and self-developed printed circuit board (PCB)-basded probe. Besides, with the artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled visual information, the system can take advantage of color recognition technology to quickly locate electromagnetic-sensitive regions, and can automatically plan and reduce the scanning area, thus significantly improve detection efficiency. Experimental results show that the system effectively reduces equipment costs and scanning time while ensuring measurement accuracy, offering a feasible solution for low-cost and high-efficient electromagnetic interference (EMI) diagnosis of highly integrated electronic products.

title: A Pneumatic Bistable Origami Actuator for Robotic Applications
authors: Keyi Zheng, Hao Liu, Changchun Wu, Senyuan Lin, Yunquan Li, Yingtian Li, James Lam, Yonghua Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Origami structures found in nature serve as inspiration for robotic design. Origami-based bistable structures are widely concerned due to high flexibility and programmable deformability. However, current origami bistable robots, obtained by folding flexible material, hardly handle the demanding requirements of high-intensity tasks and different working scenarios. A pneumatic bistable origami actuator (PBOA) is introduced based on a hybrid origami structure combining Miura-ori and Waterbomb patterns, which can be applied in diverse robotic applications using 3D-printed quick couplings. We present the design, fabrication, modeling, and experimental validation of the PBOA. Based on the PBOA, a multimodal gripper is proposed that can passively grasp objects in 0.15 seconds and actively lift targets with 41 times self-weight. By fast altering accessories, a locomotion robot is developed with 0.35 body lengths per second. The actuator exhibits significant potential for applications in scenarios that demand high speed, high strength, and multi-functionality.

title: Hamming Distance Optimization for 16-QAM Symbol Labeling Using GA and SA Algorithms
authors: Limbran Sampebatu, Andani Achmad, Intan Sari Areni
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Symbol labeling optimization in modulation is essential for improving Bit Error Rate (BER) in wireless communication systems, particularly under noise and fading. This study investigates 16-QAM symbol labeling using Genetic Algorithms (GA) and Simulated Annealing (SA), focusing on logical-layer optimization of bit-to-symbol mapping on a fixed constellation, thereby enhancing performance without altering hardware. The optimization objective is to minimize the average Hamming distance (HD) between adjacent symbols to reduce BER in Rayleigh fading channels. Simulation results show that GA achieves an average HD of 1.167, compared to 1.33 for Natural, 1.7 for SA, 2.16 for Random, and 1.00 for Gray mapping achieved. At a BER level of 10-2, Gray reaches this target at approximately 23 dB, GA requires 0.5–1 dB more, SA and Natural require about 2 dB more, and Random is nearly 3 dB worse. These findings confirm that GA and SA provide measurable BER gains over Natural and Random, while closely approaching Gray performance. Overall, this work serves as a proof-of-concept validation of logical-layer mapping optimization as a low-complexity, hardware-compatible enhancement for future 5G/6G systems.

title: Silicon Photonics Enabled Tunable Multi-Band Dual-LFM Waveform Generation
authors: A. Viresh Bhan, B. Vadivukkarasi Jeyaselvan, C. Shankar Kumar Selvaraja
abstract: A photonics-aided generation of multi-band dual linear frequency modulated (LFM) signal with tunable center frequency and reconfigurable bandwidth is proposed and demonstrated using an on-chip silicon-based dual-drive Mach Zehnder modulator (DD-MZM). The proposed approach generates a dual-LFM waveform in multiple microwave frequency bands with a spectral bandwidth of 4 GHz and a maximum center frequency tunable up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 ~ G H z}$</tex>.

title: A 9.2-ENOB, 500MHz-BW VCO-Based ADC with 64GS/s Polyphase Frequency-Digitisation
authors: Zacharie Fetchati, Viet Nguyen, R. Bogdan Staszewski
abstract: This paper introduces a wideband, open-loop, mostly-digital voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO)-based analog-to-digital converter (ADC). A polyphase frequency-to-digital converter (FDC) architecture with 8-channel time-interleaved (TI) phase-sampling is introduced, delivering a high over-sampling ratio (OSR) with an effective sampling rate of 64GS/s. Each sense-amplifier flip-flop (SAFF) operates at 8GS/s and embeds phase-folding to allow the simultaneous sampling of 8 multi-phase VCO outputs by a single FDC unit, minimising power consumption of the digital back-end. A dual-driven transistor/resistor input VCO-tuning topology mitigates harmonic distortions due to the VCO’s nonlinear voltage-to-frequency characteristics. The ADC is implemented in GlobalFoundries 12-nm FinFET and achieves a peak simulated SNDR of 57.2dB, equivalent to an effective number of bits (ENOB) of 9.2 over a 500MHz BW. It consumes 11.52mW from 0.55V digital and 0.7V analog supplies, resulting in state-of-the-art Walden and Schreier FoM of 19.6fJ/c-s and 163.57dB respectively.

title: Small Signal Stability Prediction of Wind Integrated Power Systems Based on NRBO-BLS
authors: Caihao Zhai, Xiaoqing Bai, Yude Yang, Chaoyang Lu, Chunhua Huang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: With the continuous increase of wind power penetration rate in the power system, intermittency and volatility significantly enhance the dynamic uncertainty of the system, posing a threat to system stability. This article proposes a novel multi scenario prediction method based on NRBO-BLS, aiming to accurately predict the minimum damping ratio of the power system under different wind speed conditions. Using node voltage amplitude, phase angle, generator power, load power, and branch power as inputs, and minimum damping ratio as output, construct an NRBO-BLS mapping model of power system operation data and system minimum damping ratio at different wind speeds. Introducing an improved Newton-Raphson-Based Optimizer (NRBO) algorithm to optimize the parameters of Broad learning system (BLS) and improve the generalization ability and accuracy of prediction models in high-dimensional and nonlinear feature spaces; The calculation results show that the proposed method improves the prediction accuracy of the minimum damping ratio of the system.

title: Analog Photonic RF Transport and Front-Ends for High-Capacity Satellites
authors: Metodi Belchovski, Benoit Benazet, Michel Sotom, Simon Rommel
abstract: High-throughput satellites with large-scale mmwave antenna arrays face increased SWaP from RF frontends and coaxial RF signal transport to/from the processing core. We review photonic RF frontend architectures alleviating these issues, show experimental performance evaluations, and discuss their implementation with integrated photonics.

title: Geman-McClure Function Constrained Sparse Beamforming Algorithm
authors: Wanlu Shi, Shaoqing Zhang, Pengjiao Li, Linan Wang, Shuangyu Zhao, Yingsong Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Modern radar systems are increasingly constrained by demands for reduced cost, size, weight, and power consumption, without compromising performance. Sparse array technology, as an innovative approach to sensor deployment, offers the potential to significantly reduce the number of array elements required while maintaining beam performance. This reduction directly translates to lower hardware and software costs, making sparse arrays highly attractive for low-cost defense applications. This paper presents a Geman-McClure function constrained adaptive sparse array beamforming algorithm. The proposed method is evaluated through simulations and compared against existing techniques. Results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm not only reduces overall radar system cost but also achieves comparable or superior performance in key areas relative to traditional arrays.

title: Interference Identification and Mitigation Using Selective Spectral Filtering in a Photonics Radar System
authors: S. M. R. Islam, S. Jhijie, S. Jha, T. D. Subash, M. R. C. Beson, S. Pan, B. Nakarmi
abstract: We introduce a selective spectral filtering technique to separate target, and interference beat signals from the received signal. It reconstructs both interference and the interference-free received signal- achieving 10 dB peak-to-sidelobe level (PSL) and 2 cm range resolution- enabling accurate target detection and interference visualization.

title: Multi-Scale Attentive Fusion with Adaptive Positional Encoding for 3D Object Detection
authors: Changhui Sun, Xiaolan Wang, Qiannan Yi, Jialin Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Monocular depth prediction serves as a critical intermediate module for 3D object detection in complex autonomous driving scenarios, where existing methods suffer from insufficient multi-scale feature fusion and static positional encoding limitations, leading to location perception bias and depth ambiguity. To address this, this paper proposes a 3D object detection framework featuring a hierarchical skip-attention fusion module that achieves adaptive cross-scale feature integration via local window attention to suppress information dilution, combined with a dynamic depth positional encoding mechanism. This mechanism injects spatial embeddings derived from real-time depth predictions to enhance the Transformer’s context perception. These components jointly optimize the 3D detection task, significantly improving spatial localization accuracy. Experiments on the KITTI test set show that, compared to the baseline MonoDETR, our detector achieves a relative improvement of $\mathbf{0. 4 9 \%}$ in AP3D and $\mathbf{1. 1 2 \%}$ in APBEV at medium difficulty, while ablation studies validate the effectiveness of the proposed fusion and encoding strategies. This work provides an innovative approach for multi-scale feature fusion and geometricaware localization in autonomous driving systems.

title: Passive Teleoperation with an Enhanced Compliance Model for Compliance-Position Equilibrium in Dynamic Push-Pull Tasks
authors: Hao Zhou, Jinguo Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Although teleoperation systems demonstrate potential in managing uncertainties during dynamic push-pull tasks, performance remains constrained due to latency effects and environmental stochasticity. While compliance control strategies mitigate operational risks, two primary challenges emerge: (i) Integration-achieving equilibrium between human teleoperation commands and compliant behaviors; (ii) Passivity-preventing human commands from violating system's passivity. To resolve these challenges, we present a passivityguaranteed teleoperation method incorporating an enhanced compliance model. Integration is managed by the enhanced compliance model employing vector superposition of scaled human commands and interaction force, replacing the conventional force-only compliance model. Passivity is preserved by equipping the enhanced compliance model with an energy tank and designing a dynamic energy regulation strategy: The tank allocates energy to facilitate human command integration while recycling damping energy from the enhanced compliance model for tank replenishment. Experimental validation through boxpushing tasks under both quasi-static and dynamic conditions demonstrates our method's superior position-compliance coordination and disturbance rejection capabilities compared with direct teleoperation approaches.

title: Optimization of 1D Photonic Crystal Biosensor for Hemoglobin Based Anemia Detection
authors: Smruti M, Swastika S, Divya S, Venkateswaran N, Allwyn S. Rajamani
abstract: Conventional anemia diagnostics such as complete blood count tests are invasive, time-consuming, and costly. This study proposes a one-dimensional photonic crystal biosensor for real-time, non-invasive anemia detection by monitoring refractive index shifts caused by hemoglobin level changes. The sensor is modeled using the Finite Element Method (FEM) in COMSOL Multiphysics and the Transfer Matrix Method in MATLAB to analyze transmittance spectra. FEM provides higher precision for complex geometries. The important design parameters include the material of choice, the thickness of layer and the defect layers features that makes the sensor suitable for diagnostic applications.

title: Design and Modelling of a One-Dimensional Photonic Crystal Biosensor for the Identification of Blood Components and Blood Infections
authors: Divya Sampath, Venkateswaran N
abstract: Septicemia (blood infections) is a serious bloodstream infection that causes widespread inflammation in organs and needs early detection. In this paper, we propose a one-dimensional photonic crystal (1DPhC) biosensor made of alternating <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{T i O}_{\mathrm{2}} / \text{S i O}_{\mathrm{2}}$</tex> layers containing an embedded defect layer for the early diagnosis of blood infections. The design was scaled to work in the visible range <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(400-700 ~\text{nm})$</tex> by matching the layer thicknesses to achieve quarter-wave resonance at 550 nm. During Septicemia, the optical properties of blood cells change and therefore serve as a biophysical biomarker to monitor treatment response or disease progression. Transmission spectrum from the Transfer Matrix Method (TMM) in MATLAB reveals sharp resonant mode shifts between healthy and infected states.

title: The 6-Wheeled Active-Caster-Type Omnidirectional Mobile Robot with Separation and Reconfiguration Function*
authors: Kento Nakajima, Kenta Nagano, Masayoshi Wada
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: This paper presents a noble large scale omnidirectional vehicle with 6 active-caster wheels. The omnidirectional vehicle can be divided into three parts, front, mid and rear. The front and rear parts have individual control and drive system which enables these parts to move as a omnidirectional vehicle. These three parts can dock together to carry large and heavy loads such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 0 - 2 0 0 0} \mathbf{~ k g}$</tex>. Moreover, the vehicle has a reconfiguration function where the wheel layout can be changed for some purpose such as maintaining the vehicle static stability. In this paper, the design, modeling and control of the proposed omnidirectional vehicle will be described.

title: Research on Frequency Response Analysis of Disk Space Variation Faults in Transformer Windings
authors: Xiaoxiao Luo, Mingxing Li, Qian Wang, Qianbo Xiao, Yingkai Long, Siquan Li, Suman Peng, Haishan Zheng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Frequency Response Analysis (FRA) is a core technology for diagnosing mechanical faults in transformer windings, and the accuracy of its modeling directly determines the reliability of fault identification. In this paper, a double trapezoidal network is adopted as the high-frequency response modeling framework for transformer windings, and the Finite Element Method (FEM) is used to achieve high-precision extraction of circuit parameters (resistance R, inductance L, capacitance C). Emphasis is placed on the simulation of Disk Space Variation (DSV) faults and the analysis of FRA characteristics. The research shows that the double trapezoidal network can effectively reproduce the high-frequency distributed parameter effect of windings; the finite element method realizes the cross-scale conversion of “structure-field-electrical” parameters through solving Maxwell’s equations. In DSV faults, capacitance parameters play a dominant role, and the faults mainly affect the middle frequency band of the FRA curve. With the deepening of fault severity, the curve in the frequency band around 100kHz and 300kHz shows a downward-leftward shift trend, while there is no significant regularity in the FRA curve under different short-circuit positions. The results of this paper provide theoretical support and data basis for the FRA diagnosis of DSV faults in transformer windings.

title: A New Approach for 2D Microwave Imaging Based on ODIL
authors: Tai Xu, Xue Wang, Tao Shan
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this work, we propose a new approach for 2D microwave imaging based on optimizing a discrete loss framework. The framework of optimizing a discrete loss (ODIL) transforms the inverse scattering problem into an optimization problem, enabling accurate reconstruction by leveraging the method of moments (MoM) to solve volume integral equations with high precision. Numerical results further validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, demonstrating superior performance compared to the conventional non-iterative back-propagation method.

title: Single-Output InAs Quantum Dot DFB Laser Using Integrated MMIR for Photonic Applications
authors: F. Albeladi, S. Gillgrass, N. Albittar, S. Power, B. Salmond, C. P. Allford, P. M. Smowton
abstract: We present monolithically integrated InAs-QD DFB lasers with a high-reflectivity multimode interference reflector (MMIR) for single-facet emission. The devices demonstrate stable single-mode operation at 1310 nm with high SMSR in range of 46 dB, validating suitability for scalable photonic integrated circuit applications.

title: Application of Lexicon Based Method and Naïve Bayes Classifier Algorithm in Twitter-Based Tapera Sentiment Analysis
authors: Fitri Mintarsih, Hilmi Mulya Setiawan, Herlino Nanang, Hendra Bayu Suseno, Faraditya Praba Saputrie, Yuditha Ichsani
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: This study aims to analyze public sentiment towards TAPERA using the Lexicon Based method and the Naive Bayes algorithm as a machine learning approach. Social media, such as Twitter, has become the main platform for the public to voice opinions regarding public policies, including the Tabungan Perumahan Rakyat (TAPERA). This study analyzes public sentiment towards TAPERA using the Lexicon-Based method and the Naive Bayes algorithm. The lexicon-based textblob method is used to detect sentiment based on words that appear in the text by calculating sentiment polarity. The research dataset consists of 2559 tweets, which were crawled using tweet-harvest from social media Twitter (X) which is divided into 81 positive data, 2456 neutral data, and 22 negative data, and processed through preprocessing stages, such as: Cleaning, Normalize, Stopwords Removal, Tokenize, Stemming. Meanwhile, the Naive Bayes algorithm is used to classify sentiment data into positive, negative, and neutral categories based on probability. The Naïve Bayes algorithm produces a weighted average of: 96% accuracy, 96% precision, 96% recall, and 96% F1 score.

title: Enhancing Performance and Scalability in Containerised Environments
authors: James Mahoney, Ruairi O’Reilly
abstract: Containerisation is a software deployment method that packages all necessary components needed to run an application, such as code, runtime, libraries, and configuration, in a self-contained unit called a container. Containers are lightweight and scalable and enable fast deployment. As a result, containers are commonly employed in microservices architectures. However, microservice architectures add extra layers of complexity to managing resource allocation. Cloud orchestration platforms are abstracted further, which can lead to an over-reliance on monitoring sub-optimal metrics such as CPU utilisation. Identifying and mitigating thread pool starvation in containerised environments is an area of resource allocation and scaling that has been overlooked in the literature. Thread pool starvation occurs when the number of tasks queued in a thread pool’s waiting state exceeds the processing capacity of the pool. If thread pool starvation persists, a cascade event occurs, leading to a chain reaction that results in degraded performance until the system enters a state of unresponsiveness. This work explores the question: Can Thread Pool Starvation Detection Lead to Enhanced Performance and Scalability in Containerised Environmentsƒ and suggests that detecting thread pool starvation early and scaling accordingly can significantly improve system performance and scalability. This work contributes to system architecture design by providing empirical insights into application-level monitoring metrics and pragmatic strategies for identifying and mitigating thread pool starvation.
