title: Optical Characterization of Oral Tissues Using High Wavenumber Raman Spectroscopy
authors: Elumalai Brindha, Ramu Rajasekaran, Malini Madhavan, Ganesan Bharanidharan, Prakasarao Aruna, Singaravelu Ganesan
abstract: Recent years much attention has been gained towards the Raman spectroscopic characterization of samples in the High wavenumber (HWVN) region (2600-3800 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>) as it provides intense Raman signal with excellent bio-molecular and biochemical information from cells and tissues with reduced tissue auto-fluorescence [1]– [4]. Hence, an attempt was made to study the diagnostic potentiality of Highwavenumber Raman spectroscopic characterization of oral tissue samples of normal subjects, premalignant and malignant patients. In the HWVN region, oral tissue samples show significant differences between the three groups due to the presence of various vibrational modes of lipids, proteins as well as fatty acids in the region 2600-3000 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>. [4]–[5] Above 3000 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>, Raman peaks were observed due to unsaturated =CH, CH stretching vibrations and OH stretching modes of water molecules [6]–[7]. To find the statistical efficacy of the present technique in the high wavenumber region, PC-LDA [3] was employed to differentiate the oral premalignant and malignant patients from normal conditions and appreciable results were achieved.

title: The Marriage of Neurotechnologies and Artificial Intelligence: Ethical, regulatory, and technological aspects
authors: Carlo Chiurco, Andrea Favaro, Silvia Francesca Storti, Lorenza Brusini, Ahmed M. Salih, Ilaria Boscolo Galazzo, Sergey Plis, Gloria Menegaz
abstract: The dual concepts of neurotechnology and artificial intelligence (AI) form an intriguing but also potentially explosive mixture because of its many ethical and legal implications. The advent of AI and the progress in neurotechnologies are reshaping the landscape not only in all scientific fields but also in everyday life both individually and collectively, ushering in a new era where the centrality, integrity and identity of humans is no longer a fact. Such tumultuous progress has implications at all levels, individual, societal, economical and political. Without the pretension of exploring the whole set of relevant aspects, we aim at providing a multi-disciplinary view on the main ethical, legal and societal issues stemming from neurotechnology and AI, by assessing them using keywords like trustworthiness, fairness, awareness, security, and privacy. In this paper, we propose an overview on the current scenario, taking a philosophical perspective in the light of ethics, and boiling it down to aspects closely related to the technological developments and the regulatory measures that are currently in-place and called for.

title: Trajectory Control of ROV Based on Finite-Time Extended Observer
authors: Dawei Yang, Feng Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: A finite-time extended state observer-based sliding mode controller is introduced for managing trajectory planning and control of a six-degree-of-freedom (6-DOF) ROV subject to underwater flow disturbances. A simplified 6-DOF mathematical model of the ROV, incorporating water flow effects, is established. A finite-time convergent extended state observer is employed to relax the constraints on the variation rate of the water flow velocity, enabling accurate estimation of lumped disturbances. Leveraging this observer, a sliding mode controller is devised to guarantee trajectory tracking for the ROV system. Lyapunov theory is applied to establish the finite-time stability of the closed-loop system. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed controller enables the ROV to accurately follow a given path with smooth trajectories and asymptotically convergent tracking errors.

title: SMC-Based Anti-Swing Controller of Underactuated Systems
authors: Yanshan Shi, Feng Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: A non-singular terminal SMC-based methodology is devised to anti-swing control of bridge cranes, which represent a typical two-degree-of-freedom underactuated system. The proposed sliding surface incorporates the payload swing dynamics, and its convergence is rigorously established using Lyapunov stability theory, thereby ensuring finite-time stability. The control scheme obviates the need for complex coordinate transformations and demonstrates a significant capability to attenuate compound disturbances. Extensive numerical simulations corroborate the controller's robust performance and overall efficacy.

title: Universal Approximated Real-Valued Fast Fourier Transform for Image Blur Detection
authors: Xinghao Wang, Lu Bai, Chongyan Gu, Yun Wu
abstract: This paper presents a primary study of universal approximation approach for the real-valued Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) with over-trimmed artificial neural network (ANN) for blur detection. By reducing the number of neurons in the hidden layer of ANN, we trade off the precision of the approximate real-valued FFT for computational complexity reduction. The fully connected ANN has only one hidden layer and no activate functions and bias, which simplifies the overall processing complexity compared to the normal ANN based FFT. Additional complexity reduction is achieved by dividing the image into sub-blocks. The performance of blur detection is verified, demonstrating the margin of approximate real-valued FFT with reduced computational complexity of up to ∼45% compared to untrimmed ANN, which is promising for deployment in resource-constrained edge devices.

title: Performance Measurement of LLM Classification for Imbalanced Class sizes
authors: Jonathan Dunne
abstract: Many systems generate imbalanced labelled datasets, partly due to the data collection method. Such datasets consist of classes with few observations for specific categories and many for others. Classifying these datasets using machine learning algorithms can be challenging because of the limited training observations. Since classification performance is measured, poor results for small class sizes adversely affect overall performance, even when larger class sizes are classified successfully. We use three open-source datasets to demonstrate how a variable classification threshold score and a normalised metric can be a more robust measure for machine learning classification with imbalanced class sizes.

title: Flowing Blood Analysis & Separation: Integrating Raman Spectroscopy & Acoustophoresis in a Microfluidic System
authors: Shorya Rawal, Shambhavi Sinha, Jayapriya J., Vinay M.
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: The proposed system combines Raman Spectroscopy and Acoustophoresis in a microfluidic environment to provide label-free analysis and separation of the cells present in the blood, including red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets. Based on the Raman Effect, Raman Spectroscopy captures crucial information about the structural and vibrational traits of the blood sample, exposing the molecules to monochromatic radiation and recording their Raman shift. This data is processed using LSTM recurrent neural networks, creating a deep-learning framework for species identification and quantification. The model can forecast the cell population in the blood sample and obtain information on the size and compressibility of individual cells due to the microfluidic nature of the data received by the Raman Spectroscope. Raman spectra allow estimation of the cell size and compressibility, guiding cell separation using acoustophoresis and allowing adjustments of the acoustic wave frequency based on the estimated size and compressibility of the cells. The targeted cells are directed toward a designated collection chamber within the microfluidic system by dynamically adjusting the acoustic wave frequency. Repeated application allows complete separation of the cells and pressure-driven delivery of the targeted cells to their respective collection reservoirs.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Optimized Epitaxial Structure Design of III-Nitride Based Green LEDs
authors: Chandra Prakash Singh, Kankat Ghosh
abstract: We propose a machine learning (ML)-based optimization framework for InGaN-based green LEDs targeting the persistent green-gap issue in III-nitride emitters. Four ML models were trained on simulation data for devices with three EBL structures. This approach offers a scalable, data-driven pathway for pre-fabrication structure tuning.

title: Addressing Class Imbalance in Crop Disease Classification Through GAN-Based Synthetic Image Augmentation
authors: V Parameshwar Reddy, Dr. CH. Venkat Ramana Reddy, Dr. Rajasehkar Nuvvusetty
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Imbalanced datasets are a major challenge in the classification of crop diseases, as they often result in inadequate identification of uncommon disease classes. This study presents a new synthetic data augmentation approach based on Conditional Generative Adversarial Networks (cGANs) to address class imbalance in agricultural image datasets. The proposed framework creates biologically authentic images for disease classes that are scarce, which are validated for relevance and quality using statistical similarity measures and expert agronomist feedback. A lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) augmented with attention mechanisms is trained on the augmented dataset to improve feature learning and model interpretability. Evaluation in the PlantVillage dataset showed a classification performance boost with the new approach, reaching 92% overall accuracy, 0.89 in F1-score for the minority class, and 38 % reduction in training loss compared to traditional approaches. The framework also adds disease-specific attention focus verifications with Grad-CAM visualizations. Results from this study validated the proposed augmentation as effective in increasing the robustness and generalization of crop disease classification systems, especially for rare and underrepresented diseases.

title: Measurement of Responsible AI and Sustainable AI Influence on IT Service Management
authors: Sandy Kosasi, Husni Teja Sukmana, I Dewa Ayu Eka Yuliani, Diana Fitriani, Budi Susilo, Benedikta Bunyi
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: The utilization of artificial intelligence (AI) in IT service management has demonstrated considerable promise to enhance operational efficiency and service quality. The efficacy of AI integration in IT service management is significantly contingent upon implementing responsible and sustainable AI principles that establish digital trust as the cornerstone of system trust. Furthermore, most concentrate on technical elements, like algorithmic efficiency and service automation. The research objective assesses how responsible <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex> and sustainable AI enhance the efficacy of IT service management by establishing digital trust as a mediating variable. This study employed a convergent triangulation method utilizing an explanatory design approach through sophisticated elucidation. The research population comprises firms implementing AI in IT service management within the West Kalimantan region. Data were gathered via an online questionnaire administered to 282 participants using a random sampling method, with 239 respondents providing complete answers, resulting in a response rate of 84.75 %. Data analysis with the Likert scale and Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM) tool. This research is novel due to its incorporation of ethical and sustainability aspects of AI within the measurement model of IT service management effectiveness, alongside a focus on responsible <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex> to foster digital trust and facilitate the successful transformation of AI-driven IT service management.

title: Systematic Evaluation of Initial States and Exploration-Exploitation Strategies in PID Auto-Tuning: A Framework-Driven Approach Applied on Mobile Robots
authors: Zaid Ghazal, Ali Al-Bustami, Khouloud Gaaloul, Jaerock Kwon
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: PID controllers are widely used in control systems because of their simplicity and effectiveness. Although advanced optimization techniques such as Bayesian Optimization and Differential Evolution have been applied to address the challenges of automatic tuning of PID controllers, the influence of initial system states on convergence and the balance between exploration and exploitation remains underexplored. Moreover, experimenting the influence directly on real cyberphysical systems such as mobile robots is crucial for deriving realistic insights. In the present paper, a novel framework is introduced to evaluate the impact of systematically varying these factors on the PID auto-tuning processes that utilize Bayesian Optimization and Differential Evolution. Testing was conducted on two distinct PID-controlled robotic platforms, an omnidirectional robot and a differential drive mobile robot, to assess the effects on convergence rate, settling time, rise time, and overshoot percentage. As a result, the experimental outcomes yield evidence on the effects of the systematic variations, thereby providing an empirical basis for future research studies in the field.

title: Conformal Dual-polarization Independently Phase-tunable Metasurface
authors: Jiewen Tao, Yu Feng, Ziming Wei, Dao Lin Fu, Wei Xiong, Yongjin Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper proposes a conformal dual-polarization independently phase-tunable metasurface (CDIPM) unit with independently tunable phase, loaded with four varactor diodes. It consists of one metal resonator layer, three feeding layers, and one metal backplane, using conformal PI and PMI foam as the dielectric materials. By respectively changing the capacitance values of the varactor diodes along two orthogonal polarization directions, the metasurface unit can achieve a phase difference varying between 150° and 198° within the operating frequency band, while maintaining high reflectivity. This structure not only meets the conformal requirements but can also achieve the two digital coding states of 1-bit in programmable metasurfaces.

title: Modulation Method to Reduce the Current Zero Crossing Distortion of Vienna Rectifier
authors: Ximeng Dou, Yi Li, Shaoqi Ding, Qingyan Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Vienna rectifier is a high-performance three-level topology. The operation of the Vienna rectifier has special requirements for current and voltage symbols. When space vector modulation (SVM) is directly applied to the Vienna rectifier, the input current near the current zero crossing will be distorted. By analyzing space vector synthesis, this study identifies the root causes and operating conditions that lead to current zero-crossing distortion, and proposes a modulation method that can minimize current distortion while maintaining unit power factor at the grid side. This paper compares the conventional modulation method of Vienna rectifier, the modulation method of injected common mode voltage and the modulation method of clamp current zero-crossing phase with the modulation method proposed in this paper. And the feasibility and superiority of the modulation method proposed in this paper is verified by simulation and experiment.

title: Design of a Dual-Resonance Circularly Polarized Microstrip Antenna
authors: Xinfu Gao, Neng-Wu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper presents a low-profile (0.027λ) dual-resonance circularly polarized (CP) microstrip antenna with enhanced bandwidth characteristics. The proposed design employs a parasitic patch structure to create dual resonances at 2.03 GHz and 2.12 GHz while maintaining stable CP operation. Dual coaxial feeds, symmetrically positioned along the x- and y-axis of the radiating patch, excite orthogonal TM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₁₀</inf> and TM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₀₁</inf> modes to achieve a wide 3dB axial-ratio beamwidth of 160° across the operational band. A 4×4 array configuration utilizing rotated feed technology demonstrates wide-angle scanning capability of 100° while preserving CP characteristics (axial ratio < 3 dB). The array exhibits peak gains of 14.13 dB at 2.03 GHz and 13.94 dB at 2.12 GHz, with less than 3 dB gain variation during beam steering. These results validate the design's effectiveness in combining wideband operation, stable polarization purity, and wide-angle scanning performance in a compact form factor.

title: A Low Profile Reflectarray Antenna Based on Spoof Surface Plasmon Polariton
authors: Bingzan Sun, Xinzeng Gu, He Shuang, Lang Wu, Weixing Gao, Zhaoneng Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this letter, a low profile and low radar cross section(RCS) dual-polarized dipole antenna based on spoof surface plasmon polariton (SSPP) is proposed. One SSPP structure reflectarray is placed below the dual-polarized dipole antenna. As to the dispersion characteristics of the SSPP structure, electromagnetic waves are transmitted to both sides by the periodic structural binding of SSPP, thus obtaining low RCS properties. The SSPP reflectarray can realized low profile and low RCS properties in comparison with PEC ground plane. The experimental results show that the operational frequency range 5.1-7.6 GHz. Compared to the reference antenna, the thickness of the proposed antenna is 0.087 of the central frequency corresponding to the wavelength, features more compact profile than the PEC grounded one. It also demonstrates that the RCS of the proposed antenna is reduced in the operational frequency.

title: A Robotic Additive Manufacturing System for In-Situ Repair of In-Vessel Tokamak Components
authors: Hector Marin-Reyes, Kaiqiang Zhang, Robert Skilton
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a multi-degree-of-freedom (DOF) additive manufacturing system for automated in-situ repair of plasma-facing components within tokamak reactors. The system integrates a 3-DOF delta robot and two 6-DOF collaborative robotic arms to address the challenges of maintaining complex in-vessel components. Two case studies are explored: repair and maintenance of tiles and pipework as found in tokamak reactors using fused filament fabrication with polylactic acid. Automated processes, including surface preparation, component identification, and repair using the extrusion method, were implemented and tested. Vibration analysis revealed limitations caused by payload constraints and mechanical rigidity, emphasizing areas for further improvement. Experimental results validate the feasibility of automating in-situ repairs while identifying technology gaps, particularly for applications needing high strength materials such as tungsten alloys in plasma facing components. The findings contribute to enhancing maintenance processes in fusion energy systems.

title: Design of Bandwidth-Enhanced Facet Reflection Tolerant Directly Modulated Membrane Distributed Feedback Lasers with Wire-Like Active Region
authors: C. Zhang, K. Takahata, T. Hiraki, T. Aihara, S. Matsuo, T. Kakitsuka
abstract: Theoretical enhancement of facet reflection tolerance and modulation characteristics in wire-like active-region complex-coupled (CC) membrane distributed feedback (DFB) lasers is demonstrated. Compared to index-coupled DFB lasers, CC-DFB lasers show improved reflection tolerance, 20 % higher 3-dB bandwidth, and enable <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{50-Gbit}/ \mathrm{s}$</tex> non-return-to-zero modulation with enhanced eye opening.

title: Nanoparticle-On-Resonator-Boosted Spontaneous Emission
authors: Xuran Zhang, Chongwu Wang, Qi Jie Wang
abstract: Spontaneous emission is a basic physical process which is widely applied in developing light emitting diode, fluorescence microscopy and so on. However, current emission systems suffer from low fluorescence efficiency. Here, a plasmonic NPoR is reported, achieving an ultrahigh PL enhancement of over two orders.

title: Interrogating Optomechanical Ultrasound Sensor with On-Chip Tunable Distributed Bragg Reflector Laser
authors: Liwang Liu, Tangla David Kongnyuy, Ana Lebanov, John O'Callaghan, Xin Guo, Biwei Pan, Jing Zhang, Cedric Pieters, Fabrice-Roland Lamberti, Gunther Roelkens, Hilde Jans, Xavier Rottenberg, Jon Kjellman
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate the use of a micro-transfer-printed on-chip distributed Bragg reflector laser to interrogate an opto-mechanical ultrasound sensor. By eliminating the need for an external tunable laser source, this work presents a scalable pathway toward an all-on-chip photonic platform for high-performance acoustic sensing and imaging.

title: Emergency Repair Cost Interval Modeling and Optimization Method for Power Grids Integrating Attention Mechanism
authors: Shengjie Wang, Xuefan Liu, Jinpeng Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: In the context of increasingly stringent policies and regulatory constraints, cost management of power grid enterprises faces significant complexity. Emergency repair costs, as a critical component of total expenditure, present substantial challenges for budget management due to their strong uncertainty, regional volatility, and nonlinear execution characteristics. To enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of special cost control in power grid enterprises, this paper proposes an emergency repair cost control method that integrates fuzzy interval modeling with robust optimization strategies. A dual-channel attention neural network is first constructed to fuse structural and categorical features, enabling a triplet fuzzy interval representation of repair costs. Subsequently, a risk-weighted robust optimization function is designed to generate reasonable cost ranges under varying tolerance coefficients, thereby improving decision-making flexibility and disturbance resistance. Empirical analysis based on real-world emergency repair cases demonstrates that the proposed approach has strong applicability and practical implementation value.

title: Numerical Analysis of 1-Bit Finite Periodic Arrays Using Efficient Modified SSED Basis Function Method
authors: Ping Du
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: An efficient analysis method based on the modified simplified subentire (SSED) domain basis function method is proposed for analyzing the scattering from the finite periodic arrays with variable load impedance. The modified SSED basis functions are used to model the unit cells. Then, the reduced matrix equation based on the SSED bases can be obtained. The load component has two states. The reduced matrix for different states can be efficiently generated by computing the method of moments matrices once. The accuracy and computational efficiency of the proposed method are validated by numerical results.

title: Real-Time Tracking of Instrument Motion to Enable Machine Learning Approaches to Laparoscopy Training
authors: Paul Sullivan, Walid Shaker, Mustafa Suphi Erden
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Laparoscopic approaches to surgery have become widely adopted, due to several advantages over open surgery. However, as an unavoidable consequence of the nature of the laparoscopic setup, skills are more difficult to acquire and sufficient quality feedback on simulator training is costly to procure. We propose a real-time algorithm to track instrument trajectories in 3D within traditional physical laparoscopic simulators. This enables feedback and performance assessment via machine learning techniques. The algorithm has been characterised using a robotically controlled laparoscopic setup as a ground truth and achieves dual instrument tracking up to 60 frames per second at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 5 \text{mm}$</tex> accuracy.

title: Selective Epitaxial Growth of SiGe/Si Multi-Layer Structure for Silicon Photonics
authors: Xingwen Hong, Xuan Sang Nguyen, Tanmay Ghosh, Xuan Hui Siew, Leh Woon Lim, Landobasa Y M Tobing, Xianshu Luo, Eng Soon Tok, Kah-Wee Ang
abstract: We present a novel method for selective growth of silicon germanium/silicon (SiGe/Si) superlattices using dichlorosilane and germane as precursors. By controlling SiGe composition and thickness, strained SiGe layers were obtained. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SiGe} / \text{Si}$</tex> superlattice structure can be tailored for higher modulation efficiency modulators.

title: Fault Diagnosis of Photovoltaic Power Stations Based on the CNN-LSTM-BP Algorithm
authors: Xuyi Tian, Zheng Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: Driven by the strategic goals of carbon peak and carbon neutrality, photovoltaic (PV) power generation has developed rapidly. However, PV power stations are prone to failures such as hotspots, short circuits, and aging due to harsh operating environments, which threaten their safe and stable operation. Existing fault diagnosis methods face challenges such as class imbalance, poor model generalization, and underutilization of multi-source data. To address these issues, this paper proposes a fault diagnosis method for PV power stations based on multimodal data and a hybrid sampling deep ensemble learning algorithm. The method integrates operational data and infrared images to construct a multimodal dataset, adopts a SMOTE-RUS hybrid sampling strategy to alleviate class imbalance, and designs a heterogeneous deep ensemble model combining CNN, LSTM, and BP networks with an attention mechanism for feature fusion. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that the proposed method achieves an accuracy of $99.82 \%$ and an F1-Score of $99.42 \%$, significantly outperforming traditional single models and other ensemble methods, demonstrating strong robustness and generalization ability.

title: Wavelength Dependence of Polarization State in Single-Mode Fiber: Implications for BOTDA
authors: Zhizhi Yang, Bart Kuyken, Roel Baets, Yanlu Li
abstract: We measured the evolution of the state-of-polarization (SOP) versus wavelength in 25 km fibers and the impact of bend by analyzing the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{S}_{1}$</tex> parameter. Results suggest the SOP mismatch caused by Brillouin frequency shift is negligible.

title: Simulation of Barrier Layer Influence on the Performance of Ge-On-Si Single-Photon Avalanche Diodes
authors: Jau-Yang Wu, Chi-En Chen, Chao-Hsin Wu, Gong-Ru Lin
abstract: The design of the barrier layer doping concentration to enhance the performance of the Separate Absorption and Charge Multiplication (SACM) structure in Ge-on-Silicon single-photon avalanche diodes (SPADs), achieving a two-order reduction in dark count rate and more than a 10% improvement in photon detection efficiency, is presented and discussed.

title: Ultra-Dense and Efficient 98-Channel Fiber-to-Chip Connectivity with Polarization Diversity
authors: Yiou Cui, Wu Zhou, Yeyu Tong
abstract: We present an ultra-dense, highly efficient, and polarization-diverse fiber-to-chip input/output array that supports 98 channels, effectively interfacing a single-mode optical fiber array with a silicon photonic chip. A peak coupling efficiency of −3.47 dB can be achieved within a compact footprint of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.4 \text{mm} \times 0.5 \text{mm}$</tex>.

title: Implementation of a Cloud-Connected IoT System for Real-Time Indoor Air Quality Monitoring in Tropical Environments
authors: Andi Pramono, Bambang Kartono Kurniawan, Muchammad Farchan, Ira Audia Agustina, Baskoro Azis, Wahyu Waskito Putra
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Maintaining optimal Indoor Air Quality (IAQ) in tropical climates is crucial for comfort and health due to significant impacts from temperature and humidity. This study focuses on enhancing IAQ monitoring by integrating Internet of Things (IoT) technologies. It addresses the simultaneous management of air temperature, humidity, carbon monoxide (CO), and carbon dioxide (CO2) levels. This research aims to develop an IoT-based system that provides real-time, accurate monitoring and management of these parameters, ensuring air quality remains within safe limits. The author employed a qualitative single-case study methodology. The author configured and initialized an Arduino Nano to interact with MQ-7, MQ-135, and DHT11 sensors. This setup allowed for the continuous capture and transmission of environmental data to the ESP32 microcontroller. It is relaying data to the ThingSpeak platform for real-time analysis and visualization. The results revealed that integrating these specific sensors facilitated comprehensive monitoring of CO and CO2 levels. Moreover, it is alongside temperature and humidity, directly influencing indoor environments' thermal comfort and health safety. The Arduino-based system proved effective in providing accurate and easy-to-monitor air quality readings. It is significantly enhancing the capability to respond to IAQ issues dynamically.

title: A Data Glove for Object Recognition and Classification Based on LSTM
authors: Wenjian Lai, Bingcong Jian, Zongjie Hu, Ying Feng, Zhijun Li, Yang Song, Pengbo Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: As flexible electronics and AI advance, flexible wearable data gloves show great potential in object-grabbing recognition. This paper presents a data glove system with flexible stretchable strain sensors and an LSTM-based classification model to recognize objects of various shapes. Firstly, a 10-channel flexible sensor array was developed using low-melting-point solvent-based ionic gels and serpentine-wire designs. Then, an STM32 controller, Wi-Fi module, hardware acquisition circuit, and PC software were integrated to enable real-time, wireless transmission of hand-motion data. Finally, an LSTM neural network classification model was built. Experiments with five object shapes - spherical, cylindrical, cubic, thin-plate, and irregular - achieved a 99.21% overall accuracy, indicating excellent classification stability. This study confirms the feasibility of flexible data gloves in object-grasping recognition, supports the development of low-cost, high-precision human-computer interaction devices, and suggests that system performance could be further enhanced through multimodal sensor fusion in the future.

title: Study of an Ultra-wideband High-frequency System for Terahertz Band Dual Mode Sheet Beam Traveling Wave Amplifier
authors: Jiacai Liao, Guoxiang Shu, Xinqiang Li, Wenlong He
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper presents an ultra-wideband high-frequency system (HFS) for terahertz band sheet beam traveling wave amplifiers (TWAs), featuring a double staggered grating (DSG) slow wave structure (SWS) with an E-plane coupler. The proposed HFS achieves significant bandwidth enhancement through the innovative combination of DSG SWS and dual mode operation. Cold-cavity simulations demonstrate good electromagnetic characteristics, with transmission coefficients exceeding -5 dB and reflection coefficients remaining below -15 dB across the 240-330 GHz frequency range, yielding a bandwidth of 90 GHz (corresponding to a fractional bandwidth of 31.6%). Particlein-cell simulations further confirm the ultra-wideband performance of the HFS, revealing a hot-cavity operational bandwidth of 77 GHz (238-315 GHz) with an output power of exceeding 96.7 W.

title: Polarization HRRP Target Recognition Neural Network Based on Adaptive Feature Fusion
authors: Yangbo Zhou, Xiaomin Pan, Sen Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: A novel dual-polarization HRRP feature fusion neural network is proposed to exploit complementary information from HH and VH polarizations. Experiments on a dataset of ten low-orbit satellites demonstrate that the proposed network outperforms single-polarization methods in fine-grained recognition, maintaining high accuracy across various SNR conditions, thus validating its robustness in complex electromagnetic environments.

title: Mitigating Limb Position Effect Through Data Augmentation Using Diffusion Model
authors: Yihui Zhao, Jiawei Liao, Jiayuan He, Ning Jiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Myoelectric control has become a prevalent method for controlling prosthetic devices using surface electromyogram (sEMG) data. Pattern recognition (PR) methods have demonstrated promising results in laboratory settings. However, maintaining accurate and robust classification performance in practical applications poses significant challenges, particularly due to the “limb position effect”. This effect leads to decreased classification performance when testing positions differ from those used during training. Existing approaches necessitate time-consuming and cumbersome data collection that captures the variations across limb positions. This paper presents a data augmentation method based on diffusion models to synthesize EMG data that mimics the variability found in real EMG recordings across limb positions. By leveraging single trial under various limb positions, the proposed method can generate sufficient training samples to achieve accurate classification performance while minimizing data collection requirements. Experimental results show that the proposed method enhances the classification accuracy and reduces the intra-class variability, offering a potential solution to address the “limb position effect”.

title: Impact of Interferer Azimuth on Angle Estimation Accuracy after Interference Cancellation in Monopulse Phased Array Radar
authors: Siheng Zhan, Liang Zhou, Wei Cai
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper investigates how the azimuth of a single interferer affects monopulse angle estimation accuracy in a phased array radar employing external interference cancellation (IC). A combined IC and monopulse angle estimation model is used to characterize post-cancellation residual angular error. Simulation results show a clear dependence on interferer bearing: Residual angular error decreases as the interferer’s azimuth moves away from the beam axis, reaching a local minimum at approximately −1.2° and exhibiting an error profile approximately symmetric about 0°. Cancellation becomes ineffective when the interferer lies on the beam axis (0°). These findings provide practical guidance for performance assessment and for designing countermeasures to defend against mainlobe-suppression jamming.

title: Total Response Time Estimation for On-Grid Protection Systems in Renewable Smart Grids Using Transient Kinetic Energy Waveform Analysis
authors: Seyed Hossein Rouhani
abstract: Protection systems are indispensable components of power systems and critical infrastructure, responsible for detecting and isolating faults to ensure reliability and stability. Following fault detection, these systems issue commands to circuit breakers to initiate fault isolation. The faulty subsystem must be isolated from the power system before reaching a critical clearing time, beyond which system instability may occur. Thus, to safeguard the power system, protection systems must act before this critical clearing time. A larger time interval between the execution of protection systems and the critical clearing time increases the stability margin of the system. To accurately identify the total response time of protection system execution, this article presents a novel approach leveraging transient kinetic energy wave analysis coupled with online monitoring of circuit breaker performance. Initially, the healthy condition of circuit breakers is evaluated through the proposed probability distribution curves of the timing feature of the circuit breaker coil current and contact travel. Subsequently, the total response time of on-grid protection systems is calculated via transient energy waveform analysis. The results obtained from various simulation scenarios, along with experimental tests, validate the accurate performance of the proposed method.

title: Towards a Model-based Approach for Behavioral Safety Concepts in Automated Driving
authors: Nayel Fabian Salem, Marcus Nolte, Robert Graubohm, Olaf Franke, Torben Schenkel, Markus Maurer
abstract: ISO 21448:2022 specifies normative guidelines to ensure the safety of the intended functionality (SOTIF) of Automated Driving Systems. For systems that allow SAE Level 3 or higher driving automation [1] there is a (partial) absence of human oversight. This requires developers to shift from ensuring controllability by the driver to ensuring that the Automated Driving System exhibits safe behavior in its environment. In the automotive functional safety domain, functional and technical safety concepts are established for the specification of safety measures to mitigate the malfunctioning behavior of E/E systems. However, ISO 21448 does not describe how a comparable safety concept regarding SOTIF can be generated that specifies safety measures for behavior at the vehicle level. Based on the terminology and objectives that are specified in ISO 21448, we elicit requirements for the specification (safe) behavior. Subsequently, we present the conceptualization of a behavioral safety concept that specifies safety measures at the vehicle level. We follow a model-based approach to specify target behavior and document the conducted safety analyses. The semi-formal models provide traceability between functional insufficiencies in the target behavior and the according safety measures. To show the applicability of the proposed meta-model, we create an example model instance of a behavioral safety concept. The example model is based on a domain-specific SysML profile in a selected scenario. Finally, we verify the presented approach against ISO 21448 objectives.

title: A Multi-Task Attention-Driven SegNet for Lung Infection Segmentation and Classification from HRCT Images_supp1-3646487.pdf
authors: Dmitrii Kaplun
abstract: High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) plays a critical role in diagnosing lung diseases by providing detailed visualization of infections, inflammation, fibrosis and tumors. Recent advances in deep learning have enabled automated detection and segmentation of infected regions, with attention mechanisms further enhancing feature discrimination. This study proposes a multi-task attention-driven SegNet model for automated analysis of HRCT Scans. The model integrates attention layers to emphasize key pathological regions, including consolidation and ground-glass opacities, and supports both binary and multi-class segmentation/classification tasks. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the proposed model achieves 91.4% accuracy in binary and 84.5% accuracy in multi-class lung infection segmentation and classification, outperforming the attention-driven U-Net baseline. By providing improved precision and efficiency, the attention-driven SegNet model can accelerate computer-aided diagnosis (CAD), support clinical decision-making, and promote standardized approaches for managing lung infections in healthcare settings.

title: A Broadband and Compact GaN Millimeter-Wave MMIC SPDT Switch Using Modified π-Networks
authors: Chaorong Wang, Quan Pan, Xiaohu Fang
abstract: This paper presents a design methodology for broadband and compact millimeter-wave (mm-wave) single-pole double-throw (SPDT) switches targeting the Ku–Ka band. Conventional SPDT switches based on quarter-wavelength transmission lines typically occupy significant chip area, while alternative designs utilizing standard π-type equivalent circuits often suffer from bandwidth degradation due to the parasitic inductance at the isolation path. To overcome these limitations, a novel SPDT architecture based on modified π-networks is proposed. This approach incorporates the parasitic inductance of the isolation path into the π-network design, effectively enhancing the bandwidth performance without increasing circuit complexity. For validation, an SPDT switch was implemented using a 0.15-μm GaN MMIC process, covering the 10–28 GHz band. Measurement results confirm that the switch achieves an insertion loss below 2.1 dB, return loss better than 12 dB and isolation greater than 42 dB, with a compact core chip area of only 0.62 mm

title: Asymptotic Phase Synthesis by Transport Maps -Part II Optimal Transport Problem
authors: Piero Angeletti, Giovanni Toso, Raffaele Vitolo
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: In a companion paper the authors have shown that the problem of phase synthesis of apertures with assigned amplitude can be asymptotically reconducted to a Monge–Ampère partial differential equation (PDE) which can be solved identifying an irrotational transport map from the source aperture to the target beam. In this contribution we address the general problem of synthesizing beams with shapes that cannot be obtained as a linear transformation of the aperture. According to a fundamental result of Brenier, the irrotational transport map satisfying the Monge–Ampère PDE can be obtained as a solution of Monge’s Optimal Transport Problem (OTP) with quadratic cost. The phase profile can then be obtained by direct integration. A numerical method based on Von Neumann’s alternating projections is adopted with an original discretization of the involved differential equations and boundary conditions. The numerical results demonstrate the effectiveness and accuracy of the proposed approach.

title: Symptom-Driven Personalized Proton Pump Inhibitors Therapy Using Bayesian Neural Networks and Model Predictive Control
authors: Yutong Li, Ilya Kolmanovsky
abstract: Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) are the standard of care for gastric acid disorders but carry significant risks when administered chronically at high doses. Precise long-term control of gastric acidity is challenged by the impracticality of invasive gastric acid monitoring beyond 72 hours and wide inter-patient variability. We propose a noninvasive, symptom-based framework that tailors PPI dosing solely on patient-reported reflux and digestive symptom patterns. A Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) prediction model learns to predict patient symptoms and quantifies its uncertainty from historical symptom scores, meal, and PPIs intake data. These probabilistic forecasts feed a chance-constrained Model Predictive Control (MPC) algorithm that dynamically computes future PPI doses to minimize drug usage while enforcing acid suppression with high confidence—without any direct acid measurement. In silico studies over diverse dietary schedules and virtual patient profiles demonstrate that our learning-augmented MPC reduces total PPI consumption by 65% compared to standard fixed regimens, while maintaining acid suppression with at least 95% probability. The proposed approach offers a practical path to personalized PPI therapy, minimizing treatment burden and overdose risk without invasive sensors.

title: Comprehensive Experimental and COMSOL-Based Investigation of Electric Field Distribution in Extra High-Voltage Cable Joints
authors: Cagri Koksal, Ertugrul Adiguzel, Emrah Dokur, Aysel Ersoy
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive experimental and numerical analysis of electric field distribution in extra high-voltage (EHV) cable joint structures using six different solid insulating materials. The materials evaluated include SBR, NR, SIR, EPDM, CR, and NBR/SBR blends. Electrical parameters such as capacitance, loss factor, and dielectric constant were measured under various high-voltage conditions according to IEC 60625 standards. COMSOL Multiphysics was employed to simulate electric field distribution in three-dimensional joint geometries to validate experimental findings. Results showed that EPDM and SBR provided the most stable dielectric behavior, maintaining low loss factors and electric field strengths within acceptable limits. In contrast, SIR and NBR/SBR exhibited excessive electric field intensities, rendering them unsuitable for high-voltage applications. The simulations confirmed that field stress concentrates near dielectric discontinuities and geometrical transitions, especially in the absence of stress cones. The integrated approach used in this study highlights the importance of material selection and structural optimization in enhancing the electrical reliability of EHV cable joints. These findings offer valuable insights for future design strategies and the development of advanced insulating systems.

title: Quantum Computing in the Computational Landscape of Power Electronics: Vision and Reality
authors: Nikolaos G. Paterakis, Petros Karamanakos, Corey O'Meara, Georgios Papafotiou
abstract: Quantum computing is rapidly emerging as a promising technology for solving complex optimization problems that arise in various engineering fields. Therefore, it holds significant promise to transform the computational foundations of power electronics. Motivated by this potential, this paper adopts a visionary perspective to examine how quantum computing could influence the evolution of power electronics in areas such as converter design, control, modulation, simulation workflows, and beyond. Within this framework, the current status, limitations, and anticipated progress of quantum algorithms and hardware are discussed, together with their potential to enable efficient solutions to large-scale, multiobjective, mixed-integer optimization problems. To place these developments in context, the paper begins with a concise tutorial on fundamental concepts in quantum computing, serving as both an introduction to the field and a bridge to its potential applications in power electronics. As a first step in this direction, the use of quantum computing for solving offline mixed-integer optimization problems commonly encountered in power electronics is examined. To this end, a simplified power electronics design problem is reformulated as a quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) problem and executed on quantum hardware, despite current limitations such as low qubit counts and hardware noise. This demonstration marks a pioneering step towards leveraging quantum computing in power electronics and motivates the value of early adoption and exploration. Building on these insights, the paper outlines a forward-looking vision in which quantum computing becomes an integral part of the computational landscape of power electronics, guiding its transition from classical to quantum-enabled design and operation.

title: Laboratory Environments Mask Gait Differences between Healthy Participants and Patients with Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction
authors: Lauren R. Parola, Vu Phan, Eni Halilaj
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Previous work suggests that people with mobility impairments move differently in the traditional gait laboratory than in natural environments, but the extent to which this possible divergence may have limited understanding of gait following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR) remains unknown. We hypothesized that (1) patients following ACLR walk more asymmetrically in daily life than in the laboratory and (2) differences between patients following ACLR and individuals with no gait pathologies would be more pronounced in daily life than in the laboratory. Twelve participants (six post-ACLR, six healthy) completed gait assessments in the laboratory with optical motion capture and inertial measurement units (IMU) and in daily life with IMUs. Patients walked similarly to healthy participants in the laboratory, but in daily life, they walked with a higher gait-cycle time (1.22 ± 0.03 s vs. 1.08 ± 0.06 s), double-support (21.8 ± 1.3 % vs. 17.9 ± 2.7 % Gait Cycle Time), and single-support asymmetry (8.4 ± 0.9 % vs 4.1 ± 0.7 %). While the reasons behind the observed differences were not studied, these results suggest that gaitanalysis studies to date may have not realistically captured natural-environment behavior. Wearable sensors now offer a path toward deeper understanding of post-surgical gait and the specific patterns that may place certain patients at risk for post-traumatic osteoarthritis.

title: Liquid-electrodes Electrical Impedance Tomography Sensor for Single Cell Imaging
authors: Xiaolin Li, Yini Lian, Xu Bai, Peng Suo, Lijun Xu, Jiangtao Sun
abstract: Measuring and recognizing single cells are fundamental challenges in biology. Electrical impedance tomography (EIT) is a non-destructive and label-free visualization monitoring technique, but its application in single-cell monitoring is limited by high contact resistance at the microscale and complex fabrication challenges. In this work, an easily fabricable EIT sensor at microscale is proposed, in which the liquid-electrode design enables a sufficiently large contact area between metal lead and liquid and thus significantly decreases the contact impedance, allowing the imaging of the shape, position and size of a single cell or multiple cells. The genetic algorithm is employed to optimize the sensor structure, resulting in a sensitive and concentrated sensing region at the center of the sensor to eliminate interferences from the outside surroundings. To better image cells, an adaptive block sparse Bayesian learning algorithm for small targets reconstruction is adopted and proven effective in removing artifacts near cells and at the edges of the sensitive region. Finally, experiments to image PS microspheres and yeast cells at microscale were conducted as a proof of concept. The result shows that the proposed sensor with liquid electrodes can effectively reconstruct the shapes, positions, and sizes of microspheres and cells, where the estimation errors of the microsphere size are less than 5%. The proposed liquid-electrodes EIT sensor provides a low-cost promising alternative to image single cell at microscale, which can enable the morphological characterization of single cell.

title: Near-Field Communications sensor for lactate determination in saliva and sweat using organic electrochemical transistors (OECTs)
authors: A. Lazaro, E. Rojas, M. Lazaro, R. Villarino, B. Gonzalez, D. Girbau
abstract: Organic electrochemical transistors (OECTs) are attractive devices for the next generation of biosensors, but their widespread adoption has been limited by the need for expensive and bulky measurement instruments. This work addresses this limitation by presenting a low-cost, low-power readout circuit for biasing and measuring the drain current of OECTs, specifically targeting portable and wearable applications for point-of-care testing (POCT). The proposed system utilizes a modified microcontroller-based potentiostat that is compatible with single positive voltage sources. It also includes Near Field Communication (NFC), which allows data to be retrieved wirelessly using a smartphone. A proof-of-concept lactate sensor is presented, designed for measuring lactate concentration in sweat and saliva. The sensor is based on an OECT with a platinum-coated gate and a Nafion membrane that immobilizes the lactose oxidase enzyme, significantly improving the selectivity of the substance to be measured. Low detection limits of 0.35 mM and 0.0485 mM have been achieved in sweat and saliva, respectively. This research provides a complete, low-cost, and non-invasive solution for OECT-based biosensors.

title: Enhancing CNN-Based Motion Sickness Detection using EEG Signals Weighted by Motion Sickness Dose Value
authors: Byoung-Gyu Song, Abeeb Opeyemi Alabi, Chany Lee, Namcheol Kang
abstract: With the advancement of autonomous driving technologies, passengers increasingly engage in non-driving activities. However, these activities are often limited by motion sickness (MS), which worsens with vehicle vibration characterized by longer exposure duration and greater magnitude. Although recent studies have detected MS using EEG-based artificial intelligence models, they have often overlooked the characteristics of MS in vehicles. In this study, we propose a method to enhance the performance of EEG-based convolutional neural network (CNN) models by incorporating the motion sickness dose value (MSDV) defined in ISO 2631-1, which considers both exposure duration and vibration magnitude. For the CNN models, we selected ShallowConvNet, EEGNet, TSception, and EEG-Conformer, which are widely used in brain-computer interface and emotion recognition. The proposed method assigns MSDV-based weighting factors to EEG segments, with MSDV computed from triaxial head acceleration. To validate the effectiveness of the approach, EEG signals were recorded from 42 participants who were exposed to various simulated road conditions with a motion simulator. Results demonstrated that the MSDV weighted models exhibited statistically significant improvements in classification performance compared to the models without MSDV. Furthermore, classification accuracy was enhanced by applying a cascade adaptive filter to eliminate movement artifacts induced by whole-body vibration. The proposed method achieved within-subject classification accuracies of 94.55–95.54% and cross-subject accuracies of 67.92–74.77%, outperforming existing MS detection models. These findings suggest that integrating EEG signals with MSDV weighting provides a promising pathway for accurate real-world motion sickness detection.

title: QTest: A Simulation Testbed for Distributed Quantum Computing and Networking with Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Hao Chen, Baoxia Du, Ruidong Li
abstract: In Distributed Quantum Computing (DQC), quantum networks interconnect multiple Quantum Processing Units (QPUs) to overcome single-device limitations and enable cross-server computation. We present QTest, a modular simulation testbed for distributed quantum computing and networking. The platform employs Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL)-based quantum circuit partitioning and distributed quantum network scheduling, coordinating cross-server operations under network constraints such as routing and channel utilization. With containerized QPU nodes and GPU-accelerated backends, QTest supports circuit execution across heterogeneous and geographically distributed environments. By enabling task partitioning, inter-node entanglement distribution, fidelity-aware routing, and latency-throughput evaluation, QTest provides a reproducible and extensible environment for protocol development and validation. Experimental results show that QTest achieves efficient runtime scalability under ideal conditions. Compared to CPU-based execution, GPU-accelerated distributed runs reduce execution time by up to an order of magnitude, validating the effectiveness of the proposed testbed.

title: 3D-Imaging Endoscopy Through Electronic Focusing
authors: Ines Nohales, Angel Tolosa, Genaro Saavedra, Manuel Martinez-Corral, Nicolo Incardona
abstract: Conventional endoscopic systems provide two-dimensional images of three-dimensional structures. Real depth information is lost in these systems. Therefore, depth perception relies uniquely on monocular cues, such as occlusions, shadows or motion parallax. Three-dimensional endoscopy has been proposed to mitigate these adverse effects. Nevertheless, as it is usually based on aperture sub-sampling, the provided images suffer from a strong reduction in resolution, vulnerability to off-axis aberrations, and very low light efficiency. To face the challenge, we report here a 3D-imaging endoscopy system based on the implementation of an optical add-on that incorporates an electrically tunable lens. We demonstrate that, when attached to a standard commercial endoscope, the proposed system allows the capture of stacks of 2D images focused at different depths, with the same resolution as that provided by the endoscope alone. To demonstrate that the system is capable of capturing stacks of images with distinguishable depths, we calculated the depth map of a 3D simulated biological scenario with a standard free image-processing software. All these capabilities can be of great utility in surgery practice that require the 3D reconstruction of the surgical field.
