title: Impact of Substrate Surface Roughness on Liquid Crystal Alignment for High Performance Microwave Phase Shifters
authors: Bassem Meddeb, Yongwei Zhang, Xianyang Lv, Yanwei Fu
abstract: Achieving reliable initial alignment of liquid crystal (LC) molecules on copper surface of microwave materials remains a key challenge, primarily due to a more significant surface roughness of radio frequency (RF) materials compared to smoother substrates traditionally used in optical devices, where LCs were initially tailored for. To address this problem, we studied two principle LC alignment strategies: (i) direct alignment of the LC layer on microwave device substrates via a polyimide (PI) coating, and (ii) integration of a conventional LC cell incorporating two glass substrates to provide well controlled surface anchoring. Both approaches are implemented in two distinct phase shifter designs and evaluated through full wave simulations and experimental measurements at the X- and Ku-bands respectively. The results demonstrated that the LC cell with glass substrates supports thinner LC layer, which is pivotal for obtaining a more rapid response. Devices based on the LC cell configuration exhibit a 35<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> improvement in response time, attributed to enhanced molecular orientation and reduced fringing field effects. However, the inclusion of extra glass substrates will degrade the phase shift range. The analytic study indicated that incooperation of glass layers reduced the differential phase shift (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\Delta \phi$</tex-math></inline-formula>) by 50<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> under the same LC thickness. These findings highlighted the advantages of glass substrate LC cells in enabling low loss, compact, and fast response phase shifters, making them well suited for reconfigurable antenna arrays and beamforming systems in next generation wireless communication networks.

title: Output Feedback Stabilization for Stochastic Time-Delay Nonlinear Systems With Electromechanical Applications
authors: Mengxi Zhang, Shengyuan Xu
abstract: This study establishes a novel memoryless output feedback control framework for the global exponential stabilization in mean square of stochastic time-delay nonlinear systems with a lower triangular structure. A key limitation of prior work is the inability to handle the simultaneous presence of input and state delays under stochastic disturbances. Our unified control framework effectively addresses this challenge. Employing the idea of feedback domination, we develop a memoryless (or delay-independent) output feedback control law. Under constrained input delay (with arbitrary state delays), we demonstrate the stability of the closed-loop system using the Lyapunov–Krasovskii functional method. The feedback control strategy is delay-independent, which simplifies its implementation in practical applications. To show the efficacy of the proposed control scheme, we present an electromechanical system as an example.

title: Fabrication of a Calcite Birefringent Lens Using Micro-Abrasive Blasting
authors: Md Rabiul Hasan, Amirali Nikeghbal, Seungbeum Noah, Hanseup Kim, Carlos H. Mastrangelo
abstract: We introduce a low-cost table-top scanning micro-abrasive process as an alternative to grayscale lithography for micromachining curved optical microdevices. A scanning <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> jet etches substrates with depth feedback. Its versatility is shown by fabricating a plano-concave calcite birefringent lens, challenging for milling or etching.

title: Finite Element Tearing and Interconnecting Method for Efficient Simulation of Multi-Finger MOSFETs
authors: Yushuo Zhai, Min Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This paper proposes an efficient algorithm for the simulation of multi-finger MOSFETs by using the finite element tearing and interconnecting (FETI) method with the Newton-Raphson iterative scheme. The control volume finite element method (CVFEM) is applied for spatial discretization, and FETI method is incorporated into the Newton-Raphson iteration to accelerate the simulation. The accuracy and efficiency of the proposed method are verified by analyzing the behavior of typical multi-finger MOSFETs.

title: Large Language Models in Human Subject Research, and the Presence of Idiosyncratic Human Behaviors
authors: Dionysios Demetis, Jeandri Robertson, Andrew Flostrand, Caitlin Ferreira, Richard T. Watson, Ian McCarthy, Jan Kietzmann, Leyland Pitt, Amir Dabirian
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) not only mimic human language generally but are also showing the ability to exhibit nuanced, idiosyncratic human behavior. This could lead to the expanded use of LLMs in research and a diminution of the influence of humans. It also has implications for AI alignment and the role of the technology in society.

title: Inverse Design of Polyaniline Metasurface Based on CGAN Neural Network
authors: Yunbo Chu, Naixing Feng, Zhixiang Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this article, we propose improved conditional generative adversarial neural networks (CGAN) for the inverse design of polyaniline metasurfaces based upon THz multi-resonant absorption spectra. the improved CGAN can achieve the inverse design of graphene metasurface images directly from the desired ulti-resonant absorption spectra. The CGAN model uses the absorption spectra as the conditional input to generate metasurface images with specific electromagnetic properties, and the reliability of the generated samples is improved through adversarial training. It is turned out that this work an finish facilitating the design process of artificial intelligence generated metasurfaces (AIGM), and even provide a useful guide or developing complex THz metasurfaces based on 2D materials sing generative neural networks.

title: A Tetrahedral Spectral Element Method for Multiphysics Co-Simulation of Semiconductors
authors: Jia-Hui Zhou, Qi Qiang Liu, Da-Wei Wang, Wen-Sheng Zhao, Absalom E. Ezugwu, Hairong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This work presents a tetrahedral spectral element method (TSEM) for three-dimensional modeling of nonlinear semiconductor devices, targeting efficient simulation of strongly coupled electro-thermal effects. By combining high-order polynomial interpolation with unstructured mesh adaptability, the method enables mixed-order approximation of multiphysics on a nonconformal meshes, effectively capturing multiscale coupling features inherent in electro-thermal behavior. System matrices are constructed directly on non-uniform interpolation nodes using Vandermonde and differentiation matrices, which simplifies element integration and enhances numerical stability and accuracy. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves excellent convergence even on sparse meshes, making it well-suited for modeling and analysis of electro-thermal effects in high power density devices.

title: Redesigning the Security Unit Structure in Parent-Subsidiary Organizations Based on Security Capabilities
authors: Saeed Shokrollahi
publish: 2025 9th Iranian Conference on Advances in Enterprise Architecture (ICAEA)
abstract: In parent-subsidiary organizations, which consist of a headquarters and multiple subsidiaries, cybersecurity challenges have become increasingly prominent due to their multidimensional nature. These challenges arise from the traditional structure of security units, which often fails to align with the demands of complex, distributed environments, and can be grouped into three domains of people, process, and technology. Enterprise architecture, as a key framework for integrating strategies, processes, and technologies, offers a vital opportunity to redesign the security unit within its business layer. This redesign enhances system reliability, regulatory compliance, risk management, and business continuity. This article analyzes security capabilities and their related processes to propose a restructured security unit in the enterprise architecture’s business layer. By embedding security as a core element of business strategy, it ensures alignment with organizational goals. The redesign serves as both an operational necessity and a strategic imperative, boosting resilience, cost efficiency, and inter-unit coordination. We introduce a systematic method grounded in six key security capabilities: security strategy, security management, external compliance, risk management, internal control and audit, and response and recovery. Through an analysis of inter-capability relationships, we identify how capabilities are mapped to the sections of the security unit. Furthermore, a multi-modal operating model is proposed to balance centralization and decentralization between headquarters and subsidiaries. This model centralizes governance capabilities for unified oversight while decentralizing operational ones for local agility, achieving a dynamic equilibrium between control and flexibility. Implementing this approach not only elevates organizational security effectiveness but also fosters deeper adherence to enterprise architecture principles, promoting long-term sustainability in cybersecurity.

title: SERS and Advanced Computational Chemistry Integration for Ultrasensitive Agrochemical Detection
authors: H. J. S. Graves, H.C. S. Junior, A.R. Hirdes, E.C. Moreira
abstract: This study presents an integrated nanophotonic-computational approach for agrochemical detection using plasmonic silver nanoparticle-based SERS. Spectral analysis and density-functional calculations reveal localized surface plasmon resonance mechanisms, demonstrating potential for ultrasensitive optical sensing at ppm concentrations with applications in environmental monitoring and food safety.

title: A 28GHz Mm-Wave Polarization and Angle-Insensitive Metasurface
authors: Yujie Song, Daotong Li, Qiuyu Xie, Ying Liu, Qi Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: In this paper, a metasurface operating in the 28 GHz frequency band is proposed, designed, and numerically analyzed. Adopting a classic square patch unit structure, this metasurface aims to achieve a highly robust response to the polarization state and incident angle of electromagnetic waves. Full-wave electromagnetic simulation results demonstrate that the design achieves a return loss (S11) of less than -10 dB at its central resonant frequency of 28 GHz. For incident waves with different polarizations (TE and TM), the structure exhibits nearly consistent performance. Additionally, under oblique incidence conditions with an incident angle of up to 30°, the performance degradation is negligible, demonstrating excellent angular stability. Such performance renders the proposed metasurface an ideal candidate for applications including polarizers, frequency-selective surfaces (FSS), and energy absorption in future 5G and Beyond-5G communication systems.

title: Evaluating the Usability and Sustainability of Mobile Payments: A Malaysian Study on System, Information, and Service Quality
authors: Siti Hajar Mohamad, Hazlina Abd Kadir, Doni Purnama Alamsyah, Leni Susanti, Norfaridatul Akmaliah Othman
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Mobile payment (M-payment) information systems have evolved rapidly, driven by the proliferation of mobile internet and widespread smartphone usage. In Malaysia, the adoption of M-payment continues to grow; however, usability challenges remain a significant barrier. This research aims to explore how system quality, information quality, and service quality affect mobile usability and perceived benefits within m-payment systems. Specifically, it examines the complex relationships among these quality factors and their effect on user experience. Data were collected with a structured questionnaire used with 280 adult participants in Kuala Lumpur and Selangor. This research used the PLS-SEM method and functions to examine the evaluation and structural models. The research found that system quality, service quality, information quality, and service quality all convey positive support to mobile payment usability. Moreover, perceived benefits are found to fully concentrate these relationships, highlighting the pivotal role of user-perceived value in improving mobile adoption. The findings demonstrate that high-quality m-payment systems promote more user satisfaction, trust, engagement, and longterm loyalty. From a practical position, developers and service providers should concentrate on developing user-centric platforms identified by simple interfaces, trustworthy information, and responsive <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m$</tex>-services. In conclusion, improving the three factors of quality while enhancing perceived benefits is crucial for developing a more effective, participating, and sustainable m-payment ecosystem. The contribution of the study is to the expanding body of knowledge in information systems and provides strategic insights for improving mobile financial technologies in emerging markets.

title: Adaptive Finite Time Control of Mobile Belt Conveyor System with Multi-Source Uncertainties and Disturbances
authors: Zhangui Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: In addition to the uncertainties of model parameters, the movement characteristics of belt conveyor system in unstructured road environments further lead to unknown belt displacements and control input disturbances. Therefore, this paper proposes an adaptive sliding mode control method with finite time convergence to alleviate influence of uncertainties, especially dynamic disturbances caused by the ground motion of the conveyor. Unlike traditional methods, the proposed method combines a non-singular fast terminal sliding mode function to enhance convergence speed. An adaptive control gain of chattering free is designed. The proposed method ensures that the tracking error converges to a region within the finite time. The adaptive law of leakage compensation improves the system's robustness under disturbances. In addition, this paper also designs a new desired speed function to maintain smooth acceleration throughout the entire process, thereby enhancing the stability of material transportation. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified under uncertainties and disturbances.

title: Parameter Identification of Noisy Sub/Supersynchronous Oscillations Based on TTAO-IVMD-RLS Algorithm
authors: Song Gao, Jingying Yang, Dexin Li, Jianyi Che, Jiajun Zhang, Rundong Tian
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: The decomposition performance of the IVMD method (Improved Variational Mode Decomposition) is critically determined by two key factors: the number of decomposition modes K and the penalty factor α. To ensure that the IVMD method achieves optimal decomposition results when processing signals, this paper employs the TTAO method (Triangulation Topology Aggregation Optimizer) to optimize the existing IVMD algorithm. Specifically, the optimized IVMD is used to denoise and reconstruct noisy sub-synchronous and super-synchronous oscillation signals. Subsequently, the RLS algorithm (Recursive Least Squares) is applied to identify the frequency and amplitude parameters of the reconstructed signals. Finally, the effectiveness of the method proposed in this paper is verified using ADPSS simulation examples and measured data from a new energy power station.

title: Low-Cost SERS Substrates via AuNP-Decorated Carbonized Polyimide Films for Fluorescence-Quenched Raman Sensing
authors: S. Genc, G. A. Khan, D. Tuzel, S. Kina, A. Bek, K. Cinar
abstract: We developed a low-cost SERS substrate using laser-carbonized poly-oxydiphenylene-pyromellitimide (polyimide) and gold nanoparticles. This hybrid suppresses fluorescence and enhances Raman signals. Tested with Rhodamine 6G, it reveals high signal-to-noise ratio peaks, offering a practical, scalable solution for in-situ molecular sensing.

title: Inverse Design of Mid-Wavelength Infrared Photodetector Based on Multi-Diameter InSb Nanowire Array
authors: Zeyu He, Yitao Yang, Yuxin Yang, Yuepeng Luo, Weiqi Jin, Ziyuan Li
abstract: We present an inverse design approach for designing a multi-diameter InSb nanowire array-based midwavelength infrared (MWIR) photodetector, by combining the electromagnetic simulations and particle swarm optimization. By introducing the diameter diversity across a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> array, we achieve an average absorption over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 0 \%}$</tex> in the MWIR range.

title: Research on the Transient Operating Characteristics of High-Temperature Superconducting Cables under Short-Circuit Faults
authors: Wei Duan, Lu Zhang, Xinyi Yan, Shuangzan Ren, Lu Pu, Mingxi Zhu, Lifeng Zhang, Longxiong Ma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: High Temperature Superconducting (HTS) cables offer advantages such as high current density, low transmission losses, and minimal corridor occupation, making them a cuttingedge research focus in the field of power transmission. The threephase coaxial structure is a type of HTS cable design suitable for 10 kV urban power grids. However, due to its relatively poor short-circuit resistance, it is essential to study its transient behavior under fault conditions. This paper establishes an equivalent circuit model for a three-phase coaxial HTS cable and uses the model to analyze changes in temperature and mechanical stress under various fault scenarios. The results show that during a three-phase short-circuit fault, the cable experiences the highest temperature rise within a certain period, and the superconducting tapes are subjected to relatively large electromagnetic forces. When the fault resistance is close to 0, in both two-phase and threephase short-circuit faults, the magnetic forces acting on the cable are significantly greater than the electric forces. However, as the fault resistance increases, the proportion of the electric force will increase, and it is necessary to consider the influence of both the electric force and the magnetic force. These findings provide valuable reference data for the parameter design of HTS cables.

title: Consistency Comparison of Interference Detection for EMI Receiver
authors: LiYan Su, JunQing Wang, HaiLong An, BaoDian Liu, LiCheng Dong, Xue Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: The accuracy and consistency of electromagnetic interference (EMI) receiver measurements are critical for ensuring compliance with evolving electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) standards. With the inclusion of Fast Fourier Transform (FFT)-based spectrum analyzers in CISPR 16, significant performance advantages have emerged over conventional superheterodyne receivers, particularly in scan efficiency and parallel detection capabilities. However, measurement discrepancies still persist, especially when detecting non-stationary or intermittent emissions. This paper analyzes the underlying causes of such inconsistencies by comparing the architectural and signal processing differences between receiver types. A detailed study of window functions, detector types, and timing parameters is presented to evaluate their influence on amplitude accuracy and scan reliability. Theoretical models and time-frequency domain analyses are used to derive practical guidelines for improving measurement consistency, especially in the context of short-duration transient signals.

title: CNN-Based Intrusion Detection for Vehicular Networks Using Transfer Learning and Adaptive Ensemble Methods
authors: Palle Prabhas Reddy, Nithish T U, Endrula Pavan, Roopa Ravish, Prasad H B
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: As newer cars keep developing with more connectivity and electronic control, their cybersecurity has become an essential challenge. The Controller Area Network (CAN) protocol, which is the foundation for vehicle communication, was initially developed without necessary security elements like authentication, encryption, or intrusion prevention. This intrinsic weakness leaves vehicles open to a large variety of cyberattacks, such as message spoofing, Denial-of-Service (DoS), and fuzzing, which can make both passenger safety and system reliability brittle. Conventional rule-based or signature-based intrusion detection techniques prove ineffective against contemporary threats that are constantly changing. Hence, it is necessary to have sophisticated, data-driven solutions that can detect intrusions and anomalies efficiently in real time. Creating smart Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) using machine learning or deep learning presents a promising avenue. Closing this security gap is paramount to advancing intelligent transportation systems as well as to establishing trust in autonomous and connected vehicle technologies.

title: Q-Tracking: A Robust Visual Human Following for Quadruped Robots in Dynamic Environments
authors: Yiren Su, Chao Cun, Haisheng Xia, Ying Feng, Bailin He, Qiao Sun, Jiangwei Zhong, Zhijun Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: Human following is one of the fundamental functions in human-robot interaction for mobile robots. Among mobile robots, quadruped robots have gained significant attention in mobile ground robots due to their excellent motion capabilities. However, existing quadruped robot following systems still face problems such as decreased tracking robustness under occlusion and nonlinear motion modes, decoupling perception and control, and limited motion adaptability in dynamic environments. To solve these challenges, this paper proposes a target recognition, tracking, and motion control collaborative framework for dynamic scenes of quadruped robots, dubbed Q-Tracking. At a perception level, a YOLO-Tracking-ReID threelevel architecture enhances occlusion and nonlinear motion robustness. Key innovations include spatiotemporal-synchronized RGB-D preprocessing, an observation-centered improved SORT algorithm (inverse Kalman filter + motion-appearance bimodal association), and a residual feature aggregation network with dynamic matching. At the control level, a model predictive control (MPC)-whole-body impulse control(WBIC) hierarchical architecture is constructed using the mini-cheetah solution, and the motion stability is achieved by combining model predictive control (periodic gait optimization) and whole-body impedance control (dynamic relaxation variable adjustment). Experiments show 85% real-world tracking success, enabling reliable human-robot collaboration in complex environments.

title: A Comprehensive Approach to Integrate Generative AI in Vehicular Cloud Networks
authors: Farhoud Jafari Kaleibar, Hooman Kashfi
publish: 2025 9th Iranian Conference on Advances in Enterprise Architecture (ICAEA)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive framework to effectively integrate generative AI (GenAI) capabilities into vehicular cloud networks (VCNs). The proposed layered architecture addresses the multifaceted challenges involved, such as intermittent connectivity, heterogeneous vehicle resources, data privacy concerns, and low-latency requirements. The framework delineates components for robust communication and networking, efficient data collection and preprocessing, generative AI model deployment, optimized resource management, and strong security measures. Use case and evaluations demonstrate the framework’s efficacy in minimizing latency, reducing congestion, and optimizing resource usage through AI-driven coordination across vehicles and fog nodes.

title: OTA Pattern Issues in 5G OTA Certification Testing
authors: Jinghui Zhang, Xuewei Lv, Siyang Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: Over-the-air (OTA) testing has been mandatory for 5G wireless device certification for years. However, during further analysis of the OTA pattern raw data for certification, inconsistency and inaccuracy issues have been identified after evaluating hundreds of radiation patterns. Furthermore, it is also noted that significant variations exist in the output data formats among system integrators and certification test labs. Accordingly, this work outlines and exemplifies some common types of errors and redundant data format issues. Based on the pattern analysis and evaluation, it is recommended that system integrators and test labs standardize output format for OTA pattern raw data and integrate specific error-checking mechanisms into their OTA testing process—to facilitate post-processing as well as pattern comparisons and evaluations.

title: Analysis of Modern Kalman Filter Algorithms for Radar-Based Target Tracking under Uncertainty
authors: Rudresh T K, Parameshwar MC, Purushottama Lingadevaru
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: This study offers a thorough evaluation of several advanced Kalman Filter approaches namely the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF), Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF), and Adaptive Kalman Filter (AKF) in the context of radar-based tracking for moving targets in uncertain environments. The investigation centers on scenarios with nonlinear system behaviors and non-Gaussian noise, features that are frequently encountered in practical tracking applications. Simulations carried out using MATLAB provide the foundation for assessing each method based on tracking precision, processing demands, and resilience to fluctuating noise levels. The test framework incorporates a range of target movements and varying types of measurement and process disturbances to reflect real-world challenges. Results highlight the distinct compromises associated with each technique: while UKF and other more sophisticated filters enhance accuracy in nonlinear cases, they typically require greater computational resources; the EKF is less demanding computationally but does not perform as well under complex system dynamics; and the AKF adapts effectively to changing noise but may show variable consistency. The findings underline the need to match filter selection with the specific requirements and limitations of the intended application, providing valuable guidance for engineers and researchers engaged in the field of radar-based tracking.

title: Development of an IoT-Based Smart Waste System with RTC Time Logging for Cleaning Assistance
authors: Jeremy Axel Suryamiharja, Leony Agustin, Talitha Zasizki Gunara, Mochammad Haldi Widianto
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: Maintaining cleanliness in public spaces is a constant challenge, especially when trash bins aren’t monitored regularly. Overflowing waste can create unsanitary conditions and public discomfort. To address this issue, the authors developed an IoT-based Smart Waste System that uses the Blynk app for real-time monitoring and alerts, along with a Real-Time Clock (RTC) module to record events. The system tracks the bin’s fill level using an ultrasonic sensor and records the times when the bin becomes full or is emptied. It also includes a basic prediction feature to estimate when the bin will likely fill up again. Based on the results of research that has been carried out, there are sensors with good accuracy, such as ultrasonic sensors with an RMSE value of approximately 0.062 cm, and RTC modules with an RMSE value of approximately 75 seconds. However, the prediction system, although functional, has an RMSE value of around 7.7 hours, which shows that further improvement is needed. Overall, the system performed well under expected conditions and offers a more efficient alternative to traditional waste collection methods that rely on manual inspections.

title: Novel Visualization of Audio Signals via Clustering and Curve-fitting of Reassigned Spectrograms
authors: Jan Przybyszewski, Paul Cuffe
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for creating more meaningful visual representations of audio time-frequency information. Conventional spectrograms, while effective for visualizing frequency content and its temporal evolution, suffer from some problems: they are susceptible to noise and can become visually cluttered, potentially obscuring relations between signal components. The reassigned spectrogram method transforms standard mesh-based spectrograms into discrete points within a continuous three-dimensional space of time, frequency and magnitude. This point cloud representation enables clustering techniques to be deployed that are atypical for audio data. The resulting point clusters can then be associated together for detecting harmonic relationships. Tests on both musical recordings and speech signals demonstrate the effectiveness of this technique for isolating and visualizing harmonic structures in audio data. Particularly strong performance is demonstrated in separating overlapping harmonic components. The presented processing pipeline successfully identifies harmonic relationships within complex signals and presents these aspects visually in a more interpretable format than conventional spectrograms, offering new possibilities for audio signal analysis, interpretation and depiction.

title: Context Prototype-Aware Learning and Strengthen-Operate-Subtract Enhanced Fusion for Segmentation of Soybean Dust Raising Images
authors: Jin Luo, Lei Cai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics (ICARM)
abstract: In the harvesting robot for soybean harvesting process, there will be a large number of dust particles suspended in the air, and due to the mature soybean color and dust color features are similar, it will lead to soybean boundary feature boundary blurring, which increases the difficulty of extracting the soybean boundary features and affects the harvesting effect. This paper proposes a novel image segmentation method integrating context prototype-aware learning and strengthen-operate-subtract (SOS) enhancement for precise pod region segmentation in soybean dust-laden images. Firstly, through the iterative optimization of SOS enhancement module and error feedback mechanism, the soybean pod region in the image is gradually refined. Secondly, through the context prototypeaware learning, the soybean pods and other impurity regions are accurately recognized. Experimental validation shows that the algorithm proposed in this paper achieves 86.13 % and 78.53 % in terms of MPA and MIoU, respectively, which significantly improves the segmentation accuracy of the soybean dust raising images.

title: Predicting Cart Abandonment Using Machine Learning
authors: Ahmed E. Mansour Atwa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Cart abandonment remains a critical challenge in e-commerce, significantly impacting conversion rates and revenue. This study proposes a hybrid stacking classifier framework to enhance the prediction of cart abandonment behavior using real user session data. The dataset consists of 4,284 session records characterized by 13 behavioral and categorical features, including product views, cart interactions, and customer segment types. After preprocessing, label encoding, and feature scaling, a hybrid ensemble model was developed by stacking three strong learners-Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Extra Trees-with Logistic Regression serving as the meta-learner. The proposed hybrid model achieved superior performance with an accuracy of 98.48%, precision of 100%, recall of 98.21%, and F1-score of 99.10%. These results outperform traditional machine learning models, such as standalone Random Forest, SVM, and Logistic Regression, confirming the effectiveness of the stacking approach in capturing complex user behavior patterns. The findings provide actionable insights for e-commerce platforms seeking to implement predictive strategies to reduce cart abandonment and enhance customer retention.

title: Vision-Based Vehicle Detection and Recognition in Tunnel Scenarios
authors: Priyanka M, Suresha R, Navya Raj M D, Nidiginti Siva Sai Krishna Reddy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: Tunnels provide a secure passageway for vehicles over rugged terrain, such as mountains, and water bodies are essential for maintaining traffic flow in highly populated areas. Due to challenges in lighting conditions, glare, shadows, and motion blur, the vision-based model struggles to detect vehicles in tunnel regions. To address this issue, a tunnel-based detection and recognition model is proposed. This model incorporates robustness in the preprocessing pipeline to reduce glare and enhance the contrast of vehicles, and utilizes an optimized YOLOv11n model for vehicle detection and recognition, which maintains superior performance in tunnel environments. Performance measures, such as 73% Recall, 74% Precision, 73% mAP@50, and 67% mAP@50-95, demonstrate remarkable improvements based on 4,194 samples, considering changing lighting conditions for various vehicle types, including cars, buses, and trucks. The system has high detection rates, enhancing road safety and operational efficiency in tunnels.

title: AI-Based Inverse Design of Diffractive Metasurfaces Using Diffusion Models
authors: L. Hen, E. Yosef, D. Raviv, R. Giryes, J. Scheuer
abstract: We present efficient and fast inverse design of diffractive dielectric metasurfaces using a generative diffusion models. A unique data generation scheme is developed for the training process. Compared to state-of-the-art counterparts, our model exhibits superior performance in terms of approximating on-demand diverse diffraction patterns.

title: Gallium Nitride Nanowire Array-Based Optoelectronic Synapses for Biorealistic Neuromorphic Functions
authors: Xin Liu, Danhao Wang, Wei Chen, Yang Kang, Muhammad Hunain Memon, Shi Fang, Haiding Sun
abstract: We develop a photoelectrochemical synaptic device based on p-AlGaN/n-GaN nanowires, which integrates chemical-electric behaviors into optoelectronic synapses. The device exhibits dual-modal plasticity, replicates chemically-regulated synaptic activity, and emulates biological phenomena associated with oxidative stress.

authors: Lina Shi, Qiaolun Zhang, Fabien Boitier, Massimo Tornatore, Patricia Layec
abstract: We propose a novel method for continual PDL monitoring that first detects PDL drift by tracking SNR distributional shifts at the receiver, and then provides a prediction of the updated PDL value. This approach achieves a root mean square error (RMSE) of approximately 0.15 dB over time.

title: Hybrid AI Framework for Accurate Diagnostics: Merging Deep Learning with Rule-Based and Explainable Techniques Across Imaging Modalities
authors: Naga Nirmala Kongara, Bhukya Krishna, B. Sujatha
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: This paper presents a robust hybrid artificial intelligence (AI) framework designed to improve diagnostic accuracy in medical imaging tests such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computed tomography (CT), and positron emission tomography (PET) scans. The enhancement is achieved by combining deep learning methods with rule-based reasoning and model-agnostic explainability techniques. The proposed hybrid architecture integrates convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transformer models for feature extraction, while incorporating expert-defined rule-based logic to strengthen interpretability and ensure consistency in decision-making. To improve transparency, model-agnostic explainability approaches such as SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations) and LIME (Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanations) are applied, offering deeper insights into AI-driven diagnoses. This integration addresses critical clinical concerns related to trust, traceability, and adoption of AI systems. Experimental evaluations conducted on benchmark medical imaging datasets achieved an accuracy of 94.2%, which is 3.8% higher than conventional deep learning approaches, demonstrating improved robustness. Additionally, the proposed system enhances clinical interpretability, with a 21% increase in explainability ratings provided by healthcare professionals. These findings highlight the novelty and clinical relevance of hybrid AI models by combining automation with decision support, thereby promoting greater trust and adoption of AI in diagnostic workflows across healthcare facilities.

title: Understanding and Preventing Failures of Pressure Relief Devices in Hydrogen Systems
authors: Alejandro Jimenez, Katrina Groth
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - (SPCE Portland)
abstract: Hydrogen infrastructure is typically equipped with pressure relief devices (PRD) to protect systems from uncontrolled pressure increases. Without PRDs, significant pressure increases have the potential to rupture the equipment, resulting in a hydrogen leak, which could lead to fires, explosions, and nearby damage. However, recent incidents have shown that these PRDs can also be the root cause of leaks and releases, leading to fires and explosions, which potentially impact public and employee welfare and cause organizational losses. Organizations need to understand this risk to manage it effectively. However, a consistent and standardized failure vocabulary and terminology must be established to assess the risk and accomplish asset integrity objectives properly. This terminology would allow us to align the risk assessment needs with the data collection and asset integrity efforts, ensuring an improvement of the risk characterization. In that sense, this work focuses on establishing a common vocabulary, terminology, and failure causation for PRDs installed on hydrogen systems. This standardization is performed by evaluating PRD technology through a component failure mode and effect analysis (FMEA) to identify failure pathways of PRDs installed in hydrogen systems. The FMEA result defines standard causes, failure mechanisms, failure modes, and consequences associated with PRDs installed on hydrogen systems. These failure elements are interconnected to show the failure causal chain. This chain between the failure elements is then used to define the controls needed to prevent these failures

title: Classification of JKN Mobile User Sentiment with Support Vector Machine, Naïve Bayes and Logistic Regression
authors: Siti Rihastuti, Afnan Rosyidi, Dyah Rosna Yustanti Toin, M. Nur Juniadi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: This study aims to classify the sentiment of JKN Mobile application users based on reviews on the Google Playstore platform. The research stages include data collection, data labeling, data pre-processing, TF-IDF feature extraction, data division, algorithm testing using models, result analysis and cross validation. The algorithms used for sentiment classification testing are Support Vector Machine (SVM), Naïve Bayes and Logistic Regression. The test results using the three models on 1000 datasets with a comparison of 10% test data and 90% training data, produced the highest accuracy of 97% for SVM and Logistic Regression, and 96% for Naïve Bayes. To optimize the validity of the results, the Stratified K-Fold Cross Validation technique was used to evaluate the test results. As a result, the Logistic Regression model produced the highest average accuracy of 94.80%, Naïve Bayes 94.70% and SVM 94.50, with standard deviations of 1.52%, 2.14% and 2.38% respectively. Overall, the three models are very effective in classifying the distribution of user sentiment, most of which give positive reviews to the JKN Mobile application.

title: Evaluation and Improvement Path of Provincial Power Production Efficiency in China Taking Environmental Constraints into account
authors: Wei Zhang, Bo Chao, Liwen Liu, Wenjun Gao, Meng Sun, Ceyuan Song
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: Based on the provincial panel data of China from 2013 to 2023, this paper constructs a two-stage DEA model to quantitatively assess the environmental efficiency of China's power industry, and systematically integrates the Dagum Gini coefficient, Kernel density estimation and Tobit regression model to deeply analyze its spatial distribution characteristics, regional difference formation mechanism and driving factors. The research conclusion shows that: First, during the investigation period, the environmental efficiency of China's power industry presented a nonlinear fluctuating growth characteristic; Secondly, the expansion of economic scale, industrial structure adjustment, the level of technological innovation and the degree of opening up to the outside world constitute the key factors affecting environmental efficiency. Based on the above findings, the article puts forward policy suggestions from the dimensions of optimizing resource allocation, promoting technological innovation, and improving regional coordination mechanisms, providing theoretical support for promoting the green transformation of the power industry and balanced regional development.

title: Logarithmic Regret and Polynomial Scaling in Online Multi-Step-Ahead Prediction
authors: Jiachen Qian, Yang Zheng
abstract: This letter studies the problem of online multi-step-ahead prediction for unknown linear stochastic systems. Using conditional distribution theory, we derive an optimal parameterization of the prediction policy as a linear function of future inputs, past inputs, and past outputs. Based on this characterization, we propose an online least-squares algorithm to learn the policy and analyze its regret relative to the optimal model-based predictor. We show that the online algorithm achieves logarithmic regret with respect to the optimal Kalman filter in the multi-step setting. Furthermore, with new proof techniques, we establish an almost-sure regret bound that does not rely on fixed failure probabilities for sufficiently large horizons N. Finally, our analysis also reveals that, while the regret remains logarithmic in N, its constant factor grows polynomially with the prediction horizon H, with the polynomial order set by the largest Jordan block of eigenvalue 1 in the system matrix.

title: Clustered Joint Transmission for NOMA-Enabled Content-Centric Fog Radio Access Networks
authors: Xianling Wang, Zihang Zhang, Yousi Lin, Yue Tian, Kyeong Jin Kim, Yuanwei Liu
abstract: In fog radio access networks (F-RANs), caching popular content at edge fog access points (FAPs) helps alleviate the burden on base stations and backhaul links. To improve signal quality and connectivity, this work integrates cooperative communication and non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) into content-centric F-RANs with unreliable backhauls. Specifically, a NOMA-enabled joint transmission scheme is considered, where cache-enabled FAPs are coordinated into clusters to perform non-coherent joint transmission and NOMA, enabling multiplexing signals for multiple users. Under a hybrid caching policy and non-uniform Nakagami-m fading channels, the system performance is analyzed in terms of the successful content delivery probability and outage achievable rate. To optimize FAP coordination, the clustering problem is formulated as a coalitional game, and a low-complexity transfer-based clustering algorithm is designed. Furthermore, a hierarchical hybrid NOMA-based algorithm is developed to enhance multi-user access efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that: 1) The NOMA-enabled joint transmission scheme allows the FAPs efficiently leverage the cached content to mitigate backhaul unreliability; 2) The NOMA-based design outperforms the orthogonal multiple access-based design by guaranteeing improved signal quality while maintaining the efficiency of multi-user access; 3) The coalitional game-based clustering algorithm effectively manages co-channel interference and improves spectrum utilization.

title: Observer-Based Fuzzy Adaptive Admittance Control for Unknown Environment-Coupled Physical Human-Robot Interaction With Prescribed Tracking
authors: Chengguo Liu, Kai Zhao, Zhenyu Lu, Chaoyang Li
abstract: To meet the multi-dimensional modulation requirements of enabling robots to simultaneously achieve compliant adaptation to human time-varying motions and precise force tracking in unknown environments under physical human-robot-environment interaction (pHREI) scenarios, this paper proposed a fuzzy adaptive admittance control (FAAC) strategy that integrates disturbance observation and unified performance guarantees within a force-position dual-loop structure. In the force control outer loop, an extended state observer (ESO) is constructed to compensate for disturbances arising from uncertain human intentions and unstructured environmental geometry, while a PID-based admittance enhancement scheme is introduced to improve dynamic responsiveness. In the position control inner loop, a novel barrier function is embedded into the backstepping framework to systematically regulate the convergence rate, transient overshoot, steady-state accuracy, and global performance of the trajectory tracking error. Moreover, a fuzzy logic system (FLS) is employed to approximate the lumped model uncertainty, which in turn strengthens the robustness of the control algorithm. The asymptotic stability of the closed-loop system is rigorously established via the Lyapunov analysis criterion. Experiments involving trajectory tracking, planar cutting, and curved-surface carving conducted on an actual robotic platform demonstrate that the proposed method not only realizes superior force-position coordinated control, but also accommodates flexibility in physical human-robot interaction (pHRI) and smoothness in physical robot-environment interaction (pREI).

title: Trajectory Planning and Correction for Transnasal Surgical Robots via RCM Constraint Modeling and Fiber Optic Sensing Feedback
authors: Zhixiong Zhou, Qingsong Ai, Ping Liang, Zemin Liu, Quan Liu, Tianliang Li, Weiwei Xia, Wei Meng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: Transnasal surgical robots must operate within the confined anatomical space of the nasal cavity, which requires high precision in trajectory planning and real-time correction. This study presents a comprehensive trajectory planning and real-time correction framework for transnasal surgical robots, integrating Remote Center of Motion (RCM) constraints and real-time fiber optic sensing feedback. A personalized 3D point cloud and grid map of the nasal cavity are constructed based on computed tomography (CT) imaging. The improved RRT* algorithm is used to generate collision-free paths that adhere to RCM constraints. To address sensor measurement errors, an Adaptive Unscented Kalman Filter (AUKF) is employed to accurately estimate the end-effectors position and correct minor deviations in real-time through position control. When significant trajectory deviation or contact with nasal tissue is detected, a local trajectory replanning strategy with multiple constraints is introduced, dynamically adjusting the path based on sensor feedback. Experimental results show that the proposed framework effectively generates anatomically compatible motion paths and provides real-time trajectory error correction in complex nasal environments, offering a reliable and precise solution for robot-assisted transnasal surgery.

title: MOLENA: Analyzing the Two-Step Message Flow and Opinion Evolution Process in Social Networks_supp1-3646301.pdf
authors: H. Vicky Zhao
abstract: From mass media theory, the message flow and the opinion evolution in real social networks adhere to a two-step communication process: opinion leaders first receive the messages from the message sources, and then convey their opinions to the normal agents. During this process, opinion leaders often exhibit confirmation bias by updating their opinions based on messages close to their opinions, reflecting their limited willingness to accept dissonant messages. However, few prior works jointly consider the two-step communication process involving message sources, opinion leaders, and normal agents, as well as the confirmation bias of opinion leaders. In this paper, we propose a unified framework called MOLENA to analyze how messages f low and opinions evolve in the two-step communication process. In the MOLENA framework, we introduce a mathematically tractable message preference model to quantitatively describe the confirmation bias. We obtain the approximate analytical solution of the opinion leaders' and normal agents' steady-state opinions, and theoretically analyze the influence of system parameters on their steady-state opinions. Furthermore, we examine the influence of messages on opinion leaders' steady-state opinions and study how opinion leaders influence normal agents' steady state opinions in the two-step communication process. Finally, we validate our theoretical analysis through numerical experiments and verify the correctness of the MOLENA framework via social experiments. This study is critical to understanding how messages f low and opinions evolve in real social networks and to designing effective mechanisms to guide agents' opinions.

title: ECMSFNet: Real-Time Infrared Small Target Detection Network with Efficient Convolution and Multi-Scale Feature Fusion
authors: Xin Jin, Biaohua Liu, Li Tang, Shaowen Yao, Puming Wang, Qian Jiang
abstract: With the continuous development of fields such as national defense and military applications, the importance of infrared small target detection (IRSTD) technology based on thermal imaging has become increasingly prominent. However, in practical application scenarios, it remains difficult to effectively extract the features of weak and small targets under low signal-to-noise ratio conditions, while simultaneously suppressing background clutter, preserving target details, and balancing detection accuracy and speed. To address the issues mentioned above, this work proposes a real-time IRSTD network (ECMSFNet) based on efficient convolution and attention-guided multi-scale feature weighting and fusion. During the feature extraction stage, a dual-branch hybrid convolution module (DBHConv) is designed to extract infrared small target features more efficiently. In the feature fusion stage, a three-branch attention-guided module (TBAG) is designed to enhance the input features from both spatial and channel dimensions. By using a three-branch parallel structure to process input features in a differentiated manner, noise is effectively filtered while target detail information is preserved. In addition, to further address the issue of missed detections, a multi-scale feature weighting and fusion module (MSFWF) is designed at the added detection head to adaptively weight the features and optimize the feature propagation path, thereby improving the model’s detection accuracy. Extensive experimental results on multiple datasets demonstrate that the method proposed in this paper outperforms other advanced approaches and achieves a real-time detection speed of 74.63 frames per second. https://github.com/liubiaohua/ECMSFNet.

title: Multi-Harmonics Amplitude Analysis via Space-Time Coding Enabled Spatial-Spectral Mapping for Target Angle Estimation and Vital Sign Monitoring
authors: Shuping Li, Donglin Gao, Minning Zhu, Chung-Tse Michael Wu
publish: IEEE Journal of Electromagnetics, RF and Microwaves in Medicine and Biology
abstract: This work presents a novel space-time-coding (STC)-enabled radar sensor that leverages spatial-spectral mapping for target angle estimation and vital sign monitoring (VSM). The implemented prototype integrates a 1-to-5 unequal Wilkinson power divider and five patch antennas with direct antenna modulation (DAM), digitally controlled via an FPGA. By manipulating received signals into multiple harmonics as a function of incident angle, the STC array enables multi-harmonic amplitude analysis for angular localization. Experimental validation demonstrates accurate DOA estimation across an angular range of –70<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{\circ }$</tex-math></inline-formula> to +70<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{\circ }$</tex-math></inline-formula>, within the acceptable <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm 7.5^{\circ }$</tex-math></inline-formula> tolerance defined by the physical width of the human torso (33–41 cm), at a distance of 1.2 m. Furthermore, vital sign information extracted from the harmonic corresponding to the estimated angle range exhibits strong agreement with the ground truth. Unlike conventional DOA techniques, the proposed method operates using a single-channel over-the-air signal and does not require complex signal processing algorithms, offering a low-complexity and scalable solution for indoor biomedical and smart home applications.

title: From 5G RAN Queue Dynamics to Playback: A Performance Analysis for QUIC Video Streaming
authors: Jashanjot Singh Sidhu, Jorge Ignacio Sandoval, Abdelhak Bentaleb, Sandra Céspedes
abstract: The rapid adoption of QUIC as a transport protocol has transformed content delivery by reducing latency, enhancing congestion control (CC), and enabling more efficient multiplexing. With the advent of 5G networks, which support ultra-low latency and high bandwidth, streaming high-resolution video at 4K and beyond has become increasingly viable. However, optimizing Quality of Experience (QoE) in mobile networks remains challenging due to the complex interactions among Adaptive Bit Rate (ABR) schemes at the application layer, CC algorithms at the transport layer, and Radio Link Control (RLC) queuing at the link layer in the 5G network. While prior studies have largely examined these components in isolation, this work presents a comprehensive analysis of the impact of modern active queue management (AQM) strategies, such as RED and L4S, on video streaming over diverse QUIC implementations—focusing particularly on their interaction with the RLC buffer in 5G environments and the interplay between CC algorithms and ABR schemes. Our findings demonstrate that the effectiveness of AQM strategies in improving video streaming QoE is intrinsically linked to their dynamic interaction with QUIC implementations, CC algorithms and ABR schemes—highlighting that isolated optimizations are insufficient. This intricate interdependence necessitates holistic, cross-layer adaptive mechanisms capable of real-time coordination between network, transport and application layers, which are crucial for leveraging the capabilities of 5G networks to deliver robust, adaptive, and high-quality video.

title: Asymptotic Insights into Outage Probability of Multi-Cascaded RISs Over Doubly-Correlated MIMO Fading Channels
authors: Yi Zhang, Jintao Wang, Zheng Shi, Xu Wang, Yaru Fu, Guanghua Yang, Shaodan Ma
abstract: Cascaded reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) greatly improve network coverage and reliability. This paper examines the outage probability (OP) of multi-cascaded RISs (MCRISs)-aided systems over doubly-correlated Rayleigh multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) channels. The moment-generating function is invoked to convert the OP into a numerical inversion of Laplace integral. To capture profound insights, we conduct an in-depth asymptotic investigation into the outage behavior of MCRIS-aided MIMO communications by leveraging random matrix theory in the high-SNR regime. The asymptotic results reveal that the first h RISs with the smallest number of reflective elements primarily dictate the bottleneck of reliability performance, where h is influenced by the variation in the number of reflective elements across the RISs. Specifically, smaller variations result in a larger h, while greater disparities reduce it. Additionally, we identify an “unsaturation effect” that occurs when the performance margin, or residual spatial degree of freedom (DoF), after propagation through the first h RISs cannot be evenly distributed between the transmitter and the RISs. This effect slows down the decline of the OP with increasing SNR. More cascaded RISs impair the spatial DoF of wireless communications, resulting in the loss of half of the independent fading channels compared to the system without the support of RIS as the cascaded number of RISs increases. Majorization theory is subsequently applied to unveil the negative effect of doubly-spatial correlation on system reliability. Finally, Monte Carlo simulations are carried out for validations.

title: Digital Sovereignty for Collaborative AI Engineering: A Survey
authors: Venkata Satya Sai Ajay Daliparthi, Kurt Tutschku, Victor Kebande, Nurul Momen
abstract: Collaborative AI engineering is a paradigm that enables multiple stakeholders to maintain AI pipelines by exchanging artifacts, such as data, models, and software packages. It is a cost-efficient engineering process that accelerates the development of AI applications, specifically for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). However, AI artifacts are often associated with inherent intellectual property (IP) or sensitive information, which hinders collaboration due to a lack of trust among stakeholders. Digital sovereignty is viewed as an ideal state where artifact owners maintain full control over their assets, such as making key decisions regarding access, storage, and interoperability. Thus, it is postulated that implementing digital sovereignty mechanisms in multi-stakeholder information systems can address the trust gap and promote collaboration. This work addresses this gap by conducting a systematic review of the literature on digital sovereignty for collaborative AI engineering. The main contributions of this work include: (i) mapping digital sovereignty definitions and requirements within the context of collaborative AI engineering, (ii) identifying existing technologies and concepts for implementing sovereignty features in AI engineering, and (iii) analyzing existing collaborative AI platforms such as data marketplaces, data spaces, and GAIA-X. This analysis highlights their sovereignty requirements, solutions, benefits and implementation challenges. In addition, this work (iv) identifies research gaps in data pricing, confidentiality, and interoperability, while proposing future directions to enhance digital sovereignty in collaborative AI ecosystems.

title: Breaking the Digital Divide: How Traditional Cement Manufacturing Creates Competitive Advantage Through Strategic Resource Orchestration
authors: Adi Munandir, Aurik Gustomo, Prawira Fajarindra Belgiawan
abstract: The Fourth Industrial Revolution has largely bypassed traditional, asset-heavy industries like cement manufacturing, which face significant challenges in digitizing operations while managing innovation resistance and multi-generational workforces, particularly in emerging economies. This study investigates how digital resource orchestration can overcome these barriers to create a competitive advantage, employing a single case study design with five-year longitudinal observation and twelve in-depth interviews from Indonesia’s largest cement manufacturer. The research reveals that innovation resistance is not a temporary hurdle but a persistent institutional feature that must be systematically managed. A comprehensive framework is developed, demonstrating that successful transformation requires orchestrating people assets (digital leadership, capability development), process assets (governance, resource mechanisms), and technology assets (infrastructure, integration). The findings show that organizations progress through five maturity levels-from Traditional to Transformed-by applying sequential orchestration states that address specific resistance patterns at each stage. This study contributes to digital transformation theory by reconceptualizing innovation resistance as an organizational capability and provides an empirically grounded model for traditional industries seeking to bridge the digital divide.

title: Contrastive Learning-Driven Fake News Detection: Preserving Semantics, Unveiling Distortions
authors: Yeqing Yan, Peng Zheng, Yongjun Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: The complex interweaving of authentic and fake news on social networks poses formidable challenges to modern information management. Existing fake news detection methods heavily rely on extensive labeled data and auxiliary information, such as propagation structures, facing critical issues of data scarcity and semantic integrity destruction in practical applications. Traditional data augmentation methods, due to their fixed rule-based transformation patterns, fail to effectively simulate the complexity and irregularity of information propagation in real social networks. To address these fundamental limitations, this article proposes a contrastive learning-driven fake news detection (CLFD) framework that breaks through existing technical bottlenecks through innovative distortion-reversion dual-view manipulation mechanisms and distortion-aware contrastive learning methods. The core innovation of CLFD lies in employing learnable neural networks to precisely simulate nonlinear information transformation processes, generating stylistically diverse contrastive views while preserving semantic core integrity, fundamentally solving the critical problem of semantic destruction in traditional methods. More importantly, our method achieves efficient detection using only textual content, requiring no additional information such as propagation structures or social network topologies, demonstrating outstanding universality and portability. Through dynamic view generation and multiobjective joint optimization strategies, CLFD significantly enhances the model’s capability to capture deceptive features in fake news. Extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that our framework significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in detection accuracy, robustness, and generalization capability.

title: Multi-scale Fracture Prediction in the Weathering Zone of Metamorphic Buried Hills Using Gaussian-Weighted Enhancement and MAD Dynamic Grading
authors: Shengjie Pei, Tingen Fan, Jinsong Shen, Xianwen Zhang, Xin Du
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Buried hill reservoirs constitute a key unconventional hydrocarbon resource in offshore China, where fracture networks govern seepage capacity and production performance. However, their great burial depth, low seismic signal-to-noise ratio, and complex geophysical responses make accurate fracture prediction challenging. To overcome the limitations of existing curvature-based approaches-such as high noise sensitivity, poor detection of small-scale fractures, and lack of quantitative multi-scale classification-this study proposes a novel multi-scale curvature-attribute-based fracture prediction method. The proposed approach features three main innovations. (1) An attribute enhancement strategy that integrates local dynamic smoothing with a Gaussian distance-weighted grid scanning technique to suppress noise while amplifying weak responses, thereby improving robustness. (2) A multi-directional peak scanning algorithm that effectively extracts fractures without the information loss inherent in traditional binarization–skeletonization methods, enabling more complete and continuous fracture characterization. (3) A Median Absolute Deviation (MAD)-based dynamic grading model that classifies fractures into large-, medium-, and small-scale categories using curvature statistics. Application of this method to the Bozhong A buried hill gas field in the Bohai Bay Basin verifies its effectiveness: it extracts 5.4 times more cumulative fracture length than conventional methods and substantially enhances fracture detection resolution. Even under 15% noise contamination, the method retains 90.05% of its extraction performance, demonstrating strong noise resistance. The predicted multi-scale fracture distributions (large, medium, small) show high consistency with seismic horizon deformation patterns, drilling fluid loss records, well-log interpretations, and productivity data, confirming the reliability of the results. Importantly, medium-scale fractures are identified as the dominant factor controlling single-well productivity. The proposed method provides an effective pathway for quantitative multi-scale fracture prediction in buried hill reservoirs, particularly within the weathering zone—the main hydrocarbon-producing interval.

title: EKF-GS: An Improved 3D Gaussian Splatting Using Extended Kalman Filter
authors: Kezhi Wang, Jikai Wang, Zonghai Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: We propose EKF-GS, a hybrid optimization framework for 3D Gaussian Splatting that integrates Extended Kalman Filter with stochastic gradient descent. EKF-GS enables faster convergence, uncertainty-guided Gaussian densification, and uncertainty quantification capability. Experiments on public datasets show improved reconstruction quality with fewer iterations and reduced training time.
