title: A YOLOv8-Based Defect Detection Algorithm for Electrical Meter Boxes
authors: Tao Li, Renming Yang, Jian Yang, Zhiru Chen, Bao Li, Qinggang Dong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: To address the issues of low detection speed and high dependency on manual inspection in the digital management of low-voltage metering boxes, this paper proposes a YOLOv8-based image defect detection algorithm for metering boxes, termed YOLOv8-BBI. Building upon the backbone architecture of YOLOv8, the BiFormer attention mechanism is introduced at the end of the backbone to effectively reduce computational cost and memory consumption while enhancing feature extraction capability. Furthermore, the neck component is redesigned using a variant of the BiFPN structure with learnable weights to optimize multi-scale feature fusion, thereby improving adaptability to objects of varying sizes. In addition, the Inner-IoU loss function is employed to accelerate the convergence of predicted bounding boxes and enhance the accuracy of defect localization. Experimental results demonstrate that YOLOv8-BBI achieves a 2.7 percentage point improvement in mean Average Precision (mAP) over the original YOLOv8 model. Meanwhile, the model size is reduced by $28.5 \%$, and the detection speed increases from 42.8 FPS to 57.8 FPS, indicating a significant improvement in inference efficiency. These results provide robust support for real-time defect detection of metering boxes in the digital management of low-voltage distribution areas.

title: Pattern Pulse: Revolutionizing Sleep Technology with Intelligent Cushions
authors: M. Moorthi, Dhivakaran M, Thanveer Ahamed D, M. Vanithalakshmi, C.H.C Alexander
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: Increasing prevalence and awareness of the consequences of sleep disorders on global physical and mental health require innovative treatment solutions. “Pattern Pulse” a state-of-the-art sleep device that comprises intelligent cushions along with machine learning algorithms to monitor, analyze and consistently improve sleeping patterns. Transforming sleep with state-of-the-art sensor tech, AI, and personalized comfort. The intelligent cushion uses high-precision sensors to monitor heart rate and breathing patterns, as well as motion within an area of the body. These data points are detected by real-time machine learning algorithms to understand sleep phases, interruptions, and quality. This solution is nearly invisible in daily life but provides accurate and actionable sleep monitoring data, unlike standard devices. Pattern Pulse is biofeedback-enhanced active sleep improvement. When the cushion also detects pain or restlessness, it can adjust its firmness or temperature automatically, providing uninterrupted sleep. It offers customized lifestyle modifications, sleeping position recommendations, and relaxation techniques according to their sleep profiles. In addition to personal use, the program could even assist physicians in diagnosing and addressing sleep problems. “Pattern Pulse” targets sleep apnea, insomnia, and circadian rhythm but also seeks to promote sleep health. Empowering the masses with this unprecedented combination of technology and comfort aims to revolutionize sleep behavior and improve health.

title: An Azure IoT Hub-Based Fleet Management System for Connected Vehicles
authors: Deekshitha Angadi, Naveena Budda, Sree Subha Tammisetty, Yesaswini Nagasai Amulya Pilli, Vikas Agarwal, Bharath Kumar Suryadevara, Obulesu Ooruchintala, Ramacharan Sriramakavacham, Ravi Killamsetty, Narsimlu Kemsaram
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: In the transportation domain, vehicles need autonomous technologies such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and the Internet of Things (IoT), which have revolutionized fleet management systems. This paper proposes an autonomous fleet management system that combines these technologies with web- and mobile-based platforms to enable realtime monitoring, optimization, and decision-making, ensuring that fleets operate autonomously, efficiently, and safely. The system leverages real-time analytics based on data from IoT devices and IoT edge devices. Azure IoT Hub cloud computing enables efficient fleet monitoring, route optimization, predictive maintenance, and decision-making. We present the architecture, design, and development of the proposed system, demonstrating its effectiveness in an urban scenario. The results show significant improvements in operational efficiency, cost reduction, sustainability, and safety. The finding highlights the potential of this approach for the future of autonomous fleet management in various domains, including self-driving cars in urban areas, autonomous mobile robots in logistics, autonomous drones in the air, and autonomous rovers in space exploration.

title: Efficient Whisper Fine-Tuning with Low-Rank Adaptation (Lora) for Evaluating Al-Fatihah Recitation Accuracy
authors: Khodijah Hulliyah, Zara Norenza, Fenty Eka Muzayyana Agustin
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Muslims are required to recite the Qur'an accurately, making the study and memorization of its verses essential. One common learning approach is the talaqqi method, where a teacher reads the verses and students repeat them under direct supervision. However, its effectiveness is often limited by scheduling constraints between teachers and students. Artificial Intelligence (AI), particularly Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR), offers a potential solution. This study applies the pre-trained Whisper model to assess the accuracy of reciting Surah Al-Fatihah using transfer learning. To reduce computational costs during fine-tuning, ParameterEfficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) with the Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) technique was employed. The research process comprised three stages: (1) data preparation, including audio cleaning, segmentation, and dataset compilation; (2) model training with hyperparameter tuning of learning rate and number of epochs; and (3) evaluation using Word Error Rate (WER) and Character Error Rate (CER). The best-performing model achieved a WER of 1.34% and a CER of 0.72% on the test dataset.

title: XGBoost vs. LSTM: A Comparative Performance Analysis for Global Stock Market Prediction
authors: Krisna Adiyarta M, Tri Sugihartono, Rahmat Sulaiman, Bambang Adiwinoto, Marini, Hidayat Febiansyah
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: This study evaluates XGBoost and LSTM for stock price prediction using ten years of data from Tesla (TSLA) and Alibaba (BABA). We find that model performance depends on stock volatility and market behavior. For Tesla, a high-volatility stock (standard deviation: 106.44; average annual return: 58.54%), LSTM achieved higher accuracy (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.9728, MAPE: 2.93%) than XGBoost (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.8948, MAPE: 4.65%). In contrast, for the more stable Alibaba (standard deviation: 57.22; annual return: 6.67%), XGBoost performed best (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.9877, MAPE: 3.21), outperforming LSTM (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.7592, MAPE: 19.27). Our results indicate that LSTM is better suited for volatile, momentum-driven assets, while XGBoost excels with stable, less noisy time series. These findings offer practical guidance for selecting machine learning models in stock forecasting based on asset characteristics.

title: Cloud-Enhanced Analytics for Advanced Battery Management Systems
authors: Abhishek Baer
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
abstract: This document explores the evolution of battery management systems (BMS) through the integration of cloudbased analytics. It details the system architecture for data acquisition, storage, and processing, emphasizing the role of cloud computing in enabling sophisticated algorithms for battery state estimation and safety diagnostics. The study focuses on improvements in state of charge (SOC) and state of health (SOH) predictions, as well as the implementation of advanced thermal anomaly detection within the BMS framework. Challenges and solutions related to data processing, algorithm deployment, and system scalability are specifically addressed from a battery management perspective.”

title: Data-Driven Excavation Detection and Localization Using φ-OTDR Distributed Acoustic Sensing
authors: Nhu Khue Vuong, Gen Liang Lim, Lianlian Jiang, Hailiang Zhang, Hui Dong, Dora Juan Juan Hu, Jun Hong Ng
abstract: This paper presents a data-driven approach for detecting and localizing excavations along fiber optical cables using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varphi$</tex>-OTDR distributed acoustic sensing (DAS). We conduct field trials with actual excavation activities to evaluate the performance of the developed model. The accuracy of our model is 92.86%. Compared with other benchmarking results, the scope of our experiments is much wider in terms of the fiber route length, the area we monitor, the duration of evaluation and trial.

title: Elucidating Phenotypic Changes in Cardiomyocytes Via Simultaneous Electrical and Optical Recording
authors: Louis Hanqiang GAN, Jun XIE, Tong LING
abstract: Cardiac disease arising from genetic predisposition often produces phenotypic changes in cardiac cells. To elucidate these phenotypic changes, we designed a platform that simultaneously and quantitatively measures electrical potential as well as mechanical contractions of cardiomyocytes by integrating Quadri-wave lateral shearing interferometry with multi-electrode array.

title: Mining Public Opinion on Customs Policies: A Text Association Approach Using FP-Growth
authors: Nida'ul Hasanati, Muhammad Nizar Sya Bana, Yuni Sugiarti, Zulfiandri, Nurbojatmiko
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: Social media, particularly Twitter, has become an important platform for expressing public opinion in real time on various issues. In early 2024, the Direktorat Jendral Bea Cukai (DJBC, Directorate General of Customs and Excise) in Indonesia received significant public attention on Twitter, especially regarding tax policies and import costs considered burdensome. This study aims to analyze word association patterns in public conversations about customs using the FPGrowth algorithm within the Knowledge Discovery in Database (KDD) framework. Data were collected through Twitter crawling with the keyword “bea cukai” (customs) from June 1, 2023, to June 30, 2024, resulting in 3,702 tweets. The experiment produced 14 association rules with lift values greater than 1, revealing strong connections between the term “custom” and words such as “tax” and “expensive.” These findings indicate that customs issues are frequently associated with taxation policies and high costs. Furthermore, this study developed a Python-based system that automates the processes of crawling, preprocessing, and text association analysis. The contributions of this research provide valuable insights for DJBC in understanding public perceptions and offer an efficient analytical tool for opinion mining.

title: Observation of Joule-Thomson Expansion of Light
authors: M. S. Kirsch, G.G. Pyrialakos, R. M. Altenkirch, T. A. W. Wolterink, M. Khajavikhan, A. Szameit, M. Heinrich, D. N. Christodoulides
abstract: We demonstrate an all-optical analogue of JouleThomson expansion in discrete multimode nonlinear systems. Experiments confirm power-dependent optical “cooling” manifesting as condensation of light into the fundamental mode, offering control over the spatial coherence of a beam in multimode photonic systems.

title: Simulation of Anti-Aging Skincare Effects on Facial Images Using Pix2Pix and Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Indriyani, Paula Dewanti
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Intelligent System (ICORIS)
abstract: This research proposes a system to simulate anti-aging skincare effects on facial images using a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). The model is based on the Pix2Pix architecture, enhanced with VGG Perceptual Loss, and trained on a paired dataset of 200 before-and-after skincare facial images. A U-Net generator and a PatchGAN discriminator were employed, optimized with a composite loss combining GAN Loss, L1 Loss, and VGG Perceptual Loss. The system achieved strong quantitative results, with an average PSNR of 32.65 dB and SSIM of 0.936, reflecting high image quality and structural similarity. Qualitative results showed realistic skincare transformations, smoother skin, reduced pores, and even tone while preserving individual identity, making the system practical for cosmetic product visualization and dermatological applications.

title: Enhancing BERT-LA: Robustness Analysis With Augmented Data for English-Arabic Sentiment Classification
authors: Wael Jefry, Farookh Hussain, Firas Al-Doghman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Sentiment analysis across languages has become an important subject of research, particularly for languages with complex syntax and morphology, such as Arabic. The goal of this research is to develop an advanced sentiment analysis model that can handle both Arabic and English, which are linguistically separate languages. To address the problems of Arabic, which is morphologically rich but has limited resources, we have combined BERT for English with AraBERT for Arabic. We tested several deep learning architectures, including Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM), and attention mechanisms, using the IMDB movie review dataset. The BERT + BiLSTM + Attention (BERT-LA) model we presented outperformed the LSTMbased models, especially when it came to capturing diverse emotions in Arabic and English text. A comprehensive ablation research proved its efficiency, with an outstanding 97.04% accuracy on the English dataset and 98.02% on the Arabic dataset. To increase the model's robustness, we tested it on enhanced data, and it maintained good performance with 98.24% accuracy in English and 98.38% in Arabic. These findings show that transformer-based designs and languagespecific embeddings may greatly improve sentiment analysis, particularly in low-resource and morphologically complicated languages.

title: A Method for Dual-Circularly Polarized Harmonic Beamforming in Time-Modulated Array
authors: Xumin Chen, Lu Yin, Zhirui Li, Chuan Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility (ISEMC)
abstract: This work presents a polarization-phase hybrid modulation (PPHM) method based on time-modulated array (TMA) architecture that enables independent dual-circularly polarized beam generation through hybrid modulation of 2-bit phase states and orthogonal polarization components. By implementing optimized time sequences, the method produces left-handed circular polarization (LHCP) at the +1st harmonic and right-handed circular polarization (RHCP) at the -1st harmonic without additional components such as polarization converters. Simulations on a 16-element uniform linear array at 10 GHz demonstrate high-purity circularly polarized radiation across three beam directions (-20°/-40°, 20°/40°, and- 40°/40°), and sidelobe levels (SLLs) below -15 dB, cross-polarization suppression exceeding -20 dB, and axial ratios (ARs) persistently below 2 dB within the 3-dB beamwidths.

title: Subjective Assessment of Operator Responses for Mobile Defect Identification in Remanufacturing
authors: Abbirah Ahmed, Reenu Mohandas, Arash Joorabchi, Martin J. Hayes
abstract: In defect detection, the codification of operator expertise is vital for the successful deployment of machine learning as an assistant in the determination of the next manufacturing process step. While Artificial Intelligence, specifically within Computer Vision, has radically changed the human role in the automatic identification of defects, human intervention is likely to remain crucial in the verification of decisions made by Computer Vision algorithms. This study presents a subjective assessment of operator responses that have been compared to expert responses where significant subjectivity can exist regarding the nature and type of the next process step that is required. The case study in question is taken from the mobile phone defect detection within the remanufacturing process, a key evolving step in the emerging circular economy issue of extending phone life. Using state-of-the-art Natural Language Processing techniques for short text similarity tasks, the findings indicate that models incorporating contextual understanding and vocabulary awareness significantly outperform techniques with limited or no contextual understanding. This study employs Sentence-BERT, Word2Vec, and Dice similarity techniques to compare operator and expert responses, aiming to determine similarity/dissimilarity between them. This comparison helps identify levels of expertise and establishes new, improved guidelines for the use of AI in operator training.

title: Computational Analysis of Hybrid Reduced Gradient Methods for Coffee Plantation Maintenance Optimization
authors: Eko Hariyanto, Poltak Sihombing, Erna Budhiarti Nababan, Sawaluddin, Herman Mawengkang, Tulus
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
abstract: This paper presents a Mixed Integer Nonlinear Programming (MINLP) model with a hybrid Reduced Gradient Approximation-Outer Approximation (RG-OA) method to optimize the maintenance scheduling of smallholder coffee plantations. The model integrates sequential agricultural tasks and resource constraints into a unified optimization framework, ensuring that each maintenance stage is executed in the correct order while minimizing the overall makespan. Implemented in Python using Pyomo, the model produces feasible and efficient schedules that balance workload distribution across multiple areas and periods. Computational experiments on various plantation instances show that the proposed RG-OA method achieves superior performance compared to other hybrid approaches, namely the Reduced Gradient-Genetic Algorithm (RG-GA) and the Reduced Gradient-Particle Swarm Optimizer (RG-PSO). RG-OA consistently results in shorter execution times, requires fewer branch-and-bound nodes, and maintains a lower convergence lag, especially in large-scale problem instances. These results confirm the scalability and reliability of the proposed hybrid method for complex agricultural scheduling problems. These findings highlight the potential of optimization models and hybrid nonlinear programming methods as effective decision-support tools for agricultural operations. In the context of smallholder coffee plantation management, the RG-OA framework provides a practical approach to improving efficiency, reducing costs, and supporting sustainable practices.

title: A Comparative Study of PKI and Blockchain-Based Security Architectures in V2X Communication Systems
authors: Shahul H. Abubakkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Vehicular Technology and Transportation Systems (ICVTTS)
abstract: Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication underpins cooperative intelligent transport systems by enabling vehicles and infrastructure to exchange time-critical data. However, increasing interconnectivity raises security concerns around authentication, integrity, privacy, revocation, and auditability. This paper examines two dominant paradigms—Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) and blockchain-based approaches and compares their suitability for V2X deployments. We synthesize standards and recent studies to provide a side-by-side architectural analysis and quantitative, order of magnitude metrics for authentication latency, revocation timeliness, bandwidth and storage overhead, and scalability. The findings indicate that PKI delivers real-time message authentication at millisecond level latency with mature standardization and deployment readiness, whereas permissioned blockchain improves transparency and enables near-real-time for consensus driven misbehavior handling and revocation.

title: An Evaluation Study on the Impact of Algorithm Fusion Strategies on Neck Fatigue Detection Performance
authors: Xiujuan Sun, Hao Tian, Rui Zhao, Yuqing Chen, Chuanjiang Wang, Wangning Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: In machine learning applications based on multimodal signals, algorithm fusion is a crucial step for enhancing performance, yet the effectiveness of different fusion strategies lacks systematic evaluation. This study aims to quantitatively assess the impact of various algorithm fusion strategies on driver fatigue detection performance. Using photoplethysmography (PPG) signals, electrodermal activity (EDA) signals, and motion acceleration signals collected from the neck, we systematically compare the performance differences among single algorithms, simple fusion strategies, and improved fusion strategies across different feature dimensions.(Random Forest (RF) and the Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) are employed as the fundamental algorithm pool.). Experimental results demonstrate that the improved classification model achieves an approximately $18 \%$ increase in accuracy. Moreover, with the effective expansion of input features, both detection precision and computational speed are significantly enhanced. This study provides important empirical evidence for the selection of algorithms and fusion strategies in constructing high-performance fatigue detection systems.

title: Multispectral Computational Ghost Imaging Based on Single-Pixel Silicon Detector
authors: Yixuan He, Yingxiao Ma, Baolei Liu, Yao Wang, Jiaqi Song, Weiqi Jin, Fan Wang, Ziyuan Li
abstract: We demonstrate a visible-near infrared multispectral single-pixel imaging technique based on a digital micromirror device and silicon photodetector. The experiment achieved the collection and processing of current signals from the silicon detector under random speckle illumination, followed by image reconstruction at multiple wavelength channels.

title: Research on Signal Feature Extraction and Classification Performance under Non-Stationary Stochastic Disturbances
authors: Shengjun Zhou, Yaqiong Li, Lei Zhao, Haijun Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Technology (IC2ECT)
abstract: In power systems, measurement signals are frequently embedded in non-stationary fluctuation processes driven by multi-source dynamic factors such as mechanical vibration, load variation, et.al. Feature extraction and classification provide an effective means to capture these nonstationary characteristics and detect corresponding faults. However, existing deep learning approaches remain limited, as they generally assume quasi-stationary data, generate deterministic outputs, and lack the ability to quantify epistemic uncertainty in fluctuating scenarios. To address these issues, this paper proposes a diagnostic framework based on Bayesian neural networks (BNN). By constructing a dynamic dataset that explicitly incorporates non-stationary fluctuation processes and employing the Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) algorithm, the framework enables quantitative evaluation of disturbance impacts on model performance. Experimental results show that the model maintains robustness against falling-trend fluctuations, but exhibits sensitivity to rising-trend fluctuations, where classification probabilities shift significantly as the slope increases. This study provides new insights into uncertainty quantification and risk assessment in power systems under non-stationary fluctuation scenarios.

title: Enhancing Saltmarsh Monitoring Using UAV Based Hyperspectral Imaging Sensor: A Case Study from Derrymore Island
authors: Sagar Dalai, Marco Moreno, Mahammad Irfan, Adam Dooley, Thomas Newe, Gerard Dooly, Eoin O’Connell
abstract: Saltmarshes are critical coastal ecosystems that offer biodiversity, shoreline protection, and high carbon sequestration. Monitoring these habitats is essential but challenging because of their spatial complexity and sensitivity. This paper presents a Unmanned Ariel Vehicle (UAV) based hyperspectral survey conducted over Derrymore Saltmarsh, County Kerry, Ireland, using a DJI Matrice 300 drone equipped with a Resonon Pika-L hyperspectral imager. We demonstrate the effectiveness of hyperspectral data and Spectral Angle Mapper (SAM) classification for identifying key saltmarsh vegetation species. Field data from vegetation quadrats were used for validation. Our results highlight the potential of UAV and HSI integration in supporting ecological research, improving habitat mapping accuracy, and enabling scalable, nondestructive monitoring.

title: Aydi: An Al-Powered App to Teach Saudi Sign Language
authors: Sumayah Alwadei, Albatool AL-Sama, Fatimah Alkhunjuf, Awsaf Alharthi, Shahad Madkhli, Muzun Al Kulayb
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on E-Business Engineering (ICEBE)
abstract: Sign languages, alongside spoken language, have historically served as essential forms of communication. Despite its significance, sign language instruction has not been well supported by modern technologies, especially in Arabic-speaking areas. This study demonstrates Aydi, which is the first Arabic-language mobile app combining CNN, gamification, and real-time sign recognition for children. It creates an interesting and approachable learning environment. The program uses gamification strategies, visual storytelling, and real-time gesture recognition. Over 25 users, including parents, teachers, and children, successfully tested the app, which demonstrated excellent usability and educational value with a 95.6 % model correctness. Aydi was developed using the Agile methodology, facilitating iterative development through multiple sprints. Each cycle integrated feedback from educators, parents, and sign language experts to enhance usability and pedagogical effectiveness. A convolutional neural network (CNN), trained on the Grey Arabic Alphabet Sign Language dataset, was utilized for hand gesture recognition. The model was deployed via a Flask backend that delivers predictions to the mobile application through an API. Usability testing yielded promising outcomes in terms of user satisfaction and gesture classification accuracy. The app aligns with Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 by advancing inclusive education through emerging technologies and holds the potential for broader societal impact.

title: Study on Flood Regulation Calculation of the Lower Reservoir of a Pumped Storage Power Station
authors: Qiang Liu, Jian Liu, Ziheng Lin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power System and Power Engineering (PSPE)
abstract: In response to the scheduling challenge where, after the flood standard of the lower reservoir of a pumped storage power station was upgraded (designed for a 500-year flood and checked for a 2000-year flood), the measured 24-hour flood volume increased by approximately 23% compared with the preliminary design, and the flow constraint at the downstream control section needed to be satisfied, this study designed a total of 6 flood regulation schemes, including 3 groups without pumped storage and 3 groups with pumped storage. Using the static storage flood regulation method and the joint flood regulation method, combined with the storage curve, discharge characteristics, and regional composition of floods, the evolution of flood levels and outflow processes under different flood limited water levels, convergent discharges, and pumped storage shutdown strategies were analyzed. The results show that: without pumped storage, increasing the convergent discharge at the downstream control section to 1245 m³/s can avoid the exceeding of the flood control high water level and the benefit loss caused by lowering the flood limited water level; with pumped storage, the scheme of "full shutdown of pumped storage at 212.3m + convergent discharge of 1245 m³/s" is recommended, which meets the design standards, ensures normal power generation for floods with a recurrence interval of less than 200 years, and the verification in the plum rain flood season also meets the requirements of the preliminary design water level. The research results provide key support for the project completion safety appraisal and the formulation of operation regulations, effectively ensuring the safety of the project and downstream flood control.
